business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER(Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That standing order 48A, (adjournment and next meeting) be suspended for this sitting.

I do not wish to delay the House, but it is intended that we sit tonight. This will allow people an opportunity to speak in the House on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). It is intended and agreed between ourselves and the opposition that neither government nor opposition members will call quorums or divisions so that people can have an opportunity to speak as so provided. I thank the opposition for their cooperation.

talk.start.para: —The opposition agrees with this proposal, and also with the qualifications given by the Leader of the House (Mr Reith). Given that I will be away in Brisbane while it is all happening, I hope you all enjoy it.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Williams, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill complements the National Firearms Program Implementation Acts of 1996 and 1997 supporting a firearms buyback scheme in the territories of Norfolk Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island.

Following the tragic events at Port Arthur in April 1996 the Australasian Police Ministers Council agreed to nationwide gun control measures. A significant element of these measures was the amnesty and compensation scheme for owners of semiautomatic firearms. It was agreed that people who surrendered these firearms during the amnesty period would be compensated and the Commonwealth would pay the cost of the compensation scheme. The Commonwealth also agreed to pay compensation for the surrender of other prohibited firearms of a more dangerous type where the surrender is consistent with the spirit of the national firearms program.

The compensation-for-surrender scheme in the states and mainland territories was funded by a one-off increase in the Medicare levy for the income year 1996-97. The funds raised by that one-off levy will also meet the cost of the scheme in the territories of Norfolk Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island.

The bill provides for me to authorise payments for the purpose of providing compensation to firearms owners and dealers and for purposes directly connected to the compensation scheme and for implementation of licensing and registration schemes in the territories. The bill appropriates moneys from the consolidated revenue fund for these purposes.
The national firearms program has received bipartisan support. I ask that that support continue. I commend the bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998, which is now before the House, contains amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to give effect to the government's commitment to remove tariffs on inputs to the manufacture of information industries equip ment. The amendments have been previously tabled in this House in Customs Tariff Proposal (No. 3) 1998.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made the Investing for Growth industry statement on 8 December 1997. In it he announced that the government would remove tariffs on inputs to the manufacture of information industries equipment, after consulting with local component suppliers to assess the likely impact on them. The Prime Minister also said that, whenever doubts over classification of information technology equipment arise, the lowest tariff will be applied. We are now taking action to address these matters.

The issue with tariffs on inputs is one of negative assistance. Most fully assembled information industries equipment is imported duty free. However, many of the chemical products, mechanical parts, electronic components and subassemblies that are used in local production of the same equipment attract either a three per cent or a five per cent tariff. This represents a situation of `negative assistance' in an industry which is highly competitive and in which margins are often small.

There has also been an issue within the industry whereby goods classified as information technology equipment are duty free, and goods classified as telecommunications equipment carry a duty of five per cent. This duty differential means that there has been incentive for importers to seek to have goods classified to an information technology item rather than a telecommunications item.

Following consultation with industry, we are taking action on two fronts. The central element is an acceleration of duty reductions already scheduled under the information technology agreement, ITA. Australia, along with 42 other countries, is a signatory to the ITA which covers 93 per cent of world trade in information technology products. This agreement produced a list of goods in the information technology industries on which tariffs are being phased to zero on 1 January 2000.

With the exception of a small range of finished goods, we will be bringing forward by 18 months the tariff reductions to which Australia is committed under the ITA. A zero duty rate will now apply from 1 July 1998. The goods that will be excluded, and for which 1 January 2000 will remain the operative date for a zero rate, include: line telephone, cordless, mobile and other telephone sets, facsimile and telephone answering machines, digital still image cameras, pagers, antennas and aerial reflectors. The classification issue has been resolved by reducing, to free, the duty on goods which were considered contentious at the time of the `investing for growth' statement.

The second element of the approach is the establishment of a new schedule 4 item in the customs tariff for those inputs not covered by the ITA. This will allow duty free entry for other inputs which are currently subject to a tariff concession order (TCO). The new item will cover inputs to the manufacture of information industries equipment. Information industries equipment will be defined in terms of a series of tariff items within the by-laws written to the new schedule 4 item.

If the coverage of goods contained in the ITA expands over time, this listing of tariff items will be altered appropriately. Inputs to manufacture are goods that are an integral part of the manufacturing process for this equipment, and include goods that are incorporated into the equipment or consumed during the manufacture of the equipment, as well as certain capital equipment utilised in the manufacturing process. In consultation with industry, an initial list of TCOs covering relevant inputs has been developed. The coverage for the new schedule will be expanded as new TCOs are established for other inputs to information industry equipment manufacture.

Australian information technology manufacturers will benefit from duty free access to key inputs which will strengthen the competitive base of Australia's information technology industry. The cost to government is estimated at $80 million over the next 18 months, and this should translate directly to reduced costs for industry and ultimately flow through to lower prices for consumers. Australia's position in the context of the ITA will also be enhanced, at a time when some countries are calling for accelerated action on trade liberalisation. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talker.name: Somlyay, Alex, MP
Mr SOMLYAY
talker.role: Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal for work in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 25 May 1998, namely: Erection of signage on and around the headquarters of the National Archives of Australia at East Block.

I am pleased that the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) is in the chamber because there has been some controversy about this issue and I wish to give the following assurance to the honourable member. In moving this motion, I inform the House that the new signs will not obscure the current East Block signs on the building. I am aware that this name is held in great affection by generations of Canberra residents and others familiar with the parliamentary triangle.

I also remind honourable members that the Australian Heritage Commission has been consulted about the signage and has advised that the design and location of the signs will have no adverse impact on the national estate values of the building. This advice from the Heritage Commission was lodged, with relevant explanatory papers, with the table offices of both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The new signs will be in character and appropriate to the new use of East Block as the headquarters of the National Archives of Australia. I commend the motion.

talk.start.para: —It is coincidental that I am here, but I thank the Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government (Mr Somlyay) for his courtesy and his comments. It is true that there would be some concern if the fundamental historic nature of East Block were to be impaired by the changes. The bald statement in notice No. 2 was a bit worrying to me and to other people. Inquiries were made and some reservations were expressed.

speech.para: I think the refurbishment of East Block, to the extent that I have had the chance to examine it, has been very well done and it is a very important thing, as was the previous refurbishment of West Block. Those buildings are not only full of history but, when properly refurbished, they can be modern testaments to our architectural history, as well as good, effective office space. It is very appropriate for the National Archives to be moving there.

The National Archives should have a more prominent position in terms of being accessible to Australians and to visitors and should have proper signage. In other countries, particularly in the United States, the archives is a very prominent part and a frequently visited aspect of the national capital, and many important historical documents are on public display there. It is a good thing that we are moving in that direction and that it is close to Old Parliament House where the National Archives from time to time makes good use of the space to display some of its collection.

I accept without reservation the minister's assurances and, subject to the continuing scrutiny of bodies like the Heritage Commission and the National Capital Authority, I look forward to the discreet and tasteful implementation of the assurances which the minister has given to me and to the people of Canberra.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Mr Costello:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that the Budget:

(1) does nothing to redress the pain caused to ordinary Australian families, and those doing it hardest in our community, by the impact of successive Budget cuts on health, education, job programs, aged care, child care and many other government programs and services;
(2) by seeking to achieve surplus on the basis of savage Budget cuts, rather than on growth and job creation, does nothing to give hope to the unemployed and underemployed;

(3) confirms that the Opposition's alternative Budget strategy, as originally announced in 1996, would have returned the Budget to surplus in 1998-99—on the basis of putting growth and jobs first, with much more moderate outlays reductions;
(4) lacks credibility in its growth, employment and current account deficit forecasts;

(5) confirms that Australia has a private rather than public saving problem—and the stupidity of the Coalition's promise-breaking decision in 1997 to abandon Labor's superannuation co-contribution; and

(6) is incomplete and misleading in its projections of future revenue and outlays, in that it makes no provision for election-driven new expenditures and the Government's GST and other tax proposals".

talk.start.para: —I rise to participate in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1998-99 and to take up the speech where I left off last night. With some modesty, I will say that last night I was in an entertaining and I hope challenging debate with the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), but the numbers in the chamber this morning would suggest that perhaps it was not as entertaining as I led myself to believe.
—I am sure members will always come to hear you, my colleague.

—Nonetheless, the member for Port Adelaide had, I thought, quite unkindly made the point that the only reason the budget was in surplus was the burden had been carried by, he thought, those people in his electorate who were least able to carry the burden. That, of course, was nonsense. It was nonsense because, far from the burden being carried by those people, this government can claim to have balanced the books and simultaneously introduced the sort of family assistance that guaranteed that those who were least able to bear the burden were not saddled with it. As those of us in this parliament on more comfortable salaries can attest, it has frequently been those in the higher salary range who have been asked to pick up some of the cost of what was Labor's mismanagement.

speech.para: Even more pertinent is the fact that the budget has been balanced largely because this government has been prepared to prune government expenditure and to target it more appropriately. We have every reason to be proud of the state of the nation's economy; every reason to be proud because it has been achieved in the face of the collapse of some of our Asian neighbours. In fact, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) can claim to have effectively fireproofed this economy against that collapse. As everyone in Australia knows, we would be in a dramatically worse situation had it not been for the action taken by this government in balancing the books and in ensuring that we are both back in the black and back on track.

There are too few Australians conscious of the fact that under this government exports have gone up, unemployment has fallen and our capacity to service the debt has improved because our gross domestic product has improved. As a result, we are well placed in international terms. Yet all we have heard from those opposite in this appropriation debate has been criticism of the direction the government has taken, even though we have taken the decisions, many of them unpopular, and taken them in the national interest.

The truly significant thing about this appropriation debate is that it is being held against the backdrop of all sorts of difficulties facing our Asian neighbours, yet here we stand as a nation in this part of the globe not being as affected by that Asian collapse as we would have been if we had not got on with the difficult job of paying off the debt. The government recognises that, having taken difficult decisions and having effectively fireproofed the economy against the collapse in Asia, it is now time for us to take the next step in reforming the Australian economy, and that step, of course, is tax reform.

We have heard from those opposite arguments like 1993 revisited—nonsense debated by those opposite—suggesting that in some way this government is about putting an additional tax burden on the people of Australia. Questions have been posed by those opposite about the rate at which any form of GST would be applied if it were to be applied and about how much money would be raised. What every Australian should be asking about tax reform is one very simple question, and it would not matter who the government was. The question every Australian should ask about tax reform is: how much money does the government want to collect? That is the basic question—not `Where is it collected, at what rate or how?' but, `How much money?'

We go into this tax reform debate having given one ironclad guarantee, and that is that, as a government, we do not want or need—and that is the important point—to collect any more general revenue. We do not need additional money. Every Australian needs to know that we are giving them an assurance that, because the debt is coming down, because our obligations under interest and principal repayments are falling, if our debt repayment program stays on track we will have available to us an additional $10 billion a year for as long as this government is in power. Because of that, we do not propose to collect any more general revenue.

All of the changes to tax are predicated on the understanding that the government does not need any additional tax, yet no-one opposite seems to be recognising that. I can understand the cynicism of the Australian people. They fundamentally do not believe that a government is not going to collect any tax because their experience over the last 13 years was with a government that, in spite of its l-a-w promises, kept cranking up the tax bracket. But, because we have rubbed out the debt, because we are back in the black, because our GDP is improving and so too our capacity to service our overseas debt, we have a reduced principal and interest obligation that allows us to confidently predict that there will be additional money for government expenditure without having to raise any more money. That is very significant.

It is very important that every Australian recognises that the intention of this govern ment is not to collect more tax but to collect it fairly. No-one see seems to dispute that. I do not even know of anyone on the opposition benches who suggests that the present tax system is fair. We propose to introduce a fairer tax system in the interests of all Australians, giving them the obvious guarantee that there is no need for additional tax revenue.

I believe the Treasurer has every reason to be proud of the budget he has handed down. We as a government have every reason to be proud of the fact that the nation is now back in the black and back on track. Clearly, that gives Australians an assurance at this stage, particularly when some of our near economies are suffering. I am pleased to be part of a government that has taken difficult decisions in the national interest.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak during this budget debate. I want to assure the previous speaker, the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), that he will continue to hear a mantra about tax reform over the next few months from the opposition. That mantra will not be about how we do not need any more revenue. That mantra will be very simple. It will be along the lines of what the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou) would do if he had the integrity to be sitting on our side of the political fence following his previous capacity as a political apparatchik. Our message will be very simple: no GST. That is message No. 1 which we will be ramming home month after month, day after day, hour after hour, minute after minute, 30-second grab after 30-second grab.

speech.para: The second message we will be hitting home is the hypocrisy of a government which wants to slug ordinary families with a GST on food, movie tickets and every item of their lifestyle, whilst Senator Parer and others on the opposite side of the chambers have the benefit of family trusts. I think those two messages are very well understood by the electorate. You have people who earn millions of dollars a year paying minimal tax and you have a government which is refusing to do anything about that. Real tax reform is hitting those who can afford to pay—not hitting pensioners when they go to their local corner store to buy a loaf of bread or a carton of milk, but that is exactly what we will see.

We all recall that those who are now part of the government opposed every real element of tax reform introduced by Labor during the 1980s. We well remember that the current Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), opposed the capital gains tax. We well remember the opposition to the fringe benefits tax, which was going to destroy the restaurant industry and destroy the hospitality industry in this country. We well remember that every single progressive tax reform introduced by Labor was opposed by those opposite. All those opposite can come up with is essentially a regressive redistributive measure in the form of a goods and services tax, while they fail to do anything which would hurt the top end of town.

I want to talk about some other issues in the budget that was handed down a few weeks ago. We heard nothing about tax reform in that budget—that is the irony. Here we have the final stages of this parliament leading up to an election sometime later this year and we have a government which has failed to put its program before the people of Australia. We had the extraordinary situation where the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, outlined the basis of Labor's tax plan on Sunday. So we have an opposition leading the way on tax reform, showing leadership and putting its program out there before the people of Australia, while the government continues to not even let its own backbench know what it will be doing. I note that in the government caucus room yesterday, government backbenchers raised the concerns they had about Treasury being allowed to implement its own agenda without any constraints.

The fact is that this is a do nothing, mark-time budget but it has failed ordinary working people in Australia. People in my electorate are still reeling from the cuts of the last two Costello budgets, and this year's budget has not gone any way towards making up for those cuts. The budget might be making some government members and people from the top end of town feel relaxed and comfortable, but the government has no idea how real people in the suburbs and the country towns of Australia are feeling.

My electorate is a bit different from the Prime Minister's. Figures show that 43.5 per cent of my electorate was born overseas, the fifth highest rate in the country. Grayndler has the sixth highest number of people who were born overseas and have been resident less than five years, and the vast majority of these people come from non-English speaking backgrounds. Eleven per cent of my constituents do not speak English fluently and nearly half the electorate speak a language other than English at home. Large numbers of people have settled in the inner west of Sydney from Asia, China, Vietnam, the Middle East, Greece and Italy—indeed, from all over the world. They are not feeling terribly relaxed and comfortable, because this government has cut off vital resources for new migrants trying to take their place in their new country. There have been appalling cuts of 60 to 65 per cent to the Adult Migrant English Service in New South Wales—and this at a time when those more redneck elements opposite would state that it is very important that people learn English. They say that on the one hand but, on the other hand, they are gutting the funding of those organisations.

My electorate has more people on incomes less than $500 per week, fewer people on incomes of more than $1,500 a week and lower median weekly family incomes than the electorate of Bennelong. These ordinary working families are not feeling relaxed and comfortable either. People on ordinary incomes have been slugged with huge hikes in child-care costs as a result of successive coalition budgets. It is not only disgraceful but also unbelievable that this government not only slashed $850 million in child-care funding over the last few years but then, when the budget papers were released, it turned out that child-care expenditure was $117 million less than what it should have been. That means almost a billion dollars has gone from child-care funding since the last election.

In Bennelong, the unemployment rate at the last census was five per cent. In my electorate it was twice that. The government's successive cuts to employment programs have done nothing to constrain unemployment. The government itself in these budget papers forecast that unemployment will rise above eight per cent and stay there. There has been $1.8 billion cut out of these employment services over successive budgets, and it has been cut by a further $147 million in this budget over the next four years. The government's new net spending on unemployment programs is less than one-fifth of what it has taken out of job programs.

Another thing that is very different in my electorate when compared with an electorate such as Bennelong is the number of rented houses. Forty-one per cent of dwellings are rented in the electorate of Grayndler, the eighth highest figure for any electorate in Australia. Cuts to rent assistance over the last two budgets have meant real decreases in the quality of life experienced by people in my electorate. As people would be aware, rental prices in Sydney are extremely high. The Olympics will do nothing to reduce that pressure in the lead-up to the year 2000, particularly in the inner western suburbs of Sydney.

The problem with this government is that it has no real vision. The old relaxed and comfortable cliche has been replaced by security and stability and other buzzwords being used by the government, but it is wearing very thin. The fact is that people in electorates throughout Australia are not feeling relaxed and comfortable. They are not feeling relaxed and comfortable about the slash and burn mentality of this government.

In the first two budgets we saw the Howard government slashing billions of dollars from the social welfare programs and the public sector. We saw millions of dollars taken from nursing homes and aged care, millions from higher education, millions from school education, millions from child care, millions from public health and millions from research and development. But slash and burn is not the only tactic that the coalition has used in the last 2½ years. Increases in government service delivery charges are not headline grabbing, but they nevertheless impose a burden on many hardworking and already overstretched families. User pays in Centrelink and the abolished CES mean that employers must now pay to get new staff, yet another burden on small business and yet another disincentive to employment.

At least when you go back in time you have to give John Hewson some credit for honesty. At least in the 1993 election campaign with Fightback there was a fair dinkum program for what they would do in government. But along came the last election campaign, the campaign about being relaxed and comfortable, and none of these visions of slash and burn were put forward—and not surprisingly. What we have seen since, however, is two budgets in which Costello cut in every way possible. We now have a budget which is an attempt to say, `Oh, well, we're nice people really,' in the lead-up to an election in the hope that that will wash with ordinary Australians out there in the electorate.

The fact is that ordinary Australians are not feeling relaxed and comfortable about these cuts. They are not feeling terribly secure, particularly when you have a government with its massive ideological obsession of smashing people's employment rights for what it sees as the crime of belonging to a trade union, which is essentially what the waterfront dispute is all about. We have seen images on TV of big, balaclava-clad security guards dressed in black throwing people out of their jobs in the middle of the night, using dogs and mace and other weapons and threats. We have seen scab buses employed by the government and the government legislation which it is now saying it might withdraw or not proceed with—the scab solidarity fund, effectively—at a time when this government will do nothing and has done nothing in this budget to allocate money for the miners at Cobar or Woodlawn. Those constraints—this us and them mentality; this divide and rule ideologically driven government—are having a massive impact out there on Australians. Australians are feeling terribly concerned at the direction of this government.

I want to conclude by commenting on a couple of local matters in terms of the budget which showed how much was spent as opposed to how much was allocated. The first of those is the massive underspending of the government's insulation program around Kingsford Smith airport, and this at a time when the government some year ago cut off the insulation program at Stanmore Road in my electorate because it said that the change in aircraft noise patterns meant that those people who had been promised insulation no longer deserved it. The fact that the government underspent the amount of revenue which it anticipated spending in the last 12 months is an absolute disgrace given that it has withdrawn from that obligation and from that commitment. I would remind the parliament that this was revenue raised by a ticket tax of $3.40 on every passenger who goes out of Sydney airport. So it is not as if they are not spending any general revenue.

The second matter is that in spite of the considerable funds which have been allocated for the development of a second Sydney airport only $8 million was spent on that in the budget, which is something like less than nine per cent of what had been allocated. The people in the electorates of Lowe, Barton, Watson, Grayndler, Sydney, Wentworth and Kingsford-Smith will all have a look at that and say, `Well this government isn't real fair dinkum if they can only spend nine per cent of the funds that they allocated for that second Sydney airport.' At a time when there is urgent need for action there, I think that that exposes the government's hand.

talk.start.para: —The coalition, in handing down its third budget, has for the financial year 1998-99 brought the country's finances into surplus—the first surplus for the 1990s. `Surplus' is a word that I suppose not many members opposite would be familiar with. However, it is a word that the people of Canning and the rest of Australia deserve to be familiar with, after struggling through 13 years of Labor mismanagement, including the recession we had to have.

speech.para: The 1998-99 budget is one that comes from a government with a long-term view of economic reform. We do not intend to head down the path of perpetual boom and bust as experienced under the Keating-Beazley leadership. The coalition government is committed to ensuring benefits that will create security and safety for our children and a more stable future for our country well into the next century.

Our third budget is again fair and just. It is positive and continues to deliver on our pre-election commitments to create jobs, boost savings, help families and assist small business. This budget consolidates the coalition's plans put into place in 1996. It does so by introducing measures aimed at encouraging people to save for their future and for that of their families. It reaches out a helping hand to small businesses that were given a short straw under the previous Labor government. Our young people will benefit from further work for the dole initiatives, and those who care for the disabled will be better off financially.

The average Australian home buyer is now saving $320 per month because of the lowest home mortgage rates that this country has had since the 1970s. Remember that at one stage those interest rates got as high as 16 per cent. Small business interest rates have now come down to 7.7 per cent, the lowest rate for small business since the 1960s. Let us not forget unemployment. While still unacceptably high, we now have the lowest unemployment rate in eight years—meaning, of course, that we have more people now in jobs. But I suggest that a lot more still needs to be done.

There are many aspects in this budget that deserve praise. However, as time does not permit me to elaborate to such an extent to cover them all, I will concentrate on those elements that I believe will particularly benefit the people of Canning. As a nation we need to boost our savings base. People need to be encouraged to save, to know that to do so will reap rewards. From July 1998, the savings rebate will reduce tax on savings by 7.5 per cent, and by July 1999 by 15 per cent, for the first $3,000 of income. In this way, many people who save will receive a current benefit that they may choose to reinvest.

Our budget is a caring budget. It includes plans to provide a fair safety net to both pensioners and carers in our community. We have also listened to the voices of the self-funded retirees. We have given tax fairness to self-funded retirees and expanded their eligibility to obtain the Commonwealth seniors health card. This government is the first government to legislate a commitment to maintain the single rate of pension at 25 per cent of total male average weekly earnings. By this action we demonstrate the high priority that this government places on ensuring security for the elderly and for those in need.

As of January 1999, the gold card for health care will be available to those World War II veterans who faced danger from hostile forces. I am sure that all members would acknowledge that carers make an immense contribution to the lives of those in our community who are incapacitated in some way or another. The $280 million staying at home package expands eligibility for the domiciliary nursing care benefit and has more than doubled the number of people who may be able to receive assistance. I think that is a fantastic achievement.

I now turn quickly to speak in support of the coalition government's plan that provides the unemployed youth of our country with an opportunity to increase their self-esteem. I am, of course, speaking in support of the Howard government's further work for the dole plan. An amount of $350 million has been allocated over four years to extend the principle of mutual obligation, to provide job opportunities and to increase young people's self-esteem.

Since the first announcement of this scheme, many local organisations in my electorate of Canning have expressed their interest in participating in pilot programs. I am pleased to say that the first two projects so far entered into in my electorate have been very successful, resulting in a high number of their participants finding jobs. Only last night, a representative from my office presented certificates to the participants at Amaroo Retirement Village. Indeed, my office has been inundated with calls from constituents, both young and old, employed and unemployed, expressing their support for the benefits they foresee coming from this plan.

Recent statistics show that the average full-time youth unemployment rate in the south-east corridor of Perth, which covers my electorate, is 21.3 per cent. When I spoke on this issue of youth unemployment last year, this rate was at 24.3 per cent—the highest in Western Australia at that time. It is therefore pleasing for me to note that it has come down. Even if it is only a slight reduction, it is at least a trend in the right direction. I acknowledge that we still have a long way to go, but this government has begun a process to reduce the high levels of youth unemployment. I am extremely proud of the achievements that we have thus far achieved.

It is my firm belief that work for the dole will help to wipe out the unfortunate stigma that is all too often attached to our young unemployed people—as being lazy, lacking in a sense of moral responsibility or lacking a commitment to hard work. Thirteen years of Labor government did little to dispel that perception. When the coalition government was swept into power more than two years ago, the youth of Australia were left with a legacy of a failed labour market program, the ill-fated Working Nation. Working Nation ensured that our young hopeful people were churned through endless training sessions which secured few real jobs and, sadly, it serviced only in many instances to heighten their growing disillusionment over their future job prospects.

Work for the dole, on the other hand, is one amongst many initiatives introduced by the Howard government aimed at addressing the difficulties facing our youth. Measures such as school vocational education programs, apprenticeship and traineeship schemes, numeracy and literacy strategies, Green Corps, the youth ambassadors for development program and the national youth suicide strategy are all focused on bringing the cycle of dependency to an end.

This government is also addressing the problems of those in our community who fall victim to illicit drug addiction. Drugs destroy societies. They destroy families. They destroy individuals. They destroy everything that we hold dear. The $7.5 million schools drug education strategy will deliver drug education in Australian schools and support a national goal of no illicit drugs in our schools. It is vitally important that we provide access to effective drug education models for our educators to ensure that those young Australians who need help receive it.

Health is another important matter to all of us, not only as individuals but also as a nation. The announcement of $80 million over four years to enhance preventive health programs is most welcome. It is often said prevention is better than cure, but the first step is to make people aware of this concept. In this I believe governments can play an important role through education and promotion of healthy lifestyles. Providing free influenza vaccinations, developing programs to reduce tobacco related illness and the prioritising of areas of environmental health are all good initiatives.

The government has committed additional ongoing funding to medical research. I am reminded of a very sad event that happened to a family in my electorate recently. A very vibrant, active young lady died suddenly and tragically as a result of meningococcal fever. Her parents were, and continue to be, devastated, especially because so little is known of this disease. What we do know about this disease is this. The disease has a short incubation period—between two to five days. The bacteria is spread through mouth-to-mouth transmissions by sneezing, kissing or sharing eating utensils. There is no known vaccination against the most common strain of this deadly disease in Australia. I am confident that, with the continued research dollars made available by the federal government, we will see a reduction in the number of deaths occurring from such an insidious disease.

Speaking to the Appropriation Bill in 1997, my colleague the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) offered some interesting advice to newly elected members. He suggested that a good way of attempting to gauge the public's acceptance of a budget's merit could be to consider the number of telephone calls each office receives. I must say that in the week following this budget I received only a handful of calls. All of these callers merely requested further information on budget an nouncements which they believe will benefit themselves or their families. It is indeed a popular budget, one that has been readily accepted by the electorate as being based on sound financial management. After all, most people must live within their means and they expect the government to do exactly the same.

The Howard government's job, having been left with Labor's $10 billion black hole, has been a most difficult one; but we have met that challenge. We have been tough when it was called for, but we never lost sight—the doing of which was Labor's demise—of the real battlers in local communities like Canning.

It is the consensus of many community leaders and commentators that increasing savings and reserves will bring about more important long-term economic benefits for all Australians. In quoting just one of them, let me refer to Mr Ron Silberberg, Managing Director of the Housing Industry Association. He said:
The federal government's strategy of conserving reserves is tactically correct and economically responsible.
Mr Deputy Speaker, as I have had so many coughing fits during this speech, I will reserve the rest of my speech and allow my colleague to continue.

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Canning (Mrs Johnston), expressed—and justifiably expressed—concern regarding youth unemployment. I point out, however, to members on the other side that under this government youth unemployment has actually increased; and the trends are that it is increasing. Equally, for those over 55, I think the rate of long-term unemployment is 50 per cent. The facts of the matter are that, these days, if you are over 45 without special skills and you lose your job, you are in real trouble. So there is a lot of insecurity out there. The catch-cry that the government is coming out with is: safety and security—and I forget the third `s', but I venture to say it is `sucked in' for many of those unfortunate Australians who lose their jobs, because the government is not producing any of those things.

speech.para: What is of most concern, however, is that the government is not addressing the fundamental need of Australia to become successful in the world economy, with the opportunities that are transferred to Australian citizens. The greatest threat on Australia's horizon—the greatest black cloud—is the extent of our trading deficit. That is something the government says has been aggravated by Asia. That may well be the case, in terms of some aggravation. But the fundamentals have been destroyed by the government.

I will give some figures to illustrate the concern. In the December quarter, the current account deficit was $5.7 billion, an increase of 22 per cent. There was a further massive trade slump in the March quarter, when merchandise exports fell by 12 per cent and merchandise imports exceeded exports by $1.97 billion. In the month of April we saw a $1.3 billion trading deficit—the biggest monthly trading deficit on record. The government's own budget papers predict the current account deficit forecast to rise to $31 billion, or 5.25 per cent of gross domestic product, as compared to 3.4 per cent when they took office. In terms of where this government is going, those figures are damning.

What have the government done about it? They have virtually decimated the capacity of our exporters to compete in international markets. I will give some examples of the more significant ones, although I will not go through the entire list of 38. They have abolished the DIFF scheme; they have emasculated the export market development grants program; they have abolished the international trade enhancement scheme; they have reduced the export access program; they have abolished the Asia-Pacific Fellowship Scheme, the Asia business links program, the Tradeblazer electronic commerce program, the innovative agriculture marketing program, the export access scheme and, in the ultimate act of being penny wise and pound foolish, they have cut some $400 million from the budget of Austrade and reduced Austrade's domestic staff by some 25 per cent. In total, the government has cut about $1 billion over four years from export enhancing programs. In total, some 38 industry export promoting programs have been either abolished or emasculated by this government.

While it may sound relatively trivial in the overall scheme of $1 billion being gutted from assistance, this year in Lisbon, Portugal, there will be an international exposition, obviously to promote trade and tourism in Europe. How short-sighted is this government when, for the first time, Australia will not be present at a major European trade exposition. One hundred and twenty-three nations, I think it is, will be over there marketing their tourist opportunities and their products for Europe, but this government, particularly given the Asian crisis, have totally missed the boat. They are to be condemned for that act.

The government maintains that they have fireproofed the economy. They say they have achieved that fireproofing by creating low inflation and, consequently, low interest rates. But it is interesting, is it not, that the government claim credit for low interest rates but do not claim responsibility for continuing unacceptable levels of unemployment. The facts of the matter are that the work of a number of ordinary Australians who showed restraint over a long period of time during the late 1980s and the 1990s, particularly with the prices and income accords, set in place the infrastructure that enabled the low inflationary results to be achieved. This government has obtained the benefit of that longer term restraint.

This government dismiss all that. They, of course, want to claim credit for low inflation. I suppose they can claim credit for gutting, in one year, $7 billion out of the economy, despite the fact that their own budget papers in 1996 showed that, by the year 2001, the budget would be coming back into balance and that that could be hastened by simple and relatively minor adjusting measures. As a consequence of gutting $7 billion out of the economy, we are facing record bankruptcies. The government really has no program in place to market Australian products or, indeed, as I will mention shortly, to develop Australian products and technology.

The facts of the matter are that we were developing an enthusiastic, dynamic and cooperative relationship between government and business. In 1983, the former Labor government introduced the 150 per cent research and development tax concession. All competent economists will say that the driving force of a nation and the driving force of a nation's competitiveness is investment in the nation's intellectual base, in terms of both education and research and development.

Last year, a prominent international science journal called Nature published a review of Australia's research and development program. It spoke of the startling effects that had resulted from that 150 per cent research and development deduction. Between 1982 and 1994, research and development increased from 0.24 per cent of gross domestic product to 0.75 per cent of gross domestic product. The rate of growth between 1986 and 1988 averaged eight per cent a year, compared with only 1.6 per cent in Japan, 0.6 per cent in the United States and 0.2 per cent in the United Kingdom. So we were really heading towards the front of the pack during that period.

External patent applications per unit of economic output more than doubled during the 1980s, whereas the OECD average increased by only 50 per cent. The runs were on the board, and industry, while apprehensive initially that there would not be a long-term structure in place, certainly got well and truly involved in research and development when they saw that it was working. Those figures, which have been recognised internationally, speak for themselves.

But what have the government done? Again they have decimated research and development in Australia. The Managing Director of Vision Australia, which exports high-tech medical equipment, said that the government's policies on research and development have drilled us right back into the 1960s. It is difficult not to agree with that. Cutting research and development from 150 per cent to 125 per cent represents taking $1.26 billion out of research and development over a four-year period. The nation as a whole is starting to pay the price for that.

The government, through its scapegoating policies, has tried to blame rorters of syndicated research and development programs. But, again, there are many examples of successful research and development programs that have been achieved through syndication and not one concrete example of rorting. Now, because of the red tape that the government has introduced for companies applying for research and development assistance, companies are simply abandoning it or, if they are substantial companies, they are moving offshore to Singapore and Malaysia, where there is a 200 per cent deduction for research and development.

Under this government, the number of applications for research and development assistance has dropped for the first time in 11 years. When the name of the game globally is research and development, under this government, for the first time in 11 years, Australia is going backwards. We are going to the bottom of the pack.

Figures out just this month show that a third of the money the government allocated for research and development was not taken up by the corporate sector because of the hurdles, restrictions and red tape that the government has imposed. The Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies said in a press release on 13 May:

By dithering, we are likely to continue to miss the boat . . . The Government seems bereft of ideas. . . Competitive success in the next century will be won by countries which follow the knowledge based path to generate real and enduring employment.
The government has missed the boat and, regrettably, under this government Australia is going to miss the boat.

The Financial Review reported that 20 per cent of companies in the chemicals and plastics sector are not even bothering with the government's program—it is so complicated. The Australian Food Council said in a media release of November last year:
There is an overwhelming need for firms and the nation collectively to invest in research and development.

The government has received two major reports—the Mortimer report and the Goldsworthy report—and yet we have not seen anything constructive in terms of industry programs coming from this government. Indeed, it is an indictment of this government that we will not see before the next election any programs in place to assist and develop Australia's automotive industry.

Continuing with the organisations which have condemned the lack of vision of this government, I refer to the Institute of Engineers of Australia. It has indicated that $750 million of exports in medical high-technology equipment is at risk because of this government's neglect. It is quite clear that, for purely ideological reasons, this government has retreated from the international sector. The government is simplistic, lacking in vision, boring and dull. But worse than that: it has vandalised Australia's export industry and it has vandalised research and development in Australia.

Quite clearly, this government is not up to the grade. I understand that towards the end of this year there is going to be a golf tournament in Melbourne for world leaders. I think that President Clinton, Prime Minister Blair, and indeed Nelson Mandela will be coming out here—great men, great men of vision for their countries. If our Prime Minister participates in that tournament, I think those great men will relegate him to the position of caddie.

The fact is that it is investment in exports, in innovation, in education, and in research and development that is going to make this nation great. On all those fronts, this government is lacking. Only those areas are going to create sustainable employment opportunities. Only those areas are going to develop Australian living standards on a long-term basis. Without addressing those areas, Australia's balance of trade is going to become worse. If the government does not do anything about it, the balance of trade is going to escalate at an exponential rate. The prospect of this government being re-elected is a matter for real alarm.

The reason Australia is not travelling too badly at this stage in terms of not being in the same boat as our Asian competitors is the fact that in the pipeline we have had the results of a decade of export assistance and the results of a decade of research and development assistance, and we have had a highly educated society. But all those things are at risk from this government.

Industry leaders out there are not ideologues. Yes, they are concerned for the interests of their companies but, more importantly, they are concerned for the interests of Australia. Before the next election they are going to weigh up the two teams. They are going to look at the team captains and, quite frankly, one of them is not up to the grade. They are going to look at the respective frontbench teams, and they will note that one team has had seven of its frontbench relegated to the reserve bench. With one or two exceptions, the replacements are still reserve graders. They will also look at the game plans of the respective parties, and they will see one that is boring and lacking in vision but, more importantly, they will see a party, if re-elected, that will quite simply continue its program of vandalising Australia's export industry, of vandalising Australia's research and development, of vandalising Australia's education and talent base.

talk.start.para: —The infrastructure strategy, a very visionary program I put together back in March 1996, has served its purpose well in my electorate of Capricornia. When I was elected to office, I believed it was important to have a plan for the region. The plan focused on bricks and mortar projects and capital funding for existing facilities to provide them with a leading-edge advantage over other electorates, with the end result of Capricornia becoming the most profitable and progressive electorate in the country.

speech.para: One project from the infrastructure strategy remains to secure funding—the extension of the Rockhampton city airport runway to 3,200 metres. We can see that it is a very visionary infrastructure strategy and a great plan. The previous speaker, the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), spoke about the importance of having vision. I am pleased to say that there is only one project in the infrastructure strategy left to be funded.

The people of Capricornia in the existing parts—and those people coming into the electorate from Dawson and Kennedy as a result of the redistribution—can rest assured that I am currently in the throes of completing the new infrastructure strategy to take us through the new parliament, should I retain Capricornia after the forthcoming federal election. The last plan was very successful, and the next will continue with this trend.

The drought has been very destructive to our region, especially to the city of Rockhampton. Well known as the beef capital of Australia, Rocky is the business and service centre to central Queensland. It has been important for me as the federal member to change Rockhampton's dependency on the cattle industry, as the primary producers in the area are very cautious in their spending, especially with the continuing drought.

Capricornia produces great wealth in exports, not just for Queensland but for Australia. The beef and grain industries have struggled because of the drought, but have continued to survive in the face of adversity. The coal mining industry has also felt the pinch of the lack of rain for coal preparation. This industry has also done the country proud. Therefore, it is only fitting that Capricornia should receive a spin-off from the budget. I am aware that many electorates did not receive funding boosts from the budget, but as Australia has fared well off the back of the exports from Capricornia, it is only fitting for the government to reciprocate by putting some money back into the region.

I am elated that the government has provided Capricornia with a major funding boost from the defence budget, with a total expenditure of $11 million for Rockhampton and Shoalwater Bay military training area. Expenditure of $2.78 million has been allocated to upgrade the airport for a deployment facility. This will redevelop the old civil terminal for military operations, with approximately 9,000 square metres of aprons and taxiways. Also, an explosive ordnance storage facility will be built at the Rockhampton city airport. We will have the ability for aircraft to do more manoeuvres out of Rockhampton, rather than having to travel from Townsville and from the Brisbane area, which will mean a significant benefit and cost saving.

Another significant boost for the area will be $4.8 million to upgrade the Base Adminis tration Support Centre in Western Street, Rockhampton. Troops come to the area for training from Singapore, the United States and, of course, the Australian Defence Force. I have been aware for some time that we really need new facilities. This upgrade of the local BASC is imperative for our training needs and ultimately will bring money spin-offs for the local economy, which will be great for the people in the area.

Another $1.1 million has been allocated to complete the $2.1 million small arms range at Shoalwater Bay and $327,000 for a $1.1 million sewage works project at Shoalwater Bay. This will complement the existing accommodation facilities at the bay—the taxi drivers, retail clothing outlets, jewellers and the corner stores. Last year, we had a significant win for the small business sector in Rockhampton with the granting of a licence to local operators to sell duty free goods to the visiting military personal from overseas. The visitors do not carry an airline ticket as such. Their military identification card or a letter from their commanding officer is sufficient for them to purchase duty free goods from local retail outlets. This was a significant boost for small business in Capricornia.

I take this opportunity to thank the Rockhampton Chamber of Commerce and Mr Phil Peel from Phil Peel Jewellers for their support and assistance while I put this together. It just goes to show that we can do a lot for small business. Federal members just need to listen to what the people they represent want and work together with them. As a team nothing is impossible.

We have heard the Labor Party moan and groan about the budget. I do not know what the members on the other side have been doing for the past 2½ years, but I say to them: why don't you get off your hands and help the people you are here to represent? If I can make it happen for Capricornia, I am sure that, if you applied yourselves to your work as much as you do to your constant whingeing and backbiting, this country and those people you are here to represent would be a lot better off.

Capricornia has fared well under the coalition government. In fact, all that is left to fund out of my infrastructure strategy, as I said previously, is the extension to the Rockhampton airport runway to 3,200 metres. And, quite frankly, it makes sense to do it. The 1996-97 budget saw funding to the tune of $2.3 million to build accommodation at Shoalwater Bay and a further $2.1 million to build an air-to-ground live firing range at Shoalwater Bay. Now we have the aircraft deployment base being built at Rockhampton city airport and the ammunitions storage facility on site, all that is required is the extension of the runway. That will give assault and large military aircraft the ability to get in and out of the Rockhampton facility—another great win for the people of Rockhampton and Capricornia. It will do a lot for the local economy and is what is required in my region to keep people in business, particularly while the effects of the drought are still biting at the heels of the public.

The last two budgets have also seen a win for Capricornia in relation to education. The Central Queensland University has seen increases in funding in the past two years to make Rockhampton and Capricornia an educational hub. This has drawn people to the area who spend money, which helps the local economy and stabilises the area, ultimately creating jobs.

We have focused heavily on sporting facilities as well. We have tried to push Rockhampton as a sporting centre for Queensland. In the past couple of years, Rockhampton has marched forward as a sporting destination, particularly with the development of the Kalka Shades hockey fields, which have been pitched with new artificial grass to provide a superior playing surface second to none in Australia. The latest win in the area is the funding to build rowing lanes on the Fitzroy River. These will be used in the run-up to the 2000 Olympic Games. These are but two of the many first-class facilities we boast in Capricornia which will bring people to our area who will spend more money in the region.

Water is imperative to the development of any region and Capricornia is no exception. The infrastructure strategy from 1996 was to develop the Nathan Gorge Dam near Theo dore and the Mount Morgan No. 7 dam. The intention is to put 4.5 metres onto the existing dam wall to increase the water supply some threefold. I am proud to say, once again, this is another fully funded project. I turned the first sod several weeks ago and construction is well under way.

I take this opportunity to thank the people of Mount Morgan for giving me the honour of having the dam named after me—the Paul Marek Dam. This has been a most humbling experience for me. I walked up a lot of dry gullies to secure the funding for this project, but we secured the funding. I thank the mayor, Richie Bills, and the Mount Morgan Shire Council for playing a very strong role, working as a team and being instrumental in the rebirth of the township, which received nothing but words, not deeds, from Labor.

The rural industry has had five interest rate cuts in a row, worth some $500 million to Australia's farmers, which will benefit them by way of a lower exchange rate. The interest rate cuts combined with the currency devaluation represent a $6,100 boost to farmers' income since the coalition government has been in power. Each one per cent cut in interest rates increases farmers' income by some $2,400. The aviation industry, under the coalition, has received the biggest kick-start in years, with the reduction in the excise on avgas by approximately 16c a litre. For those graziers who use helicopters for mustering, this is great news. For those who use air tractors for the aerial spraying of their crops, this is also great news. Effectively, 16c a litre off the cost of avgas will reduce the cost for primary producers by thousands of dollars. One helicopter operator told me he was set to save up to about $32,000 a year.

There is a lot of great news in this budget. I mention the gold card for veterans and the Commonwealth seniors health card for self-funded retirees. It is a great budget and a great win for the area. The big issue on the tongues of most Australians at the last election, when the people threw out the Keating-Beazley Labor government, was the extreme debt this country had. Thanks to the National and Liberal coalition team, we have provided this country with a surplus of $2.7 billion. And be warned: the Labor Party will undo all this responsible fiscal management we have put in place if they have an opportunity to take office.
Effectively, red stands for debt, which is the Labor Party colours. The budget is in surplus, it is in the black and, consequently, back on track.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make some observations on the federal budget and what it has done in the transport area, which is my shadow portfolio, particularly with respect to the areas of road and rail. I will also make some comments on the stevedoring levy bill and the off-budget attempts to raise money with respect to redundancies in the stevedoring sector. I will conclude by making some observations about the missing item in the budget, the bit that made it a phantom budget, not a real budget—namely, the tax package and the GST.

speech.para: This government came to office with a lot of very overblown promises with respect to road funding, always portraying themselves as the party of the road transport sector, as the party of regional Australia, as the party that would deliver more on roads. We had the promise to maintain Labor's funding in real terms on roads, and in addition to reintroduce the black spots program and also fund the Pacific Highway to the tune of an additional $65 million per annum. Unfortunately, the delivery has fallen well short of the promise, as has been the case in so many other areas of this government.

In the budget a couple of weeks ago, we saw yet again further cuts to road funding. Against their own forward estimates from the previous budget, road funding was cut by a total of $28 million in the current financial year. We have seen in particular further cuts to the national highway to the tune of $12 million against their own estimates, the bulk of which, over 55 per cent, is to be borne by Tasmania, whose funding will go down from $28 million of national highway funding last year to $21 million of national highway funding, and a further approximately $17 million worth of cuts to the grants for road funding to the states and to local government. These figures for the national highway look even more stark when you look at the actual expenditure that has occurred in recent years in that area. In the last Labor budget, the figure for the national highway was $834 million. By the 1997 Costello budget, that figure had diminished to $697 million. In the budget two weeks ago, that figure had again diminished to $675 million. So we have gone down from $834 million to $675 million within the space of three budgets.

That is a massive reduction in anybody's terms. But to compound that reduction, what we have, on their estimates, is a reduction in the funding for maintenance of the national highway, over a period of four years, of virtually half the budget. The maintenance budget for the national highway for the year 2000-2001 is expected to be roughly half of what it was only four years earlier—in other words, a couple of years ago. Half the maintenance budget has been cut.

The implications of that will be borne by the road transport industry, by users of the roads, by regional Australia, in years to come, as that national highway continues to deteriorate. That is the price that the Australian people are paying for electing a coalition government which conned them on road funding, which said, `We are the friends of the road transport industry, we will help you, we will look after you.' In fact, a simple analysis of the figures across Labor's period in office compared with the first couple of years of the coalition government and their projections for the out-years indicates the lie in that claim.

Under Labor, in 1995-96 dollars, average road funding from the federal government was $1.7 billion over its 13 years in office. That was the average in 1995-96 dollars. Look at the actual expenditure by the coalition government and its projections in the forward estimates, convert that to 1995-96 dollars and what you get is an average of $1.5 billion—in other words, an average in 1995-96 dollars of a $200 million per year cut in road funding from this government. To add to that outrage is the fact that they have substantially besmirched the model of objectivity and transparency that was introduced by the Hawke government in 1991-92, with the agreement of all of the state premiers, to finally introduce some rationality and objectivity into road funding in Australia.

The Hawke government introduced the model whereby the national highway was directly funded and maintained by the Commonwealth government and the balance of road funding handed over to the states and local governments for them to make the decisions about how that money should be allocated. The current government has introduced the roads of national importance category which, as some members will know, we have tagged the `roads of National Party importance category'. We have recently seen the extent to which this is degenerating into pork-barrelling and misuse of government money for the purposes of seeking electoral advantage.

Main road 92 in the electorate of Gilmore is to have up to $70 million of federal money poured in to upgrade it. Parts of it are currently gravel road. It is a significant road and it needs upgrading—there is no question about that—but it is not a road that the federal government should be funding, based on the criteria that this government adheres to. You have the absurd situation where this government is proposing to pour money into that road, and not a cent for the Geelong road—the Westgate Freeway—which is desperately in need of upgrading, not a cent for the Great Western Highway which has similar problems, and not a cent yet—and maybe not at all—for the western orbital project. All of those roads are major, critical national economic roads and are far more important to the nation's economy than main road 92, yet the government can find money to pork-barrel in a marginal electorate.

I turn now to the area of rail funding, where the record is no better. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile), in the wake of this budget, possibly set a new record for the number of times that a funding initiative has been announced. After the budget, he put out yet another press release saying `Government announces new infrastructure funding initiate in the rail industry'. What he was announcing was the same thing that John Sharp announced after the 1997 budget, which in turn was the same thing that the same John Sharp announced after the 1996 budget, which in turn was a scaled down model of what Laurie Brereton, as the then Minister for Transport, announced in the 1995 budget. So we are looking forward to the 1999 budget—if by some mischance these people should actually get back into office—to see what they are going to announce then.

They have offered the people of Australia and the rail industry of Australia too little and too late. Under the Brereton proposal in 1995, $370 million was to be spent on upgrading the interstate rail infrastructure of Australia through the means of a new organisation called Track Australia. The new government has broadly picked up on this concept, but it has cut the funding. In fact, John Sharp as minister managed the spectacular achievement of announcing that he was going to continue with this funding but cut it—less money was going to be put in—and proclaim that this was something both new and good. In fact, he was simply reannouncing established policy that was already provided for in the forward estimates. The reality is that none of those figures I have quoted are sufficient to tackle the enormous problem we face with the interstate rail infrastructure. The amount that is required to fix our interstate rail track is in the billions—not in the hundreds of millions—but certainly a few hundred million is a pretty good start. Unfortunately, it has taken two years for anything to be done.

We are finally seeing some agreement being reached between the Commonwealth and the states with respect to how this money should be dealt with and what can be done to start the process of fixing the track. The problems are many: speed restrictions in many parts of the track; you do not have the ability to double-stack containers in most parts of the interstate rail track, the main exception being the Adelaide to Perth link; 19th century alignments that have been built around steam trains and their ability to go up hills and the like; all sorts of labyrinthine curves in parts of the Melbourne to Brisbane alignment—and a host of other problems. Concrete sleepers that were funded by the One Nation project are still lying next to the track near Ararat because the Victorian government is refusing to pick up the tab to insert those sleepers. There is a long list of problems.

The minister has congratulated the government yet again on its performance, even though its performance is sadly inferior to that of the previous government and that it has taken it a couple of years to get anything done. The sad thing is that now that that money is finally starting to flow, the government has failed to put the initial amount of money at the place where it needs to go most, which is the Adelaide to Melbourne connection. That is where you can get a pretty good bang for your buck fairly quickly—by getting rid of the speed restrictions and by changing some of the configuration in the infrastructure such as the bridges, the tunnels and the like in order to allow the double-stacking of containers.

As far as Labor is concerned, our first priority is to fix up that link. Unfortunately, this government has chosen not to do that. As a result, the Overland passenger service, which was privatised as part of Australian National privatisation a year or so ago, is now under threat. And this government is not doing anything to protect it; it is not doing anything to save the Overland. A relatively limited amount of investment in that track would substantially reduce the time it takes for the Overland to travel between Melbourne and Adelaide, which in turn would obviously improve its attractiveness to customers, not to mention the benefits that would flow into the freight rail sector as well.

It is estimated that getting rid of those speed restrictions by upgrading the track would cut the time of the journey between Melbourne and Adelaide by two or three hours. These are obvious benefits, particularly for the people of Adelaide who rely heavily on that service and on the tourism and freight services that it brings. That is a double disappointment.

Finally, in the transport area, I reiterate the opposition's concern about the stevedoring levy that the government is attempting to impose upon stevedoring companies. Our objections to it are various. First, and most obvious, this is a substantial part of what is found to be prima facie an unlawful conspiracy involving the federal government, Patrick Stevedoring, the National Farmers Federation and various others in an attempt to sack 2,000 Australian workers for no other reason than that they belong to a particular union, without any reference to their individual characteristics, their work performance or the like.

We object to the bill because stevedores who have no involvement in the current dispute, such as Strang and Sealand, who do not wish to make workers redundant, are being forced to pay that levy. We object to the bill because it creates a situation where the major stevedores are saying, `We will absorb the $6 and $12 levies,' yet no question is being raised by Professor Fels of the ACCC or, indeed, the government, as to why, if the major stevedores can absorb that levy, the equivalent amount is not being passed on to their customers already. If they can wear the $6 and the $12 per car or per container, why are they not doing that already? Why is the ACCC not investigating these things?

These are all issues as to why we object to this legislation. We object to the fact that the government is basically trying to blackmail the workers and the MUA into giving up substantial numbers of jobs, the bulk of the employment in the industry for its members, or putting them in a position where they face companies that have been artificially created with no assets and are being liquidated, therefore creating a situation where large numbers of people lose their jobs with no access to normal redundancy entitlements or their accrued entitlements with respect to long service leave, annual leave and the like.

This is essentially what the government is doing: it is trying to blackmail people into copping its political agenda by misusing this stevedoring levy, which in turn is a clear breach of the government's commitment to no new taxes. It is a tax. It is an indirect tax. It is an indirect tax on the users of a particular service; it is not a levy on the industry.

In conclusion, on the matter of tax, let me restate both my personal perspective and the opposition's view on the GST. It is amusing to see the frozen faces and the fear in the eyes of members opposite as they start to realise the implications of the GST proposal. It is regressive, it is inflationary, it threatens thousands of small businesses with additional paperwork and bureaucracy and it is grossly unfair.

At the moment, we are in a phoney war situation. Every interest group and every commentator out there thinks that their pet hate is going to be solved by the GST: payroll tax is going to be wiped out, the fuel excise levy is going to be wiped out, we are going to get income tax cuts, and so the list goes on. Everybody thinks that their problem is going to be solved. The anomalies in the wholesale sales tax system are all going to be swept away by a GST. At this rate, the GST will be 25 per cent.

Of course, the reality is that that is not going to happen; that is not what will occur with a GST. What we will see is all the bad bits. We will see the regressive shift away from income taxation, which means that people on very high incomes will pay the same amount of tax on an item of clothing, a loaf of bread, a trip to the pictures or whatever the case may be as people on a very low income. And, as a result of those things being taxed, there will be less tax on incomes and, in particular, there will be less tax on people on higher incomes. The ordinary people in this country understand that, because opinion polling demonstrates that there is a stark difference in attitude to the GST according to your income. If you are on a low to middle income, you oppose it. If you are on a high income, you support it. That means that the people of Australia understand what a GST is about: it is about redistribution away from people on low and middle incomes in favour of the wealthy. That is what a GST means, and there is simply no way around that fact. That is what this government stands for, that is whom it represents, that is whom it wants to help and that is whom it wants to advantage. That is why it is putting forward a GST.

This is not tax reform; this is tax redistribution. It is tax redistribution in a regressive direction. It is tax redistribution in favour of the wealthy. There is no way around it, and the people of Australia will recognise that, as they have recognised it before, and will vote these people out of office accordingly.

talk.start.para: —This year's budget consolidates our finances and sets the scene to ride out the economic difficulties in Asia and Indonesia which are impacting negatively on us. We are in the best economic position for 25 years—in the black with a $2.7 billion surplus.

speech.para: There are plenty of great economic reasons for the coalition government to be working so hard to repay Labor's debt. But it is not just about economics; it is about the quality of life we leave for our children. Currently, we have to raise $8,000 million in taxes to pay the interest bill on Labor's debt. I look forward to the day when this money will be spent on health and education instead of our interest debt.

This budget contains certain initiatives that will have a direct impact on the quality of life of Australian families. A budget initiative in my own portfolio area brings together what my constituents tell me are the three most important issues to them—health, the environment and jobs. The budget includes funding for a national medicines disposal program, building on pilot projects already under way in South Australia and New South Wales.
