This Australia-wide program will improve the health of Australians by removing unwanted and out-of-date medicines from the home, where they pose a danger, particularly to our children. On an average day in Australia, seven children under the age of five years are admitted to hospital because they have taken medicines not prescribed for them. This budget initiative will help the environment by removing up to 700 tonnes of medicines from landfill and sewerage systems each year. While the national program is in its early stages, it is expected to help create jobs across Australia.

I am very proud that this national project will grow from an innovative and extremely successful scheme that has its roots in my own state of South Australia. The overseas pharmaceuticals for aid life—or OPAL—program is the brainchild of Geoff Lockyer and his wife. They have had the support of a number of organisations and individuals in setting up and maintaining OPAL—people like Dr Joy O'Hazey, the former Mayor of Mitcham, and Humphrey George, the President of the Pharmacy Guild in South Australia, and those opposite will be interested to know that their former colleague Peter Duncan has also taken a leading role and now chairs OPAL. I look forward to seeing OPAL work with the New South Wales based Return of Unwanted Medicines group to develop a national program that I expect will attract international attention, as so many of Australia's other quality use of medicines initiatives have already done.

Most of us believe that having good health is one of the most important things in life. The government agrees, which is why it has featured so strongly in the budget. Free flu vaccines for people over the age of 65 years will be provided from autumn next year. More than 200,000 people in South Australia alone will benefit from this measure.

Visits to the doctor will remain affordable, with $127 million being allocated over the next four years to fund rebate increases for GPs. There is $6.1 million for anti-smoking initiatives, a national approach to cancer control will be implemented, and funding for the National Health and Medical Research Council will be restored to a level of $165 million per year—an increase of more than $50 million.

The importance of medical research to the community cannot be overemphasised. It enables us to keep pace with our overseas counterparts, it creates jobs, it attracts investment—the spin-offs are endless—and it also means that we do not have to keep doing things in the same old way. New ways of treating diseases are found and put into practice and everybody benefits.

This week is National Reconciliation Week, and National Sorry Day yesterday provided an opportunity to reflect on the injustices which indigenous Australians have suffered and continue to suffer. I regret this suffering and I regret the fact that many indigenous Australians do not have the same health, education and employment status and general state of wellbeing that other Australians do. I believe that reconciliation is important—far too important to ever politicise. This budget provides more than $22.6 million to immunise indigenous Australians and ensure early detection of sexually transmitted diseases. There is also increased funding for indigenous health care services and for health infrastructure and capital replacement.

Hostel residents will have access to the medication reviews currently available to nursing home residents. This will be provided by accredited pharmacists, and doctors will also be able to identify patients in their own homes for such a review. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is one of the most generous and best systems of its type in the world. The government is committed to doing all it can to ensure that all Australians—and in particular older Australians as high users of pharmaceuticals—make the most of this system and also use their medicines wisely.

Our endeavours are not helped by people like the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and various Labor candidates who seem intent on scaring the most vulnerable members of our community by making ridiculous and completely insupportable claims about the safety and effectiveness of medicines on the Australian market—much to the horror of health authorities and the pharmaceutical industry. In fact, in relation to another argument about medicines, in the 15 May edition of the Australian Doctor the medical editor wrote of the shadow health minister:
We really don't need woolly, unscientific thinking on health.

It is grossly unfair to mislead members of the community over something as important as their health. Those who hold public office or who seek to hold public office should not prey on people in this way just because they want to score some cheap political points.

When it comes to older Australians, the federal government has a different agenda to the Labor Party. As we head towards the International Year of Older Persons, we have made a real commitment to helping older people retain their independence, both physically and financially. The budget includes $280 million in the form of the staying at home package to help older people remain in their homes and to give support for their carers.

Changes have been made to nursing home arrangements to improve the standard of accommodation for the fewer than five per cent of elderly people who enter residential care. Labor had a poor track record in this area, and as it was put to me at the seniors information service in Adelaide, `Why should people leave the comfort of their own homes to die in dormitories?' Improving accommodation where necessary is important.

Many low income self-funded retirees have contacted my office over the years expressing concern that they are not eligible for a health card. This issue is addressed in the budget, which provides for 220,000 people in this category to receive a seniors card which will entitle them to cheaper medicines. This initiative rewards people who have taken financial responsibility for themselves. A further 50,000 Australian World War II veterans will have access to a gold card for health care, which provides them with free treatment as a private patient with their choice of doctor in hospital, plus a wide range of other services, free of charge.

The budget also includes $291 million for the environment program, up from $256 million—a 14 per cent increase on last year. Funding has been allocated to clean up Australia's rivers, for landcare and bushcare grants and to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions by more than five per cent by 2012.

Recently, Australia's unemployment rate dropped below eight per cent for the first time since 1990. About 280,000 new jobs have been created since March 1996. Along with others, the government has worked, and continues to work, very hard in the community to bring that figure down to create opportunities for the next generation. It was concern for our young people's future that triggered us to abolish the CES and install a new system of privately run employment agencies. While it is still early days, the needs of those looking for work are already being catered for by having 19 different job providers operating in my electorate of Adelaide alone—and until recently three CES offices were providing this service.

The federal budget builds on the government's commitment to creating a brighter future for young Australians by allocating $350 million over four years to improve education, training and job prospects, including increased funding for the work for the dole program and for literacy and numeracy training. There will be an extension of the job placement employment and training program until the year 2000, which will help people up to 21 years of age who face multiple disadvantages, particularly the homeless. From July, for the first time some 70,000 students will receive rent assistance under the new youth allowance.

The government will set up a volunteer ambassadors for development program to provide about 500 people up to 30 years of age with the opportunity to live and work as volunteers in the Asia-Pacific region. We are also providing funding of about $215 million over five years to reduce the demand for and supply of illicit drugs in the community, for drug treatment and rehabilitation and for community education. Earlier this month the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said:

Our ambition must be to build a nation whose economy is strong and innovative, whose society is fair and tolerant, and whose contribution to the region and the world is valued because it is principled and generous.

I think that appropriately sums up the government's wish list and emphasises the goodwill with which it caters for the people it was elected to serve. I look forward to continuing to work towards this goal in partnership with those who share it.

talk.start.para: —Overall, it can be fairly said that this budget achieves sensible outcomes. It was more fortuitous than good design that the government adopted a budget strategy, from the time it brought down its first budget in 1996-97, to get into surplus at the end of its first three years in government. I say `fortuitous' because the government could not have known of events which were to transpire in our near north, in particular in Indonesia, Thailand, South Korea and even Japan. The fact re mains that if it had not adopted the strategy it did we would have been in a far worse situation than we now find ourselves in terms of the strength of our economy. So it was a strategy tailor-made, but lacking intent at the time, to enable our economy to withstand, to the best possible extent, the worst of the fallout from these crises we have witnessed recently in Asia.

speech.para: Many subscribe to the notion, as do I, that the disciplined budgetary approach of the Howard government is probably its single greatest achievement. It has enabled and runs concurrent with a strengthening of our domestic economy and performance. No-one would dispute the fact that there is room for improvement; nevertheless, the fundamentals are there as far as government can provide them.

As I have already indicated, a very desirable outcome of this is that the budget strategy adopted by the coalition does offset to a very important extent those external impediments to economic growth. Having said that—and as usual—there are some extravagant claims for some of the elements within the budget. That is pretty normal in political life, and it seems common to the circumstances which prevail when any budget has been brought down in the past.

I just want to touch briefly now on the spending side of the budget. There is a perception in the minds of some that, because the government has budgeted for a surplus, spending has somehow been contained or curtailed. Despite that commonly held view, it is still growing and has grown quite considerably during the lifetime of this parliament. Back in 1989-90, Commonwealth spending, as a proportion of gross domestic product, was around 24 per cent. That was not that very long ago, yet we find that the forecast in the budget papers for 1998-99 is that it is higher—in fact, some 24.6 per cent of GDP.

There are many who agree with former Labor finance minister and now journalist Peter Walsh who claims that the high level of spending and the trend of high expenditure to GDP—even though it has come down from last year's figure to 24.6 per cent of GDP—cannot be maintained. As Mr Walsh said, to allow spending to continue at present levels will only postpone the day of reckoning, not eliminate it.

I also want to touch briefly on the Medicare levy and some matters arising from that particular impost. A comparison of the take for the Medicare levy for 1995-96 and the estimated take for 1998-99 can be instructive. It shows a 24 per cent increase in the levy over the life of the Howard government to around some $4.1 billion projected for next financial year. What is interesting about that is that, at 30 June 1996, the Medicare levy added to the revenue some $3.35 billion—you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the guns buyback scheme was financed by a one-off increase to the Medicare levy—and, in 1997-98, including the gun buyback money, it totalled some $3.76 billion. This year, we are at $4.16 billion for the Medicare levy. That represents a 24 per cent increase since 30 June 1996. That is partly explained, of course, by an increase in the number of taxpayers paying the levy, but it is also because of the income tax surcharge which the government decided to impose. The budget figures suggest to me that there is an expected huge increase which would not have been apparent when the government announced its intentions in that regard.

Despite that particular increase, nevertheless, there remains a substantial disparity between the total levy expected to be collected in the coming financial year of $4.16 billion and the forecast overall expenditure on medical services which the Medicare program facilitates. Total expenditure on medical services alone is estimated for the next year to be some $7.9 billion. We know the Medicare levy does not cover the pharmaceutical benefits scheme or hospital services but, if you add those in, you get a total of $16.4 billion. Altogether, a total of $22.2 billion is being spent by the Commonwealth on health services generally.

I want to just take this opportunity to repeat the call I made two years ago and have made since: the Medicare levy should either reflect the total cost of medical services—that is, it should be raising at least $7.9 billion—or it should be scrapped. It is a game we play. It should be scrapped and added on to the marginal tax rates for individuals. We carry on with this pretence and we leave the public with the impression that the Medicare levy pays for all medical services when it does not. It leads to a mental approach by some who think they are actually paying all they need to pay towards the provision of their own health care, when that is obviously far from the truth.

Another interesting sideline is that the government is now speculating about adding another tax bracket to the Medicare levy. That was the very point I made when the government introduced its Medicare levy surcharge, if you like. I anticipated it at that time—as will happen with the superannuation surcharge and as already happens—so we are going to have another tax in there which will benefit from tax bracket creep amongst other things. It would be more efficient in taxation terms if the Medicare levy were scrapped and made part of the marginal tax rates for PAYE and other individual taxpayers.

Despite its implications for revenue, I think it is about time the major political parties examined the possibility once again of allowing tax deductibility for health insurance premiums. I know it has severe implications for revenue but, in the context of a tax reform package, the coalition might want to think along those lines. The simple truth is that the big stick approach adopted with the surcharge and the like has failed to keep people in private health insurance, and I suspect it is time to get back to offering the taxpayers something of a carrot. If that could be done in the context of tax reform of one sort or another, I think that would be all well and good. The budget papers, amongst other things, say:

Growth in Commonwealth health outlays over the decade to 1997-98 has averaged 4 per cent a year in real terms . . . The growth mainly reflects a steady increase in utilisation of medical services and pharmaceutical services over the period and a drift towards more costly drugs and medical services.
Health expenditure and health care outlays are a bottomless pit, and the major parties should be doing some radical thinking about that.

I have made the point that a positive of this budget is that it arrives at a surplus and it recognises the old dictum that, in relatively good economic times when there is reasonable economic growth, governments should be budgeting for a surplus and they should only resort to deficit spending when there is a need for some stimulus to the economy. That is clearly not the case, and it has not been the case for a number of years. It did take this government to finally overcome the legacy of the $10½ billion underlying deficit it was left when it was elected, a legacy which it did not expect. I think the Australian people did not expect it as well. The government tackled that deficit and it did so responsibly and no-one can take the credit for that away from them.

If we are to come to grips with some of the worst aspects of our overseas debt—which has arisen to some large extent out of our current account deficit—we have got to at some time or other improve the rate of private and household savings in this country. The fact is that at the moment our taxation system is simply not conducive to private and household savings growth. Given the low level of savings, it is necessary—as the government has done with its surplus in the budget—to bolster savings by increasing public sector savings to offset the poor and unimproving levels of private and household savings.

I must say that I welcome several matters which I have advocated during the life of this parliament being included in the budget. One is the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor and another is tax deductibilities for businesses meeting the cost of the conversion of computing systems to cope with the millennium bug. Also, I am delighted to note—although I have not seen it in the budget papers, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has personally assured me that it is there—that donations to the campaigns of independent candidates will in future be tax deductible, as are donations to the candidates of political parties.

talk.start.para: —That is a growing liability.

—It might very well be. I still have some concerns of course about the superannuation surcharge, the government's approach to research and development generally and incentives for research and development in Australia. There are some things wrong with the bills stalled in the Senate—the Managed Investments Bill 1997 —and I guess we are going to hear more about the announced intention in this budget to change investment rules for superannuation funds. I am sure that will be the subject of interesting debate in the coalition party rooms and in the wider community before we see it in some form of legislation. At this stage, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which I have taken the trouble to provide to members around the chamber.
—Is leave granted?
—Is this adjusted for inflation? Are they real figures or absolute figures?

—Before the member for Curtin continues, I might say to the minister that whether it is adjusted for inflation or not really does not affect whether it meets the guidelines. I would make the comment that leave is granted and, even more significantly than that, the chair gives approval for it to be incorporated in Hansard , because the practice has arisen, and I think it is appropriate at this time to remind the House, that only such things as tables can be incorporated. Matters which can be read into the Hansard do not meet the guidelines. So I thank the honourable member for Curtin.

interjection.para: Budget Statements 1996-97, Budget Paper No. 1 Page 43-28
Budget Statements 1997-98, Budget Paper No. 1 Page 5-3
Budget Statements 1998-99, Budget paper No. 1 Page 5-3
** Increase in Medicare levy in 1996-97 influenced by gun buy-back scheme

talk.start.para: —I thank the House and I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In response to the parliamentary secretary, why would you adjust it for inflation? You tell us there has hardly been any over the period.

speech.para: With time running out, I probably will not have the opportunity to comment in detail as I would have liked. But let us reflect on the fact that the government's total tax take from individuals has increased by nearly 24 per cent over its three budgets, or will have at the end of the next financial year. That represents a serious increase in revenues to the government. If you look at gross PAYE taxpayers, they are contributing something like 26 per cent more than they did in total at the end of 1995-96. I have already mentioned the Medicare levy and the fact that it includes a new tax in terms of a surcharge, and I know that the government claims that it is not a new tax but of course such a claim is fatuous.

I want to dwell for a moment on refunds. Refunds have increased by 27 per cent over the same period. I suspect that that is largely due to the provisional tax uplift factor being far in excess of what it should be in reality to achieve an equitable result. Those figures are not available, but I am going to attempt to discover them. Even at five per cent, there will be an incremental movement in provisional tax levels which will end up in necessitating refunds being made. So it gives the government the revenue and the use of funds for up to 12 months which it really should not have. I still think at five per cent the provisional tax uplift factor is far too high given the level of inflation in this country these days.

All in all, though, the government has earned the credit it has received from commentators for a sound budget. The outcomes are all the more credit worthy because there will be an election before the time the next budget is brought down. In its proposals for the coming year, the coalition resisted the temptation to buy votes in the populist approach which has characterised so many pre-election budgets in the past.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the 1998 budget delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 12 May. Ten years ago Paul Keating brought down a budget that he described as `bringing home the bacon'. History has since proved just what a pig of a budget it really was. But that was typical of budgets in those 13 years—a bit of give, a bit of take. The people gave and the people got taken. When the party was over, for all the noise about the world's greatest Treasurer and their economic vision, Labor bequeathed us a $10.2 billion deficit courtesy of the then finance minister and now Leader of the Opposition, Bankcard Beazley.
—Mealy-mouthed Howard.

—It was not a great place for the coalition to start. Our first budget was tough and not exactly the most pleasant way to repay the people for putting us into office, but we told the truth and we stopped the rot.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I quite frankly think that the honourable member sitting across the table should be made to withdraw that comment.
—Which comment's that?
—You know perfectly well.
—I did not hear the comment that the minister refers to.
—It was demeaning of the Prime Minister. It needs to be withdrawn.
—If the minister finds the comment in some way offensive, I ask the honourable member for Batman to withdraw.
—Which comment was it?
—You only made one.
—Was it the reference to the Leader of the Opposition by the member for Deakin or the reference to the Prime Minister as a mealy-mouthed person? Which one was it?
—The demeaning comment of the Prime Minister. You know damned well what it was.
—Was it the same as the demeaning comment made by the member for Deakin about the Leader of the Opposition? That is appropriate but not the one about the mealy-mouthed Prime Minister?
—The honourable member for Batman will withdraw.
—But he is mealy-mouthed.
—I ask the honourable member for Batman to withdraw.
—I will withdraw and I ask—
—That is all that is required from the member for—

—I ask that the member for Deakin withdraw the comments about the Leader of the Opposition. If you can give it, you take it. I withdraw on the basis that the member for Deakin also withdraws the unparliamentary comments about the Leader of the Opposition. It is tit for tat.

—On the point of order: there was no demeaning comment by the member for Deakin. It was the comment that the honourable member made and just repeated which he said he would withdraw that needs to be withdrawn unconditionally.
—We will deal with the member for Batman's comment first. I understand you have withdrawn; is that correct?

—I have withdrawn but, in doing so, I request that the unparliamentary reference to the Leader of the Opposition also be withdrawn—a comment which seems acceptable to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. It is almost as if there is one rule on that side of the House and another rule on this side of the House.
—The honourable member for Batman finds the comment offensive. I ask the honourable member for Deakin to withdraw the comment.
—`Bankcard Beazley?' Yes, I will withdraw that in order to get on with the speech.
—Just before you do, Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Oh, sit down and give your own a go.
—Order! I believe the honourable member for Corio wishes to speak next in this debate. If he wishes to do so, I suggest that he remain silent at the moment.
—Are you threatening me?
—Absolutely.
—The member for Batman will also remain silent.
—Very simply, on the point of order, even in the wildest dreams of the member for Batman he could not say that the term `Bankcard Beazley' is unparliamentary language.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I don't regard the term `mealy-mouthed Prime Minister'—
—We are not going to debate the point of order. The honourable member for Deakin, in the spirit of wanting to get on with his speech, has withdrawn the comment. That is the end of the matter.

—As I said, Labor's $10.2 billion deficit was not a great place for the coalition to start. Our first budget was tough and not exactly the most pleasant way to repay the people for putting us into office. But we told the truth and we stopped the rot, with the vast majority of Australians recognising that we needed to do exactly that.

speech.para: The third coalition budget is quite an achievement. As with our first two budgets, it sets the stage for a stronger and more stable economic environment. Most importantly, for the first time since the early 1990s the Commonwealth's budget is in surplus. In my electorate of Deakin, people understand about paying their own way. While households from Blackburn to Bayswater North live within their means, it is reasonable that they expect their federal government to do likewise. No parent wants to saddle a child with debt. I do not want to saddle my children with debt. No government should leave future generations in the red.

I would like to thank the people of Deakin for their self-sacrifice, understanding and cooperation for their role in wiping out Labor's debt. This debt was only recently acknowledged by Labor who, far from apologising, seem hell-bent on doing exactly the same thing all over again. Labor would have us believe they have changed their ways. But one only had to hear the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) on Monday night to know that is not so. The esteemed Austrian economist and author Frederick von Hayek once said:
. . . the ultimate decision about what is accepted as right and wrong will be made not by individual human wisdom but by the disappearance of the groups that have adhered to the "wrong" beliefs.

The member for Charlton and so many others on the other side still cling to those wrong beliefs. The class warfare promoted by the member for Charlton and the divisiveness promoted by the union movement and its marionettes in the Labor Party do not go down well with the people of Deakin. Nor did Labor's deficit. Despite our efforts in bringing the budget back to surplus, all of Deakin's residents, whether they are taxpayers or not—the pensioners, students, self-funded retirees, community workers, and working mums and dads—are still paying for Labor's mistakes. Labor knows it; so do my people in Deakin.

People may not care for economic jargon, but they are beginning to notice an improvement, a steadiness in the economy with the coalition at the wheel. Benefits are beginning to accrue to many sections of our community. I would like to outline some of those benefits which have taken place in Deakin as a result of this government being in office in the past 2½ years and now delivering a budget surplus.

First of all, over 25 per cent of households in Deakin are being purchased. Mortgage rates have come down to their lowest level since 1962—the year when my parents, who came out to this country as migrants, achieved their great Australian dream of buying their first home.

Secondly, there are about 4,000 businesses in Deakin, and business interest rates have also come down. At one stage under Labor, the rates were 20 per cent—now they are merely one-third of that. Memo to Paul Keating: `You were wrong. It wasn't as good as it gets!'

About 14 per cent of Deakin residents are aged 65 or older. The coalition has increased pensions and is the first government to tie them to average male weekly earnings. Self-funded retirees rightly reminded us that they not only paid taxes but also provided for retirement themselves. We have continued to recognise their sacrifices by, firstly, easing requirements for the health care card to low and middle income seniors—a measure which they have demanded and this government delivered. Secondly, we have reduced the provisional tax uplift factor to five per cent. In Labor's years, it reached twice that. And, thirdly, we have expanded the eligibility for the gold card—a measure demanded by the World War II veterans which it took this government to deliver.

Under Labor, there was no possibility of saving any money. Under the coalition, there are now incentives to save. The coalition's crackdown on welfare cheats and high income earners who rort the tax system has gathered extra funds without increasing income tax and without increasing the hidden sales taxes—two measures which are very popular with the Australian Labor Party. Taxpayers in Deakin were angry about obvious rorts that existed, despite Labor's threats to crack down. We heard time and time again from the ALP that they would crack down on tax cheats; yet, once again, it was this government that did it. In the Ringwood and Box Hill Centrelink offices alone there have been savings in excess of $2 million last financial year simply through improved data-matching.

While the states have cried poor over health funding, we have offered increased funding to hospitals and to Medicare, with more than $121 million extra earmarked for Victoria. I recognise, as does the government, that more needs to be done in the area of health and I am looking forward to further measures being announced in the coming months not only as part of the lead-up to the election but also as part of the tax reform package initiatives.

Furthermore, the people in Deakin have also benefited from the recently announced carers package, a package which injects an extra $280 million to enable people to look after relatives in their own home. Carers now have an opportunity to look after your elderly parents or relatives in their own home. What greater recognition is there for those carers who look after relatives in the safety and sanctity of their own family home than for the government to provide this carers package?

We have also made changes to aged care institutions to ensure the growth of that sector and to guarantee a high level of care for the frail. The aged care sector was neglected for 13 years by Labor, despite Labor's protesta tions over recent months. It is a sector which Labor acknowledged was too hot to handle and so they ignored it for 13 years—only now are they starting to cry foul. Aged care facilities in Deakin have done excellent work in looking after our elderly who cannot do it themselves. I am happy to say that nearly every one of those institutions has passed initial accreditation procedures and we can look forward to them providing top quality care well into the future.

To single out just one of them: Coronella Retirement Village is currently raising $5 million to ensure their facilities are top shelf. I am pleased to be associated in a very tangible way with that fundraising drive. It will ensure that the retirement village will look after the aged people of Deakin well into the next century. The fundraising drive is made up of local business people, community leaders and members of the Seventh Day Adventist Church—all working hard under the steering committee, chaired by Errol Peterson, to raise those funds.

We have also done quite a lot for the business community. In the recent budget, we even announced a package of measures to help business deal with the millennium 2000 bug. I am happy to say that last week the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) visited my electorate. In a dedicated boardroom meeting with a number of IT industry people, the minister went through the various packages and measures with them and received unanimous endorsement and support for what the government is doing. I thank the minister for his contribution that day and for his accessibility to the business community of Deakin.

In the tariff area, it took this government to handle the hot potato of the TCF and automotive industries. We did it despite the fear and anxiety created by the Australian Labor Party in the run-up to those announcements. I know the TCF and automotive industries in my electorate have been most grateful for the announcements and the security of investment which this government has introduced. There was evidence of many false promises by the previous government, such as the promises of assistance which they made to DuPont in my electorate. Yet DuPont, only as recently as last week, closed their doors and sold out to Godfreys.

Labor spouted on about this nation being called `the clever country'. At the same time, our schools were turning out graduates who could not read or write. Our tertiary institutions had excelled only in mediocrity. The reforms we have made will ensure that institutions offer a higher level of excellence and that our students are better equipped to meet the education and workplace demands of the 21st century.

According to the 1996 census statistics, 21 per cent of Deakin residents have a tertiary qualification. But what of the rest? What had the previous government done for the rest? This coalition has concentrated great energy and considerable funds into helping young people who do not go on to tertiary study. In Deakin, I have had the pleasure of working with many young people who now feel there is some light at the end of the tunnel. The electorate of Deakin has a lower level of unemployment than some others—at approximately seven per cent. This is due, in part, to the excellent relationship between government, businesses and schools in the area.

I am happy that this budget provides additional funding for the job pathway program. These funds will help organisations such as the Ringwood based Maroondah Careers Network's jobs pathway team. In a matter of months, the jobs pathway team placed 240 young people into apprenticeships, traineeships or employment. My congratulations to Peter O'Connor, Ashley Clinch, Marie Holmes and their team for an excellent result. Having met their placement target, this dedicated team is now assisting those students who have been identified as at high risk of leaving school early.

The VET program has also been successful in providing job readiness to over 1,800 students in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. Congratulations also to the Eastern Industry Education Partnership. To the ASTF, Tina Hambleton and the Melbourne East Group Training Company through David Windridge, I offer my congratulations on their excellent achievement and wish them well in the next round which will commence very shortly.

The initial round of the work for the dole program was most successful and funding has been increased for the next stage. The RSPCA headquarters, located in East Burwood in my electorate, was one of the sponsor organisations for the first round and was very happy with the pilot program. The level of hope has risen among the young and I know that brighter outlook has spread more widely in our community.

I give my firm commitment to the young people of Deakin that the work I have embarked on in the last 2½ years will continue—so that they also have the opportunity to work. They deserve the same job opportunities that their parents and I enjoyed. Businesses, schools, job brokers and Jobs East are working hand in hand with me to ensure that they get those opportunities.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to put in a small word for Jobs East—an organisation that I know you are familiar with. It is setting the standard for area consultative committees in Victoria—they are to be commended for their fine work under Louise Rowland and Louise DeGiusto—particularly for their initiatives in the first stop and one-stop shops in helping young kids get into apprenticeships, traineeships and also for designing measures which will fill the greatest skills gap in the region, that is, metals industry skills.

After the despair caused by Labor, our sound economic management has delivered security and a greater sense of purpose. The biggest immediate challenge for the future is to deliver a taxation system that is fair and equitable. Certainly, from the responses I have had in my numerous constituent contacts, their support for real change is considerable. The coalition will propose such a system, and I believe that people will support it. But the question is: will the Labor Party and the Senate independents bow to the will of the people or will they thumb their noses at the Australian people? Will they allow us to capitalise on the first three coalition budgets and set up this nation for a new century? For the sake of the 110,000 people in Deakin, I certainly hope so. I commend this budget to the House.

talk.start.para: —The third Howard-Costello budget reflects the mediocrity and lack of vision of its principal architects, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello). It fails in the same way the Howard government's two previous budgets failed. It really has just thrown in the towel on the nation's No. 1 problem, unemployment, and it has committed Australia to another period of mediocre economic performance.

speech.para: Australians who have a vision for this great country and who get excited by its potential literally bleed in despair at the squandered opportunities and the unnecessary pain delivered to its citizens by an incompetent government which, after 22 months in office, has forfeited its right to govern.

It is a deceitful budget which has been built on delusion. It has been brought down by a government which has had eight ministerial resignations in 22 months, and multiple backbench defections as well, making it the worst government in our nation's history. It is a budget that continues the betrayal of Australia's older citizens who are seeking nursing home accommodation and our young and older unemployed who desperately look to the government and industry to create the full-time jobs necessary to provide them with the dignity of work. It is a betrayal of the young mother with children in child care working to supplement the inadequate income of the household. It is a budget which continues its betrayal of regional Australia.

It is a fact that Australians seek a lot from their Prime Ministers. They expect real leadership when the national interest demands it. They expect their Prime Ministers to make significant gestures on their behalf to bring the nation together in order that the nation can progress in unity to the new millennium.

Yesterday was National Sorry Day when many in the community took the opportunity to apologise for the untold harm done to the stolen generation of our first Australians. We know how the Prime Minister let the nation down in his response to that event of national significance. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said yesterday in the House that there is no point in saying sorry, there is no point in making an apology, if your heart isn't in it. The word `sorry' does not come easily to this Prime Minister.

On the economic front, many of us are still waiting for the Prime Minister to come into this chamber and apologise to the Labor Party and the Australian community for the absolute mess in which he left the Australian economy in 1983. I would like the Prime Minister to come into this House and say sorry for the 11 per cent inflation rate that he left Labor in 1983 and for the burden that he imposed on pensioners and families in this country. I want him to come into this House and apologise for the 10 per cent unemployment rate and the lack of hope that he left this nation with.

We would like the Prime Minister to come into this House and apologise for all the Liberal budget deficits that were run by the Liberal Party from 1975 to 1983, especially the Howard budget deficits during his year as Treasurer. We would like him to say sorry for failing to reform the Australian taxation system when he let $2 billion slip through the net in bottom of the harbour tax rorts. Perhaps it is time for the Prime Minister to apologise for the fact that, when he left office in 1983, Australians were losing their jobs at the rate of 1,000 a day across the length and breadth of this great country.

I have listened to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and many members of the government in their attempts to cover up the inadequacies of their fiscal management, feverishly trying to claim credit for the economic achievements of Labor over 13 years. The myth makers in the coalition have been working overtime, but no amount of myth making can gloss over the fact that this is an incompetent and deceitful government, led by a weak and vacillating Prime Minister and an arrogant and incompetent Treasurer.

The Prime Minister regularly comes into this place claiming credit for the low inflation rate in this country. He wants us all to forget that, during his time as Treasurer, he left pensioners, families and businesses with an inflation rate of 11 per cent. Labor reduced that rate by nine per cent to around two per cent. The Prime Minister reduces it by a further one per cent and claims a great economic victory! I say to the Prime Minister: when you can reduce the inflation rate by nine percentage points, as Labor did, then you can come to us and claim some credit for your economic achievements.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, could I take a point of order. Not only are the words painful, but I am sorry to say there is something wrong with the microphone. The sound in this place is just deafening. Although I am perfectly pleased not to hear the words, one can hardly understand the syllables.

—I take the minister's point. The clerk is making some inquiries about the sound now. If it is possible for the sound to be turned down, that will still enable us to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Corio.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I know these are words that the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel opposite and members sitting opposite really do not want to hear. But let me continue. On the growth front, the Prime Minister left the economy in a state of negative growth when we were losing jobs by the thousands in 1983. It took Labor to engineer four years of 4½ per cent-plus economic growth, and massive job growth as well.

speech.para: What has been Prime Minister Howard's and Treasurer Costello's great growth legacy to the nation over the two years they have been in office? They succeeded in lowering the growth rate to only 2.7 per cent in 1996-97, and now we have a slight increase to around three per cent in 1998-99. When you can come into this House and produce for me an economic growth record that equals Labor's, then we will listen to you.

Another great Liberal myth relates to the budget deficits. The Prime Minister might be on some high moral ground on this point if his past record reflected some great achievement in the area. But, as the Australian public understand, no Liberal government in the last three decades ever ran a budget surplus. We had Liberal budget deficit after Liberal deficit. It was only Labor in office that was able to run four budget surpluses in a row. And who could forget the Prime Minister's $25 billion deficit legacy to the nation in 1983? What an appalling record by the Prime Minister. We know why he is obsessed with turning any budget into a surplus. It is something new for him. He was never able to do it when he was Treasurer. No Liberal government in the last three decades has been able to deliver a budget surplus, so we welcome the Prime Minister's conversion to the concept of a budget surplus, one which was introduced to the fiscal management of this nation by the former Labor government.

The cruellest myth of all being perpetrated in this budget by the government is that it has insulated the nation from the Asian economic firestorm or meltdown by running a budget surplus this financial year. Any junior economist knows that the real buffer against the Asian financial and economic crisis is a strong economic growth rate—not simply a budget surplus. A strong domestic economic growth rate of the kind that Labor had in its last four years of office, of around 4.5 to five per cent, would give Australia some latitude to absorb the shocks of the Asian economic meltdown. We could sustain a falling growth of one per cent. It would enable the economy to sustain and absorb that shock but keep growing jobs and reducing the unemployment rate. In its past two budgets the government engineered a lowering of Australia's growth rate, exposing the nation to an economic shock wave from Asia over which it has little control.

I stated earlier in my speech that this is a budget which does nothing for my electorate of Corio. It has not restored funding to the public hospital system which will assist in reducing waiting lists in the Geelong hospital. While the Treasurer arrogantly boasts a budget surplus, working families in Geelong continue to pay more for their child care. The budget has not restored funding to the Commonwealth dental health program, and many Geelong pensioners continue in pain on long waiting lists for treatment—and those waiting lists get longer every day.

This budget does nothing to assist the many long-term unemployed in Geelong, who have had their opportunity for another shot at the title in the workplace dashed with the slashing of labour market programs and a poor growth rate. It has done little to allay the fears of Geelong's older citizens who, in the twilight of their years, worry about increased nursing home fees and the prospect of selling their homes to gain admission to nursing homes to obtain proper care.

The budget does nothing for Geelong's migrant community, who have seen their local immigration office closed and resources to migrant programs slashed and not restored. It has done nothing for Geelong's tertiary students, who have faced higher HECS fees, reduced class sizes and reduced opportunities as a result of the actions of this government. Nor does the budget assist our young unemployed who have been denied access to proper training support as they seek to improve their skills and create opportunities for themselves.

This is a budget which sets the stage for the introduction of a GST, a measure that will turn every small business in Geelong into a tax collector for Peter Costello. And that is not a proposition that any of them warmly embrace. It is a budget from an incompetent government which has short-changed Geelong yet again.

In conclusion, let me say that Australia deserves better. It deserves better than a Prime Minister who displays weakness. It deserves better than a government that displays incompetence. It deserves better than a government that delivers only low growth rates. It deserves better than a government that falsely claims to have lowered the inflation rate. It deserves better than a government that is corrupt—with eight ministerial resignations and backbench defections—a government which has long forfeited its right to govern this proud and prosperous country. The sooner the Australian people cut the Howard-Costello cancer out of Australia, the better we will be. We see that Australia has great potential to grow and provide for its citizens, but it cannot do it with weak leadership, it cannot do it with corrupt government. And that is why we warmly embrace the prospect of a federal election so that, once and for all, we can cut out the Liberal-National Party cancer from the Australian body politic.

talk.start.para: —Two weeks ago, Peter Costello handed down the Howard government's third budget and delivered Australia's first budget surplus in almost a decade. The magnitude of this achievement cannot be overstated. When the coalition was elected to office in March 1996, the budget was $10.3 billion in deficit. Over the last five years of Labor's term in office, from 1991-92 to 1995-96, Labor had run deficits of $11.5 billion, $17 billion, $17.1 billion, $13.2 billion and $10.3 billion, deficits amounting in total to almost $70 billion.

speech.para: In less than three years, this government has turned the situation around completely. Today we are in surplus to the tune of $2.7 billion with increasing surpluses projected into the future. By the end of financial year 1998-99, we will have paid back $31 billion of Labor's debt. Taking into account the proposed sale of Telstra, Commonwealth general government net debt is expected to fall to around 1.5 per cent of GDP by 2000-01, which is a far cry from the almost 20 per cent of GDP which the coalition inherited in March 1996.

Of course, governments cannot control everything—sometimes I think it is just as well. Never has there been such a stark reminder of this fact as in the Asian economic meltdown. Governments do, however, have a responsibility to put their own affairs in order, to protect the country from risk and to lay the foundation for sustainable economic and employment growth. I believe the government has done this.

When the coalition came to office, its strategy was straightforward. The budget deficit had to be addressed to make a positive contribution to national savings, relieving pressure on the current account, inflation and interest rates; to reduce government debt and insulate Australia from adverse international economic shocks; and to give the government some scope for future policy flexibility.

Subsequent events in Asia—which were totally unexpected at the time the budget strategy was laid out—have highlighted the importance of our approach. We still do not know what the full impact on Australia will be of the events in Asia. What we do know is that the measures taken in the first two coalition budgets will have reduced this impact, and these have been further built upon by the third budget.

Moreover, the government's budget strategy has underpinned a number of fundamental economic positives. Inflation and interest rates are at their lowest levels in a generation. There are now more Australians in work than ever before. Unemployment, while still too high, has fallen to its lowest level since 1990. The OECD has predicted that economic growth in Australia over the coming year will be stronger than in any of the other major OECD economies. The achievements of the budget are quite clear and transparent.

What is rather more complex is the response of the opposition. As a humble backbencher, I listen to the speeches of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) reasonably intently. Actually, it is not a big ask because he tends to give interesting speeches. His reply to the budget was as interesting as any. In the limited time available to me, I want to focus on two of its elements: its dominant motif and his comments on Telstra.

The motif of the Leader of the Opposition is, I think, expressed by him right at the beginning of his speech when he says, `We all have our sustaining fantasies.' Perhaps we do, but what is certain is that the Leader of the Opposition must have an extremely rich fantasy life in order to declare that:
We need surpluses of the kind that Labor delivered four years in a row . . . surpluses built on jobs and growth.

When I heard that, I did not quite remember those years in the same glowing way. So I went back over the budget papers starting in 1990-91, the last year in which Labor ran a surplus. Labor's budget in 1990-91 predicted an $8 billion surplus, which was to be accompanied by economic growth and an increase in employment. It was supposed to produce, in the ringing phrase of the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, `the outcome the government was seeking delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession'.

Unfortunately, the last of the fabled Labor surpluses, surpluses which the Leader of the Opposition tells us were `built on jobs and growth', were actually built on the opposite; they were built on high unemployment and a savage recession in 1990-91. Unemployment rocketed. Employment, far from picking up, actually went into reverse. There were 200,000 fewer jobs at the end of 1990-91 than there had been at the beginning. Far from growing, the economy went negative. Australia went into recession. But there was still a surplus—it came in at $400 million.

The Australian people will not forget—even though the Labor Party is apparently desperately trying to—the last fabled year of Labor's surpluses. Paul Keating engraved it in their memories by coining that most brutal and unforgettable phrase `the recession Australia had to have'. We may criticise Paul, usually fairly, but you have to give it to him: he did have a way with words—`the banana republic', `the J-curve', `Placido Domingo', and `this is as good as it gets'.

What is sad about the sustaining fantasy of the Leader of the Opposition is not just that it transforms 1990-91—the year so clearly remembered by Australia as the year of the recession that we had to have—into a year in which there was a surplus built on jobs and growth; it also distorts the reality of the previous three years. Those years were based on an economic fraud which could not be sustained and which inevitably tumbled into recession. In fairness, since we are all politicians, you do not have to take my word on this. Let me quote fully what Paul Keating as Treasurer said in November 1990, after the economy that he had spoken of so glowingly just a few months beforehand had fallen in a heap:

This is a recession Australia had to have. The Government would not have inflicted this pain on itself or on the community unnecessarily. The unsustainability of spending in the economy over the past couple of years had to be slowed.

It is interesting that the concern about the pain inflicted on the government preceded the pain inflicted on the community. But, leaving that aside, the lesson of all this is that sustaining fantasies may have their place but they should not be taken out of the closet and presented as truth.

The other observation I would like to make about the reply by the Leader of the Opposition to the budget relates to the privatisation of Telstra. When the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) first announced that the government would move to sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, the Leader of the Opposition made this unequivocal declaration: `We will not be privatising the other two-thirds of Telstra; end of story.' Listening to his reply to the budget, however, I noted that the declaration by the Leader of the Opposition was not repeated in that speech. I heard reservations about the full privatisation of Telstra in the fashion proposed by the government, but what was absent was any statement of commitment that Labor would not sell off more of Telstra in one form or another.

I was a bit puzzled about this and I thought it might be an oversight, so I followed it up by reading his two subsequent speeches—the first to the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce on the Friday after the budget reply, and the second to the Victorian ALP's conference on Sunday. In both of these speeches he did raise criticisms of the government's decision to privatise Telstra. In neither of these speeches did he rule out the possibility that Labor would sell off more of Telstra.

There are two possible explanations for this. The first is that the Leader of the Opposition does not believe that he has the credibility to convince Australians that Labor will not sell more of Telstra, so he does not bring the issue to a point. If this is the case, he is entirely right; in government, the Leader of the Opposition was Labor's great privatiser, and the Australian people simply do not believe him on Telstra. They did not believe him or Labor at the last election; they will not believe him or Labor at the next election.

But there is an alternative explanation for the Leader of the Opposition's studied ambiguity. The explanation is that Labor is currently secretly considering selling more of Telstra in some fashion other than that proposed by the government. If that is the case, I think that the Leader of the Opposition should come straight out and tell Australians what Labor's true intentions are. Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe that this is an exceptionally good budget and I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —There has been a lot of discussion on the economic shortcomings of the budget from those on our side of the House and from others. I will not focus primarily on those. What I want to talk about is the fact that the budget—and, indeed, the image presented by the budget—totally fails to show any vision or leadership as to where the Australian nation is going, especially when we consider fundamental questions such as those concerning our national identity and those concerning questions of race and multiculturalism.

speech.para: I think it is pretty sad that the only international reference to Australia yesterday in the AAP wires, Reuters and so on read like this: `National government refuses to say sorry.' That was the image of Australia yesterday that was presented throughout the world. This is part of the overall picture of our nation that exists at the moment. Having recently returned from travels abroad, having had discussions in a number of countries, the leaders of every country to whom I spoke raised with me these issues: the question concerning the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson); the question of where multiculturalism is going in Australia; the question of whether racism is on the rise in Australia.

These are the issues which this government has totally failed to confront in its two years in office. And nothing in the budget and nothing in the pronouncements of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have done anything to help alleviate these continuing and deepening problems.

A few years ago, Australia was held up in terms of an image of a nation that was tolerant, multicultural and an example to the world. In the last two years, and especially in the last 12 months, we have had the politics of division based on attacks concerning race, culture and multiculturalism. Indeed, the failures of the government have now created an atmosphere in the media and in society in which one can become popular, sell books, appear on television in populist programs. Why? In order to pronounce racist views; in order to pronounce divisive views; in order to pronounce views against multiculturalism; and in order to pronounce views against particular sections of the Australian community.

You would think that in this context the coalition and the Liberal and National parties would have been alarmed and would have acted. And do you think the Prime Minister has acted in the face of all this? On the contrary, in the Queensland election coming up, we got the news today that all the candidates for the Liberal and National parties, with the exception of only one candidate, one person of Chinese background, are going to give preferences to Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party, completely contrary to the public request of the Leader of the Opposition and of the Labor Party that all major parties should put that party last on their how to vote tickets.

But what is even worse is that not only did they decide to do that but also they admit to actively seeking out representatives of Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party and seeking to do a deal with them on preference swaps. These are the same people who protest that they really do support multiculturalism, that they really do support a fair society, that they really are opposed to racism in our community. Imagine that—actually seeking out those officials and seeking to do a deal with them. You can imagine what would have happened in such a meeting, if it had taken place: `Ms Hanson, we are of course publicly opposed to everything you stand for, but we would love to have your preferences.'

This is a disgrace for this country. This has created fear in the ethnic communities of this country. That is what it has done—it has created fear. Go and talk to the Chinese community in Australia and see what they think about the Howard government now. The Prime Minister promised them before the election that all of his pronouncements in 1988 were to be forgotten and that he would stand up for their rights. Instead, he has run away in the face of the assault from the member for Oxley and her team.

This failure is compounded by many other actions, or lack of action, on the part of the government to show any backbone in relation to this amazing and terrifying threat to our society and to the unity of our country. There is the failure of the government to spend $5 million which it put aside two years ago in its budget for a campaign against racism. We hear from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) all sorts of excuses: `Oh well, this takes a long time and we've got to do test campaigns and we've got to do this and we've got to do that,' all of which could have been done within a matter of a couple of months. The reality is that this government has never been committed to that campaign, and it has not pursued that campaign. In the end, we had the offensive situation where, as part of this extremely long process of trying to consult people as to how to run the campaign, they had some agency ring up people and pose to them very offensive questions about race and racism. And the minister would not even apologise for that activity.

We have also had the virtual emasculation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The commission made a statement about what was happening, but it did not have any impact. Now there is legislation coming before this parliament which would effectively emasculate that commission and its activities, which are orientated towards ensuring that human rights are properly protected in this country, including human rights based on an opposition to racism and support for a multicultural Australia.

With the abolition of the Office of Multicultural Affairs, the promise from the government was that this was only a structural thing—that it was not something which was intended to reduce the level of programs of support for the ethnic communities. But, in actual practice, that is what happened—there has been a reduction in the support of those programs. Increasingly, we have fewer and fewer references to the philosophy and to the practice of multiculturalism. Meanwhile, we have an increasing level of attacks against multiculturalism in the mainstream media from all of the friends of this current government. And what do they do? They get up in the media and they strongly attack the essence of multiculturalism. They try to misdescribe it and to redefine it in some way which is contrary to its true meaning. Then they seek to attack ethnic leaders and specific migrant communities. They attack the question of Australia's role in its neighbourhood within the community of Asia. All those things are part of this process.

In Monday's Australian, there was an article by Mr Frank Devine, headed `Tailing the Tigers was a cow of a path'. Basically, if you look through the sophistication of the article, it really comes down to an attack on multiculturalism. For example, he says:
Official assertion of multiculturalism without the American coda of "from many, one", has alarmed rather than rallied Australians.

Where does he get the evidence for that? Lies! The fact is that all of the recent opinion polls show that more than 70 per cent of Australians support multiculturalism both as a philosophy and as a practice. But that has not deterred people like Mr Devine from claiming nonsense—that the Australian people do not support multiculturalism.

Do you think that if I wrote an article in response to Mr Devine it would be published in the Australian newspaper? Of course not. In the last few years, we have had article after article, and newspaper reports and television reports, all attacking multiculturalism. Recently we had attacks in Victoria on the only Cambodian born member of the state parliament, the only Turkish born member of the state parliament, the only Croatian born member of the state parliament and the only Vietnamese born member of the state parliament. All of these attacks were based on a very clear understanding: they were coming from people who were being organised by enemies of multiculturalism; they were organised in such a way as to bring discredit to those people. This is irrespective of the fact that we in this country have an official access and equity policy, and that we have heard ministers and others say, `We want to promote the participation of people of non-English speaking backgrounds in our parliaments and in our society.' And yet we have all these attacks in the media.

The responsibility can be sheeted back to the federal government and the leadership of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said, just before the election, that he had abandoned his previous views on multiculturalism, that he had abandoned his previous views on race and that he was in a position to say to the Australian people that he now believed in different things. The Australian had an editorial saying, `Forgive and forget, the Prime Minister has learned his lesson. When he becomes Prime Minister, he will be very good on these issues.' Well, he has been appalling on these issues—not only on the Aboriginal issues, so that his behaviour has been overwhelmingly condemned here and internationally, but also on the question of support for multiculturalism and on the question of a clear denunciation of Pauline Hanson, the One Nation Party and its supporters.

The Prime Minister himself said only a matter of a couple of weeks ago that the supporters of Pauline Hanson are no more racist than you and I. What is he talking about? Does he know who is behind Pauline Hanson and her party? Does he understand what is going on in this country in terms of the divisions being created by the One Nation Party and its supporters? Why will he not stand up and be counted in these matters?

We are facing a crisis situation in respect of these issues and, unless something is done, we will be in a situation where we will have gone from being a united multicultural country based on tolerance to a divided country based on prejudice, on race and on dividing those who come from European or British backgrounds from those who come from non-European backgrounds. Is that what we want for this country?

It is about time the Prime Minister made some clear, unequivocal statements on these issues. He should especially condemn the decision of the Queensland Liberal and National parties in relation to giving their preferences to Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to be able to speak on something that is not portfolio related, and I thank the Chief Government Whip most sincerely for one of these rare opportunities.

speech.para: I have listened with interest to the comments from both sides of the House today and yesterday. I think the clear message that would be received by the Australian people is that there is a huge divide between the coalition members and the members of the opposition. That clear divide is very much evidenced by the fact that we have one group of speakers, the opposition members, who are looking to the past, and another group of speakers, the coalition ranks, who are looking to the future.

When we go to an election at the end of this term, there is a very clear choice for the Australian people between a party that is looking back, that is still indulging itself in self-denial and acts of gross hypocrisy, and a government that is looking to the future.

If we look at what this country needs, we would have to say that we want a decent Australia. We want an Australia that cares for the vulnerable; we want an Australia that encourages and rewards initiative; we want an Australia that provides genuine opportunities for our school leavers. It is obvious that all the rhetoric I have heard from those opposite in the last 24 hours is a clear indication that they do not share this government's vision for the future.

If you listened to every single word said by those opposite, you would understand they have failed to acknowledge that this country has got to start addressing its future and the needs of those who will be running it in the generations to come. I am one of those people who happen to think this younger generation is smarter than we were and more ambitious than we were, and I think they are exceptionally well placed to lead this country into the next millennium. But we as a nation have to make sure that those who are now running this country leave it in a position where those opportunities can be maximised.

One of the most distressing things I have heard in the last seven days was a comment by one of the senators in the other place attacking the government for providing a system within which our young people who are still at school are able to start gaining industry experience. They are now able to get dual recognition to do part-time apprenticeships and part-time traineeships. We simply cannot let these young people lurch towards the end of their compulsory education without saying to them, `We have something at the end of this for you, and we are going to maximise your opportunities.'

The Labor Party put in place a system whereby 70 per cent of the funding for higher education or TAFE was going to 30 per cent of school leavers. That is simply not fair. It was a system that prejudiced those young people who wanted to make some other career choices, and this government is doing something about that. We recognise the fact that everyone should be given a fair go, not just those who are in a position to go on to TAFE or university.

What causes me the most concern is this constant self-denial about what the Labor Party did in government and about the fact that we had a former finance minister, now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), denying—until the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans), the shadow Treasurer, finally came clean about it—the state this nation was left in at the end of their term of government.

Some very clear messages were sent to the opposition by the Australian people in 1996. They wanted honesty from the ALP. They wanted proper financial management from the ALP. They wanted the ALP to stop pandering to sectional interests and to provide vision and hope for young people. The ALP has failed on that scorecard. Some two and a half years after the last election when the Australian people said, `This is what our expectations of the ALP are,' it has failed. It does not have the vision which this country requires.

I think a lot of people get tired of facts and figures—and they hear a lot of them in this place—but I want to repeat some facts and figures today that are the absolute essence of what this government has done to set this country up for the future. Low interest rates equal high hopes for families. Low interest rates also mean high hopes for small business—the engine room of this country, the great employer of this country, and the prospective even greater employer of this country—and low interest rates mean that we can provide them with opportunities to invest with confidence.

In terms of how the Labor Party has failed the Australian people in relation to the question of honesty, after 1993 the people were promised tax cuts—the l-a-w law tax cuts—and what happened? They lost the tax cuts and the former government actually dramatically increased that insidious form of taxation—wholesale sales tax.

In the time left to me, I want to talk about this budget and, indeed, the past budgets of this government and the positive effects that they have had on my electorate. A lot of people say that their electorate is a microcosm of Australia; I passionately believe that the federal seat of Ballarat actually is the microcosm of Australia. The effect of reduced interest rates on small business has been dramatic. The effect on families of low mortgage interest rates has been very dramatic. The provisional tax uplift factor for people paying provisional tax in my electorate has been quite dramatic.

There are other things in this budget for the people of the electorate of Ballarat. One is their passionate commitment to ensure that the environment we leave our children is an environment that we can be proud of. It is not about hugging trees; it is about realistic assistance for those who are best placed to provide the sort of environment we want to leave our children—our farmers. The tax rebate of 34c in the dollar, up to an annual limit of $10,000, for landcare works is positive assistance to the people who are able to deliver the sort of environment that we want to leave our children.

In terms of the money put into tourism, about $50 million has been provided to the ATC to build an Australian presence in new and emerging overseas markets. Some $8 million is provided for a regional tourism program which is going to assist my region greatly. The Ballarat electorate is a high tourism area. Ballan, Avoca, Daylesford, Stawell and Ballarat all have employment generated by tourism. This money is great news for the local tourism operators, and equally great news for the young people who want to enter that industry.

An additional $13 million has been allocated to increase the number of GPs in regional communities. People living in Melbourne and Sydney have no idea what it is like to have no access to a doctor. They take it for granted that they are there, but a lot of country people would desperately love that ready access to a doctor. This government has stopped talking and has started to do something about it. We had talk for 13 years and we have now got some action after just two years.

A large number of older Australians live in my electorate. The gold card extension has been very warmly welcomed by them. Some 14,000 people over 65 live in the Ballarat region and the free annual influenza vaccine for people aged over 65 is a great initiative. A significant number of the more than 24,000 people aged over 55 in the Ballarat electorate are self-funded retirees and the changes in relation to them are great news, especially on top of the raising of the tax free threshold in line with pensioners and the government's savings incentives. These are important initiatives.

This government has addressed the future. We want to leave a country for our young people that we can be proud of. I am a family man, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are aware. I have three children aged 12, 10 and eight. I want to leave a country for them that I can be proud of. I want to be able to say to them, `We have given you the opportunities to maximise your potential. We do not want you to be what you are not, but we want to be able to give you the opportunity to maximise your potential.' The best way of doing that is to have the economy of this country in a position where they can take advantage of those opportunities.

These budgets have been important budgets because they have not only provided specific relief and assistance to the Australian community but also set us up for the future. The wanton economic vandalism of the former government should never be inflicted upon the Australian people again. My very passionate view is that the Australian people realise that we had to make some tough decisions. They realise that the government has taken those tough decisions. At the end of the day, it is the Australian people now who will benefit but, of equal importance, it is the young people who will be leading this country in the next 20 years who will gain the most advantage.

talk.start.para: —This budget represents the scorecard on the Howard government's first two years in office. It does not have the government marked down as a winner. It points to the Howard government not being a good economic manager. The budget has delivered an economy which is underperforming. The cuts in the first Costello budget considerably slowed the economic growth that this nation was capable of.

speech.para: In Labor's last three years in office, the economy grew at an average of 4.3 per cent each year. The Howard government, in contrast, has presided over an average 3.2 per cent growth in its first two years. This year's budget forecast is for a decline in growth from 3.75 per cent to three per cent in 1998-99. The Howard government has, through its `good economic management', presided over a decline in growth of over one percentage point. Without growth, you simply cannot get unemployment down. That is why unemployment, under this government, under its policies, in particular the policies implemented in its first budget, is stuck at around eight per cent, with no improvement in sight.

The government also claims that, through its budgetary measures, it has `fireproofed' the economy from the effects of the Asian crisis. The truth is it has not because in 1998-99 the current account deficit is expected to rise to around $31 billion, over five per cent of GDP. This is almost double the level of 1996-97. The government has created an environment of falling growth in exports and falling growth in business investment and a budget whose forecasts simply cannot be believed. The analysts do not believe them, and it is little wonder against this background that the Australian dollar has fallen, and that is before the anticipated impact of the Asian economic crisis.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), of course, wants to shoot the messenger, blaming, in his words, the `poorly informed, economically illiterate money market dealers at the other end of the world' for pushing the dollar to a 12-year low. The truth is the level of the dollar reflects the vulnerability of a slower economy and a continuing deterioration in its current account. The analysts themselves join the growing list of people who cannot accept that the government's forecasts of slowing economic growth will result in increased employment opportunities. How can you create more jobs with less growth and less opportunity? Simply put, the figures cannot be believed.

Westpac has found that there are serious risks to the government's fiscal position from overambitious job growth forecasts. It has found that the cumulative negative impact of weaker employment growth on the underlying budget to 2001-02 is likely to be about $7.3 billion.
