Far from getting the economy into the black, the slower growth, according to them, could take us back into the red. Not only will the falling dollar put pressure on interest rates, but so too will the introduction of a GST. A GST raises prices and that, in turn, raises interest rates.

The Prime Minister claims that his government offers safety, stability and security. This is presumably because his polling is telling him that people are increasingly feeling less secure, less stable and less safe. But this polling reflects Australians' reaction to his government's policies. The government policy pursued on the waterfront, for example, is to conspire with companies to sack workers, to actively participate in the undermining of worker security, to back the sackings with legislation and to establish a pattern for other employers to adopt, further undermining job security in this country.

The government's policy on tax is not genuine reform but to up-end the existing system and replace it with a complex, unfair and regressive system. Despite telling the Australian people last year of the great adventure in tax that he wants them to share with him, he is simply adding now to their insecurity and fear by not telling them what he has in mind as to either the rate, the exemptions or the so-called compensation. This policy approach, or non-policy approach, is also contributing to a sense of unease, insecurity and, indeed, instability.

The Howard government's disastrous policies on nursing homes, child care and charging fees for universities, together with its inability to solve the public hospital crisis—in fact, the only thing it seemed capable of securing was a walkout of all state premiers, a rare act when your own team walks out on you—have not created safety, security and stability but created insecurity, instability and unease bordering on fear. Security and stability do not come from turning the system on its head.

In government, Labor was prepared to spend to achieve economic growth. It was done in a responsible manner. We as a government accepted the need for surpluses. Indeed, in our last period in government, Labor produced four surpluses. The truth is that there have been only five surpluses produced in the history of this nation since the war, and four of them have been under Labor. One is now promised by the coalition, about which doubt is already being expressed on the ability of the government to achieve the size mentioned or to sustain it in the longer term.

Labor is also committed to producing three more budget surpluses in our first three years back in office, provided the government's parameters stick, but our approach to achieving the surplus is different from that proposed by the government. We would produce the surpluses through higher and more sustained economic growth. We do not accept the need for surpluses at any cost. This government has gone blindly in pursuit of a surplus, cutting without consideration of the consequences.

In pursuit of a surplus, the cuts to industry programs have resulted in a decline in development, investment and net exports from that which could have prevailed. Recent figures show growth in business spending on research and development—which reached an all-time high of $4.3 billion in Labor's last year, having climbed every year for nine years—stopped dead for the first time in a decade, following the savage cuts that were perpetrated in the Howard government's first budget. It is these cuts that see business expressing its lack of confidence in the climate for research and development in this country and in innovation. It is driving our research offshore. It is stopping us continuing to become the clever country.

Having torn $2 billion out of research and development programs, the government has replaced them with much smaller research and development initiatives. The R&D start program, the government's grand plan, has been a total failure. The budget papers reveal that $54 million allocated to this program will not have been spent by the end of the financial year. A confidential report to the IR&D board reveals that the basis of this shortfall is that only $46 million of the 1997-98 allocation for large grants of $87 million was committed in the first 10 months.

Is this underspend any surprise? Not only has the program got only a fraction of the money available to it under the initiatives that we had in place, but the government has also restructured the program to the point of near incomprehensibility. Applicants for the program need to establish whether they should apply for R&D start, R&D start plus or R&D start premium. Businesses are drowning in paperwork for a small return. As a consequence, many are not bothering to apply and, more worrying still, many have stopped doing the research and development.

The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) meanwhile claims, against the evidence in his own budget papers, that R&D spending is `going up'. Indeed, he would like to spread the good news. Whilst he has effectively cut $50 million of research funds, he has also told his department to find $125,000 to buy him a gold sponsorship and a speaking spot at the forthcoming Australia Summit. What other good budgetary news will he tell his audience? That manufacturing support will continue to decline, from $542 million in 1997-98 to $405 million in 2001-02? That the shipbuilding bounty is set to end at the end of 1998-99? That $300,000 will be cut from the anti-dumping system at a time when manufacturers are facing unprecedented pressure from international competitors? That information technology support has collapsed, from $84 million to only $6 million over four years? That no legislation has yet been introduced into the parliament to secure the assistance packages for the TCF and automotive industries which the government was forced to adopt last year? That there has been no provision made in the budget to replace the $100 million import credit scheme for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry? Although the minister did claim in the parliament that funds had been set aside, what he did not say was that only $7 million a year had been set aside.

Is the minister also going to tell his audience that support for the pharmaceutical and food industries is falling from $175 million to $55 million? Or perhaps that AusIndustry will be virtually abolished, with support for enterprise development dropping from $38 million to just $1 million over four years? One thing he is unlikely to be talking about is his promise to create 200,000 new jobs in the manufacturing industry by the year 2000. Two years after making that promise, there are fewer manufacturing jobs in Australia, not more. The government is already 102,000 jobs short of its target.

When talking about broken promises, we need also to turn to regional development, and I use the term `development' lightly. This government came to power promising to commit to revitalising the social and economic infrastructure of regional Australia, yet in its first budget two years ago, it abolished the department. It wiped out the regional development program—$150 million of it—and the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) said, `There is no clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development.' Regional Australia was betrayed by this government.

Since that time, people in the bush have suffered greatly through the actions of this government. There have been cuts for surpluses—again, a consequence of pursuing a surplus regardless of the cost. Regional Australians were looking for a message of hope in this budget. They did not get it. Indeed, the betrayal has continued, because the Telstra sell-off legislation guarantees nothing but existing basic phone technology to the bush. There is no provision to ensure that Telstra delivers new communications technology throughout the country, not just to the areas where it is profitable to do it—the capital cities. The government is allowing 35 per cent of the shares to be foreign owned, and those foreign shareholders will not have any incentive to guarantee services to regional Australians. Regional communities will have their phone services frozen in time.

When Labor was in office, we took a conscious decision to stimulate growth. That is why we were able to create employment growth at twice the rate this government has done. We created 250,000 jobs per year; this government has not even reached that amount in two years. Its rate is half that of Labor. How can this government's forecast in the budget that employment growth is going to increase possibly be believed when the budget is forecasting lower economic growth?

The truth of it is that this pursuit of a surplus at any cost has held this nation back. It has made us underperform. As a consequence, unemployment is higher than it should have been. Had Labor's policies of growth and the Working Nation program been in place, unemployment today would not be 7.9 per cent, but six per cent. There would have been 150,000 extra jobs. That is the difference between using budget policy and spending to achieve growth. That is the difference you can achieve if you are prepared to recognise an active role for government—not this myopic view that all you have got to measure yourself by is the surplus, regardless of the consequences. The consequences are that this nation has suffered, the unemployed are suffering and there are many others in the community who are suffering as well.

talk.start.para: —The coalition government's 1998-99 budget has been an outstanding success, and the response from business and industry leaders, as well as from the broader community, has been very positive. In framing its final budget prior to the next election, the government had to focus on ensuring the delivery of its social and economic priorities, strengthening our national economy against the impact of events in the Asian region and dealing with the dismal economic and policy failure of the Keating-Beazley Labor years.

speech.para: The strong budget outcomes, which have not been the result of good luck, as suggested by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), have been delivered through hard, disciplined work, strong fiscal policy and good economic management by the coalition. I would like to thank the people of the Riverina for the sacrifices they have made to help put the nation back on track.

The coalition has had the courage to take the difficult decisions to turn around the disaster years of Labor and has every right to proudly boast of its achievement of a $13.2 billion turnaround of the budget after two years in office. What an achievement it has been, turning the $10.5 billion deficit inherited from 13 years of Labor mismanagement into a $2.7 billion surplus in two years. I was just listening to the speech by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), and I heard the wish list. No wonder the previous government got into trouble.

However, one of the most important aspects of the budget was health, which is arguably the greatest area of concern throughout the broader community. Despite the problems that currently beset the health system, I think we could all agree that Australia has one of the best systems in the world. But, like most other countries, Australia's hospitals are facing increased stress and strain as a result of the ageing population, the cost of new technology and the sharp decline in private health insurance over the past decade.

There is no doubt that the exodus from private health insurance, under Labor, has had a dramatic and deleterious impact on our public hospital system. Labor were determined, for philosophical reasons, to destroy the private health sector, and they nearly succeeded. When they took office 14 years ago, 65 per cent of Australians had private health cover, but that figure was halved to around one-third of Australians now with private health cover. The effect of this exodus has been felt heavily on waiting lists for elective surgery, with only 600 public hospitals to serve 19 million Australians. The challenges that confront our health system can be met only by the Commonwealth and the states and territories working together in partnership for a strong public health system supported by a strong and viable private health system.

The Commonwealth pays for almost half of the costs of running public hospitals in Australia, and its total contribution under the next five-year Medicare agreement is $30.2 billion. This represents a real increase of 14.9 per cent in funding to the states. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would agree, $30.2 billion is quite a substantial amount of money.

In making that enormous contribution to health, the Commonwealth has every right to expect the states and territories to play their part and deliver value for the dollars they receive. The Commonwealth also has every right to expect the states, which are responsible for the administration and delivery of health services, to focus on efficient and quality patient outcomes, coordinated care and effective disease management.

Most Australians now regard free public hospital care as a basic right, but because of the huge costs involved all governments know that delivering this right is a budgetary impossibility. Health costs more every year because people live longer—the average life expectancy in Australia has risen by four months per year over the past two decades, and by the year 2050 the number of people aged 65 and over is projected to be nearly a quarter of the total population—because of the cost of high-tech medicine and surgical procedures (for example, hip replacements are now a routine procedure but at an estimated cost of around $14,000); because of the high rate of hospital admissions—Australia has the highest rate of admissions among the OECD countries for which data is available—and because medical litigation is running rampant and the medical indemnity has soared accordingly.

The states must accept responsibility for their own health services and the shortcomings and criticisms. In the state of New South Wales, the system is in crisis. There is ample evidence of this in my electorate of Riverina, and no doubt the situation is the same in many other rural and regional areas of the state. For example, the delivery of obstetric and gynaecology services in the Riverina, even in large centres like Wagga Wagga, is in crisis, and there are many reports which suggest there is a crisis in obstetric care right across non-metropolitan Australia.

This is highlighted by the fact that two years ago in Wagga Wagga, the largest inland city in New South Wales, we had six gynaecologists, with five actively doing obstetrics and providing an on-call rotation at the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital. In the last four months that number has shrunk to only three obstetricians and gynaecologists, and there is a real prospect of this number falling to two by the end of this year. The sad fact is that these three remaining obstetricians and gynaecologists in Wagga Wagga represent the only remaining specialists in the whole of the Greater Murray Health Service, which takes in the whole of southern New South Wales.

From an individual lifestyle point of view, this crisis situation is unsustainable and, without a fundamental change of conditions, on-site obstetric services will collapse in the region. The wider implications of this occurring are quite enormous, and it is a tragedy that specific attempts by the Wagga Wagga doctors to raise the issue have been effectively ignored. A reason common for this decline in numbers is the decreased viability of obstetric practice, and this situation is going to worsen with declining private health insurance, low Medicare benefits rates and seriously rising medical indemnity insurance premiums—the latter being a factor not officially recognised.

On the question of medical indemnity insurance, the premiums are rising alarmingly. In New South Wales alone, there was an 18 per cent increase in 1997 and another 15 per cent increase in 1998, bringing the current premium to $38,000. This is an enormous cost impost on medical practitioners and forms a large slice of the estimated $180,000 annual cost of just staying in practice.

Let us look at what is happening in the thriving city of Griffith within the Riverina. To provide a proper service in the Riverina, the core staffing at the Griffith Base Hospital should include general physicians, an obstetrician/gynaecologist, a consultant anaesthetist, general surgeons, paediatricians, a director of accident and emergency services, ancillary staff including a physiotherapist and an occupational therapist, and a casualty director.

What do we have? I think we are very short on general physicians. We do not have an obstetrician/gynaecologist or a consultant anaesthetist. We have some good general surgeons, but very few. We have been promised a paediatrician. We have an acting director of accident and emergency, and we have one physiotherapist at the hospital. That is simply not good enough in a thriving community like Griffith.

All political parties and interested health administrators agree there is an over-concentration of medical services in capital cities compared with regional areas. The federal government has put in many innovative programs which I am sure will have an impact in the medium to long term. Part of the solution in my electorate would be for support for and a greater focus on registrar training schemes from teaching hospitals in both Sydney and Canberra. Over the years, the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital has played a key ongoing role in these training programs, and at the same time the University of New South Wales Medical School has sent medical students to Wagga Wagga for clinical experience in obstetrics and gynaecology.

The University of New South Wales also has quite advanced plans to set up a formal section of the medical school in Wagga Wagga to provide wider medical student exposure to high quality medicine, in its broadest sense, and that is not being practised in a capital city. This cannot happen soon enough. Another service that we are trying to obtain in the Wagga Wagga region for the people of the Riverina and the wider community is a radiotherapy unit as part of an oncology unit. This will save people, particularly women, from having to go to Canberra, Melbourne or Sydney for those services.

I congratulate the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) on his determined efforts to stem the bleeding in the private health sector and on his role in encouraging private hospitals and medical practitioners to work with the funds to achieve better cost control, establish single billing systems and eliminate the gap payment.

In rural Australia, cities like Griffith and Wagga Wagga, just to name two that I know well, find the reduction in health services accelerating at a tremendous rate. This not only affects the cities themselves but also affects the surrounding areas. In Griffith in particular we have a skilled labour shortage in many areas, not only in the health sector. But the irony of the situation is that people wishing to move to fill those vacant positions check to see what health services are available. I know that when I was a young man with a family, I used to do the same thing. As I said, if there is any doubt about health services in an area, people, particularly people with children, will simply not move to those areas. It is the case, therefore, that if cities like Wagga Wagga and Griffith are to reach their full potential, a sound health system must be in place.

I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on their budget. Now that we have become an economically responsible country, I look forward to improvement in many areas, but particularly in the provision of health services in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —This is a budget that continues the decline in national investment in education. This is a budget that continues this government's regressive policies with regard to education, research and training in Australia. Indeed, it is interesting to note the full extent of the education cuts as outlined in the budget papers themselves. There is a graph at page 437 of Budget Paper No. 1 that obviously the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, was not allowed to doctor; a graph from which you can draw the following figures. When one extrapolates figures from that graph, they show a six per cent fall in total education expenditure between 1996-97 and 2001-02. They show a massive 20.6 per cent fall in higher education expenditure over the same period. They show a 3.2 per cent fall in expenditure on vocational education and training. They show a 1.3 per cent fall in schools expenditure between 1998-99 and 2001-02. They also show a 5.9 per cent decline in expenditure on student assistance between 1995-96 and 1997-98—and that is the last measurement that will be given before those assistance provisions move to the social security portfolio.

speech.para: The decline in schools funding is particularly significant, given that enrolments are expected to be around 70,000 higher in 2000 than in 1996. Overall, schools are losing 1.3 per cent of their expenditure out of Canberra even though they are enrolling some 70,000 more students through the relevant period. These figures show that Dr Kemp's claims about education expenditure are totally false. For example, the claim of a 3.8 per cent increase in schools funding in 1998-99 is absolutely incorrect. Dr Kemp is a master of doctoring the figures, using absolute numbers when only real funding amounts can be applied as a relevant measure.

We hear a great deal from the government about its supposed concern for vocational education yet, with 35,000 people missing out on a TAFE place last year, Commonwealth expenditure will decrease by almost eight per cent between 1997-98 and 2001-02. Dr Kemp, on every count, whether he is talking about this government's funding of universities, vocational education or schools, is presenting a false figure. The real figures are provided in the detail of the budget papers. I would urge all educationalists, teachers and parents around Australia to refer to that chart at page 437. They will find the truth in the associated figures; the truth of this government's massive cutbacks in our greatest national asset—the skills and insights of our people.

In the time available to me today I want to talk about Labor's repair and reform job when it comes to education policy—briefly, because I only have time to refer to two government measures that Labor will abolish when it wins the next election. The first of these is the government's divisive and regressive enrolment benchmark adjustment. This is a policy which now has a rather unique status in Australian politics. It takes a particularly bad piece of public policy to unite the government and non-government school sectors in this country, yet that is what Dr Kemp and this government have achieved through their divisive enrolment benchmark adjustment scheme. Both sectors want the EBA abolished.

This is a scheme that will take $12 million away from government schools around Australia this year, even though those same schools are enrolling 8,500 extra students. What a regressive policy—to take away $12 million in schools funding from schools that are increasing their enrolments around the country by almost 9,000 students. But the very worst aspect of this policy, for so little financial gain in the Commonwealth budget, is that it has reopened the oldest and most divisive debate in the history of schools policy in Australia. It has reopened the state aid debate. This is the old point of division between school administrators and supporters in the government and non-government sectors.

This is a divisive debate for so little gain. That is why people from the non-government sector are joining with their colleagues in government schools and saying this is a policy that should be abolished. It should be abolished because it takes money away from schools that are actually enrolling more students. Even more importantly, it is a policy that should be abolished because it has set back the education debate in this country by decades, with Dr Kemp taking us back to the 1960s and the divisive debate about state aid.

Labor of course has one principle to replace this policy with, and that is the principle that schools should be funded according to need and growth. I do not particularly care whether it is a school in the government or the non-government sector. If the school is enrolling more students and it can demonstrate need in educational resources and parental capacity to assist, then it deserves more money from the Commonwealth budget. They are the principles that this parliament should be using to fund schools around Australia, the simple principles of need and growth in enrolments—and Labor does not make any particular distinction between government and non-government schools for that purpose. If it is a school in need, we will fund it more. If it is a school that is enrolling more students, we will fund it more substantially than this government does. That is the simple principle that Labor will be applying in the forthcoming campaign on schools policy.

The second aspect of repair and reform is another job of abolition—Labor's task in abolishing the regressive up-front undergraduate fees that this government has introduced for university students. It is plain unfair to have a policy for universities that establishes one rule of entry for wealthy families that can afford to pay the up-front fee and a totally different rule of entry for families that cannot afford fees that go up towards $30,000 per annum. There should not be one rule for the rich and one for the not so rich when we talk about university entry. We should be expanding the access that young Australians have to a higher education instead of embarking on this government's policy of taking 21,000 student places off the forward estimates. So Labor will abolish the up-front fees not only because they are unfair but because they have been impractical and unsuccessful in their implementation.

We had Dr Kemp, the minister, in this very parliament last November promising the parliament and the people that 90,000 new places could be generated by this policy of up-front fees. How many have been created? There have been 800 places created—less than one per cent of the minister's promise. If he were a student sitting for an exam with a success rate of less than one per cent, he would be tossed out of the institution as an absolutely gross failure. This is a policy that has failed because it is unfair. It is also a policy that has failed because its implementation has been rejected hand over fist around Australia's universities.

I turn to an issue closer to home for me as the member for Werriwa. I want to express my dissatisfaction that one of the very few institutions that is embarking on this fees policy is the University of Western Sydney, Macarthur. We have had an attempt by the Deputy Vice-Chancellor, David Barr, to introduce up-front fees. This is the wrong philosophy for the University of Western Sydney. It is an elitist attempt to take the University of Western Sydney away from its core charter, which is about access and equity in the working-class suburbs of the Greater West. I would urge David Barr, the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of that institution in and near my electorate, to reconsider.

The problem with the up-front fees—a problem particularly acute in western Sydney—is that they add to the perception that higher education is now outside the finances of a working family. The changes to HECS have deterred a whole generation of young students from wanting to go on to higher education. The half billion dollar cuts to Austudy have had a damaging impact on the affordability of a university education. So the last thing—the dumbest thing—that any institution can do when it wants to create equity and access is add to that perception by talking about the introduction of up-front undergraduate fees for domestic students.

Indeed, the University of Western Sydney conducted an extensive survey—it spent its own money—in 1997 to survey school leavers. This showed that, because of this perception of a lack of affordability, the HECS changes, the Austudy changes and the up-front fees, between 10 and 20 per cent of school leavers are being deterred from going on to a university education. They think, as do their parents, that it is just too expensive for them. They cannot afford the HECS debt at an early age at a low threshold, they are worried about the Austudy changes, while the prospect of up-front fees just scares them witless. That is why the University of Western Sydney's own survey showed that between 10 and 20 per cent of school leavers, particularly from low income backgrounds, are turning their backs on a university education. They are effectively turning their backs on the best chance they had, prior to the Howard government, of holding down a good education and thereby a good job and a good working career.

Why would a vice-chancellor at the UWS Macarthur campus then want to rub salt into the wound, want to aggravate the inequity and want to make it much worse by moving down the path of up-front fees? I am heartened, indeed thankful, that the new vice-chancellor at the University of Western Sydney—Vice-Chancellor Reid—has publicly opposed the Macarthur recommendation. She has rebuked David Barr's foolhardy scheme, and I wish more power to her arm in making sure that when it goes to the central decision making body at the University of Western Sydney her view prevails, because she knows that this is not good for the central mission of UWS.

Indeed, it makes me rethink the whole question of educational access and opportunity in a working-class area. It is true that in the mid-1980s the Labor government did one of the great things for western Sydney by building and funding that university. But I suppose it is one thing to build an institution with the potential for educational access and opportunity; it can be a different thing in the management of the institution for that potential to be realised. It is a good thing to build it, but we also need to follow through and make sure that the management philosophy is not elitist. We need to make sure that the management practices of promoting policies are consistent with the university's core goals for equal access and opportunity.

I bring to the attention of the House some of the figures that have been presented in a recent edition of People and Place published by Monash University in Melbourne. They have produced statistics highlighting the percentage of commencing undergraduate students drawn from low socioeconomic areas in 1996. The low socioeconomic areas are those that relate to the lowest 25 per cent according to postcode. The figures are interesting. The Victoria University of Technology draws 31.4 per cent of its students from the bottom 25 per cent group of socioeconomic status areas—a great equity achievement; overachieving in terms of equity goals. In the western suburbs of Melbourne, going through VUT, a higher proportion of students from those lower socioeconomic backgrounds are going through the university than at the upper level of income groups. The VUT is to be congratulated on having such a high penetration—31 per cent of its students coming from the bottom 25 per cent on the socioeconomic ladder.

Let us look at some of the institutions otherwise known as the great eight—some of the oldest and most reputable universities around Australia. The proportion of students coming out of the bottom quarter of suburbs reveal the following results: University of Queensland, 14.5 per cent; University of Melbourne, 14.3 per cent; University of Adelaide, 13.1 per cent; University of Western Australia, 11.6 per cent; and Monash University itself, 11.2 per cent. Then we come down to the University of Western Sydney, which has an equity and access charter, and just 10.7 per cent of its students are coming out of the bottom 25 per cent of socioeconomic areas in the greater western Sydney region—a third of what is being achieved at the comparable institution serving the western suburbs of Melbourne, the Victoria University of Technology. That sort of performance by the University of Western Sydney needs to be enhanced. It needs to be performing up near the standards of VUT to fulfil the basic charter of access and opportunity out of working-class areas—students, no matter their family background, having an equal opportunity to go through to a higher education.

I would urge people such as David Barr at the Macarthur campus of UWS to learn from the experience of the Victoria University of Technology—learn how they have moved from passive management systems to a more active approach, of reaching out into communities to let them know that a university education is within their life horizons, within their educational capacity. The policies of VUT reflect a guaranteed place, the student compact and the guaranteed pathways. What VUT can say to each and every student coming out of the western suburbs of Melbourne is this: `Even if you have not done as well as you had hoped at school leaving, we can guarantee you a path that will take you through to your higher education goal.' They can do that. VUT can do it because they are a dual sector institution. They have both university and TAFE sectors working in unison, so they can take someone who wants to be an accountant with a higher education qualification, start them out with a TAFE certificate and move them through the various stages—a guaranteed place and a guaranteed pathway because they have the breadth of a dual sector institution to achieve those particular equity goals.

I have had cause to suggest that this same model might be relevant for western Sydney. We should not leave the dual sector model as solely a Victorian phenomenon. We need a national policy statement about the dual sector model for post-secondary education in Australia. Let us not just leave these efficiency and equity advantages to the Victorians. I have suggested that this may be a useful reform—a useful way of considering the means by which the University of Western Sydney can achieve greater and improved equity goals.

Who was the first person to jump into print condemning the possibilities of this particular reform? David Barr from the University of Western Sydney, Macarthur. He is wrong on the up-front fees and he is ignorant indeed to ignore the equity possibilities that come out of consideration of a dual sector model for the University of Western Sydney.

talk.start.para: —There we have it: the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has now confirmed the direction of debt and deficit we will see for our next Labor government. Australia will go back down the path of inflation and rising interest rates, and I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is not the direction in which Australia should be going into the next millennium.

speech.para: On the issue of the abolition of up-front fees, I do not know what the problem is. This year there has been 19,000 extra people going into tertiary education at universities in this country, and I do not understand the claim of the member for Werriwa that somehow the up-front fees are a disincentive. HECS is the cheapest loan a young person will ever get in their life.

One of the notable achievements of the Howard coalition budget has been perhaps one of the least talked about. The shielding of Defence from budget cuts at a time when we were faced with the task of turning around Labor's $10 billion budget deficit has been a significant achievement. Defence, under Labor, was always a soft target for budget cuts. When the coalition secured office following the March 1996 election and found the cupboard bare—in fact $10,000 million in the red—I think it is fair to say that there was more than a little resentment at the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) took a stand on defence and said that there would be no more cuts. There was resentment from many at the decision—but not from Townsville and my electorate of Herbert. Townsville has a long and close association with the Australian Defence Force. Indeed, it is fair to say that Townsville is as much a part of the ADF as the ADF is a part of Townsville, as anyone who has spent any time in our little piece of paradise will certainly testify.

Stability in the funding base for Defence is vital. It allows forward planning to be undertaken with certainty and security, and I am proud to have been part of the Howard coalition government which has provided Defence with such a solid and stable funding base for the first time in many years. This does not mean there has not been change within Defence. There has been tremendous change, which at times has been difficult to manage, but Defence are working through that change and, at the end of the day, they will be the stronger for it.

The 1998-99 budget further cemented Townsville's place within the Australian Defence Force system. We are the sharp end of the ADF. Over the next financial year there will be capital upgrades to the defence facilities in Townsville valued at more than $19 million. That $19 million is a small part of the major $275 million capital works program that is proposed in the years ahead in Townsville. The figure of $10 million has been allocated this financial year for work to begin on the second stage of the redevelopment of Lavarack Barracks, home of the ADF's Ready Deployment Force; $2 million has also been committed to the first stage of a $70 million upgrade of RAAF Garbutt.

I want the House to understand that I am determined that the government is going to proceed with these capital upgrades. I intend to be at the doors of the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) as many days as it needs to make sure that this money is provided on a continuing basis, to make sure that the Public Works Committee approves this for Townsville and to make sure that this very much needed work is in fact secured for the ADF bases in Townsville.

Other major capital works programs at Townsville include $6.4 million towards continuing upgrades of facilities at the army's 5 Aviation Regiment, which primarily aim to improve the service life of the Black Hawk helicopters. Almost half a million dollars has been allocated to continue the construction of the facilities for 10 FSB and a further $1.4 million will be spent this financial year in the army's high range field training area at 10 FSB. For the Australian Defence Force as a whole and for the individual army and RAAF personnel stationed in Townsville in particular, these upgrades are vital. I intend to see that they are delivered.

As I said earlier, the ADF is as much a part of Townsville as Townsville is a part of the ADF. In that respect, Townsville and the neighbouring city of Thuringowa also stand to benefit enormously from these funding commitments. Certainly the business community—contractors, builders, electricians and so on—will benefit directly from the capital upgrade project, but other small businesses will also benefit from the flow of that money back into the local economy.

I know that the Liberal Party candidate for the Queensland seat of Thuringowa, Mr David Moore, is a big supporter of the ADF. His commitment to the ADF, as a recent serving officer with the ADF's 4 Field Regiment Ready Deployment Force in Townsville, is matched only by his commitment to his family and his desire to get a better deal for the local community of Thuringowa as their state representative. He has indicated to me on a number of occasions the importance of providing the ADF with secure and certain funding. Indeed, I share with Mr Moore a desire to see in the near future an increase in spending on our defence forces.

Governments make many different decisions each day, but only rarely are any identifiable as landmark decisions of major national significance. Last week the Queensland coalition government and federal government indicated their strong support for the establishment of a medical school for North Queensland to be based primarily in Townsville. The establishment of a Townsville based medical school for North Queensland will be an event of major national significance. While the announced support for a North Queensland medical school was not part of the budget—it is still too early for that—I wish to make some comments regarding it.

The Commonwealth now needs to commit the extra capital funding that will be required to make sure that this project proceeds. The state government has committed $10 million. The federal government needs to commit an additional like amount. I want to put the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) on notice that I do not intend to rest until that money is secured to ensure that James Cook University gets its medical school. If I have to be sitting outside their door every day while I am in Canberra, I will do it. I want to make sure that this money is delivered, and I am confident that the government will support me in this major new national project. I cannot think of another decision that will have a more lasting and positive impact on the health and welfare of all rural and regional Queenslanders than a decision to establish a medical school specialising in tropical and rural medicine and indigenous health.

With the establishment of a medical school in North Queensland, medical students for the first time will be able to be taught and trained in regional centres like Townsville, Cairns, Mackay and Mount Isa. This is significant because students from regional centres currently must leave home and travel to Brisbane and other southern universities in order to pursue a medical career. Once there, few incentives exist for those students to come back home or set up shop in other regional centres. A North Queensland medical school will dramatically improve our ability to attract and hold more doctors in regional towns and communities.

Indeed, the indigenous component is very exciting. The university intends to discard the current entry requirements for medical schools and look at the ability of indigenous students to successfully complete a course, not necessarily at the actual marks that they had in their senior year. That is very exciting because it will mean that we can get indigenous doctors into North Queensland, and that can only benefit the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population in our area.

James Cook University's Professor Ian Wronski, a central figure behind the push for a medical school in Townsville, firmly believes that establishing a medical school in the north will, in time, rate alongside the formation in Australia of the National Health and Medical Research Council after the Second World War in terms of historical importance. The NHMRC changed the face of medical research in Australia. Similarly, a North Queensland medical school may well revolutionise the delivery of health and medical services throughout regional Australia.

While securing a medical school is a big win for Townsville and James Cook University, it is a much bigger win for the tens of thousands of people who live outside Brisbane and the south-east metropolitan corner of Queensland. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) was not overstating the critical nature of the matter in any way when he once said that securing a medical school for the north was a matter of life and death. North Queensland makes up about 45 per cent of the state's total area and 17 per cent of our population, but it is home to only about nine per cent of our registered medical practitioners. According to Professor Wronski, this ratio has created enormous problems in the Queensland medical work force community. Try making a quick trip to the nearest medical centre or local GP in regional centres like Charleville or Cloncurry and compare that with inner-city Brisbane or Sydney and you are really comparing apples with oranges. They are poles apart, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) will testify.

A recent Queensland Council for Rural Medicine study found that 70 per cent of rural GPs work more than 41 hours a week. Of those, 15 per cent work in excess of 60 hours a week. Many of our rural doctors are literally working themselves into the ground, and it is a problem which is starting to affect Townsville. Only two months ago local medical centres started to shut their doors and reduce their hours of service because of the trouble they were having in finding locums and relief doctors. In the past these problems have been addressed by such means as importing foreign doctors—a solution which is short term at best. Professor Wronski said that Queensland imported some 350 overseas trained doctors last year alone. He said that the problem of accessing doctors and medical services in rural and regional Queensland demands practical, long-term solutions. A Townsville based, North Queensland medical school is such a solution.

I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his personal commitment to date for this project. However, I would like to say that I will continue my representations to both the Prime Minister and the health minister up until the day the school officially opens its doors, because I am determined that Townsville, and James Cook University, is going to have its own medical school.

This has been a budget of achievement for the coalition in Australia. As the Treasurer said in his budget speech, `We are back in the black. We are back on track.' Australia faces many challenges over the coming months and years. The economic instability that has crippled many of our neighbouring countries demonstrated the importance of this government's decision to bring our economy back into surplus for the first time in some years.

The regional military instability we are currently witnessing in the Asia-Pacific, with the actions of the government of India testing nuclear devices, playing a game of one-upmanship with Pakistan, demonstrates the importance of the Prime Minister's decision back in 1996 not to cut our defence spending any further.
I am pleased to support the budget. It has been extremely well received throughout Australia. I would hope that the coalition will be able to deliver similar budgets for many years to come.

talk.start.para: —One of the glaring aspects of this year's budget was again the lack of mention of anything to do with positive measures for the unemployed. It is very much a budget that ignores the plight of the unemployed. In his treatise The good society: the human agenda , John Kenneth Galbraith had this to say:

speech.para: There is no serious doubt as to the economic basis of the good society. As sufficiently noted, there must be employment opportunity for all willing members. This means, with a growing population and greater aspiration, a steady expansion of the economy and therewith a steady and reliable increase in the number of workers employed.

But what do we see in the associated papers of this budget? We see unemployment staying at around eight per cent. We see estimates of growth of around three per cent. We can be critical of economists not agreeing about many things, but one thing that I have learnt is that most economists agree that without an economic growth operator of at least four per cent there will be no expansion of employment. This is what this budget fails to deliver.

This mundane budget claims, as its centrepiece, a budget surplus of $2.7 billion. Australians are asking themselves, and quite rightly, at what terrible cost to this country the budget surplus has come. It is, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), built on the hundreds of deficits in people's everyday lives. The pain that this surplus is built on is something that members are seeing every day in the communities that they represent. There are thousands of examples of how this budget surplus has been achieved at the expense of ordinary Australians and particularly at the expense of people living in electorates such as the one I represent.

talk.start.para: —And very well, if I might say so.

—I thank the honourable member for Denison. The most obvious victims of this third Howard-Costello budget are the unemployed. As is so often the case with this government, the unemployed are thrown on the scrap heap. Just as in the previous two budgets, there is nothing in this one to give them any hope. Indeed, it is exactly the opposite. The budget forecasts that unemployment will remain around eight per cent for the next 12 months. The budget does nothing to reverse the savage cuts to labour market programs undertaken in the first budget. The amount of $1.8 billion was ripped from programs that gave the unemployed hope, and in this budget there is nothing to replace that. This budget is confirmation that the government has given up on solutions for the job crisis and has once and for all turned its back on unemployed Australians.

speech.para: My office deals with cases every day that demonstrate the suffering that has been caused in reaching the budget surplus. These people's stories are the stories behind Treasurer Costello's budget surplus. Since the start of the Job Network in May, there has been a great deal of concern about its operation and its failure to provide the free universal service that the Commonwealth Employment Service had provided Australians for over 50 years. One constituent contacted my office last week to share with us the story of her treatment at the hands of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs' Job Network.

This woman is married and had decided to return to the work force. She used the touch screens at Centrelink and found an appropriate vacancy. The information from the entry advised her to contact Drake Employment. She contacted Drake. Drake told her that she was well suited to the vacancy and was in fact one of the best applicants they had heard from. They then asked her for a Job Network number. She replied that she did not have one and was told to contact Centrelink. Without the Job Network number Drake would be unlikely to give her the job. Without a Job Network number the government would not pay Drake for filling the vacancy. Centrelink advised her that she could not register because she was married. It was this aspect, of all the advice she received, that enraged and angered my constituent the most and prompted her to contact my office.

Her experience leads to the question of whether the Job Network is really about putting people who want to work into work or whether it is a cynical exercise to bodgie the unemployment figures by excluding certain categories of people from the labour market. Like me, my constituent is now convinced of the latter. When the government talks of the $2.7 billion surplus, that is cold comfort to this particular constituent. She sees only how the Howard government's Job Network disregards her contribution to the labour market as a married woman.

In a further example of the callousness of this government, my office was contacted by a pensioner whose daughter had had to defer her university studies for medical reasons. I stress to the House that this constituent's daughter did not choose to defer her course; she had to. She did so because she was ill and she has medical documentation to confirm this. Centrelink advised her that the 13-week waiting period between coming off Austudy and going onto sickness benefit would apply in her case because she had a relatively small amount of money in her bank account, an amount her father had given her following his work payout. Even under the Howard government, this seemed quite harsh to my office, which then contacted Centrelink. This young woman did, after all, defer her studies due to health reasons and, even with that small amount of money in her bank account, was eligible for Austudy.

Centrelink confirmed that what had happened was indeed the case. Had she had no money in the bank Centrelink could have waived the 13-week waiting period because her father was a pensioner. However, Centrelink said that, because she had an amount that was more than one sickness allowance payment in her bank account, the 13-week waiting period applied. So, even if the amount were $1 over one sickness allow ance payment, she would have to wait 13 weeks. I still hope that the minister can tell me that this is not correct and that my office has been given incorrect information. However, sadly, under this government, I and my office have become used to hearing such stories.

The government's crude attempts in this budget to gloss over the savage cuts to health in its previous two budgets fool no-one. They particularly do not fool a constituent who approached me in March. This constituent had a mastectomy in October and went back to hospital in December to be told that a prothesis would be fitted in February. She contacted the hospital in March when this had not occurred only to be told that she would have to wait another three to six months because the hospital had insufficient funds available. This comes at a time when the Northern Hospital in Epping in my electorate has been told that it will have to find savings of six per cent in the next financial year because of the Howard government's inadequate Medicare agreement offer to Victoria. I remind the House that this hospital opened only in February this year.

These three examples show the pain that the zealous striving for budget surpluses at all costs inflicts on the community. They are only three examples, but I would bet that for every $1 million of the Treasurer's budget surplus there would be, at the very least, 1,000 such stories.

Another way that the government has made life far less comfortable for ordinary Australians is by ripping almost $1 billion out of child care. Working parents face decisions about the length of time that children can spend in child care, the length of time that they can work or even if they can work at all. Recently I surveyed child care providers in my electorate to determine what the effect of the cuts had been. Half the responding centres had increased their fees and had done so by more than $10 per week. One centre had increased fees by $25 per child per week. Furthermore, another 60 per cent of centres intend to increase their fees again in the next 12 months by figures ranging from $4 to $10 per child per week. One particularly disturb ing trend in the data is that 70 per cent of the responding centres have decreased their staff in the last year and a half and 60 per cent anticipate further staff reductions over the next year.

One feature that unites all centres is that 100 per cent report adverse comments about the new arrangements from parents using the centres. Some of the general comments that providers gave in their survey replies are very revealing. They stated:
There is no incentive for community to be involved because there is no help for families, only costly service.
I would like to see more support for struggling families who choose to work but end up paying the majority of the second wage in child care fees.
There is not time to help families if they have other worries or problems.
Another said:

Co-ordinator becomes more of a policing person—check on all extra administration, children's hours of attendance, asking parents every day for extra proof of their situation, check whether they are looking for work, study etc.
Perhaps the comment that sums up people's overall feeling is the following:

The senseless policy of the current government with respect to families of Australia and thus working mothers will lead people to vote for a caring alternative government who can come up with a better child care system or the same one as what was in place before these cost cutting Costellos and Howards ruined the whole system.

That is a view that I share wholeheartedly. I also note that in Monday's Australian there was an article quoting top Australian fashion designer Collette Dinnigan as saying that a GST would be bad for small business. If anyone should know, it would surely be a successful, internationally renowned person like Ms Dinnigan, who has been asked by the New South Wales government to chair the New South Wales Small Business Development Corporation. Ms Dinnigan says that small business already has more than enough paperwork and red tape to deal with. She recognises, quite accurately, that the government's GST proposal would turn every small business in the country into an arm of the Australian Taxation Office.

I wonder how that fits in with the Prime Minister's commitment to reduce the amount of time small business needs to deal with paperwork, which was made in the light of the Bell report. With the GST on the way back, it is probably about as honourable as his other commitments. We have to remember that this, of course, is Prime Minister Howard of the never-never—we would never, never see a GST.

If we look at the contributions from those opposite, we see that many of them, especially those who represent regional electorates, have talked about the need for capital infrastructure in their electorates. That intrigues me because at the same time they have fallen for the government line about the surplus and about the need to reduce what they perceived to be future generations paying for what is being spent now. As John Kenneth Galbraith outlines in his book The good society, that is a very narrow view of the way in which capital infrastructure outlays should be looked at. Much of that is appropriate spending for not only the economic benefit of the present but also the economic benefit of the future.

It is quite right to expect that that would be acknowledged by the burden being spread over many years. It is just callous and naive to withdraw and not recognise that that is the basis of much of the borrowings that governments make. Indeed, many studies have indicated that unless we increase our effort in infrastructure spending the infrastructure stock will go backwards in quantity and quality. It is about time governments, like the Howard-Costello government, recognised that.

In their contributions to this budget debate, many of those opposite have been chanting the mantra that Treasurer Costello has engaged them to chant. You know the line: the budget in the black, back on track. We now have Howard and Costello—we of the never-never. It is a track all right, but perhaps it is the track to the never-never. Of course, as the Macquarie Dictionary indicates, the never-never is `a remote and isolated region'; another definition is that it is `imaginary'.

talk.start.para: —As I sat preparing these remarks, reflecting on the third coalition budget in this parliament, I asked myself: what would be the single most emblematic image that might encapsulate its achievements? What would be the single image or epithet that is most evocative of this milestone in the journey of the Howard coalition government? On reflection, I have selected the title of this year's appropriation speech from a most uncharacteristic source, that being the quotations of Chairman Mao. While I shall borrow from the imagery of the Long March, the title of my speech today is `Let a thousand flowers bloom'.

speech.para: This budget is best understood not as a series of figures in successive sterile looking budget papers but as the critical next step in Australia's long march back from the financial brink. That journey began with the decision of millions of Australians to make John Howard the Prime Minister of Australia on 2 March 1996. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) has now confessed to the reality that the ALP's principal legacy to Australia in March 1996 was an annual recurrent Commonwealth deficit of over $10,000 million.

I note that Mao's Long March over one year was a journey of 10,000 kilometres from Hunan to northern Shaanxi. The coalition's long march over three years has been a fiscal journey of 10,000 million small steps—10,000 million small steps in reducing the Commonwealth's annual indebtedness to future generations of unborn Australians. We have come from the financial brink to our destination today—a shelter of safety and security in a turbulent world economy.

Behind Kim Beazley's black hole was a psychology of deficit and debt, which riddled the entire fabric of the former government. Its ethos was eat, drink and be merry for someone else, some day, will pick up the tab. Its entire preoccupation was the next day's headline, the next press release, the next ineffectual spending program, the next opportunity to dish out government largesse and patronage to one of its vested interest groups.

It was a view of the world which saw the dead hand of government at the dominant centre and the freedom and opportunity of individual Australian citizens as a mere footnote. It was a world in which enterprise and diversity was starved of sunlight and few flowers bloomed. Under ALP rule, the accumulated Commonwealth debt grew by over $70 billion in the past five years of its government alone. It was therefore essential that we begin the long march back.

The first and second budgets of this government were in some respects painful, but we worked to ensure that the pain was shared fairly by the whole community and especially by those most able to bear the burden. By our tenacious commitment to bring spiralling Commonwealth debt under control, we took pressure off private financial markets, which led to five successive falls in interest rates. Official rates have fallen under the coalition's economic stewardship from 10.5 per cent to 6.5 per cent.

My electorate of Parramatta includes just under 10,000 people following the Australian dream, paying off a mortgage. They are largely made up of 12,500 couple families with dependent children. For any of those families paying off an average mortgage of, say, $100,000, that rate fall represents $75 a week in additional disposable income. Let me repeat that: $75 a week in additional disposable income. That benefit would be entirely thrown into jeopardy if we ever contemplated a return to Labor's entrenched culture of deficit and debt. So I say to every one of those families in Parramatta: let a thousand flowers bloom.

It was my pleasure, with the assistance of my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), two weeks ago to launch the Parramatta Job Network. Under that initiative, this government has replaced the two existing CES officers in my electorate with 14 keen-as-mustard employment service providers. The benefits of reform are already being felt with national unemployment falling below that crucial psychological threshold of eight per cent for the first time in eight years. Unemployment in Parramatta is now well below the national average, and that includes long-term and youth unemployment. Each service provider in Parramatta has expertise in a different area. Each employs different strategies. Each is available to job seekers at no cost. So I say to every job seeker in the Parramatta electorate, old or young: let a thousand jobs emerge.

Because of our commitment to doing the right thing, this third budget was in a position to acknowledge the efforts of those Australians who had spent their lives, in a financial sense, doing the right thing. I am referring to independent retirees. These are the people who have sacrificed and saved to take responsibility for the costs of their own retirement. Many in my electorate, which has a high concentration of tradespeople and labourers, find themselves just above the asset and income threshold to qualify for the pension, but their fixed income is barely enough to make ends meet. These people feel, in relation to their entitlement to Commonwealth benefits, that their efforts at self-help have been punished rather than rewarded.

The extension of the seniors health card to an additional 220,000 self-funded retirees will allow a significant proportion of the 14,600 retirees in my electorate to buy eligible pharmaceuticals for $3.20. In addition, this budget provides a free flu vaccine for every Australian over the age of 65. So I say to all Australian seniors: let a million healthy winters pass.

We have increased funding to $165 million for medical research, including $50 million to make up for Labor's shortfall. This is especially important to me because of the high concentration of medical research which takes place in my electorate in the shadow of Westmead Teaching Hospital and Westmead Children's Hospital, Sydney University and the University of Western Sydney. Sixteen grants from January 1998, involving an increase of seven grants and expenditure of $1.1 million, will fund projects in my electorate which will benefit the health of all Australians.

It was my pleasure recently to welcome Minister Wooldridge to a function at the Westmead Institutes of Health Research and, as a consequence of that visit, I expect to be able to make an announcement in the next couple of weeks about a substantial funding grant for that institute. I look forward to continuing these remarks later this afternoon.

talk.start.para: —It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—As members will be aware, yesterday the level of noise in the House was totally unacceptable. I do not intend to allow it to proceed on that basis.
—As it was when I made my budget reply, Mr Speaker.
—The Leader of the Opposition will not make response. If he does so, he will not be called to ask a question. I suggest that he direct his question, otherwise he will not be called.
—My question is to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister whether he recalls saying yesterday in this House:

question.para: Our policy of opposition to a co-payment stands. It will not be altered.

Is the Prime Minister aware of the report in today's Australian regarding a possible government intention to introduce up-front fees for public hospital patients after the next election? Do you agree with the statement by your spokesman that the government will `go to an election with a health policy to win' and `whatever happens after that is hypothetical'?

talk.start.para: —The government's policy is that there will be no co-payment. The report in the Australian is wrong. It was based on a complete misinterpretation of what the paper was told. It is absolutely wrong.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I remind members of the opposition frontbench that they should remain quiet.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to recent studies of changes to Australia's indirect tax system? What are the implications for the current debate about tax reform?

—In reply to the honourable member for Lilley, yesterday the Leader of the Opposition, in asking me a question about tax reform, relied upon a statement made by Dr Neil Warren, a noted academic who does have quite a reputation in this field. As a result of the Leader of the Opposition's reference to Dr Warren, I had occasion to look back over some of the recent academic work of Dr Warren. I came across an extremely interesting paper which he presented to a conference on tax reform and a GST on 15 April 1998.

answer.para: What Dr Warren did in that paper was to lend support to the assertion that has frequently been made by the coalition: that before the 1993 election the Labor Party promised tax cuts without a GST but after the election the Labor Party in government gave us the exact opposite. They not only failed to deliver through their notorious repudiation of the l-a-w law commitment and failed to deliver the income tax cuts but also in fact delivered their own goods and services tax. To add insult to injury and further pain to the working men and women of Australia, they delivered it without any compensation. When you go through Dr Warren's paper, it contains one of the most damning indictments of the two-faced politics of saying one thing in a campaign and doing another once you get into office.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I remind members of the opposition of my remarks.

—It is a warning to the entire Australian community. They did it in 1993. If you let them do so, they will do it again in 1998. At the beginning of his paper—it is a document that would repay study by all those who are interested in a proper discussion of the Australian taxation system—this is what Dr Warren had to say:

answer.para: To demonstrate this point most clearly, we shall focus on the equity and efficiency implications of the electorate's failure to support the Fightback indirect tax reform package in 1993 and contrast this with the indirect tax reforms introduced by the newly elected Labor government between 1993 and 1996.
This paper will argue that there are a number of important lessons to be learnt, and these include:
(1) Labor introduced in 1993 its own form of a goods and services tax but in this case without any compensation to those adversely affected;
(2) That, even if Labor had compensated groups for the adverse equity impact of the indirect tax changes introduced, what their tax reform did was
(a) make Australia less internationally competitive by increasing input taxation; and
(b) make the tax system less economically efficient by increasing the tax rates on a range of selected goods but not on services.
This is what Dr Warren goes on to say:
Even though in practice no-one advocates the introduction of a GST without compensation, an important finding of this paper is that this was effectively what Labor did in the period 1993 to 1996.

What you have from one of the most respected taxation academics in Australia is a clear indictment that, in government, what the Labor Party, having gone to the people and said, `We will cut your tax without fixing the indirect taxation system,' and having sneaked back into office on that deceptive commitment, then did in government was to repudiate the personal tax commitment, effectively embrace a goods and services tax and, to rub the electorate's nose in the dirt, they did it without any compensation to the working men and women of Australia. It represented one of the most cynical and one of the most calculated betrayals of the Australian electorate.

talk.start.para: —But you said you would never ever introduce it.
—The member for Corio.

—I would commend to all members of the House a very careful study. What Dr Warren reveals is that the cumulative effect of the changes introduced by the Labor government between 1993 and 1996 was to erode household real disposable income by an average of 2.1 per cent. In other words, you promise the electorate income tax cuts without changing indirect taxation. You scramble back into office and you do the reverse. You snaffle the tax cuts and, to add insult to injury, you introduce a goods and services tax, you do it without compensation and you rob the poor and the battlers of disposable income to the tune of 2.1 per cent. It represents a total demolition of the credibility of the Australian Labor Party on the subject of taxation.
—Tell us about never ever.
—The member for Corio.

—It is not surprising that there is gathering support within the Australian community for fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system. I want to put on record my appreciation of the willingness of sections of the Australian business community to get behind the cause of fundamental reform.

answer.para: We have needed a better taxation system for a long time in this country. As far back as 1975, the Asprey report to the Whitlam government recommended the need for fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system. We have got the courage and we have the openness to put the proposals to the Australian people. By contrast, the Australian Labor Party deceived the public in 1993. They promised tax cuts; they did not deliver them. They promised no GST; they delivered one of their own and, for good measure, they kicked in with no compensation. That was a total and cynical betrayal of what they told the Australian people. They ultimately deserved the fate they enjoyed in 1996.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister does not stand by his staff's claims, does he stand by his own claim that his health insurance tax rebate will raise health fund membership to 40 per cent of Australians by the year 2000?

—The situation with health insurance is that, if measures had been taken as recommended by Graham Richardson in 1990, there would not have been the loss of critical mass in private health insurance. If we had not taken the measures we took after our election in 1996, the number of Australians in private health insurance would now be significantly lower than what it is. The fact is the Labor Party hates private health insurance. The Labor Party wants to drive people out of private health insurance. The Labor Party wants to disadvantage people who have private health insurance. And that is why they deliberately allowed the system to run down over a period of 13 years.
—My question is addressed to the Acting Treasurer: is the Acting Treasurer aware of community support for tax reform, and what is the government's response to this support?

question.para: Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Hunter will remain silent.

—I thank the honourable member for Makin for her question. I am aware of that widespread support in the community for tax reform. All members of this House would see it whenever they visit their electorate and whenever they speak to community groups, whether they be business or other ordinary Australians. That was confirmed this morning in a report, the Yellow Pages Small Business Index report, which stated that, across all small business, 80 per cent viewed tax reform as `vitally important' or `very important'. It was further confirmed today with a speech given here in Canberra by the President of the Business Council of Australia, Mr Stan Wallis, where Mr Wallis urged a case for comprehensive tax reform. Mr Wallis said in that speech:

answer.para: Tax reform is essential if we want to improve prosperity and employment prospects in the community generally, and it is essential for business competitiveness.

Why would Mr Wallis say that? Firstly, he heads the Business Council of Australia. Its members are the major employers in this country who are employing hundreds of thousands of Australians every single day. He and his members recognise that the system that we are currently dealing with is not serving Australia and is not serving Australians. He went on to say:

Not to put too fine a point on it, our tax system is in poor shape. There should be no mistake about this: it has come to the point where it is now on its last legs. It is broken in a number of places.

We certainly know that on this side of the House. What we see from the other side of the House is that they are prepared to do a bit of readjusting and they are prepared to do a bit of broadening. Only today on radio the Leader of the Opposition stated that, yes, he was going to have a look at the wholesale sales tax area. He is quoted as saying:
". . . a bit of a look at where the wholesale sales tax is at the moment but basically in principle, yes (we will leave it as is)" . . .

On Sunday the Leader of the Opposition told all Australians, `Our tax system is going to give you a new fridge.' The last time he had a chance to do something about a new fridge for all Australians, he put the price on new fridges up in the tax sense by 10 per cent. The last time he had a chance to do something for Australians on the question of the family car—something all Australians have or seek to have—what was the rate that the sales tax on cars was increased? It went from 15 per cent up to 22 per cent. He added thousands of dollars to the cost of the family car.

What he is now trying to put to the Australian people after that speech last Sunday is: `We will do a little bit of tinkering to a system that we created, a system that is broken'—Mr Wallis has stated that again today—`a system that is held together with chewing gum and pieces of string. We'll do a bit of broadening. We'll do a bit of readjusting. We'll add a bit more chewing gum, some more string and maybe a bit of sticky tape. But we don't intend to give Australians the chance to progress with their lives and to progress with their jobs.' The Leader of the Opposition and all members of the opposition should take note of what Mr Wallis has said today because he is taking about benefits for all Australians. He is talking about giving an opportunity for job creation.

I have no idea how members opposite can come into this house and talk about leaving the system as it is when they know that it is destroying jobs and it is destroying small business—it is not giving them the chance to employ more Australians. I say again that, before the next election, the coalition will put before the Australian people a fair and simple system—

talk.start.para: —We have been hearing that for months.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition. The minister will wind his answer up.
—a system that rewards families, a system that will encourage a system that will create jobs and a system that will benefit all Australians.
—The Treasurer said it was snake oil.
—The member for Corio will remain silent.
—My question is again to the Prime Minister: will the Prime Minister today rule out imposing a GST on health fund premiums?

—The attempts of the members of the opposition to divert attention from the mess that they made of the Australian taxation system know no bounds. We will be unveiling the details of our taxation policy at the right time. When that taxation policy is unveiled, I can assure those who sit opposite that the one thing you will not be able to avoid is that the Australian people will see it as a fair policy, the Australian people will see it as a policy that helps Australian families.
—Mr Speaker!
—The Prime Minister will resume his seat. The member for Dobell needs to have a pertinent point of order.
—My point of order, Mr Speaker, is that it was a very specific question: will the Prime Minister rule out today imposing a GST on health fund premiums? He is giving us a general rave.
—The question need not be repeated. The Prime Minister is fully aware of the standing orders and is responding accordingly.
—I can assure those who sit opposite, including the member for Dobell, the policy will win very widespread support from Australian families.
—And when will we see it?
—I warn the honourable member for Brisbane.
