talk.start.para: —by leave—Mr Speaker, I want to take this opportunity on the first day of National Reconciliation Week to confirm the government's strong commitment to the cause of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. This week all Australians can show a commitment to reconciliation, inform themselves about the indigenous perspective and participate in reconciliation activities.

speech.para: National Reconciliation Week is marked by two very significant dates. Today, 27 May, is the anniversary of the referendum in 1967 which empowered the Commonwealth to make laws for Aboriginal people. The concluding date of National Reconciliation Week is 3 June, the anniversary of the High Court's decision in the Mabo case.

The theme this year is Communities Working Together. All over Australia local councils, churches, business and community organisations will be acknowledging the cause of reconciliation, and I urge Australians to join in their local activities. Australia's traditional values of a fair go, of tolerance and acceptance of diversity, of looking after each other in times of need provide the context for successful reconciliation.

In 1991 the coalition parties supported the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I take this opportunity to acknowledge the contribution of a couple of members of that council—firstly, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), who represented the coalition parties, and, more recently, my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mrs Stone). We continue to support the council's objective, which is to promote reconciliation based on an appreciation of indigenous cultures and achievements and the unique position of indigenous people in Australia.

There are three major elements to a successful reconciliation process. We should acknowledge the realities of our shared history and its continuing effects. We should, in line with the theme of National Reconciliation Week, work together towards a common future in which we share equally, in which we appreciate and respect our varied traditions and cultures. Finally, and this is the key, we need an ongoing commitment to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage.

This is a major policy priority of the government. There can otherwise be no meaningful reconciliation. We do look forward to the day when indigenous people share equally with all other Australians in the social, economic and cultural life of our nation. We look forward to the day when indigenous people are able to leave behind welfare dependence and take control of their own lives and their own communities. We know that this will not be achieved if indigenous people continue to lag behind in the key socioeconomic areas of health, housing, education and employment. My government's efforts therefore have been concentrated in these areas and I believe that we are beginning to see results.

In the recent budget, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) issued a ministerial statement which, for the first time, puts on record exactly what the government is doing to meet its goals. It shows that we spend almost $1.9 billion annually on indigenous specific programs and that over 70 per cent of this money is spent in the four key areas I mentioned.

Since coming to government, we have increased indigenous health spending by nearly 40 per cent. I will say that again. Since coming to government, we have increased indigenous health spending by more than 40 per cent. That represents a practical, on the ground, sincere commitment to the area that ought to be of greatest concern to people who claim that they are concerned about the welfare of our indigenous people. There is nothing less acceptable that in 1998 our fellow Australians within the indigenous community should suffer such appalling levels of general health. That is why, in line with my government's priorities, we have increased—I say it again—indigenous health spending by nearly 40 per cent.

I was very pleased to be able to announce in February a project to address the severe eye health problem in indigenous communities. In a country with all of Australia's comparative advantages, it is intolerable that so many indigenous people should be afflicted with avoidable blindness. The measures we are putting in place will make an appreciable and early difference. We are also providing an immunisation program for influenza and associated diseases which are a major cause of ill health and death in indigenous communities. It is by practical, realistic and effective measures such as these that we aim to achieve significantly better outcomes for indigenous people.

We recognise that there is a huge backlog in the provision of adequate housing and health related infrastructure in indigenous communities. Unfortunately, the available funding is not unlimited. We have decided that our priorities should be those communities that are particularly needy and, because of their location in the remote areas, cannot access mainstream programs.

The innovative ATSIC army community assistance program, which we initiated shortly after coming to government and which, incidentally, was initiated as a result of a direct approach to me by three members of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, has already had some excellent results. Seven priority remote communities have been identified and the army is providing housing, sewerage, and better, cleaner and safe water supplies. Most significantly, they will also have community members who are trained by army personnel to maintain the new infrastructure so that the value of the asset will be preserved and the benefits in terms of improved health will be sustained.

Indeed, during my recent trip to the Northern Territory to visit Aboriginal communities I was able to see the very real improvements which will be made to the community of Elcho Island under the program. These include the construction of 10 homes, the provision of solar power and the upgrading of water supplies. These results demonstrate that this program is delivering real benefits to indigenous people in the most needy of remote communities in Australia. I am very pleased to announce today that the government will commit an additional $5 million to extend the ATSIC army community program. I have asked my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to consult ATSIC to provide matching funds as it did under the pilot program.

I particularly want to express my thanks to army personnel who have contributed so willingly to the success of this program and the productive consultation processes which they undertook with local communities. Indeed, the program is an excellent example of this government's approach to the reconciliation process, particularly in light of the very constructive relationships which were formed between army personnel and the indigenous communities.

Indigenous children suffer particular disadvantage in educational outcomes. The comparative participation figures are very telling. Indigenous children have a secondary school year 12 retention rate of less than 30 per cent, compared with some 70 per cent for other young Australians. Only nine per cent of indigenous young people are attending tertiary institutions compared with 22 per cent of the rest of the Australian population. Twenty-five per cent of indigenous students leave school before year 10; for other students, the figure is only two per cent.

In terms of educational attainments, 75 per cent of indigenous students in primary schools have significantly low levels of literacy and numeracy, compared with 33 per cent within the rest of the population. The situation is exacerbated by the remoteness of many Aboriginal communities which have no educational facilities and are located a considerable distance from the nearest schools.

My government is committed to assisting indigenous students reach their full potential and has provided increased funding, including to the indigenous education strategic initiatives program. I note that the government will be providing a package of initiatives of more than $15 million under this program for new equipment and facilities, including computers, school buses and accommodation for teachers in remote areas. The additional funds will also be used for curriculum programs aimed at improving the reading and writing skills of indigenous children, particularly in those vital early primary years. This funding will go to schools, both government and non-government, preschools and vocational and training institutions. It augments the $20 million announced by my government in December for similar facilities and projects for indigenous students in non-government schools and preschools.

We also remain very supportive of the community development employment projects scheme. It may not be very well known that, under this scheme, indigenous people have been working for the dole for the last 20 years. This scheme was introduced by the coalition government led by Malcolm Fraser in 1977 both to gain work experience and to improve community amenities. Demand for places has always been high, despite some disincentives in terms of reduced welfare entitlements and taxation rebates. We have now removed these anomalies and will provide CDEP workers with the same allowances available to mainstream work for the dole participants. This will bring more money into indigenous communities to assist in their economic development.

An appreciation in the wider community of the unique culture and heritage of Australia's indigenous people is also integral to reconciliation. I felt very privileged to have experienced the culture of the Torres Strait Islands and Eastern Arnhem Land earlier this year. The pride that indigenous people take in their traditions, the enormous effort that is put into maintaining them and the important role of the family in indigenous communities are greatly admired by other Australians. Over recent years, increasingly, many Australians will have enjoyed outstanding work by indigenous people in the visual and performing arts.

Understanding the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians is essential to an appreciation of their culture. We have a profound respect for the deep attachment of indigenous people to their traditional land and we support the principles of native title as set out in the Mabo and Wik decisions. But, of course, other Australians also have attachments and rights to land, and a balance must be struck. I believe we have achieved that balance with our native title amendments and, even if no single group is entirely happy with the outcome, I hope it will be acknowledged that the result is the best compromise amongst varied interests.

The other key element is understanding our shared history and recognising that this history continues to contribute to today's disadvantage. Last December we announced a $63 million package of practical measures clearly targeted at the most urgent needs identified in the Bringing them home recommendations. The funds we set aside will be used by ATSIC to establish Link Up centres in each state and the Northern Territory to assist people wishing to trace missing relatives. Substantial funds were also allocated to provide new and enhanced counselling services, in recognition of the distress that many have faced.

But, importantly, reconciliation is also about the future. It is especially about the future. It is about determining common goals and building enduring partnerships that will take us together into the next century. We are an egalitarian people, a fair and tolerant people. I believe that we have a real commitment to those elements of the reconciliation process that I have talked about—acknowledging the past, appreciating indigenous culture, working together but, most importantly, addressing those disadvantages that prevent indigenous people taking their rightful place in contemporary Australia. We are approaching an important, indeed exciting, time in the history of our nation and, with mutual trust and respect, the process of reconciliation will be one of the greatest successes of that history.

In conclusion, I wish to thank and congratulate Mrs Evelyn Scott, the new chairman, and Sir Gustav Nossal, the new Deputy Chairman, of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation on their efforts and the efforts of their fellow council members in coordinating this week's activities. I again urge all Australians to enter wholeheartedly into the spirit of reconciliation. I present the following paper:
National Reconciliation Week—Ministerial Statement, 27 May 1998 .
Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the statement.
Motion (by Mr Reith)—by leave—agreed to:
That so much of standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 16 minutes.

talk.start.para: —Reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians is critical to our capacity to move forward as a maturing nation. It involves reconciliation between our cultures and reconciliation with our shared history. Reconciling with our shared history involves acknowledg ment, acceptance and mutual respect. It must involve a shared sorrow and regret for the events, attitudes and policies of the past which brought pain then and which have left a legacy of personal and social distress with indigenous people today.

speech.para: The first step in dealing with problems of dysfunction in indigenous families—the problems that arise from the destruction of cultures—starts with the essence of the reconciliation process, which is not a taxonomy of initiatives or otherwise in relation to expenditure but a statement about what is in the human hearts of each of us. It is impossible, of course, to define that, but to some extent it has to be said that by people's deeds you know them.

The notable event in race relations in this country, on this day on which we are discussing this reconciliation issue, is the statement made overnight by the National Party and Liberal Party state secretaries that the Liberal and National parties in Queensland will extend preferences to the One Nation Party in the course of this election campaign.

The One Nation Party has, as part of its self-definition, attacked the reconciliation process, attacked relationships with the Aboriginal community, attacked expenditures on the Aboriginal community and attacked the Aboriginal community's culture. It has attacked—in some instances—the Aboriginal community's right to exist.

All members of the government who have responsibility for the conduct of foreign policy—bar the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—have found themselves, when overseas, explaining the hostility of the majority of the Australian people to this party's operation and how they deplore its positions. It is only possible for the Liberal and National parties to be extending preferences because the Prime Minister has given them licence to do so. And to call upon us for reconciliation when the Prime Minister himself—and this is also well known—has encouraged these sorts of statements is more than a little rich. We all recollect, Prime Minister, your statement after the maiden speech of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). When you went to speak to this same Queensland Liberal Party which has now extended preferences to One Nation, you said:
The pall of censorship of the Keating years has been lifted.

This directly related to the statements then being made to the leader of the One Nation Party nationally. It has to be said that what is being provoked here is division. And I note here the cynicism—the utter cynicism—of the choice of the one seat in Queensland where preferences will not be directed to One Nation. That one seat happens to have a substantial Chinese population. Talk about hiding your light under a bushel!

The Prime Minister notes that Reconciliation Week will end with the anniversary of the Mabo decision. I applaud his assurances that the government accepts the outcome of the Wik and Mabo cases. What a pity the actions fail to reflect the statement and sentiment! The Mabo decision was central to and critical of reconciliation. The pride and assurance that flowed to indigenous Australians from this recognition of their prior rights in this country have been real and measurable—measurable in the willingness and ability of indigenous Australians to pursue the logical benefits of these discovered rights in public and in the courts. It truly affirmed them and gave many of them confidence that our system of justice can recognise and protect them. I do agree that that is an important part of the reconciliation process.

A critical part of the reconciliation process—for any person with citizenship, anywhere, whether they be Aboriginal or anyone else—is that if there are particular circumstances that ought to, under common law or in any other way, be recognised, then those circumstances should be recognised. There will be protection of that position in the courts. It does not matter whether you are an Aboriginal or anyone else. But what was the response to that? The response of certain members of the government at the time was to attack the decision and deny its legitimacy.

They embarked on a deliberate campaign in regional Australia—and they still conduct it there—to spread misinformation, fear and panic. The Queensland Premier was out there doing precisely that during the course of the last two days. Whatever the short-term political results may have been, we all have to live with the resultant racial disharmony for years to come. They did not stop there; they attacked the High Court that delivered the decision as well. As Gerard Henderson remarked yesterday:
Neither Ben Chifley in 1949 nor Robert Menzies in 1951, despite High Court decisions that cut to the core of their political agendas, ever did such a thing.

They never did it—not Menzies, not Chifley. Menzies and Chifley were prime ministers for all Australians and they were big men. They were big men in this nation's history and they came from both sides of the chamber.

The coalition let loose the more lamentable specimens from the dark corners of the back bench. They assailed the court from the front bench and the back bench in the course of this particular debate. The Deputy Prime Minister's pronouncements on qualities essential in a High Court judge not only reflected on the court at that time but also sullied, by inference, the perceived impartiality of those later selected by his government to join the bench. He and his colleagues ill-served indigenous Australia, the wider community and the rule of law in what they had to say.

If the question goes to issues of the human heart in this National Reconciliation Week, the Prime Minister cannot escape the consequences of encouraging that type of sentiment in the community. He has persistently sought an opportunity to let the view run and sought to take advantage of it politically. Now it has hit, big time. The Liberal and National parties in Queensland have taken it to the point where they have determined that it is the basis on which their government may survive. That is precisely why they are doing it, not for any other reason. Rely on Labor Party preferences to get you over the hump, where you happen to be in direct contest with National Party members. But where it is Labor and One Nation contesting those top two positions for the final distribution, extend preferences to One Nation.

In all probability you and we will succeed in our task. We will succeed in defeating One Nation candidates and electing National Party candidates. You will succeed in defeating Labor Party candidates and electing One Nation candidates. They will be the consequences of the actions that you have undertaken and that you have persisted with and encouraged.

The Prime Minister read out a list of achievements in expenditures and focus. I cannot take exception to any particular item of focus that the Prime Minister put down, but I do think there needs to be some qualification on the said expenditures, because the programs that he alluded to—with the exception of the military one, which I will get to a little later—are against a background of very substantial reductions against the forward estimates in expenditures as far as the Aboriginal community is concerned.

It should be noted that expenditure on community housing and the infrastructure program has fallen 15 per cent in real terms, and the new figure represents a fall of $20 million on 1997 funding. The Prime Minister rightly alluded to substantial educational problems. The education strategic initiative program shows a 12 per cent cut for the forthcoming year. The Prime Minister rightly referred to the success of the CDEP program. Indeed, it has been a massively successful program. The forward outlays anticipated when this government came into office, the positioning of some 2,000 additional places—

talk.start.para: —Some 2,500 additional places were slashed, eliminated, and 600 of them have now been effectively restored, as indicated by the Prime Minister in his remarks here today. That needs to be understood as well.

speech.para: And then there was the mention of the Army program. I know this actually brings me into some disagreement with the odd person on my side and elsewhere in the community, but I actually like the program. It is a good program. It is something that ought to be done. It would have been drawn to the Prime Minister's attention for the simple reason that, for a very substantial period of time when I was Minister for Defence and then subsequently Senator Ray was Minister for Defence, every single time the Army conducted large scale exercises in the north or elsewhere, they went through processes, as part of their engineering exercises, doing precisely what this program does. They did very well with it, too, and that drew the attention of the Aboriginal community to the potential effectiveness of these programs, so some who have been involved with them think that they are very good things to pursue—and so they are.

We, of course, did it in a context—and this is how I would like it to be presented, instead of the way in which it is—of the integration of the Aboriginal community into the total defensive effort in the north. We have been magnificently served in recent times by the Aboriginal willingness to join our armed forces, particularly in our crack surveillance units.

I note Norforce's regular success against the SAS. There has been a considerable capacity shown by the Aboriginal soldiers to locate very well hidden SAS units. The role of Norforce, however, does not permit them to ambush; they call in a heavy mob to do it. Nevertheless, there has been that substantial contribution.

So, in terms of Army-Aboriginal relationships, this is a very good thing. But I tell you this: it is not a substitute for a serious infrastructure program. It is a relevant element of the development of the defence policies of Australia. It is a relevant element of Army community relations. It is not a relevant element of a serious infrastructure program to deal with the health and related issues which flow from the substantial problems that Aboriginal communities have concerning access to power, roads, clean water and the like. That requires a much more systematic attack. And the community housing and infrastructure program area of the budget has been reduced—as I said in the figures that I presented a short while ago—by something like 15 per cent.

These things need to be reflected upon if this is to be the defence for not addressing the issues of the human heart but addressing the issues of the practical needs. Both have to be addressed. But I would have thought that, if you decide to do one exclusive of the other, effectively you might well have chosen, down the road, a genuine statement of generosity instead of the old Leninist principle of two steps back, one step forward, which is precisely the policy that has been pursued in this regard.

Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister made reference to the reconciliation committee that he has established. I share the congratulations that he extends to the existing members of that committee. What a pity their entree to the scene should have been presaged or preluded by such extraordinarily tawdry shenanigans with the then Chairman, Pat Dodson, and Deputy Chairman, Ian Viner. What a pity that it should have been foreshadowed by that. What a pity it should have been accompanied by at least the public assertion—by leaking to the media—that what was expected was a quieter performance and a less critical one from those involved in that reconciliation process. It is manipulation of a group of people to achieve a political outcome for the government, not reconciliation for the community.

I am not sure what the current reconciliation committee will do as far as those issues are concerned. I am inclined to think that they will be tough minded enough to continue to pursue the real basis of reconciliation rather than the political agenda of the government.

When it comes to dealing with race relations issues in this community, the Prime Minister has said, as he looks back over history, that we ought not to have a black armband view of history. At other times he has called for an end to the self-flagellation, the introspection, the willingness to accept unfounded criticisms—`We can look any people in the eye'—and so on. He has made one statement after another in which it is supposed that the one or two recent remarks about history that he has made offset against that. Perhaps, in terms of public statement and public indication of an attitude, it is the same as expenditure: it is two steps back, one step forward, as far as the Prime Minister is concerned.

As an Australian I am enormously proud of Australia's history. We have much to be proud of in terms of military endeavour, scientific achievement and sheer survival in an unforgiving land. The relationship with the Aboriginal community has instances where pride might be applied but many where shame has to be attached and sorrow ought to be the appropriate response. The reconciliation process is supposed to deal with that. The reconciliation process is to bring us together. The reconciliation process is pursued seriously by many members of this parliament on both sides of this House. The Prime Minister ain't among `em.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anderson) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The damage being done by the Howard Government's health policies and the dangers posed to the health system by a goods and services tax.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —In the last answer by the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), to a question in question time today we had a bit of a revelation of and a glimpse inside the heart of this Prime Minister. And it was a pretty shocking vision, I have to tell you. It was quite Nixonesque. We had the Prime Minister claiming that his promise on the GST would be no longer operative—that his statements before the last election would not be broken if he now seeks to introduce a GST. That is despite the fact that before the last election the Prime Minister said:

speech.para: A GST or anything like it is no longer Coalition policy, nor will it be policy at any time in the future.
Then he was asked the question:
Never ever?
His reply:
Never ever.
I have gone to the Concise Macquarie Dictionary , which defines `never' as follows:
1. not ever; at no time. 2. not at all; absolutely not.

That is what the Concise Macquarie says. The John Howard dictionary says that `never ever' means `as soon as you can get away with it'. When this Prime Minister promises to never ever bring in a GST, it means that it applies only for one term. When this Prime Minister says that he will retain Medicare, just like he will never introduce a GST, that is the warning bell that his promises about retaining Medicare are valid for only one term. And guess what—we are getting close to the end of that first term, and that is why under this Prime Minister we are very concerned about what is going to happen to the future of health care in Australia. Mark my words: as sure as night follows day, John Howard will axe Medicare. As sure as night follows day, this Leader of the Liberal Party will be seeking to axe Medicare and undermine it at every opportunity.

The plan for the next term is now clear. First, health costs will go up, through the dismantling of Medicare. When they get away with that, they will try to put a 10 per cent GST on top of the higher costs that will be imposed on ordinary Australian families. But to work out what this Prime Minister is all about, to try to work out what he is going to do to you next, you have to look behind the words.

You only have to look at his performance over the last two years. Before the last election, he said that Medicare would be retained. Once he got elected, he slashed the federal funding for public hospitals. Before the last election, he said that bulk-billing would remain. Once he was elected, he squeezed that GP rebate to try to force doctors to switch from bulk-billing to charging up-front fees. Before the last election, he said that pensioner entitlements would be retained. Once he was elected, he axed the Commonwealth dental health program. Before the election, he said the PBS would be retained. Once he was elected, he increased the cost of essential medicines for the chronically ill, for older Australians, by taking lots of medications completely off the pharmaceutical scheme. Before the last election, he promised that health insurance premiums would be cheaper. Once he was elected, premium rises went through the roof, completely swallowing up that tax rebate. Before the last election, this Prime Minister promised that private health insurance membership would increase to 40 per cent by the year 2000. Once elected, he spent $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money on health fund subsidies, and membership is down to 31 per cent and falling at 800 a day.
Is it any wonder that we are starting to get concerned about some of the things members of the government are saying about health? We had the Treasurer (Mr Costello) stating a little over a week ago:
I intend to re-engineer the health care system.

We had the Treasurer saying that free care in doctors' surgeries and public hospitals is `a problem'. He said that it is a problem that people are getting bulk-billed or getting free treatment in a public hospital. And we had the Treasurer saying that his view is that public hospitals should only be for those who cannot afford medical care. That is his view of the future of public hospitals in Australia.

In some ways this is no surprise. In many ways, this is the fulfilment of the member for Bennelong's view about Medicare and health care in Australia for many years. Let me remind some of my colleagues of the long-term views that the member for Bennelong has expressed about Australia's health care system over many years. He has made the following statements: `We'll take a knife to Medicare.' `We'll pull Medicare right apart. The second thing we will do is to get rid of bulk-billing—it's a complete rort.' `Medicare has been an unmitigated disaster.'

We know that the Liberals have always hated Medicare. They have hated Medicare and Medibank from the first days they were introduced. And this mob have their priorities so upside down that they see Medicare as being some dangerous impediment to private health insurance rather than as the guarantee to all Australians of a right to decent health care at a reasonable price.

At the last election, the Liberals conned ordinary Australians into believing that things could be improved by subsidising health funds. They promised that premiums would go down and that the membership of the health funds would go up. Premiums have gone through the roof, and the membership has gone through the floor. The tragedy is that that $1.7 billion in health fund subsidies that they have put down the drain—to use Jeff Kennett's words—could have been spent directly on patient care. You can imagine the impact it would have had on local public hospitals right across the country if the same amount of money had been spent by this government on patient care. Even if you had spent it in public and private hospitals, you could have reduced the waiting lists, you could have employed more nurses, and you could have made a real difference to the quality of care out there.

Today, the biggest problem facing Australia's health care system is the crisis in public hospitals. We had the AMA saying this week that the waiting lists will double over the next few years if this government does not increase the amount of federal funding going into Australia's public hospitals. Yet at the time that the government brought down a budget with a $2.7 billion surplus, it could not find one extra dollar for Australia's public hospital system.

A few weeks ago the budget was brought down with $2.7 billion put aside in the surplus; yet the offer to the states was not increased by one dollar since the Premiers Conference a couple of months ago when Labor and Liberal Premiers walked out because of the inadequate federal funding for Australia's public hospitals.

The evidence of the crisis in our public hospital system is growing by the day. Let me draw to the attention of my colleagues an example that the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) drew to my attention this morning. She received a letter from one of the staff at Fremantle Hospital. It concerned an inquiry made by the member for Fremantle about one of her constituents who needs a partial reconstruction of her leg. She was told in this letter:
Thank you for your enquiry regarding Mrs—
I will call her `Mrs Smith'—
Smith's wait for surgery.
I regret that the current wait for non-urgent surgery is approximately 3 years.

This woman, who is waiting for partial reconstruction of her leg, has been told she has to wait three years! That is a symbol of the crisis in Australia's public hospital system right across the country. It is a crisis that will get worse because the government has not been prepared to provide enough federal funding for public hospitals.

Even after we have gone through the growing evidence that the government's tax rebate policy has been a failure, we have been unable to get the Prime Minister to admit that he was even wrong. He is unable to learn from his mistakes and unwilling to admit that he was wrong. We now have reports that the government is going to develop a second rescue package to put more subsidies into private health insurance. This is a further example of the Prime Minister's obsession. His obsession with private health insurance means that he cannot lift his eyes beyond the 31 per cent of Australians who have health insurance.

The Prime Minister is turning his back on the 12 million Australians who have decided to rely on the Medicare system. He is also blind to the very central tenet of Medicare that, whether or not you have private health insurance, when you are really sick you rely on the public hospital system to look after you or your family. By putting inadequate federal funding into the public hospital system, the government places at risk the health care of every Australian, whether or not they have private health insurance.

The more ordinary Australians are placing their faith in Medicare, the more they vote for Medicare with their feet instead of voting for private health insurance, the more determined this Prime Minister is to axe Medicare. If Medicare is working, they axe funding for bulk-billing. If Medicare is helping public patients in public hospitals, they axe the funding for the public hospitals. If Medicare is looking after older Australians, they axe their dental scheme. If Medicare is assisting the chronically ill, they axe the funding for their medicines.

In the first term of this government we have seen Medicare undermined by stealth. But as sure as night follows day, if this mob get a second term, Medicare will be axed. After they have hacked off the arms and the legs of Medicare, it will be unrecognisable. The sort of Medicare that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer believe in is a system whereby public hospitals provide care only to the poor. They believe in a Medicare where doctors bulk-bill only the destitute. They believe in a Medicare where families battling to get by on tight budgets are forced to pay more than $2,500—and this is before the GST—for their private health insurance.

If the government is re-elected, it will then set out to introduce a GST. A GST on health is a frightening prospect. A 10 per cent GST on full top cover for private health insurance is going to cost families an extra $300. For a hospital admission, for example, for the delivery of a baby, a 10 per cent GST will mean an increase in the cost for a private patient of $350. For a total hip replacement, a GST of 10 per cent will mean an increase of $1,250. For a specialist consultation, a 10 per cent GST will mean an increase of $16. A standard GP consultation will be up $3.70.

For pharmaceuticals, simvastatin, a drug used to treat high cholesterol which costs up to $80 a month, a 10 per cent GST will mean an increase of $8. The most commonly used antibiotic will go up $1.10 for every scrip. For a pack of 100 Panadeine tablets, a 10 per cent GST would increase that by $1.50. A 10 per cent GST on glasses would increase the cost by $10. A standard visit to the dentist for a check-up and clean costs $110. A 10 per cent GST on that will mean an increase of $11. The cost for an orthodontist to fit braces on a young child is up to $4,000. A 10 per cent GST on that will mean an increase of $400 or more.

Add to that the extra costs that my colleague the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) explained yesterday on families. Child-care costs will go up $17. We will pay an extra $20 for prams and $7 for bassinettes. Families will be asked to pay an extra $3.70 a week just to clothe their children. All in all, fami lies will be asked to pay an extra $10 a week just to pay John Howard's GST bill.

On this side of the House, we believe that the government would be wrong to impose a GST. We believe that the government would be punishing those Australians who can least afford it. In many ways, health care in Australia is like a tax. The system we now have in health is not perfect, but the turmoil in Asia, which is growing by the day, demonstrates that, whatever we do, let's not make the problem worse. Our tax system is not perfect, but whatever we do, let's not make it worse. How can a GST improve the tax system?

talk.start.para: —Why not make it better?

—The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy thinks that it will make it better. I would like him to explain to his constituents how a GST on health would improve the health system or how a GST on the cost of the basic necessities of life would improve the tax system. All of us on this side of the House believe that the Medicare system is not perfect. There are real problems in the public hospital system. There is a right for more Australians to get access to better dental care. We believe the way you fix that up is not to impose some new 10 per cent GST on the health system. It is not to give further subsidies for private health insurance when the public hospitals are in crisis. The way to fix the problem is to make sure that extra federal funding is going to public hospitals and dental care.

speech.para: We need to make sure that this government does not get a second chance. If John Howard gets that second chance, as sure as night follows day, he will axe Medicare. He will take the axe to the public hospitals. He will take the axe to bulk-billing. He will take the axe and go hacking after the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. That is not about reforming the health care system; that is about a Howard government trying to get square with the universal health insurance system. It is a universal health insurance system which they have always opposed from day one; a universal health insurance system which they have never understood was the only guarantee that every Australian had a right to a decent standard of health care. That is what we will be fighting for every day until the next election.

talk.start.para: —In the Australian Doctor on 15 May, the editor of that magazine, writing about the shadow minister for health, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and some views he held on certain medicines, said:

speech.para: This doesn't augur well should the Labor Party win the next election—we really don't need woolly, unscientific thinking on health.

Most unfortunately, we have had woolly and unscientific thinking on health, tax reform and a whole lot of other things this afternoon. The shadow minister has made claims again which just cannot be substantiated. For instance, he said that we have cut funding for public hospitals. That, very simply, is not true. Between 1993 and 1998, there has been expenditure of $25 billion. From 1998 to 2003, in the next five years, there will be expenditure of $30 billion. So I am not sure where this `not one cent extra' comes from.

He made claims about cuts to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Once again, there has been no such thing, because the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is continuing to grow by at least $200 million a year. It is imperative that we manage that well so that we can afford to have good, new and safe medicines coming on to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

I am always astounded to hear the shadow minister—or, for that matter, any member of the opposition—say anything about the numbers of people with private health insurance. In 1983, when they came to government, 65 per cent of Australians had private health insurance and the figure fell by over 30 per cent during their term of office. Of course, they had a Prime Minister and a health minister at that time—only a little over two years ago these things were still being said—urging people to accept the fact that they did not even need private health insurance. But now, all of a sudden, because they are in opposition, they oppose everything for the sake of opposition and they are finding fault with the levels of those who have private health insurance. Of course, we would like to see the number of those having private health insurance very much higher than it is. We have been doing, and we will continue to do, everything we can to see that that figure is increased.

The shadow minister referred to the fact that the government was wanting to do away with Medicare and bulk-billing. That is absolutely false. In fact, I can inform the House that the level of bulk-billing is higher now than it was in March 1996. The shadow minister referred to the dangers of a GST. One can only assume from this that the Australian Labor Party wants to go backwards, wants to see no reform in taxation and is happy to see low to middle income earners paying far too much tax.

talk.start.para: —We want clever reform, smart reform.

—We will have smart reforms, we will have fair reforms. They have not been announced; there has been a lot of supposition. But what we can say is that in three budgets in a row—and that has not happened for decades—there have been no increases in taxes. As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) told the chamber yesterday, there is a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on shampoo, soap, detergent, toothpaste, toilet paper and non-medicated mouthwash. There are a whole lot of other things on which there is a 22 per cent tax as well.

speech.para: After all the fuss about l-a-w and what would and would not happen about tax reform before the 1993 election, the Keating-Beazley Labor government increased taxes on toilet paper, toothpaste, deodorant, soap, shampoo, non-medicated mouthwash, et cetera. In case it has escaped the attention of the shadow minister, all these things are necessary for good personal hygiene, and contribute towards food hygiene, safer living standards and preventive health measures. One could easily and accurately argue that there have been tax increases during the last Labor government's term of office on things that are required for one's personal hygiene and good health.

There is a 32 per cent wholesale sales tax rate on many commonly used household items. By contrast, I stress again, there have been no increases in tax under the current government. We have the lowest interest rates and inflation rates in 30 years. These sorts of figures stack up to an increase in wages of about $90 to $100 per week, which always assists with what is necessary to care for one's family, for the mums and dads of Australia. Labor does not want change; Labor does not want reform of the tax system. It is happy to go on arguing about the same old things, but always knocking from opposition.

The shadow minister's arguments today do surprise me because the health record of the Australian Labor Party in government is very poor. It has failures in a number of areas. One of the critical failures, however, is in the failure to deliver on promises, yet the shadow minister talked today about promises. However, some of those failures to deliver on promises have actually been a great blessing for patients. For example, in 1992, the Labor government introduced co-payments for general practice services, spelling the end to bulk billing for millions of Australians. Thankfully, this policy only lasted for a few months before the Labor Party heeded the howls of protest from the coalition, the community and welfare groups and dumped that charge. A co-payment for general practice patients is a charge on the sick. The coalition will have no part of it.

Another policy initiative that Labor thankfully failed to deliver on was the abolition of the government subsidies for optometry services promised by the then finance minister, Mr Beazley, in 1993, costing patients over $350 million. As well as failing to deliver on these shocking attacks on Medicare, the ALP failed to deliver their 1993 election promises on health. It is interesting to look at the promises the Labor Party made on pages 3 and 4 of their 1993 health policy. I quote:
1. New initiatives to contract the private sector to provide elective surgery for public patients on waiting lists—
$100 million never delivered—
2. Private hospitals included in regional health services planning under the Medicare Agreements—
never done—
3. An aged care industry review to examine the adequacy of nursing staff to meet the increasing dependency of those living in hostels—
never done—
4. The National Rural Health Program would focus on expanding rural health centres initiative—
it did not happen—
5. Access to Medicare rebates for bone densiometry for women at risk of developing osteoporosis—
not delivered—
6. The establishment of a national health promotion authority—
never done—
7. Legislative reform to the National Health Act to ensure Australia's commitment to the promotion of health—
never seen—
8. Provision of language services in public hospitals—
never done—
9. The establishment of a national health advisory council on ethnic health—
not done—
10. A continuation of the National Health Strategy—
it was abolished the next year—
11. The development of a national primary health care policy—
never happened—
12. A national environmental health strategy—

and it was never developed. Here are 12 broken promises on two pages of Labor's 1993 health policy. Remember that the Labor machine is still the same as it was under Paul Keating. The failed former finance minister, who now leads the opposition, is still here. The former Senator Gareth Evans is still here, but now in this chamber. The former communications minister, the member for Dobell, is still here.

talk.start.para: —Only just!

—Yes, most fortunately for you—just. The former health minister, the member for Fremantle, now sits on the back bench, but is still here. The former ACTU bosses, Crean and Ferguson, are here. This team does not have a good track record, and I think it is a bit cheeky to come in here and pretend what may or may not happen with tax reform and to talk about broken promises and changes to policy which cannot stand up to any scrutiny.

speech.para: As I have said before in this place, I am proud of what we have been able to achieve in just over two years. One only has to look at a few things that have come out of the budget relating to aged care and health. While we as politicians might have headings of aged care and health, those people in the community see them running together. I remind the House that the Commonwealth seniors health card will be extended to 220,000 of Australia's self-funded retirees, enabling them to buy prescription medicines much more cheaply—in fact, for $3.20, the same as for pensioners. This comes into effect in January 1999.

People with a yearly income of no more than $40,000 and couples who earn no more than $67,000 will pay $3.20 instead of $20 for prescriptions. Twice as many people will be able to remain in their own homes with the $280 million package `Staying at Home—Care and Support for Older Australians'—and the families who care for them. Over four years, $500 million will pay for a gold card for health care for an additional 50,000 Australian World War II veterans. This provides those veterans with free treatment as a private patient with choice of doctor or medical practitioner in hospital, together with a wide range of other services, free of charge. The shadow minister might be interested to know that this single measure alone will save the states $400 million a year in their public hospital costs, so we need to take a holistic whole of government look at this.

The health funding for the states and territories will increase by a generous $2.9 billion over the period 1998-99 through to 2002-03. The shadow minister yesterday made some claims about how none of the state arrange ments could be finalised because the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) was overseas. I congratulate the minister for the initiatives he is taking on HIV and the role that he now plays in UNAIDS. But the shadow minister should have known, if he does not know, that this is an agreement reached between Premiers and the Prime Minister. The Premiers and the Prime Minister are still in the country. I would encourage those Premiers who walked out—rather foolishly, I think; good things can only ever come out of people keeping on talking and sorting things out—to come right back to the drawing board and finalise their arrangements. However, if they fail to do that, the Commonwealth will ensure that they still get their funding.

To continue with this good list of things we are doing in health, there will be free annual influenza vaccines for people over the age of 65, which will start in the autumn of 1999 and cost about $20 million a year. Once again, there will be savings for the states in public health. If we can keep these older people from getting pneumonia or coming down with the flu leading to pneumonia, we are going to be keeping them out of hospital.

A total of $6.1 million will go towards an anti-smoking initiative—I am sure no-one will criticise that. A national cancer control initiative will be implemented to provide a national approach to cancer control. More than $22.6 million will provide immunisation for indigenous Australians and ensure early detection of sexually transmitted diseases. There will also be increased funding of indigenous health services of $42 million over four years and additional funding of $7.9 million for health infrastructure and capital replacement. The shadow minister would have heard the Prime Minister say just after question time today that there has been an increase of 40 per cent oN spending on indigenous health since we came to government.

Funding for the National Health and Medical Research Council has been restored to $165 million per year, which is an increase of about $50 million per year, from 1999-2000. This redresses what the former government did in dropping the funding in this vital area of medical research. If we do not keep up the work that has been done on medical research, our best people will go overseas, we will lose jobs, we will lose good programs and we will lose our international reputation. But, most importantly of all, we will miss out on having things done better and we will miss out on changes that come in. In fact, we will go back to that old bad philosophy of dipping our hands into the Medicare pool and throwing money at people once they become ill instead of investing money in ways to keep them healthy.

There is a program for removing unwanted and expired medicines which are hoarded in people's homes to ensure that they are disposed of safely. This will help stop the inadvertent poisoning of young children and will better protect the environment. The single greatest poison in anyone's home and the single most commonly taken poison for any child is their parents' or their grandparents' prescribed medicines. This is a very important measure.

The government will also extend access to medication reviews, which are already being provided for people who are residents in nursing homes. This has now been extended to those in hostels. In fact, doctors will be able to nominate patients whom they consider need this type of review, and they will be able to have that in their own homes.

I think it was somewhat brave of the shadow minister to come in here and make attacks on what the government is doing in health while not being able to defend Labor's record of the past. I am not surprised about that; it really has been quite a disaster. We are committed to providing good health for all Australians, and we are committed to having a fair tax system in the future so that all Australians will benefit.

talk.start.para: —As was so lucidly and succinctly put by the shadow minister for health, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), Australia's health system is indeed in a parlous state. Waiting lists for emergency and preventive dental care have blown out following some $400 million being cut from dental care by the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program; low income Australians are being asked to pay the top rate for pharmaceuticals, again following $1.4 billion in cuts, resulting in increased co-payments for everyone, including pensioners; and there is the introduction of what we might loosely call a `drugs tax' and the removal of more than 20 drugs from the PBS.

speech.para: We have seen participation rates for private health insurance cover at their lowest ever, plummeting at the rate of some 800 per day. Public hospitals will no doubt remain in crisis, given the falsity of the government's claim that the budget contained a 15 per cent real increase for public hospital funding, something that was rejected out of hand by the former Liberal leader, Dr Hewson. There will be more on him later, but suffice to say that he knows, as I am sure most Australians now know, that some $800 million was cut from public hospitals in this government's first two budgets. Indeed, as the shadow minister has said, there has not been one dollar more given to the Premiers over and above what was offered to them when they walked out of the Premiers Conference in March. The AMA has since said that waiting lists will double in the event that this situation is not rectified—and still the government sits on its hands.

What is the government's response to this present crisis? Its response is a GST. In summary, our view on a GST is that it is plainly regressive. It hits high income earners at the same rate as low income earners and, of course, places a higher relative burden on low income earners. Contrary to the exhortations of the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), Labor does indeed recommend tax reform. We will be putting a decent and fair tax policy at the next election, based primarily around the tax credit system, which no doubt whetted her appetite when it was released in recent days.

But will the GST apply to health? Health was zero rated under Fightback and, like our beloved former Prime Minister, I too have a copy of the old Acme Fightback in my top drawer. When one reads from it, those opposite still recoil in the same way they recoiled when Paul Keating brought it out. I am not quite at the K-Mart Keating stage that the Treasurer's routine adopted, but I am working on it.

If we go to Fightback Supplementary Paper No. 5, at section 5.4.1 we see that it states that, under Fightback, health care goods and services would be zero rated. But Fightback was unclear in several areas. For example, each of the professionals who provide health care, be they doctors, hospitals or others, might be required to pay an additional GST component based on their business input. It can be reasonably argued that the price of medical and health services could increase by more than the rate of a GST because doctors and other health professionals would be taxed on their private consumption and may seek to recoup this via increased fees. It should be noted that the Commonwealth has no power whatsoever over the level of fees that private practitioners charge. Increased fees through a GST may even result, given the perceived need by professionals and others of their ilk to seek compensation for the additional administrative burdens that a GST imposes.

The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), to his credit, recently called for health to be zero rated in GST terms. This is indicative of what little confidence he has in the tax reform fantasy of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The minister is also at odds with his Victorian colleague the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who operates on the mantra `the fewer the exemptions, the lower the rate'. But, when all is said and done, the Prime Minister must ease the pain of health system users and give a core promise that health will be zero rated when it comes to a GST. He squibbed that chance on two occasions today: he squibbed it in the Australian and he squibbed it in question time this afternoon.

talk.start.para: —You couldn't believe him if he gave it.

—You couldn't believe him if he gave it; that is correct. But that begs the question: if a GST on health is bad, how can a GST on food and clothing be good? That is the imponderable the Prime Minister must ultimately come to terms with and, indeed, answer.

speech.para: If a GST were to be set at the lower end of the scale, say, at a 10 per cent rate, the shadow minister for health has outlined in some detail what that would impact upon. Let us summarise some more examples. A GST would add $350 to the cost of having a baby as a private patient and, as he said, $8 a month to the cost of the anti-cholesterol drug Simvastatin. If a GST of 10 per cent were to be imposed on health insurance premiums, it would also add $300 to top family health cover with extras. If we were to apply a GST to health insurance premiums, what would be the point of the government falsely claiming that its tax rebate on health insurance encourages people to subscribe to private health insurance while it simultaneously beavers away in its backrooms on a new 10 per cent GST based proposal on private health insurance costs, making it even less attractive and increasing the numbers leaving health insurance daily—currently around 800?

I can draw to the attention of the House many other instances of the adverse impacts of a GST on the health sector, especially those for the privately insured. For example, out-of-pocket costs—already at excessively, and perhaps intolerably, high levels—would also be subject to the impact of a GST.

I have outlined in overview the impact of a GST on our health system. Let me make a couple of additional brief points. If health and hygiene products were not zero rated or exempt from a GST, the price of all medical and health goods would be expected to increase by the rate of the GST. This would include prescription and non-prescription drugs, wheelchairs, hearing aids, dentures, spectacles, and medical and therapeutic devices.

All health and medical services would be expected to increase by the rate of the GST. This would mean, for example, that a typical consultation with a GP would increase in price from $37 to around $40. Outlays by the Commonwealth on medical benefits may also increase accordingly. To that end, I say that consultations with opticians, dentists, physiotherapists, podiatrists, clinical psychiatrists and other health professionals would be expected to increase by at least the rate of that GST, which I am sure is among the many reasons why Australians will soundly reject it, as indeed they rejected the old Acme Fightback in the 1993 election.

Above all else, Australians have a right to know—and they have a right to know now—if health services will be zero rated. The Prime Minister cannot go on playing this game of hide-and-seek. Many people out there are suffering pain of the kind that the shadow minister alluded to, based on anecdotal evidence given to him by the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence). If it was good enough for Johnny Hewson to put out his tax proposals 18 months early, why isn't it good enough for Johnny Howard to put out his proposals eight weeks early? There is surely no safety, security or stability in avoiding this issue.

The government should be roundly condemned for placing at risk decent and affordable health care for all Australians. I urge the government to come clean now and state its position on the application of the GST to the health sector in the interests of all Australians who have been so adversely affected by its many across-the-board cuts in this crucial area of our society.

talk.start.para: —High spending, high taxing—that is the legacy of 13 years of Labor government. Who in this House does not remember the l-a-w tax cuts? I remember them. The electorate does. And guess what? The l-a-w tax cuts never happened. In 1993, Labor said there would be no new taxes. What a joke. In the 13 years of the Keating-Beazley Labor government we saw the highest taxing, highest spending government in history. In 1996, the Australian people sent a message to the Keating-Beazley government saying that enough was enough. The federal election results showed that its traditional voters deserted the party in droves.

speech.para: But wait! What did Labor do? It reinvented itself and now we have Beazley's so-called `New Labor'. What has been one of its first policies? Health. Labor wants to increase the Medicare levy, scrap the $450 private health care rebate and commit Australians to another $6 billion worth of extra spending that the shadow health minister has already promised. Hold onto your hats everyone—the big spenders have hit town again.

Let me to say to the House that I have absolutely no hesitation in telling the thousands of people in my electorate of Canning who now receive the health care rebate that their private health insurance premiums will increase by $450 under Labor should it be re-elected. What about low income earners who depend on Medicare for their health care services? Guess what? Labor wants to increase the Medicare levy.

On Nightline, in March this year, the shadow minister for health said, `I think that right now ordinary people will be prepared to pay a slightly higher level of taxation.' Let me remind this House that Medicare is part of the tax system.

talk.start.para: —Finish the quote.

—It's all right, I am going further. The shadow minister went on to say, in the same interview, `If we did have a higher level of taxation, people would be prepared to pay it if it went into the health system.' So why didn't you do it when you were in office? You did nothing about it. You had 13 years and not once did you do anything about it.

speech.para: Then, in true Labor style, on Radio 5DN in May 1997 the shadow Treasurer said, `Middle Australia is well and truly taxed enough at the moment.' Has the leopard changed its spots? Who are we to believe—the shadow Treasurer, who has only just admitted to the $10 billion Beazley black hole, or the shadow health minister sitting opposite me, who has committed Labor to $6 billion worth of spending promises? Then again, do we believe the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) who has said absolutely nothing?

On the one hand, we have the shadow health minister making unfunded promises, and on the other hand we have the shadow Treasurer preaching fiscal restraint. All of this begs the question: who are we to believe? Who is telling the truth? Where is the money coming from? All I can say is that this rhetoric is, once again, the classic Labor tax and spend, boom and bust approach to fiscal responsibility.

Our government considers health a very important matter to all Australians—not only as individuals but also as a nation. We are determined to pursue new directions in preventive and public health. As one who has worked in the health profession for over 20 years, I can say from experience that the system we inherited from Labor was in disrepair. This government has just brought down a budget that is fair and just. It is positive and consolidates the plans we put into place in 1996.

In health, we have achieved substantial realignment in spending towards programs that enhance quality, prevent illness, save children's lives and boost our health and medical research efforts. That is not bad for a government that has only been in office for just over 2½ years. Yet everyone should be reminded again that Labor was in office for 13 years and it still could not get its act together.

Let us just list a few of the initiatives in the health area that this government is about to put into place: free annual flu vaccinations for all Australians over 65 years of age and $165 million per annum for health and medical research—and that is an increase of more than $50 million a year to redress the projected drop in research funding resulting from previous Labor government decisions. Later this year, the biggest ever public health initiative undertaken in this country will take place to protect our children from measles. Access to Medicare claiming will be improved through the establishment of 200 additional Medicare easy claim facilities in outer metropolitan areas. There are many other issues, and the list goes go on, but obviously time restricts us from covering them all.

The single most important initiative that this government has announced in health is its private health care rebate. I have absolutely no doubt that the Leader of the Opposition knows that, in his own electorate of Brand, there are over 12,000 households who receive this rebate. I wonder, how will the Leader of the Opposition explain to his electorate that private health care premiums under his regime, should he be re-elected, will in fact be $450 more per family? Is he going to tell a pensioner couple in Brand that they will be paying $250 more for their private health care premiums? Is he going to tell the people of Brand why he wants to withdraw their rebate and push up premiums by 18 to 25 per cent in one hit?

The fact remains that the shadow minister for health proposes to spend more than $6 billion in health policies. I ask again: where is the money coming from? Who is telling the truth—Evans, Lee or Beazley—or does it simply mean Australians will pay more tax again? Higher taxes, higher spending, boom and bust, more of the same—that is all you will get from new and old Labor.

For the first time in this decade, this government has handed down a budget surplus. Home mortgage rates are the lowest they have been since the 1970s. Small business lending rates are the lowest since the 1960s. But this government does not stop here. Everyone knows that the archaic tax system in this country is unfair and unworkable for ordinary Australians. It is the system that we inherited from Labor, and we are determined to fix it. We are determined to make it fair for all. Indeed, as somebody from the opposition bench said, we will make it smarter for all.

I am sick of trying to explain to families in my electorate of Canning the unfairness of the current system and why it is that toothpaste is taxed at 22 per cent and toothbrushes are tax exempt. Where is the logic in that? Where is the logic in something that is totally opposite? Again, this government is determined to have a fairer tax system for all.

But what do we hear from Labor, who have continually said the tax system is okay? Here is an example: when asked on the Sunday program in August 1997 whether the present indirect tax system was equitable, the shadow Treasurer replied:
There is some inequity, I think that's fair to say, yes. But I am prepared to state generally that there are some anomalies in the present tax system and there is a case for having a look at that.
Again, more forward thinking, more intelligent ideas—get the states to charge death taxes. `The old chestnut of property and inheritance taxes,' I think was how the shadow Treasurer referred to them.

The bottom line is that Labor do not think anything is wrong with the present system, and they are not prepared to do anything about it. Even if they were, they have the shadow Treasurer preaching fiscal restraint, they have the shadow health minister promising $6 billion in health spending and they have the Leader of the Opposition running around in circles. This country does not want to see the old days of big spending, high taxes and big budget deficits return.

Only the Howard government wants a fairer tax system. Only the Howard government is committed to removing the remaining legacies of Labor's 13 years of neglect of the health care and tax system. We on this side of the House want to make sure that everybody has choice, that everybody has security, that everybody has a fair go and that our hospital systems are what they used to be. We will make sure that everybody gets that opportunity.

talk.start.para: —Order! The discussion is concluded.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Grievously.
—Please proceed.

—During her contribution to the appropriation debate, the honourable member for Canning (Mrs Johnston) accused me of supporting an increase in the Medicare levy and of advocating the scrapping of the health insurance tax rebate, both of which are untrue. She also stated on several occasions that I have outlined $6 billion worth of spending commitments, which is based on a laughable press release of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge).

speech.para: To demonstrate my position on this, I have advocated an increase in funding for public hospitals. In the minister for health's laughable press release, he claims that is a firm commitment to spend an extra $5 billion on public hospitals, which I am sure the House can understand is a complete and grievous misrepresentation.

talk.start.para: —The Speaker has received advice from the Government Whip that he has nominated Mr Halverson to be a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in place of Mr Tony Smith
—The Speaker has received a message from the Senate transmitting the following resolution agreed to by the Senate:

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —The tremendous thing about the individual measures which I outlined in my earlier remarks is that they have been achieved without recourse to increases in taxes—without increases in income tax, without increases in sales tax and without increases in fuel or other excise taxes. My colleague the member for O'Connor, Wilson Tuckey, recently pointed out to me that no government in recollection has been able to produce three successive budgets without increases in taxes, let alone been able to produce a third budget which actually generates a surplus.

speech.para: I suggest that honourable members ought not just take my word for the great qualities of this budget, but we ought to look to some of the independent commentators who are no special friends of this government. I note that the Daily Telegraph editorial on 13 May observed that:
Peter Costello's third budget is, as promised, a responsible document that lays the groundwork for a secure economy in uncertain times.

Terry McCrann on the same day said that Peter Costello `can stick out his fiscal chest with pride'. He went on to describe him as a worthy claimant to the title of the `world's best Treasurer'. Most significant of all, in my opinion, was the description by Malcolm Farr of this budget as the `signal of a generational change'.

In my concluding moments, I want to emphasise this fact to the listening public and to my constituents in Parramatta: do not focus primarily on any individual budget measure, not even the $2.7 billion surplus, but reflect on the generational change, the sea change, which this budget represents. Ours is a government that believes that, if you are going to lecture the Australian people about the importance of national savings, you have to practise what you preach. We are a government that believes that, before you can fix the national economy with any credibility, you have to get your own house in order. Before you can congratulate yourself on some new spending program, you have to have a way to pay for it. That is the long march back. As Treasurer Costello said, we have completed the first leg of that march in turning around the recurrent deficit. Now we must tackle the accumulated debt.

In doing that, this government believes in the essential capacity, the potential, the diversity, the enterprise and the initiative of the Australian people. We do not believe that the sole repository of wisdom is the government itself. We do not believe in so dominating the national life that no other voices can be heard. We seek to create the conditions under which the Australian citizen, the individual, the Australian family, the Australian company and the Australian economy can grow and flourish. The satisfaction we receive is that derived from the success of others. Let interest rates fall. Let debt be repaid. Let us begin the second phase of the long march back and let a thousand flowers bloom.

talk.start.para: —In March 1996 the Australian people elected a government that they thought would make them feel comfortable and relaxed. Those of us who have followed politics for some time were aware of the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) previously as Treasurer. With that in mind, I want to pose a few questions. Who was the Treasurer, the only one in living memory, that had official advice before an election advising him that all the budget forecasts had gone gang busters, had gone berserk? Who was the only Treasurer in living memory with that information in writing from the Secretary to Treasury? The answer: the current Prime Minister.

speech.para: Who was the only Treasurer in postwar Australia who oversaw double digit inflation and double digit unemployment at the same time? Who caused that? The answer: John Howard, the Prime Minister. Which Treasurer oversaw the biggest drop probably ever recorded since the Depression in the manufacturing work force? Who was that? The current Prime Minister. In 1982 the Australian manufacturing work force declined by eight per cent in one year, in 12 months. One in 12 people working in the manufacturing sector lost their jobs in one year. Which Treasurer left office with a deficit in prospect of, in current terms, $25 billion? The answer is the same one.

We know his form very well. He has been around for quite a while and a lot of us know him well. I think the Australian people who thought they were getting someone who was comfortable and relaxed are starting to realise that that is not the case. What we have had since that election has been anything but comfortable and certainly not relaxed. We have had a period of chaos unmatched since 1982, when he was last there. We have had chaos in child care, and we still have, and massive uncertainty. We understand this because, as members, people are coming to us and asking us how it is working, what is happening and why. The answer is that no-one has the answer, including government members.

What did the budget in 1996 do for child care and aged care? What did that do to the aged in Australia and their families? The absolute anxiety and trauma that that has caused has been unbelievable. All the patch-up and all the catch-up that is going on now still has not addressed the core problem they caused back then. In relation to the services area, in the Public Service alone 30,000 jobs have gone missing. All those households have now been impacted and hurt by this government.

There is chaos in terms of people in the economy. We have seen a shift in national bankruptcy figures, and I quote them from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In March 1996, there were 4,400 bankruptcies. In March 1998, there were 5,900. We are seeing all-time records in bankruptcies under whom? The same man who was Treasurer in 1982. The long-term unemployed in March 1996 was 216,000. In March 1998 it was 233,000. The graphs are there. They are stark. There is no escaping them.

The ripping apart of the employment support system for unemployed Australians is now finally being understood by the community. The fact is that hundreds of thousands of Australians who are looking for a job will get no help from the government. In fact, it is the opposite. They will be locked out. They will not be able to apply for a job because the employer and the agency know that the government will pay only for those on the dole. So, if you are not on social security, you either pay yourself or you get excluded from even applying for the job.

In two years and three months, we have been seen how many ministers go—seven, eight, nine? This is an Australian record. The events of recent months with the former Speaker were absolutely amazing. We have seen 2¼ years of chaos. What happens this week? We are back to a new mantra, the triple S, which is supposed to stand for safety, security and stability. But what the triple S stands for when talking about this government—they are triple S, all right—is sly, sneaky and slippery. That is the triple S, because that is what they are and that is what they have been doing.

We have had 2¼ years of chaos. Then we have the Prime Minister masquerading and talking about security and stability. Go tell that to the hundreds of thousands who can no longer access employment; go tell that to the 30,000 former public servants; go tell that to the thousands of people who have taken their children out of child care or to the many thousands of families whose aged relatives cannot access residential aged care services. Go tell them about security, stability and safety.
