Sly, sneaky and slippery is what the triple S stands for, and I have no doubt that the Australian people understand that much better than the Prime Minister would have us believe. There is also no doubt that the triple S mantra this week came about because of opinion polling. It has finally got through that the Prime Minister does not understand the country. He did not in his previous incarnation as Treasurer; he does not now.

I think Gerard Henderson put it very well last night when he talked about the Sorry Day and said that somehow the Prime Minister has got it wrong and that it is an error of judgment. He certainly has. He has misread and misunderstood the nature of change, the nature of the Australian community and the nature of how we work together. So the Prime Minister has put this country through turmoil such as we have not experienced for I do not know how long—certainly much worse than he left us with in 1983-84.

talk.start.para: —Ha!

—The member for Warringah laughs at that, but he was not in this chamber then. He was not facing the difficulties that we inherited with a $25 billion deficit and an eight per cent drop in the manufacturing work force—all the chaos amongst our community in that period from 1983 onwards. He was not there then. He can laugh about it. It was not amusing then, but it is much worse now.

speech.para: I have found it rather amusing to hear government member after government member talking about this budget in such glowing terms. Let us get back to it: this budget is based on a set of Treasury estimates made in about April—perhaps some made before that but most of them would have made by April to be wrapped up in time for the budget—to estimate income and expenditure in the year starting in July through to June of next year.

I suggest that those government members who are feeling so ebullient go back and look at all the previous estimates for the previous years, because they are worth looking at. While they are looking, I will give them a couple of figures. The forecast for the taxation revenue in the 1995-96 budget was $124.4 billion. The actual income a year and a half later, as measured by the final accounts, was $121.6 billion. That was a shortfall of $2.8 billion. I say to those government members who think they have a surplus, `Keep thinking it while you can because, let me assure you, you do not have one.'

This budget is just as rubbery as the budgets of former Treasurer Lynch and just as rubbery as the last budget of the current Prime Minister. He knew, when he put his budget down in August 1982, that it was already out of date and it was wrong. We all know that these budget forecasts are wrong now. He is going to the polls as quickly as possible because he cannot afford to have Treasury redo the estimates, given the crisis that is occurring in Asia. This budget has underestimated in both its growth figures and its current account balance figures the effects of Asia from which the Treasurer says we are fireproofed. Every serious commentator says that. The reason the dollar has gone down in the overseas money market is due to the underestimation in the budget.

This is a slippery, sneaky budget with figures that are rubbery. We know it, and the commentators know it. If you do not get to an election soon, the whole world will know it because you are now going to require Treasury to publish the forecasts. If the forecasts had been published in 1983, they would have shown the prospect of a $25 billion deficit. Those people who are looking at the budget should keep in mind that the Treasury estimates only need to be out by a very small percentage to make a huge difference in the outcome. I say to all the government members who think what a wonderful thing they have done in projecting a surplus: watch it in about November or December when it has all gone, and do not come in here screaming, whingeing and complaining because you are sitting here now knowing better. You are misleading the public of Australia. You know it and you will not get away with it.

We have heard a lot about tax reform in the last 12 months. Remember that it is almost 12 months to the day—in June last year—since the Prime Minister announced the formation of a task force which would report within two months. But a year later we have not seen one single thing. We now discover from the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) that the government members' committee that was formed was not allowed to make recommendations. It is a good way to have a debate when a government committee cannot give any advice. Not only is the debate not in the public arena but it is obviously not happening within the government itself either.

We need tax reform. The reason we need tax reform is that this is the biggest taxing government on record. This government has ripped more tax out of the Australian people than any government in history—and not just a little bit more but a lot more. Again, going back to the last Labor budget for 1995-96, PAYE taxpayers' revenue was $52 billion. The same projected revenue in the budget in prospect, the budget we are dealing with now, is $65 billion—an increase of $13 billion or 25 per cent. This government has presided over an increase in revenue of 25 per cent from PAYE taxpayers.

Yet in this very same budget—and I would prefer members opposite to actually go and look at the budget for a change rather than read the stuff they are handed out by the Treasurer—let me quote from page 21, Budget Paper No. 4, on budget receipts. I have just quoted the individuals (PAYE) income tax. Let me quote the individuals (Other) income tax; in other words, the non-PAYE personal taxpayers. In the current year it was $8.2 billion; in the year in prospect it is $7.8 billion. On one hand, PAYE taxpayers are paying $5 billion more, or 8.5 per cent; non-PAYE taxpayers are paying $400 million less. This is your third budget—you cannot blame us for that! Non-PAYE taxpayers are paying $400 million less for the year in prospect than in the current year. PAYE taxpayers go up 8.5 per cent and your friends with family trusts go down five per cent—a differential of 13 per cent. We sure do need tax reform.

You are letting the system fall apart with bracket creep and rorting in terms of disposable income as an excuse to justify the ideological GST. This is what you are really doing—and you know it; it is so blatant. If you were genuine about tax reform, there would be a discussion paper out in the open. We at least put out a white paper, which allowed some discussion. A member left your party yesterday because he could not talk about these things. The need for tax reform will always be there, as will reforms in the workplace, education, health and everything else—the world moves on. Tax reform is not a GST. A GST is regressive. It is not an advancement of the tax system; it is a regression of the tax system.

You should go slightly further and think through some aspects of what the GST is about. Some of us have studied the GST proposals, both here and abroad. Business is asking the government to shift the payroll tax off them and to put a tax on services whose major cost is the payroll tax. Effectively a GST shifts a payroll tax from big business to small business at a much higher rate. Anybody who thinks that somehow a GST is about employment should forget it. If you are a supplier of services which are heavily reliant on labour and your consumer chooses to spend the same amount of money per year, what do you do? You reduce your labour costs; that is the only way you can compensate. A tax on services is a tax on labour at a much higher rate.

I have been sitting here in recent days and have been having a real feeling of deja vu. I recall the 1992 and 1993 GST debates in this chamber and the fact that the then opposition were gung-ho about what wonderful ideas they had. They did not understand what on earth they were talking about. I am watching it now sink into the minds of government members. You can almost see the expression of shock, horror come onto their faces as they suddenly start to realise what they have had foisted upon them. As the member for Dickson said, it was `without discussion'—a fait accompli.

This next election will be a bit of deja vu as well. This budget will fall apart before Christmas. Get to the polls soon. If you don't, Treasury will destroy you. But even in the process, this budget is not one to be proud of. It is one to be a bit embarrassed by. It is a sly, sneaky and slippery budget. And it does not deserve the support of the House.

talk.start.para: —It is good to see that the drip theory is working—that members on the other side are seeing taxation reform as a necessity, to overcome the legacy that they have passed on to this government, a legacy of burdening taxpayers in a most inequitable and disadvantageous way. The coalition government is in the process of mapping out a journey that all Australian families can follow. The government is in the process of delivering stability, safety and security to all Australians and this budget is part of that process.

speech.para: Families have benefited and will continue to benefit from the government's last two budgets because we have set the right priorities and they are high on our agenda. Families now have more disposable income—due to no increase in taxes, no new taxes and no overall increase in the taxation burden for families. The family tax initiative is providing an extra $35 a fortnight for eligible one-income fami lies. The combined impact of lower mortgage rates and no increase in the tax burden has put the equivalent of an extra $100 into the pockets of Australian home buyers. Mortgage interest rates have dropped. We now have the lowest home mortgage rates since 1970. Low home interest rates mean more disposable income for home buyers. By repaying the debts of the past, we can set up new opportunities for the future—for the future of our families and our youth.

In the words of the Treasurer (Mr Costello), this year Australia—and the Australian government—will live within its means. It will live within its means not because of any increase in taxes, but by getting government spending under control. We all reap the rewards of this controlled spending because this government is clamping down on people not entitled to benefits. Those people cheating on the system is one area of keeping spending under control. When we started, we clamped down to the tune of $28 million a week. With Jocelyn Newman as our Minister for Social Security, that is the kind of issue that is reaching into the heartland of the Australian community. People in the community were fed up. They did not want to see these rip-offs continuing. After all, it was their hard-earned money being wasted by rorters. Labor let this practice continue for 13 years.

It was also the Labor government that let the time-wasting, soul-destroying, incentive-breaking habit of `revolving door' labour market programs continue. Labor did not even blink an eye when unemployment hit 11 per cent. We did not hear, `Shock, horror!' from the Labor government. Let us face it, they had no idea how to solve this growing problem. This government took on the task of reforming labour market programs, but not just in the marketplace: schools are also becoming a part of this reform process. What better way to achieve long-term changes than to foster a sound work ethic in the minds of our youngsters? Instead of accepting the gloom-and-doom `as good as it gets' attitude, we can offer hope and a better future—a future based on generating the belief amongst our youth that they will be prepared for employment through their schooling years, and that there will be jobs when they finish.

A key priority of this government has been to expand employment opportunities. We are committed to ensuring major improvements in education and training and ensuring vocational education subjects are provided in all our educational institutions. I am fiercely proud of the fact that in my electorate of Bowman, Wynnum State High School, Alexandra Hills State High School, Wellington Point State High School, Iona College, Wynnum North State High School, Cleveland State High School, Carmel College and Moreton Bay College all provide curriculum opportunities that focus on employment outcomes for their students.

No longer do students attend school for purely academic pursuits. Vocational education options are a significant part of real choices for our students, particularly in my local area. Our schools have benefited and will benefit over the next four years in accessing part of the $340 million allocated to address the issues associated with youth unemployment. Of particular merit is Wynnum State High School's joint education initiative program, boasting 10 certificate subjects and strong student participation and support. I commend the efforts of our school communities in providing a diverse range of educational opportunities for both vocational and academic careers.

Workplace learning is developing as a beneficial option for many students returning to post-compulsory schooling and our TAFE colleges also provide a wide variety of practical employment courses. The long-term unemployed and youth of my electorate are clearly benefiting from the work for the dole program. Two groups—the Moreton Bay Marine Association and Wynnum Enterprises—have succeeded in providing worthwhile community activities to assist our unemployed. With people such as Craig Belmano, David Gasteen, Rob Wolski and Paul Ryan coordinating these groups, they have provided excellent opportunities for skill development and community assistance while fulfilling their tasks in the Wynnum and Bayside areas. A street poll in a recent edition of the Wyn num Herald asked a random selection of shoppers, `Should unemployed people have to work for the dole?' The newspaper ran the following responses:
1. "Yes. They shouldn't be able to just sit there and get paid for it."
2. "Yes, because it improves your self esteem so you are more likely to get a job."
3. "Yes, because if you don't do something you get into a rut. You need to keep your mind active."
Not only do these projects enjoy wide support, but also the environment and the community benefit from their continuing efforts. I wish them every success in future applications for funding.

Job placement and employment and training have also come under close scrutiny. With new Job Network groups such as Drake, Sarina Russo, Bridgeworks, Leonie Green, Employment National, Bayside Adolescent Boarding Inc. and Trevor and Clare Sterling, more options are now available for our unemployed to provide them with real work opportunities—not just the two CES offices that we had previously in the local area.

Others who missed out on the tender have not given up. They continue to provide complementary employment preparation assistance. REPS of Cleveland and Wynnum-Manly Workplace Training both offer literacy options and up-skilling in subtendering for some of these employment agencies. The Job Club of Wynnum is keeping its options open to assist local unemployed as well. The new youth allowance, which simplifies income support arrangements, encourages young Australians to further their education and develop basic skills needed to secure their future. Students who may be at risk due to a variety of factors, including family circumstance, social conflict, personal neglect, family abuse and criminal activity, will benefit from pilot projects.

The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) recently visited my electorate to discuss specific strategies at a local level with Capalaba State High School. The administrators and coordinators were in agreement that these pilot projects should be available. These services will go a long way to securing a combined effort to assist students returning to school for vocational opportunities that will lead to better employment.

The health and wellbeing of our young people has not gone unnoticed as $80 million will be provided over four years to enhance preventative health programs. A school education campaign to warn our children of the dangers of smoking will be part of the $6.1 million awareness campaign to reduce tobacco related illnesses.

The recent drug summits, coordinated by myself in conjunction with community based organisations such as Queensland Health, the Queensland Police, the Redland Shire Community Safety Consultative Committee, Life Education and Save the Children Residential Care, aim to secure funding for regional drug education assistance. It is hoped that some of the $215 million provided for the national illicit drug strategy over the next five years will be channelled into local areas of need.

Mr Deputy Speaker, what better asset to invest in than our youth? Their health and wellbeing are our primary concern. Parents need assurance that all levels of government provide real opportunities for the future of their children. That is what this government is all about—future opportunities. Paying back Labor's debt provides Australians, young and old, with opportunities. And remember, once we pay back our inherited debt, we will not have to raise $8 billion in taxes to pay our interest bill. We can spend that money on schools, health and education. The opportunities are endless.

This government inherited a debt of $96 billion. Why should our children inherit this debt? Why should our children's children inherit this debt? Whilst unemployment is still too high, it is now the lowest it has been in Australia since 1990. We are laying the foundations for continuing jobs growth through sound economic policies. I am proud to represent my electorate of Bowman in a government dedicated to building a better and brighter future for our children and our children's children.

talk.start.para: —It was interesting what the member for Bowman (Mrs West) said about the so-called debt they inherited. She claimed it was $96 billion. What she did not say in the next sentence is how much it has gone up since then. It is another $26 billion or $28 billion, from memory. You know the old debt truck going around Australia? If you are going to quote things, you need to finish the quote and say that it has gone up, under this so-called government, by another $26 billion to $28 billion.

speech.para: History will show that this budget was somewhat of a sleight of hand, like the speech of the honourable member for Bowman. We are now starting to see the real nasties—not coming out so much from the budget just brought down but from the preceding two budgets. I listened to the honourable member for Bowman saying how families are going to benefit from this budget. I will tell you one area where the families will not benefit, and that is the area of the youth allowance, which was announced a couple of budgets ago but starts on 1 July. This measure will hit middle and low income families. The electorate of Throsby, with its high rate of youth unemployment will be particularly hard hit. It contains only middle and low income families, and many will be forced into poverty, with the government withdrawing income support for their 18- to 21-year-olds.

While there has been much criticism of the youth homeless allowance, I predict a huge rise in the youth homeless allowance after 1 July. Those opposite make much about the sanctity of the family, and constantly parade their family values, yet see nothing wrong with disadvantaging working-class families by withdrawing income support for 18- to 21-year-olds. Perhaps—and who am I to argue?—this is a disguised measure to keep these young people at home.

One of the proudest boasts of the Labor government during our years in power was what we did for child care. Despite the comments of those opposite, I remember what the child-care situation was in my own electorate and throughout Australia when I was first elected in 1983. Under Labor, I saw the growth of good, affordable child care, and it saddens me immensely to see the attacks that this government has made on child care. It also amazes me when I hear those opposite parrot their weasel words about child care. The simple fact is that Labor put child care on the agenda. It was affordable, it was accessible, and you have attacked it and made it non-affordable for so many families.

With their cuts to child care, this government is creating a generation of latchkey kids. Only last week a child-care worker at a centre in my electorate was telling me that people are withdrawing their children from centres because of the increase in fees and are presenting the children with a key to the door. We are returning to the 1970s when latchkey kids were commonplace because of the lack of child-care facilities. The Labor government provided the centres and now this government, with the withdrawing of operational subsidies and substantial fee increases, is returning us to the latchkey generation, with all the inherent problems. So much for this government's so-called commitment to families.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you probably do not know but it would be appreciated by members from New South Wales, Throsby is basically a working-class electorate. We do not have the high income earners, the high rollers, but we do have lots of what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) refers to as battlers. We do have battlers in Throsby, and their battles have been made even greater by the uncaring, anti-family policies of this government in power.

In a policy of pure spite, federal government services in Throsby have been withdrawn. I remember the Liberal candidate for the seat of Throsby making his one visit to the electorate before the election. They could not find a Liberal candidate in Throsby to stand—I do not think there are any Liberals in Throsby—so they imported a chicken farmer from the outer suburbs of Sydney. When the chicken farmer came to the electorate, the big issue for some time in the Dapto area—which is one of the fastest growing parts of my electorate, given the developments in west Dapto—had been to have a Medicare office located in Dapto.

I remember that pensioner groups and others had been running a campaign for some time to get a Medicare office. They had been to see me. I had brought them here on a couple of deputations. It was explained to the people that, with the growth in west Dapto, they would get a Medicare office but not immediately. Well, our chicken man, the Liberal candidate, came to Dapto and stood outside the Dapto post office—which, incidentally, has been closed by the Liberal government. He said that if the Liberal Party were elected—he did not say `if he was elected' because he knew it was a pretty uphill battle in Dapto, even for a chicken farmer—then Dapto would get their Medicare office.

As we all know, as Australia knows to its cost, the Liberal Party was elected, but what happened to the promised Medicare office in Dapto? `Was it built?' I hear you ask. Is it up and running? Is it processing the forms and so on? No, it must not have been a core promise. Not only was the Medicare office not built but, in a fit of pure spite, the closest Medicare office to the proposed one, the office at Warrawong, was closed. To add insult to injury, the next Medicare office at Corrimal, in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), was also closed. So, instead of a new Medicare office being opened, as promised by the Liberal Party—a non-core promise—two Medicare offices were closed.

The Illawarra region, covering the electorates of Cunningham and Throsby, is one of the most ethnically diverse regions in Australia. We had a fully functioning Immigration office. Hardly was the poll declared when it was announced that it would be closed. Now people from our region, if they want any information or need to go for an interview, have to travel to Rockdale in Sydney. What in the Illawarra would have been an hour's visit to our local office now involves a one-day trip to Sydney.

The slash and burn policy of this crowd does not stop there. Centrelink at Warrawong was also closed. The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service at Shellharbour Square was closed. The CES offices at Shellharbour, Dapto and Warrawong have been closed and only last week there was a threat of closure of the Centrelink teleservice centre at Warilla. Yet we hear those opposite come in here and parrot how wonderful this government is.

If one looks at the speeches by the member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash), one will see that she always waffles on about how she has had no complaints about the fear and uncertainty of those approaching nursing homes in her electorate or how the young people from Nowra are dancing with joy because they are working for the dole. Mind you, she has been known to write the odd letter getting stuck into the government on dental care, but she will not come into this chamber and give the government a serve on their disgraceful role in regard to dental care and a whole range of other issues.

It amazes me when I listen to those opposite speak. How can they come in here and not properly represent their electorate? Why can they not articulate the problems that are being put to them? I do not believe the electorate of Gilmore is all that much different from my electorate. Yet I do know the problems with nursing homes and other problems that have been put to me. Why do they have their slavish adherence to the Howard-Costello line, which will cost them dearly at the next election? The other thing you hear is that they come in here parroting the old party line. Why can they not debate these issues? Why must they always so slavishly and foolishly follow their party leaders?

The one thing that really surprises me in this parliament is the hatred of those opposite for the trade union movement. I sometimes wonder, given they so often have a small business background, whether any of them have ever spoken with a trade unionist. It would be wonderful if we had reached that utopia where there was no need for the protection of the trade union movement, but unfortunately that utopia is still a long way away. Hardly a week goes by when someone does not come into my office to tell me how they have not got their entitlements or how they have been discriminated against in the workplace.

I am not talking about the situations of the Cobar or Woodlawn miners or the Grafton meatworkers, or even Clutha. They have been shocking indictments of this government which have received wide publicity. I am talking about the ordinary worker, such as the guy who came to see me last week who had a job as a courier. Part of the job deal was that he could not belong to a union. Given the high unemployment level in the Illawarra, this married person with two young children took the job paying $10 per hour with no overtime and no penalty rates. He was lifting a large crate which fell. He fell and hurt his back and, of course, he got up and continued working. Next morning he could not get out of bed. He was put on sick leave. Then after six months he was sacked from his job. This is what is constantly happening. That is why we so often need trade unions.

I have no argument when people say they should have the right to belong or not to belong to a trade union. That is fine, but I make the point that, if you do not belong to a trade union, do not have your greedy hand out to get the benefits that the trade unionists or their unions get for you. If you do not belong to a union, you should not be entitled to any of the benefits that come from union membership.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to tell the House that the 1998-99 budget has been warmly received in my electorate of Swan over the past week and a half and I know of no phone calls to my office that have had any criticism of the third budget from this highly responsible government. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) makes some very good points. I was a union representative myself, so I am not down on unions.
—Which union?

—I was a local representative for the Teachers Union. But I have to say to the member for Throsby: you have just come out with a lot of ideological claptrap. But, anyway, you are entitled to your opinion.

speech.para: The third budget in the first term of the Howard government epitomises what good government is all about—responsible expenditure of taxpayers' money, ensuring that this country does not live beyond its means in this region of uncertainty. To deliver a budget surplus in our first parliamentary term, after 13 years of reckless spending by the Labor Party, is something of which every member on this side of the House can be justifiably proud. I am sure the member for Moore (Mr Filing) would also say that it is a very responsible budget. The old analogy of the speeding ship hurtling towards the deadly iceberg is in mid-story. We might have stopped the ship, but now we have to concentrate on turning it around and sailing to better chartered waters.

talk.start.para: —Presumably without hitting the iceberg.

—Absolutely. You have seen Titanic . Better still, it is ordinary Australians around this country and throughout my electorate of Swan who are reaping the benefits of getting back in the black and back on track. The 12,000 families in Swan who are currently paying off mortgages are saving on average $3,800 a year because of this government's responsible economic policies that have produced the lowest home interest rates since 1969. The pollsters are reporting that this is the best received budget in years. The member for Brand, Kim Beazley, and the ALP have not been able to dent it, despite their best efforts.

speech.para: The Australian people are pleased with this budget. Under the coalition government, families are now more than $300 a month better off than they were when they were paying off their mortgage under Labor. This is cold hard cash back in their pockets—something they understand very well.

There are 7,000 small businesses in Swan. They are now paying just one-third of the interest on their overdrafts that they were paying under the high debt interest rate policies of the previous government. As small business is our largest employer, this is great news for job seekers.

This budget, along with the two previous budgets, has put Australia in a strong position to weather the economic storm and the currency crises which have plagued our Asian neighbours. When we came into office in 1996, no-one predicted what would unfold in the Asian markets, but by paying off Australia's debt—paying off Labor's debt—our house is now in order.

I shudder to think what would have happened if Labor had been voted in for another term and they had continued on their big spending, high debt merry-go-round. We would have been a partner to the Asian meltdown. Despite creating a $2.7 billion surplus, this budget continues to focus on important issues for those in my electorate: families, older Australians, health, small business, and employment growth.

Government spending as a proportion of the nation's total income, measured by the gross domestic product, has reduced from nearly 27 per cent to around 24.6 per cent this year. This represents about $12.7 billion less in government outlays and this government projects that spending will be reduced further as a proportion of GDP by 2001-02, down to around 22.8 per cent. That is a great achievement.

The message is clear: good economic management can deliver a surplus, while still providing for appropriate and adequate government spending. The government has put in place better controls on spending and has not raised revenue through higher taxes. Again, there have been no new taxes. This is miraculous—for the third budget in a row, there have been no new taxes, no increase in taxes, under this government.

The opposition can claim there have been harsh cuts and reductions. The member for Throsby tried that line. But the reality is that welfare spending has increased. A larger and larger share of the budget under this government has been allocated to welfare spending—to nearly 38 per cent of the budget. But this government's approach to welfare is markedly different from the opposition's. It is clearly a hand-up, not a hand-out, approach. This government's spending on welfare assists those who have helped themselves, like the superannuants, but who still clearly need government assistance. This is particularly evident with the introduction of the seniors health care card, which will assist around 220,000 self-funded retirees.

Families, importantly, benefit greatly from this government's spending on welfare. I refer to family allowances, family tax payments, parenting payments, child- care payments, maternity allowances and sole parent benefits. These schemes together receive a significant proportion of this budget and will assist families to bring up our greatest asset, our children, who are the future, naturally, of this great country.

The unemployed continue to receive assistance, but coupled with the government's initiatives involving mutual obligation, work for the dole, volunteer work and so on, and an improved and streamlined employment agency scheme called Job Network, opportunities for the unemployed will be greater. This is already starting to be seen, with the lowest unemployment rate since 1990. Again, it is another fantastic achievement. We are taking the problem of unemployment seriously. We are not going to throw money at schemes to keep people out of the real unemployment figures, as the previous Labor government did. Unemployment is now at its lowest level since before Keating gave us the recession that he said we had to have, and we are looking at a target of three per cent growth which, by the way, is higher than the figure for the United States, Britain and most of Asia.
Nearly 400 World War II veterans in Swan will benefit from the budget announcement that they will receive the gold card.

talk.start.para: —They deserve it.

—Absolutely, they do deserve it; the member for Moore is quite correct. These veterans spent quite a number of their younger years risking their lives for this country and now, at an average age of 76, it is time to take care of them. They will receive comprehensive health care as part of this package. Labor chose to ignore this section of our community who have lobbied for this measure for years. It has been a priority for this government, and it has been delivered.

speech.para: It is ironic that in my home state of Western Australia, the largest number of veterans to benefit from this budget measure live in the seat of Brand. I wonder how the member for Brand is going to explain the fact that he did not deliver to the veterans, but that it took a coalition government to do so.

The benefits of the Commonwealth seniors health care card are now being enjoyed by up to 3,000 self-funded retirees in Swan, many of whom have already contacted my office expressing their gratitude for the government's move. Most of these retirees believe that this budget measure to provide them with cheaper medicines at last recognises this sometimes forgotten section of our community. A common question asked of me is: `Why should we scrimp and save to make sure we can look after ourselves in retirement, not go on overseas holidays and live modestly, if we always seem to be penalised compared to pensioners? We've paid our taxes all our lives and we still pay tax.' By lifting the income limits for a health care card to $40,000 for a single retiree and $67,000 for couples, we are able to help this group now, as well as remove a disincentive for those coming close to retirement to save.

talk.start.para: —That is another good measure.

—Absolutely. This budget also recognises that younger Australians face many challenges. As a former teacher, I know only too well how important it is for our children to be able to read and write. This budget provides $176 million for literacy programs in our primary schools. The national literacy and numeracy plan aims to have every child in Australia reading and writing properly by the time they leave primary school. The funding will help to establish assessments for literacy standards for all children in years 3 and 5, as well as providing professional development programs for teachers to help them identify children with literacy and numeracy problems. Their older brothers and sisters will also benefit from the budget with more government-funded university places than ever before—in fact, up 10,000 on 1996 figures.

speech.para: This budget puts Australia back on track but there is still a lot of work to do. With gun law reform, native title, aged care reform and welfare fraud compliance measures, this government has proven that it is not afraid to tackle the big issues that many might put in the too-hard basket or simply ignore. The Howard government is willing to tackle these issues if it means that the outcomes will benefit ordinary Australians now and well into the future.

That is why we must introduce tax reform. Everyone in Australia—including the welfare sector, as well as the business community—recognises the need to reform our outdated and unfair tax system. Labor has chosen to put its head in the sand over tax reform. I think they are selling Australia short with their attitude to this issue. Even their own supporters must feel let down.

We do need to reform both the direct tax system and the indirect tax system. Both are unfair, inconsistent, grossly outdated and remove incentives to work and save. In fact, ordinary Australians, especially middle income earners, pay too much income tax. You do not have to be an economist to work that out. All you have to do is earn 1.5 times the average weekly wage to experience paying nearly half of what you earn in tax.

High rates of direct tax encourage those who can afford it—the millionaires the Labor Party wants to keep in the present system—to avoid paying their fair share of tax, and it puts the burden on everyone else. I would like to have spoken in detail about the hidden tax system and such things as wholesale sales tax and the rates that were left to us by Labor and sales tax costs and the system of sales tax that really was invented for a time well before now; but, noticing the time, I will move on. I make a commitment to my constituents in Swan that, before the next election, they will know clearly and precisely the details of the Howard government's tax reform package. I will do what it takes to make sure my electorate can make an informed decision when they vote for tax reform at the next election. I believe that when more information comes out about the detail of the government's tax reform and the electorate compares it with the opposition's belligerent, inflexible attitude towards tax they will embrace the reforms as they have embraced the most recent budget. I commend the budget to this House.

talk.start.para: —I was interested to hear the comments of the member for Swan (Mr Randall), and he is entitled to take some credit for the good measures in the budget. I have been campaigning for some of those for some time, and I am pleased to see them eventually come to pass, particularly the gold card for World War II veterans and the seniors card or health care card for self-funded retirees within particular income thresholds.

speech.para: I want to mention a couple of things the member for Swan has spoken about. One of those is the question of interest rates. There is no doubt the government have been more fiscally responsible than the previous government, and I commend them for it. But, if one looks at the Economist magazine and looks at the table which samples a basket of developed nations and their interest rates, one will see that Australia still has the highest prime rate of the countries sampled in that particular basket which, in its own way, puts the interest rates back into context. They are certainly a lot lower than they were under Labor.
Mr Randall interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The point is that, if you are endeavouring to make Australia a competitive nation, able to compete with its neighbouring countries in trade and other forms of economic activity, quite clearly you have to have competitive interest rates. All I am saying is that, if you were to compare them with the countries that the Economist magazine chooses to compare Australia with, you would see that Australia still has the highest prime rate of those sample countries. I am not making a harsh criticism. I am just saying we should put it back into context. One of the problems of taking credit for lower interest rates when they are low is that you then have to take the blame when they go back up again. One of the possible consequences of the Asian meltdown is that interest rates may start to rise in the medium future. Will you accept responsibility for that? I doubt it; no-one generally does. But the point is that they, in themselves, are possible consequences of events that are outside the control of the government and, therefore, all one can do—as you have rightly said—is trim the sails of the government's sailing boat to ensure that it is in the right position to take full advantage of whatever economic conditions prevail in our region.

speech.para: The second thing I want to mention is in relation to tax reform, and I imagine there will be tax cuts included. I want to make a couple of observations. I recollect Fightback quite clearly, as I am sure you do, Mr Deputy Speaker. I recollect quite clearly back in 1990 or 1991, when the Fightback package arrived at Parliament House, we were all given a copy and essentially told to learn it and go out and promote it. In my view, after that experience, that is not the way to formulate policy.

One of the things that concerns me is what I have heard about the so-called tax task force activities and the government's attitude to the tax task force—whether or not, for instance, the government is seriously considering the tax task force's work and its possible recommendations as part of the considerations for the tax reform package. I very much doubt it. Being a bit of a cynic and having seen programs like Yes, Minister and Yes, Prime Minister, I would think that when the suggestions go into the suggestion box they will probably go straight down into a shredder. I suspect that a tax reform package is going to arrive at Parliament House—somewhat similar to the Fightback package in its presentation—for members to go out and promote in their electorates as part of their election campaigning. I hope not. I hope the coalition has learned from that particular era because that, I felt, was a mistake.

At the time, in the euphoria of the release of Fightback back in 1990, when it was seen to be a plan that could solve some of Australia's serious economic problems, we overlooked the fact that in the end policy making has to be as closely connected as possible to the people we represent. You cannot make policy an abstract, you cannot formulate policy as though it were some sort of philosophical fight, because the people will not accept it—and they are far smarter than governments sometimes care to admit. There is a very strong prevailing commonsense in the Australian community, and the Australian community reacted to the attitude, the arrogance and the dismissive attitude of the previous administration by throwing it out in a big way and electing a large number of coalition members as well as a record number of Independent members—numbers that have been augmented in recent months—and in fact the largest number of Independent members in the House of Representatives since Federation.

In speaking to this bill, I want to start by commending the government for having as its guiding light a determination to return our economy to surplus and a sense of fiscal responsibility. We cannot ever hope that this country will live up to its potential unless we are able to pay our own way and get away from the spiralling debt of the past. It is unnerving, however, to have watched as the term `fiscal responsibility' has become a mantra for the Howard government, where ministers and backbenchers recite the term as if it is a known truth and believe that simply by attaching it to a policy endeavour that makes it a good policy.

I have watched as small `l' liberal policies and philosophies, promises and undertakings have been dropped by the wayside in the name of some fiscal responsibility, and it has become almost a form of political correctness, rivalling the mantras of previous Labor administrations. But, to their credit, the people have taken the Howard government at its word that the national debt must be reduced and that, in doing so, some necessary suffering will come to pass. However, now that we are told that the structure is in place for economic revitalisation, instead of sharing in the fruits born of hardship, the community is being told to remain vigilant and not to relax its adherence to the commandments of fiscal responsibility.

At the same time, the government has made deep, substantial cuts to spending on health, education, aged care, child care, disability spending, law and order and the like. Although I intend to participate in the process, one has to question the overwhelming importance of the projects of national significance that are going to be funded through the program in members' electorates.

Unfortunately, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, having been in this place for some time, it is difficult at times not to reinforce the public's perception that the government is out of step with the community and that it is lost in the mire as it follows its own agenda of reform. The Howard government has asked the Australian people to endure the hardship caused by its program of fiscal responsibility without really explaining the fine print and telling us what it is and what it will mean. Further to that, now that we can achieve a surplus of $2.7 billion, even after its $1 billion natural heritage exercise, it still proposes to deny average Australians a direct share in the rewards they logically expect through government programs.

I have spoken a number of times about the results of Hugh Mackay's research in his latest book Generations. I note with great interest that the government has finally picked up on my comments and, I must say, Mr Mackay's writings. For instance, I now see that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is using his slogan of security, safety and stability. Those words actually echo the comments made by Hugh Mackay in his latest work. One of the fundamental points made by Hugh Mackay in his work is that the community is deeply affected by a very strong, underlying sense of insecurity.

One of the problems with reform programs is that reform can at times feed insecurity. People who have become used to particular programs or policies suddenly find they have changed and that the acronyms have changed. Let us face it, when you ask people what particular acronyms actually refer to, they find it extraordinarily difficult at times to know what you are talking about. The officials responsible for administering programs get to learn the acronyms, programs, policies, fine print and, of course, the interpretation of the law. All of a sudden, the reform programs come in and they have to change. With the best of intentions, that leads to a further sense of insecurity.

I am glad to see from the Prime Minister's recent statements in this place that he is now intent on responding to the electorate's feeling of insecurity. Obviously he or one of his staff has now read Hugh Mackay's work. But the Prime Minister needs to pay more attention if this is indeed an election year. He of all people should acknowledge the reality that part of the reason for the current government's initial popularity is the unpopularity of the one it replaced. That initial impression has been replaced with a growing cynicism that some of the change that has been meted out to the community has not been worth the suffering. The failure of the government to carry out its election commitments through to workable legislation has further damaged this.

While the Keating government could be criticised for caring more about and measuring its success by its volume of spending rather than the quality of spending, the Howard government is equally to be criticised for its policy of determining its degree of fiscal responsibility in terms of the volume of its cuts to spending rather than their quality or uniformity. You do not have to look at the government's philosophical attack on welfare spending to find questionable funding cuts.

I will give a very brief example of a funding cut in my own area. It relates to the CSIRO laboratory at Marmion. Back in the days when the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) was the Minister for Science and Technology, he promised that this would remain as one of the most significant contributions on the part of the government to scientific research of the ocean environment and to fishing management research. I was recently contacted by a constituent regarding government funding for the facility of around $3.6 million about 15 months ago. The money had been spent to upgrade the facility to allow scientists and researchers there to better study marine ecology, especially important to WA with its extensive fishing interests and offshore gas exploration and mining. The problem is that the improvements have been made, but nothing more. On investigation I was advised that the offices are closing down or essentially becoming dormant. The lab now concentrates on marine ecology in the North West Shelf area, and it has had some interaction with the petroleum and gas divisions of CSIRO. Most of the fish species research is done elsewhere by universities and state fisheries organisations. This project was to look at external earnings from its research on marine ecology, including environmental impact studies, through harvesting or industry placement. So far, however, it has done no research and it appears the project has lost its way.

The explanation I received was that, `The government has cut operating costs for the CSIRO, creating a situation where the Division of Marine Research is faced with a financial deficit that had to be addressed.' The federal government still refuses to provide any money to the laboratory to keep it operating properly. This has caused a decision by CSIRO to close its coastal ecology subprogram and to redeploy its people to other sites. There is a risk of up to 10 potential redundancies from 280 throughout the division.

The $3.6 million was allocated for the building of hardware, tanks, pumps, pipes and research stations within the building, but the government did not allocate anything for ongoing costs. The building/research areas were completed early last year, and have been undergoing proving work since then. No actual research seems to have been done at all. There are currently 13 researchers there, with facilities for up to 60 to 70. The crazy thing is that we have this wonderful, world-class facility but apparently no money to operate it. The CSIRO's solution is to now go forward and negotiate cooperative partnerships with universities, CALM, WA fisheries and other state departments such as the WA museum, et cetera, to share the facility for research purposes as a means of keeping it going.

Despite the government's somewhat unthinking financial cuts, the situation may be salvaged. The potential is there for a very productive industry research entity which could generate significant income and valuable productive research either to exploit the marine ecology sustainably or to best develop multiple use strategies. This will depend on negotiations between CSIRO and the other entities. If the situation is salvaged, it will be down to the action of the CSIRO, not the government.

How many other stories like this can be told about the Howard government? I make the observation—because the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is here—that the National Party for a long time, probably since the early inception of the CSIRO, has very strongly supported its objectives and has ensured over the years that it has been properly funded. All I can do is urge National Party members who have a commitment to the CSIRO's important contribution to scientific and agricultural research in this country to pressure the government to make sure that the particular industries I have mentioned are not let down by the closure of, or further reductions in, facilities at this important research station.

I now want to talk about vertical fiscal imbalance because this is the most important facet, in my view, of any proposal for tax reform. I have raised this issue a number of times. The West Australian newspaper had some very interesting articles criticising the Liberal Party members in this place from Western Australia who have failed to properly represent the cause for a better deal for Western Australia from its tax revenues.

We have a situation where, in essence, Western Australia has lost a calculated $778 million of what would be considered to be its fair share of taxation revenue over the past five years. In terms of vertical fiscal imbalance, I want to talk about getting a better deal for WA. Western Australia needs to have a better deal in order to become the dynamic economy that it should be. If we can liberate the economy of Western Australia from the shackles of the Commonwealth-state fiscal relations at present, Western Australia would become one of the great financial and economic centres in our region—the Indian Ocean region. Until recently, this region has been largely ignored by the Commonwealth government as far as economic potential is concerned.
I subscribe to some of the views expressed by Professor Cliff Walsh at the fourth annual micro-economic reform conference. He said:

. . . to limit excessive coercion and increase democratic participation through multiple access to government, it would seem essential that, to the greatest extent possible, all governments should have independent access to revenues to enable them to respond to citizen preferences and that they then be capable of being held appropriately accountable for their use of those revenue sources.

In a simpler form, this means the converse of the cry from the Boston Tea Party immediately prior to the American Revolution—`No taxation without representation.' The converse of that is `No representation without taxation'.

Whenever one of my constituents in Western Australia complains to me about the absence of a particular community facility or service, I contact the relevant state minister and immediately get the cliched response, `Oh, it's Canberra's fault. Go to Canberra and tell them.' So I did. I took them at their word and I came here as part of my duties and asked the Prime Minister what I should tell my constituents, given that we have been dudded out of $778 million. He stood there and said, `Tell them to vote Liberal. What is the problem? WA is doing very nicely indeed.'

The West Australian, which had been following this quite closely, then asked those Liberal members who had said, `We don't actually grandstand in the House about vertical fiscal imbalance—we chew the ear of the Prime Minister and his senior ministers in private.' They said, `As you have been chewing his ear so much, how come you came up with such an answer?' They said, `Well, you don't expect him to know everything.'

In essence, this means that Western Australian ministers and members of the Western Australian parliament are not accountable for the lack of services that they provide and are responsible for. They say that it is Canberra's fault. Canberra then says that it is their fault. As a consequence, my constituents get nowhere. When they want a new school or the railway line extended, or they need more police—as they desperately do—the old answer comes back, `It's not our fault, it's Canberra's.'

This is the problem. Until we reform Commonwealth-state fiscal relations by giving the states a proportion of income tax collection for their own purposes, we will have this age-old handball exercise ad nauseam. Unfortunately, the people who lose out are people like my constituents in the developing areas of my electorate who cannot get schools for their children, who are faced with virtually the lowest ratio of police to citizens in the state, and who have the situation where the local Joondalup Health Campus as it is now called—it used to be called the Wanneroo Hospital, which I thought was a perfectly reasonable name for it—has cancelled non-essential or elective surgery because of funding cuts and cost overruns.

The citizens ask me, as their local member, `Why is this so?' When I ask the question here I am told that everything is okay. They say, `That is their fault because they are not administering their grants properly. Go back and see them.' When I see them, they say, `Go back to Canberra and blame them.' This has to change. It is childish and unproductive. It has led to the situation where Western Australia, which has the potential to become one of the great economic powerhouses of our region, has been shackled by a system that has been going on for years and years and is in essence a straitjacket on the sort of development that we want to see in our state. We need devolution and reform of the taxation system—not arguing the toss over whether or not you have a broad based cascading consumption tax or a retail services tax or you merely reform the wholesale sales tax—where we fundamentally reform the relations between the Commonwealth and the states.

In conclusion, as representatives there is no greater task for us than to make appropriate representations on behalf of our communities, our citizens, our voters. As the result of a tax reform package that really works, I want to have a situation where I can go back to my citizens and we can identify where the problem really exists and fix it so that those services, those things that they require or need or have an expectation of, can be provided at the best possible cost and in the most efficient way. In the end, what we need is a new way of looking at the relations between the Commonwealth and the states. It is long overdue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The most appropriate aspect of this budget is that unemployment in my electorate of Griffith has dropped to below seven per cent and, in some suburbs, to below five per cent. This is a fact overlooked by members of the opposition as they champion their reign of high interest rates, high unemployment and an ever-increasing welfare bill that was sending Australia and all Australians bankrupt.

speech.para: I am fast coming to the conclusion that the Labor Party and its policies are the dinosaurs of Australian politics. I am convinced that the opposition is so firmly entrenched in its socialistic beliefs that even its proven failure to balance the taxpayers' books has not yet hit home. The fact that other socialist governments such as the Soviet Union have crumbled in the last decade and are still desperately struggling to rise out of the disaster of their socialist policies also seems to have gone unnoticed. Times and technology have changed, but apparently not the Labor Party.

In listening to the opposition's speakers during the last two days, I heard a constant, unbroken theme—that is, this government is to be damned for not spending enough and Labor will do better by spending more. The former minister for health, the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), accused this government of `ripping funds out of hospitals', while repeating that old Labor mantra—that is, this government is attempting to undermine Medicare. Nothing could be further from the truth. Medicare remains unchanged, as promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

The crisis in our public hospital system, referred to by the former Labor health minister, was not of this government's making. Under both a Labor state government and a Labor federal government, Queensland had the worst—and I mean the worst—and the longest hospital waiting lists in Australia. The coalition government has turned that completely around, and today Queensland has the best waiting list in the nation. A typical example of just how Labor underfunded our public health system in Queensland was one Queensland hospital where patients on the vital category 1 list had to wait for treatment longer than the recommended 30-day period. Today, under the coalition, there is no-one waiting on the infamous category 1 list.

As for the so-called slashing of funds to public hospitals statement by the former health minister, the opposition gets it wrong again. In 1993, the Labor government gave the states $25 billion to run their public hospitals. In this budget, the Howard government has committed $30 billion. All I can say is that, typically, Labor cannot get its sums right. Queensland's public health system is heading into the year 2000 with a $2.4 billion building program which will see my constituents able to use facilities that will rank with the best in the world. That is this government's contribution to public hospitals—a complete turnaround from Labor's worst waiting lists in Australia, as I said before, to the best in Australia.

Next, let us take a look at unemployment. We all want to see an economic environment that creates job opportunities for everyone. But Labor did not manage to do it during its 13 years of social programs which created a culture of training for jobs that did not exist. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) made the accusation that this government is `brutal in its disregard for the unemployed'. I beg his pardon. This government has reduced our national unemployment figure, not by prolonging training programs that lead to more training programs but by totally reforming a tired and worn-out system.

The coalition's Job Network has utilised the technology of today to make a wider range of jobs available to every job seeker who enters the new Centrelink one-stop shop. The former CES system presented to job seekers only 20 per cent of available jobs, at best. Today, the coalition's Job Network, which utilises the skills and talents of professional job brokers, presents 80 per cent of available jobs to its clients.

Our vocational training program in schools is more than a pathway into a career. It is a complete social reform. Students are now given a good, productive reason to finish their secondary education. The government's new apprenticeship and traineeship programs allow for employers and employees to cut through the red tape and get down to the reality, which is a career path for young people and a return to fulfilling an urgent need for trained tradespeople. These are budget measures which the Howard government put in place with the first budget, measures which proved to be a firm foundation for the second, and now the third, budget. The result in my electorate has been a drop in unemployment figures to below six per cent in the majority of suburbs and to below five per cent in many others.

The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) has had the temerity to claim that this government's child-care reforms are `disastrous'. The only people who are claiming we have cut funds to child care for Australians are the Labor Party. The truth is that, under the Howard government budget reforms, more women with dependent children now have access to government funding for child care. The Labor Party, with its casual attitude to book work, omits the fact that more women are now working, both full time and part time, than three years ago. In fact, the increase is some 36,000 since April 1995.

Under Labor, the system did not take this increase into account, nor was it fair. Labor provided a subsidy to community based centres, which provided less than 30 per cent of all centre based places. This same subsidy was not available to the remaining 70 per cent of places, which means that 70 per cent of people needing child care were not receiving the government's subsidy—a total of some 70,000 families.

The Howard government redressed that imbalance and spread the subsidy to enable an extra 51,000 families access to government funded child-care assistance. The truth is that the Howard government is today spending more on child care than Labor did in 1995-96 and the funding has been directed to low income families, those who need the most help.
The member for Hotham summed up the opposition's attitude to spending Australia's hard-earned dollars. He said in his speech:
In government Labor was prepared to spend to achieve economic growth.

Spend it certainly did, but at the detriment of not only our economic growth but also our social growth. Just how can a couple afford to buy a house when the interest rates rocket to 17½ per cent, as they did under Keating? The facts are there for all of us to see. Today an Australian family can take out a mortgage for as low as 6.25 per cent and that is the foundation for economic growth if ever I saw it.

The member for Hotham had the temerity to add that Labor now promise to produce a surplus balance if restored to office. Labor could not do it before, so what has changed? All I have heard in the past few days is just how many of the government's programs Labor intend to abolish if they could just get their hands back on the till.

A front page article in today's Australian states that Labor is expected to vote for the government's $2 billion savings rebate, even though it intends to scrap this initiative if it wins the next election. The article goes on to say that Labor wants to use the money to top up the tax cuts it will offer in its own election platform. That says it all. Labor needs the coalition to pay back its own debts and put money back in the bank so it can go out and spend it all again.

I wholeheartedly support the appropriation bill because it is the culmination of not one but three cautious and effective budgets to give all the people of this great and free nation safety, security and stability. It has given the people of my electorate of Griffith more jobs. It has been done without any increase in income tax, without any increase in company tax, without any increase in petrol excise and without any increase in the wholesale sales tax. It has also seen the engine room of the Australian nation—small business—benefit from a drop in interest rates from 11 per cent two years ago to 7.7 per cent today. It has stabilised our nation to such an effect that we are riding out the Asian crisis without falling back into Labor's black hole. Yet the opposition continues to preach doom and gloom, trying to convince the people of Australia to re-adopt its policies of out-of-date welfare programs and unbridled spending and its fundraising methods of spiralling taxes.

The Howard government has established a strong foundation and one which I do not believe the people of Australia will allow to be trashed by the Labor Party which admits its policies require spending, spending and more spending. Labor has proven its policies mean debt, debt and more debt, which trans lated means higher taxes for all Australians. Because this budget and those before it have wiped out Labor's $10.3 billion debt without one cent of increases in taxation, I see a return to the values of the past, the values which the Howard government aspires to, which are simply security for all Australians. I support this bill.

talk.start.para: —I must say that the people sitting in the public gallery today at question time would have been entitled to think politics in this House was something of a blood sport. I think it is time perhaps as an institution that we looked at the nature of the body politic, because the unfortunate thing is that any objective observer making a judgment about this House as an institution would feel—and probably rightly—that at question time we could do much better than we do. I do not believe the sorts of exercises that took place today and on most days do us as an institution any credit.

speech.para: Perhaps before we bring them into question time we should provide some sort of a system where they see the hard work that is done on the various committees of this parliament, and I have served on many of them. Members relate to each other. They still have their political philosophy, they still have their differences, but they are able to relate to each other, embrace each other's opinions and produce a report which deals with many of the problems faced by the government of the day.

talk.start.para: —They work in harmony.

—That is right, I adopt the expression of my colleague. It is unfortunate therefore in this sense that within our Westminster system—and I am a strong supporter of that system—there are aspects to our processes which are in fact unduly and unnecessarily adversarial. I was a part of this institution and these processes in a state parliament for some time but, as I will be retiring at the next election, I hope I can make some comments which might strengthen this very important institution.

speech.para: I just want to say that there are many issues which, by their very nature, will always produce controversy. This is not a House for sissies; this is where arguments will be put and argued cogently and forcefully. Equally, we should not forget that on many of the issues which government and the parliament have to deal with there is a large measure of agreement and that policies have been developed in this institution and in the old House which have become very much part of the social fabric of our community. I refer—and I think this is probably the most interesting example—to the way the late Arthur Calwell founded the basis of our multicultural society.

You only have to go to any kind of naturalisation ceremony to see people from all political parties—and in my own community there are members of the state parliament who are members of the Liberal Party who retail their own experiences as young people coming from migrant families—who are as strong and positive supporters of multiculturalism as I am. I think that is one of the things which we can take credit for in this parliament. We have had a series of ministers for immigration from all political parties who have been dedicated and committed to extending that concept so that it has become part of the fabric of our Australian society.

Equally, one of the controversial issues of this government was the introduction of its gun laws. It was done with the support of the opposition. Without that support it could not have been done. It was a reaction to a tragedy that beset Australia. Of course, the government has had to carry a lot of the flak—but I think we also carry some of it—from the gun lobby around Australia. But the more we look at what is happening in America where the lack of gun laws is a part of their history the more we are seeing children being executed in their schools—when some kid wakes up not feeling too well, he blows his parents away and then goes and shoots some of his colleagues at the local school. It is an increasing pattern.

What I am saying is that there are many issues on which as Australians, as part of this community, we agree. The focus of this institution is part of its tradition. If you are in government, you support your ministers, you support your colleagues, and the opposition is treated as the political enemy, despite the fact that on many issues we can work together in a very positive way.

Questions without notice have become a bit of a joke. They have been a joke for years because the one thing they are not is questions without notice. One of my colleagues has left a list of the number of people who are supposed to ask questions to ministers and the ministers probably prepared the questions and prepared the answers. That is not just a sin of this government; it was a sin of Labor governments, and it was my own sin when I was a minister. Therefore, some of the heat that can be engendered in question time in some way vitiates that system.

But it is important, certainly in my own experience, that there are many core values on which as a community and as members of this institution we have common agreement. I think within this parliament there is no doubt of the strength of the feeling right across the parliament about the nature of our gun laws and our willingness to listen but not to resile from the position that was taken by the parliament. I think it was a correct position, and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is entitled to claim some credit for it, but I would remind him that he did it with our assistance.

The other policy which I think has become part of the mosaic of Australian society is our support for the concept of multiculturalism. All ministers succeeding Calwell have extended and expanded that policy. It has altered the fabric of our society, I believe, for the good. It was therefore with considerable concern and with some dismay, and I might say with some disappointment, that I read in today's paper that the Premier of Queensland has decided—and he must be feeling fairly desperate—to give preferences to the One Nation Party over the Labor Party.

I have been in politics too long to carry my heart on my sleeve, but if there is a decision which I believe will cause concern, not merely within the broader community but within the ranks of his own party and within the business community of Queensland, it is that, as well as the attitude that has been expressed in this parliament by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). She came in as a new member. She is the only member in this House I have ever heard say that they regard Aboriginal people as privileged. She is the only member I have heard in this place denigrate those Australian citizens who have had their birthplace or their origins in China. I do not believe, by the way Australian society is developing, that those sorts of views, whilst she is entitled to express them as a member of this parliament, are entitled to any kind of support from any of our major political parties. I include in that, of course, the Liberal Party.

I say with complete candour that if a One Nation candidate popped up in my electorate I would have no hesitation in putting them last. The situation that we have arrived at in Australia did not come about by accident, but we have produced a multicultural society. That is important for Australia in its geographical location in the world. So many of our primary producers and businessmen are geared to servicing markets in Asia.

Whatever might be said about our political structures, we are a politically stable community. We cannot trade with Asia if any major political party in Australia, in an endeavour to obtain a small political advantage in an electorate, is prepared—and the major political parties are not—to embrace any of the views of One Nation, because those views are not only detrimental to our society but also detrimental to the way we are thought about in Asia.

When I was in Asia recently we had, over a lunch or a dinner, parents saying, `What is all this problem about? We want to know whether we can send our kids to Australia to be educated. Will they be the subject of racist taunts and vilification?' You can say with confidence, `They won't—not in Melbourne, not in Sydney and even, I believe, not in Brisbane.' But there are organisations which beat the racist drum. In Queensland one of the prominent organisations—which had its historic origins in Victoria; it is the most historically based organisation—that has always played a leading role in anti-Semitism is the League of Rights. When the honourable member for Oxley got all those invitations from elderly gentlemen in dress suits for $50 dinners she was wandering around the corridors of parliament saying how kind `the league' was to her. Did she not know what `the league' was? I suspect she may not have. It was the League of Rights; they are there, they are active.

On one occasion I was privileged to represent the Prime Minister at the creation of a Holocaust memorial in the Jewish section of the cemetery at Surfers Paradise. It is a small cemetery, but it was a matter for great involvement by the Jewish community and a great commitment from the donor of the memorial. Within 24 hours it had been vandalised. There will always be people with those sorts of views in Australia. We live in a society where people are able to express whatever political view they like. The government of the day, the Liberal Party, is a serious political party. It is the party founded by Menzies, Fraser; it has a distinguished list of prime ministers. Would they seriously embrace One Nation? Would the members who represent marginal seats in this place embrace the kind of lunatic assertions that come from the member for Oxley? I do not believe that they would. I think more highly of them than that.

I do not think it will be successful but it is a grievous blow to the body politic. It is sad that any political leader is feeling so desperate in the run-up to an election that he gets into a situation where he says, `We will put the Labor Party last—One Nation as a matter of preference before them.' And he does not even get an effective political deal. He says, `We will do that in every electorate except one where there is a large Chinese community.' Who is he trying to kid? A great deal of work has been done to produce the kind of political institutions we have and this is an important one of them. It is important that people come to value the role of this institution and the role that people play in it. There is really no place in the society we are trying to build in Australia for the kind of political opportunism shown by Mr Borbidge. I do not believe it will succeed, but it is sad in a party that has played an important role in the development of Australia. I have plenty of differences with the Liberal Party in my own state but I say this: I do not think Jeff Kennett would ever make that deal. I do not think any political leader—although their philosophy may differ from mine—would get into the kind of sordid political stunt that this is. It gives a credibility to someone who is passing on the political scene, who is not and who has never been treated seriously in this parliament and does not deserve to be. She is a creature of the press. The very unorthodoxy of her views has made her that and she has had some interesting characters writing her speeches and being her political mentors and guides.

Politics for most of the people in this place is a serious business. There are people who would probably do much better economically outside this place if they did not regard it as serious business. It is time that all members of parliament put some value on themselves, their institution and their own political parties. All political parties go through periods of strength and weakness. In a major policy party you cannot separate a Queensland branch from a Victorian branch; they may have quite different attitudes but if you are the premier of a state, even if you are holding on by only a narrow majority, there is not only a public responsibility but also a political responsibility. The Premier of Queensland deserves to be consigned to political oblivion because of the action that has been taken today.
