It is not only an action that is not in the interests of the Australian people but also an action that is not in the interests of his own party. It is a sordid political endeavour which deserves to fail because it brings him and his party to a depth of political cynicism which I did not believe I would ever see in Australian politics—and I have seen a fair bit.

I believe it would be appropriate for the Prime Minister to say to Mr Borbidge, `If you are going to go down that track, don't expect any support from me, my ministers or the members of our parliament.' It is also regrettable that the National Party, whatever its problems, seems to have got itself involved in this. I hope saner views will prevail because it is important. It is not for me to tell other political parties how they should behave. I do not do all that well in telling my own party. But I think it is important that on a matter which embraces some of the issues that are involved here which go to the very nature and fabric of our society, all of us stand up and be counted and say, `This is not a game we are playing. The kinds of decisions that are involved here go to the nature of how we see ourselves and, more importantly, how other people who have come to this country and people with whom we are trying to build close relationships will see us.' This has been a retrograde step for the body politic in Australia and I hope it will be resolved.

talk.start.para: —At the outset I commend the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) for a great deal of what he said. I was interested in the way he started his contribution because I intend to do exactly the same thing. Like him, and I am sure many of our colleagues, I have got to the point where I am most dissatisfied with the standard of behaviour in this place during question time. That is not to say that we should not have a vigorous exchange. Question time, after all, is the focal point of the parliamentary day. It is the only time when all the ministers, all the shadow ministers and all the back benchers are here. It is being broadcast. It is being telecast. It is a theatre. There is no doubt about that. That does not mean that there cannot be a vigorous exchange, but when we have got to the point of having gratuitous rowdiness, which makes it impossible for Mr Speaker and other members to actually hear what is being said, I think collectively we do ourselves a great disservice.

speech.para: Without being piously pompous, I would certainly like to encourage all of our colleagues to give some thought to this. I will name no names. After all, if I am sitting in that chair if I name names, they walk. So no names. There are people here who engage in constant, ceaseless interjection and running off at the mouth. I sometimes have the thought: if only your mother could see you now, what would she think? I know what the kids sitting up in the galleries think. I get a lot of schools here from Cowper. I give them the special `Gary Nehl tour'. I take them everywhere. They come out of question time and they say `Oh, Mr Nehl, we wouldn't be allowed to behave at school like that.' And of course they are right.

I, like the member for Melbourne Ports, am passionate about democracy. I know he is, and I respect him for it. I made mention of the schools that I have taken around here. I take every opportunity, whether it is in talking about parliament or presenting a flag, to bash their ears about democracy and freedom and liberty, because democracy is a very fragile flower. It is something that everybody in this place has a responsibility to protect and cause to flourish.

I suppose, as this is the appropriation bill, that I should perhaps talk about the budget, although before I do I must comment on something else the member for Melbourne Ports said. That was his great defence of multiculturalism. He may well remember other speeches I have made in the time that I have been here and in the old place. I do not endorse multiculturalism the way he does. I endorse cultural diversity. I acknowledge the great benefit to Australia from the vast numbers of people who have chosen to leave their own homes, who have chosen to benefit us as a nation by becoming Australian. But I have doubts, I have reservations, about multiculturalism as it is practised. I believe that it engenders to some extent, the way we are doing it, a degree of separateness, and that I am really concerned about. But cultural diversity? Certainly.

Getting to the budget, I have to say right at the outset that this is a great budget for Cowper because there are so many good things in it which will benefit the people whom I represent. I am reminded of Norman May and his commentary on us winning gold medals. You will recall that he called: `Gold, gold, gold for Australia.' The thing that comes through first and foremost for me is gold, gold, gold for World War II diggers. I congratulate the government and, in particular, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, because this is recognition of the service given to this country by those World War II diggers over the age of 70 who faced danger from the enemy. My late father, of course, was one of those. I have enormous sympathy and empathy for our returned servicemen community. I am so pleased and so thrilled that we have taken this action.

I acknowledge, too, the tremendous support that I had in working for this from the veterans' community right throughout my electorate. I am so delighted that it has happened. I am also very pleased that self-funded retirees of pension age have had the qualifying amount of income extended to I think $40,000 for a single and $67,000 for a couple to enable them to get the seniors health care card, the very real benefit of which is in pharmaceuticals. It gives them the opportunity of paying only $3.20 per prescription for the first 52, and then their pharmaceuticals are free thereafter.

It is not very often understood that a great many self-funded retirees whose income is such that they just miss out on getting a pension or a part pension in many cases have been worse off than pensioners because they do not get the benefits—they do not get the reduction in vehicle registration, they do not get the reduction in rates, they do not get the telephone concessions and so many other things.

I am delighted that the Howard-Fischer government not only has increased the tax free threshold for self-funded retirees but has taken this very positive step of giving a real benefit to people who are advancing in years and who will benefit enormously from paying not $18, $20 or $25 for their chemist prescriptions, but a maximum of $3.20 per prescription. That is a tremendous benefit.

I would like to talk too about how disappointed I am with my friends and colleagues in the opposition who have already embarked on a scare campaign about `the GST'. One would think, to hear the people on the opposition benches speaking, particularly in this appropriation debate, and at every other opportunity, that tax reform involved one facet only, the GST. But as you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the tax reform package required for the Australian people is far more than the GST. A goods and services tax, if it comes—no decision has been made on that yet—will be but one facet of a package.

Let me say that I for one—I do not know what is in the package—will be incredibly disappointed if wholesale sales tax is not abolished totally. It is a most unfair tax; it is a tax that inhibits business, it is a tax that destroys our exports. I had hoped, but I do not have time, to take the people who may be listening to this speech or who may read it for a walk through their home, through the kitchen, through the laundry, through the bathroom and just point out the items that they pay sales tax on.

Let me say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if any of my constituents do take a walk through their home and visit every room, there will be very few things they will find there that do not have sales tax on them. I do not have the time to do that. I would just like to make one point. I am a father and a grandfather, as many, or most, of our members are—and there are many mothers here, too. One of the things that we all like to do is to have photographs of our kids or our grandchildren but what Mr and Mrs Cowper should realise is that when they buy a film to take a photo of the grandkids, they pay 32 per cent sales tax on that right now, and it has been so for years. When they actually take the film to the chemist or the photo shop to get it processed and printed, they pay another 22 per cent sales tax. So there is 32 per cent sales tax on the film and then another 22 per cent on the top of that. People do not realise that—and they should.

I well recall the situation when we had the Fightback program some two elections ago. Then we had the same sort of scare tactic coming up as we have now. I want to take this opportunity to say that sales tax is almost everywhere, even on a pound of butter. I can recall Mr Keating saying there is no sales tax on butter. The reality is that on a kilo of butter—I will get up-to-date, away from the pounds—if you take it right down the line from the dairy farm and the delivery and manufacture of the fertilisers, and all the other things, there are 320 separate tax inputs on a kilogram of butter; but they said there is no sales tax. What we have to have is a tax reform package—and we will have it—which is fair for every Australian.

I want to dispel once and for all the scare tactics of the opposition. Pensioners and low income earners will be totally protected and isolated and insulated from any adverse effect. What we will be seeking to do with the tax reform package is get Australia back on track. We are back in the black. We want to make it even better—and it will be. I conclude by saying that this budget is really great for Cowper and the people I represent; and I congratulate the government for what they have done.

talk.start.para: —I want to depart from the normal political rhetoric that has engulfed most of the debate on appropriations from the differing viewpoints and actually look at the economics of the package. When we lost office in March 1996, the financial year 1995-96 figures showed a growth in the Australian economy of 4.1 per cent. These are average year growths. In fact, when we left office in March 1996, the growth rate for that quarter was 4.6 per cent, a huge rate of growth in the economy that was producing opportunities and jobs and generating wealth opportunities for all Australians. That average rate of growth of 4.1 per cent in our final year of office has not only not been matched on any occasion by this government but has deliberately, through the actions of three budgets now, been suppressed.

speech.para: In their first year in office the Howard government comatosed the economy. They used their rhetoric from the election campaign to justify cuts that were ideologically driven and for which there was no economic necessity. They took an economy which was averaging 4.1 per cent growth in our last year of office and immediately, in their first year in office, turned that into a growth rate of 2.7 per cent only—a very substantial cut in the opportunities available for Australians to share in prosperity. Put simply, the cake was not growing as it did the year before.

There was no massive Asian currency crisis in 1996-97, there were no external influences that produced that cut in economic growth in Australia; it was a direct and deliberate outcome of mismanagement on the part of the Howard government in their first budget. If it was not mismanagement then it was driven by deliberate ideological desire to cut into the public sector and through their rhetoric to convince the public that there was a crisis in the economy which in fact did not exist, and they talked the economy down. They created the self-fulfilling prophesy that totally sapped the confidence of the business community and consumers.

I was quite surprised to find—as were others on the Labor side who were in touch with their electorates—that small businesses in my area which I am certain did not support us in March 1996 were saying in frustration a year later that the economy was so bad they wished Paul Keating was back because they were doing well then.

In its first year in office, this government produced a cut in economic growth from our level of 4.6 per cent in the March quarter of 1996 to an annual average in its first year of 2.7 per cent. In its second year, it managed to return economic growth of 3.75 per cent, still well below that which it inherited in March 1996 from the Labor government and, I might say, well below our average for the three years. That 4.6 per cent with which we ended our term in office in the March 1996 quarter was in keeping with the sort of growth rates we had achieved over a three-year period. In our last three years in office, economic growth in this country averaged four per cent—a figure which has not been met in any year by this government. In the second year they managed to get it up to 3.75 per cent.

This is their third budget and it predicts that economic growth is going to shrink again, back to three per cent. That three per cent is widely regarded by commentators both here in Australia and abroad as an optimistic assessment. The simple fact is that most economic commentators believe that the Australian economy will fall back to below three per cent growth in the year ahead, back to the levels that the Howard Liberal government produced in its first year in office. That denies millions of Australians an opportunity to not only share in jobs but, for those who have employment, it denies them any security. It means that they cannot be confident that the job they have is going to be there the next year.

The government has made great play about interest rates and the fact that they have come down, and of course it is a good thing that they have come down, but every member in this place knows—except the members on the government side do their best not to think about it—that, whether interest rates are at two per cent, 12 per cent or 22 per cent, people will not invest in new opportunities, take loans to redo the house, build a new house, buy a new car or go on a holiday if they do not have confidence and if they do not believe their job will be secure in a year or two. If they do not think that they have got an income stream next year, it frankly does not matter to them what the interest rate is. They will not invest. That is the reality in the economy at the moment; it is a reality produced by the blanket this government has thrown over economic growth to which I have just referred.

Economic growth is predicted to be less in the 12 months ahead than it was in the past 12 months. With that lower economic growth, the government budget predicts that they will reduce unemployment at the same time. There are not a lot of laws in economics that hold true, but it is a bit hard to construe any economic analysis to say that a lower economic growth rate will produce greater job opportunities. Of course it will not. The government is talking about the unemployment rate, not job opportunities. The unemployment rate does not just reflect how many people have a job; it reflects how many people are looking for a job. What this government hopes will occur in the next year is that many more thousands of Australians will stop looking for work, as occurred last year and the year before. It hopes that the confidence in the economy, which is gone, will turn so many Australians away from the job market that the unemployment rate will actually come down. The economic growth will not produce the necessary jobs. If the participation rate stays at its current level, in 12 months time unemployment will be substantially higher than it is today. That is an inescapable outcome of the government's own budget projections.

The government has also sought to make great political play about government debt and foreign debt, and I want to say a couple of things about that. I remember that foreign debt truck that broke down in the Blue Mountains—the foreign debt truck that was 100 per cent imported, adding to the debt of the country. In March 1996 the foreign debt was well below the current levels of debt. In fact, the foreign debt today is some $25 billion to $30 billion more than it was when this government took office.

If all of the things government members said prior to the last election were true, it is even more true today that they have failed in every one of those measures. Foreign debt is now $25 billion to $30 billion higher than it was at the time of the last election. The simple fact is that when Labor left office the economy was in good shape; by any international comparison, it was in very good shape.

One of the other measures of the federal government's performance prior to 1996 is the government debt. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) and others like to refer to debt fairly amorphously and merge them all together. As I have pointed out, net foreign debt is now worse than it was before. In terms of government debt as a percentage of GDP, 1996 OECD figures show that Australia's general government net financial liabilities as a percentage of GDP—that is, how much debt the government had—was 27.6 per cent. That beats the hell out of just about every other OECD country. The United States in 1996 was running at 48.4 per cent, Germany at 48 per cent, France at 40 per cent, Italy at 110 per cent, Canada at 70 per cent and the United Kingdom—after it had suffered under 15 years of Thatcherite slash and burn policies—was at 44.3 per cent of GDP government debt. What was the Australian government debt that John Howard inherited in March 1996? It was 27 per cent; well below all of those countries that we would compare ourselves with.

The simple fact is that the Australian economy was in good shape. In those days John Howard, the Prime Minister, was prone to make the odd honest statement about these things and actually referred to the fact that the economy was better than good in parts. It was, but that was said in one of those rare outbursts of honesty which have since eluded him as the polls get worse for him.

One of the other fallacies is that this is a government that has not increased tax. We will leave aside in this debate the new taxes the government have imposed. There have been new taxes. There is the superannuation tax—except the government call it a surcharge, but everyone out there understands it is a superannuation tax—and there is the new reef tax. But I do not want to talk about those things. I want to talk about the sleight of hand; the sneaky way in which this government has managed to ratchet up the tax revenue and pretend that they are not increasing the tax burden.

In every budget document there is an interesting table that sets out how much money the government is bringing in—that is, its revenue from the Australian economy, the percentage of the GDP, what the country has produced in the year. How much of that is the government actually taking out? The government's own budget papers show that this year that revenue has increased to 25 per cent. Twenty-five per cent just happens to be the highest take of any federal government since 1991, bar one year. We need to understand that. This budget plans to extract from the economy in revenue 25 per cent of GDP, which is the highest tax grab from the Australian economy since 1991 except for one year in that period.

This is a high tax budget and this is a high tax government. Where are they getting the money from? They are not getting it from their mates in big business. They are not getting it from ACCI. The crew that have been out there in the media in the last day or two saying, `We want tax reform. We want to have a GST,' are not saying that because they think business should pay more tax. I have not heard anyone in ACCI say they want to change the tax system because they think companies are getting off too light. Where is this government planning to get this money from?

In the budget papers there is a great table. I notice that the people in the advisers box have some interest in this. The table can be found on page 5-3 of statement 5 on revenue. It shows where the money is coming from. This government is taking that money away from ordinary workers. It is gross PAYE, pay-as-you-earn. This year the government plans to increase the tax that it takes from the money in the pockets of ordinary working Australians who pay tax every week. There will be an increase in tax of 8.4 per cent, but the members of the government say there is no tax increase. Their assertion is totally untrue—totally, absolutely and deceitfully untrue. There is an 8.4 per cent increase in PAYE revenue this year. That is the sneaky way of getting the money.

This government is using bracket creep to get the money through the back door and pretending that they are not hurting people. It is a bit like the sneaky way the government tried to present itself in defence funding. As the shadow minister for defence I will make a couple of quick comments about that. This government managed to conduct a pretty good mirrors trick on the public and on some of their own members who did not understand what they were doing when they said they would quarantine defence spending. Most people thought that meant the government were not actually going to cut defence spending. Most people though that meant defence would get what they got before. It did not mean that at all. In fact, the 1996-97 budget, the first budget of this government, cut defence by $50 million in real terms—a 0.5 per cent cut in real terms.

What the government really meant but did not want to tell some of its own backbenchers or the military or the community was that it was actually going to cut defence. It was not going to maintain the defence budget; it would maintain the defence estimates. That is what the Labor Party was going to spend. Finally, that has been admitted to. In a press release issued by the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) on Wednesday 14 May, just after the budget, he said a number of things, one of which I like very much—it was an admission. He said:
Outlays for Defence under the Howard government are exactly the same as those that would have occurred under Labor.

Thank you very much for an outburst of honesty. Yes, that is absolutely true: you have adhered to the forward estimates of the former Labor government and provided to defence exactly what Labor was going to provide. It is about time you were honest about it.

It is a pity that for three years you deceived defence and actually took out $50 million over the three years which has not been replaced. That means that, if you had done what you actually had promised the public you would do and what the public thought you were saying, defence would have had $150 million more in these three budgets. But they do not because of the dishonesty in the way in which this government has presented itself.

Time is up because of the restrictions of time in this debate. I look forward to having an opportunity in subsequent appropriation bill debates to say more about these matters and expose the deceitful way in which this government has portrayed its economic management.

talk.start.para: —I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity of joining this debate on the appropriation measures in a very fine budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) recently which, for the first time in eight years, saw the Commonwealth accounts returned to the black. We have a $2.75 billion surplus. I must say that that ought to be compared to the $10.3 billion deficit left to us by the former Labor government. `Back in the black and back on track'—that is the catchcry and those are the catchwords which are being used around the nation by people who are independent arbiters to comment on the important achievements of this third Costello budget. This is a wonderful performance—the best since the recession that the Labor Party said we had to have.

speech.para: We all know that in March 1996 the Labor Party claimed that the budget was in surplus. We remember that the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and other Labor luminaries said in the media that their budget was in surplus. We sought to get the figures but they claimed they could not tell us the exact situation. However, it was amazing that, on the Monday after the Saturday when the Labor Party was decimated at the general election, the magic figures were brought forth. We all saw that the Labor Party was $10.3 in deficit—$10.3 billion added to the deficits which they had successively brought down over the 13 years of Labor rule.

Understandably, the government said that never again would the people of Australia be subjected to such deceit by a government approaching an election, and we brought in the charter of budget honesty legislation which has become law. That will ensure that prior to any election campaign independent public servants will be able to give a state of the accounts for the nation so that Australians, when they go to vote at the polls, will know exactly the economic condition of the economy and of the nation generally.

It is interesting to note that for a long time the Labor Party sought to defeat this legislation. The Labor Party was not prepared initially to back this legislation which will ensure that the accounts of Australia are open, transparent, obvious and clear for all people to see, so that the electors are able to go to the polls with a clear conscience knowing that they are voting for or against a government on the basis of true facts. No longer will governments be able to lie and cheat their way back into office, as the former Keating government sought to do.

It is interesting that people, many of whom are not close friends of the government, have been prepared in an objective way to give honest and open praise of the achievements of the Howard government in the budget brought down a few weeks ago. Mark Paterson, CEO of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:
This is a good budget which leaves the Australian economy stronger and more resilient in the face of certain difficulties which will arise because of the crisis in Asia.

Imagine how desperate the plight would have been for this country had we gone on with the same deficit budgeting which had been the hallmark of 13 years of Labor rule. Stan Wallis, President of the Business Council of Australia, said:

This is a budget that is absolutely right for the times. This budget makes sure that we keep a check on interest rates and inflation. This must be good for national savings, good for investment and good for jobs growth.
Terry McCrann from the Daily Telegraph said:
The benefit for all Australians of eliminating government debt cannot be overstated.

Mrs Maureen Kingston, National President of the Association of Independent Retirees, said that the association is `delighted that the government has listened to the voice of independent retirees who have endeavoured to provide their own income in retirement'. Editorial comment equally was very praiseworthy. The Daily Telegraph said:
Peter Costello's third budget is, as promised, a responsible document that lays the groundwork for a secure economy in uncertain times.
Piers Ackerman said:

After five years of fiscal snake oil, financial sleight of hand and monetary gimcrackery, Treasurer Peter Costello's third budget appears at first blush to be positively soporific. It is reassuring that it isn't boring.
The Australian Financial Review said that Peter Costello should be applauded for a budget that promises to deliver Canberra's first surplus since 1990-91.

So there was adulation in the Australian community for the sound, solid, responsible economic performance which got the economy back in the black and back on track. On the Sunshine Coast, an area I am privileged to represent, most people who contacted me said what a wonderful document it was. The praise that flowed for the performance of the Howard-Fischer government and the performance of Treasurer Costello in the budget was quite overwhelming.

The budget sets the right priorities as we move towards the next millennium. We inherited an economy that had been suffering from high government debt, high unemployment, high inflation and high interest rates. We really did not have much going for us despite the words given to the House recently by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis). This budget delivers on our pledge to live within our means and to put the budget back into the black. A $2.7 billion or 0.5 per cent of GDP surplus is expected during the 1998-99 year and further surpluses are projected over the period to the year 2001-02. Our budget repairs have helped achieve a stronger Australian economy able to withstand the Asian economic crisis, the lowest bank mortgage interest rates since 1970, rates of inflation not seen since the 1970s and the lowest unemployment rate in eight years.

The Labor Party are obviously aware that a few months down the track the people of Australia will once again have the opportunity of condemning their abject failure during 13 years of government. That is why we will find Labor speaker after Labor speaker rise in the House and seek to denigrate the responsible, sound economic management of the Howard government. But the people of Australia will see through them. They saw through them in the March 1996 election and they will continue to do so, because there is an appreciation that in Australia we need to manage the nation's books in exactly the same responsible way that we would seek to manage our own household accounts.

I do, however, in the remaining minutes available to me, want to comment on the importance of the extension of the Commonwealth seniors health card to an additional 220,000 self-funded retirees. These are Australians who have planned for their own retirement. They were fortunate to be able to plan for their own retirement. They have been hit by the successive interest rate reductions which are very good for the economy as whole, but they are folk who scrimped and saved to put themselves into a position where they would not have to call on the public purse. These are fine citizens. They have worked during their lives to contribute to make Australia the wonderful country that it is.

The pharmaceutical benefits scheme gives concessional access to some people, and the Commonwealth seniors health card is one mechanism by which Australians are able to obtain pharmaceuticals at concessional rates. I was privileged to be Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs during the time that we had an inquiry into concession cards. Mr Deputy Speaker Forrest, you were my successor following the Prime Minister's appointment of me as Government Whip.

talk.start.para: —Your successor did a better job.

—We are both doing a wonderful job, as the honourable member for Dobell would know. If we needed any proof the parliamentary system works, we would only have to go to the report entitled Concessions—who benefits? handed down in October 1997 by the committee I formerly chaired. It recommended that the government extend eligibility for the Commonwealth seniors health card. We did have a robust discussion on the committee, as Mr Deputy Speaker would be aware, as to the extent to which there should be access to the Commonwealth seniors health card. I was one who wanted the committee to go as far as the government has now gone. The decision contained in the budget is fair and equitable. Even the Labor Party has been prepared to congratulate the government on extending the Commonwealth seniors health card to 220,000 Australian retirees who have scrimped and saved to provide for their own retirement.

speech.para: Time is limited in this debate. This is an opportunity for those of us in the House to be able to congratulate the government on the wonderful economic management it has given to the people of Australia since the election in March 1996. We have made some difficult decisions. We inherited a black hole of $10.3 billion when we attained government. We were not responsible for creating the problem, but we do accept that we have a responsibility to fix it—and fix it we have. We have made some difficult decisions. It has not been easy, but these tough decisions have had to be made because of the irresponsible way in which the former Labor government sought to run this country.

The feedback that I am getting from people right around the country is that this government is on track, this government knows what has to be done and this government is carrying out the economic responsibilities entrusted to it by the people of Australia. Whenever the election is, I am absolutely and utterly convinced that the Labor Party will be exposed, once again, as the snake oil merchants of Australian politics.

People listened to Prime Minister Keating and Prime Minister Hawke and other Labor ministers over 13 years. At the end of the day they failed. They claimed that the budget was in surplus, but the reality was quite different. They sought to lie, rob and cheat their way back into office in the March 1996 election. The people of Australia saw through them. We got elected to office. We now have a charter of budget honesty, and prior to the next election people will be able to see that this government's word is its bond. This government will tell the truth, and I believe that we will receive a continuing ringing endorsement from the people of Australia. I commend the budget to the House.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the member for Dobell, members in their contributions to this debate are going very close in some of their terminology in a way that makes me uncomfortable, and I ask them to please be very careful about their descriptions.

—Listening to the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), it is hard to keep a straight face. He is probably lucky it is an empty public gallery, an empty House of Representatives chamber and not a broadcast day, because for him to claim that this government is on track is a great endorsement of things like the crisis in public hospitals. The crisis in public hospitals is on track, according to the member for Fisher. As bulk-billing rates fall, as this government squeezes the GP rebate, the member for Fisher says, `Health care is on track.' As the waiting lists for dental care increase by the day, the member for Fisher says, `Health care is on track.' He finished with a great rhetorical flourish, saying that this government's word is its bond.

speech.para: We all know that the two issues that will dominate the next election campaign are this government's plans to introduce a GST and this government's deliberate intention to axe Medicare. I make it clear right from the start that you have only to listen to the words that the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) used time and time again before the last election. He said that a party that he led, the coalition that he led, would never ever introduce a GST. Yet today we have this farce. Following the member for Fisher's claim that the government's word is its bond, the Prime Minister's words that he would never ever introduce a GST do not seem to have much of a bond about them; they have about as much strength as a bond as a rubber band.

This government sets out to introduce a GST, and one of the ways that they are going to go about trying to win enough votes to get themselves over the line at the next election is to have a few giveaways in this budget. The member for Fisher was trumpeting away about the benefits that flow from the government's decision to award seniors health care cards to self-funded retirees. I hope it was not against the standing orders of the relevant committee or this chamber, but the member for Fisher revealed that, within the considerations of the relevant House of Representatives committee, he was advocating a recommendation that seniors health care cards should be extended to couples with incomes of up to $67,000 a year, which is what the government has finally done.

I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the actual report of the relevant committee recommended a much tighter upper income limit for the awarding of the seniors health care card. I suppose it says something about the advocacy skills of the member for Fisher that he admitted here tonight that he was rolled by his own committee and he was not able to convince his own committee that there should be an upper limit of $67,000 for eligibility for the seniors health care card—although perhaps he has been able to persuade his own government to head down this path.

That, in itself, raises some concerns in that the government has decided to award 200,000 self-funded retirees the benefits that flow from having a seniors health care card—mainly, cheaper pharmaceuticals. That is fair enough in that self-funded retirees were hit by this government in the 1996 and 1997 budgets through pretty dramatic increases in the costs of their health care, particularly in pharma ceuticals. So we certainly do not object to self-funded retirees getting something back, given the massive slugs that were applied to them in past budgets. But what disturbs me is that, for every self-funded retiree who gets a card because of the budget, there are 20 other pensioners and low income family members who, like the self-funded retirees, were hit in 1996 and 1997 and who have got nothing in the budget.

In fact, the government is going to spend about $200 million a year over the forward estimates in the budget on the extension of the seniors health care card. If you look back at the savings the government made in the 1996 budget, the decision to increase the costs of essential medicines for pensioners, increasing the minimum amount from $2.70 to $3.20, saved the government about $300 million. While full-rate and part-rate pensioners were slugged in 1996 to save the government $300 million—people on very low incomes were hit in 1996 and were given nothing in this year's budget—self-funded retirees, who were also hit in 1996, were given back $200 million or so in this year's budget. I think it does raise certain questions about whether low income earning pensioners and low income families should have been entitled to something in this budget as well.

If we focus on the area of health, there is a real crisis out there in Australia's public hospital system. That crisis in the public hospital system will only be able to be addressed if the federal government faces up to its responsibilities and provides extra funding for Australia's public hospital system. I am sure I do not need to bring to the attention of the House some of the graphic examples that are around about the extent of that crisis. An article in the Advertiser of 6 May under the headline `Brown warning on "corridor patients"' said:
SOUTH Australian patients would soon be sleeping on stretchers in hospital corridors, the Human Services Minister, Mr Brown, warned yesterday.
Giving evidence to a Senate inquiry into Medicare funding . . .
An article from the West Australian entitled `State considers patient fees as funds cut hurts' said:
WA Health Minister Kevin Prince has refused to rule out the introduction of fees for public hospital patients to make up for shortfalls in funds.
An article in the Age entitled `Hospital waiting lists may double' said:
Hospital waiting lists would double unless the Federal Government dramatically lifted its Medicare funding offer to the states, doctors said yesterday.
This is based on the views and statements of one of the AMA's federal councillors, Mr Robert Hodge, who said:
Some 116,000 Australians are on hospital waiting lists—this is likely to double over the next few years unless a better deal is struck.
Back in South Australia Dean Brown, in his evidence to the Senate committee, said the following:
. . . there are examples where people have been asked to leave the hospital earlier than good health care and medical advice would suggest they should.
This is Dean Brown, the Liberal Minister for Human Services in South Australia. He continued:
You are increasingly seeing, I think, poor or third-rate health care delivered to people as a result of those [funding] pressures.

There is certainly very strong evidence around the country that the public hospital system needs extra funding. The great tragedy is that the government, in its private health insurance initiative, the tax rebate, has spent a very large sum of money, some $1.7 billion, in subsidising health funds. If media reports are correct, the government is planning on putting more money into subsidising private health insurance.

It really is disturbing that the government, having spent a very large sum of money on private health insurance, has not realised that it has not kept its promises on private health insurance. Private health insurance premiums have gone up, not down. Membership has not increased, as the Prime Minister promised; it has actually declined. We are now down to 31.1 per cent and falling at 800 people a day. Yet the government claims that it has been unable to admit its mistakes and unwilling to face up to the policy errors it has made. As a result, the government is now looking at throwing more money into health fund subsidies at the very time that the public hospital system is in absolute crisis.

I would have thought that the government would realise that, with a $2.7 billion surplus, perhaps some extra funding could have been put into the public hospital system. But, in fact, on budget night we learnt that not one extra dollar was provided by the Howard government for the public hospital system. That was not on the table at the Premiers Conference two months ago when all the premiers walked out. The government decided not to put one extra dollar out of that $2.7 billion surplus into dental care despite the fact that we have large numbers of Australians who are in pain because they cannot get access to emergency and preventative dental care.

I met one gentleman from Rutherford in the Hunter Valley last Thursday when I was visiting the electorate of Paterson with the former and the next Labor member for Paterson after the next election, Bob Horne.

talk.start.para: —Fat chance!

—I reckon he would be a better bet than the honourable member for Mitchell in his own electorate. We all know that he is in a bit of trouble in Mitchell. I am sure Bob Horne will be home before he is in Mitchell, although I would not put a large amount of money on that bet. The gentleman from Rutherford who spoke to me at Maitland made the point that he had been unable to chew meat for 12 months because of the time he had been waiting for some pretty basic dental care. When you consider that people on low incomes like him are sentenced to simply eat soft meat or soups because they have been unable to get the dental care to which they are entitled, it is a—
—Oh, a three-year program that you pulled in—
—Order!
—I can't believe you. You can't present that.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will get his opportunity shortly.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member for Mitchell interjects by saying that it was a three-year program. Every time he or anyone else makes that claim we on the opposition simply ask them to explain how the 1996 budget papers could claim a $100 million a year saving on the forward estimates by abolishing the Commonwealth dental health program if the program was going to end in 1996. We know that the member for Mitchell is one of the leading lights with great talents in the area of economics, so perhaps he could explain to us how the 1996 budget papers contained that saving of $100 million a year totalling $400 million over the forward estimates by abolishing the Commonwealth dental health program if it was going to end in 1996, the end of the three-year period.

speech.para: The truth is that the former Labor government had funding $100 million a year out in the forward estimates. That is why the government could claim the saving by abolishing the scheme, and that is why this government is going to be held responsible for that $400 million saving. That $400 million cut is forcing people—like the gentleman I met at Maitland—to wait for the dental care that he is entitled to. It is something that needs to be addressed if people on pretty low incomes do not get the care to which they should be entitled. All of these are areas of concern, and we are entitled to ask what the future holds for the Australian health care system—the future of bulk-billing, the future of Medicare and the future of the public hospital system.

One of the great concerns I have is that increasingly it seems that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is not calling the tune in this whole policy debate. We had the Treasurer (Mr Costello) a couple of weeks ago saying that he was going to re-engineer the entire health care system. We also had the Treasurer stating that free access to doctors' surgeries and public hospitals was a problem. His view was that free access to treatment in a public hospital should only be available to people who could not afford medical care. I am sure that there would be many people in most honourable members' electorates who would be very concerned by those sorts of messages that the Treasurer is sending out.

We also have the Prime Minister working on a second rescue package for private health insurance. All the signals are that the current minister for health is not playing the central role that you would normally expect the minister for health to be playing in health policy development. That concern led me back to the minister for health's first appearance as health minister on the Sunday program on 24 March 1996, shortly after the election. When asked by Laurie Oakes about his Master of Business Administration course at Monash University and his thesis on how the Fraser government messed up health policy, the current minister for health said:

Michael Wooldridge: Well, the people deciding the policy were separate from the people implementing the policy; and, second, there was a complete breakdown between the Health Minister and his department, and the Government and the department. So they're two mistakes that won't be made again..
Laurie Oakes: I mean, when people talk about the people deciding policy, you mean the Prime Minister's department, don't you? They imposed a policy on the Health Department.

Michael Wooldridge: In the 1970s, it was the Prime Minister's department and Treasury, but things are quite different today. Departments have far more autonomy and I don't think what happened in the `70s could happen again.

Isn't it funny how early interviews can come back to haunt you? Despite the minister for health's wishes to control health policy, it is the current Prime Minister and the current Treasurer—ironically, it was the Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, who was accused of interfering with both Ralph Hunt and Jim Carlton's administration of the health portfolio—who are clearly calling the shots on the future directions in health policy.

If this government is re-elected, as sure as night follows day John Howard, the member for Bennelong, will axe Medicare. We will see continuing attacks on bulk-billing and on funding for public hospitals; we will see no money going into dental care; and we will see increased costs of essential medicines. All of those things will mean that pensioners, older Australians, people with chronic illnesses, and families living on tight budgets will be the ones hit by these changes. They are the ones who will feel that axe that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister will wield on Medicare.

talk.start.para: —A quick review of the Australian economy now and the opportunities for Australians, particularly those who are involved in small business, must really paint for all Australians the massive change that has come about in Australia over the past 2½ years. I would like to remind the House that a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 June 1995 spoke of the need to pay attention to the economic needs of Australia. This is what the Sydney Morning Herald said about the prospect of an interest rate drop:

speech.para: But with US ratings agency Moody's on Friday reminding everyone that more needed to be done to cut Australia's $27-billion current account deficit, recent concerns about the weakness of the Australian dollar, and signs that the Government's May Budget package is fraying at the edges, the Reserve Bank simply could not justify a cut in interest rates so soon after the release of such a bad figure.

That was Australia less than four years ago—an absolute cot case, a basket case—and the Labor Party comes in here to speak about this last budget before the next election portraying their period as one of success and wanting to build on the success of the current government. They claim that nothing was wrong previously but now things can be fixed for the future. How wrong they are, because the Australian people will not forget that period less than three years ago when Australia was a cot case and, in the words of the Sydney Morning Herald , `the Reserve Bank simply could not justify a cut in interest rates so soon after the release of such a bad figure.'

What were the circumstances in 1995? We were a bankrupt Australia with our current account deficit at $27 billion. The cost of our annual payment to cover our debt was around $9 billion or $10 billion. So the amount we were paying for education or defence was the same as our annual interest and capital repayment bill. That is the record of the Australian Labor Party. Australia had record borrowings in debt to everybody around the world and was having to pay it off, record unemployment and a record tax take.

At a time when the Australian government had maximised its income by charging Australian taxpayers more, when they had borrowed more than any other government previously and when they had laid off people from their workplaces to reduce costs, Australia was still going broke because of the tenuous and difficult circumstances of the Australian economy. As the Sydney Morning Herald said, `the Reserve Bank could not justify a cut in interest rates so soon after the release of such a bad figure.' On top of that, we had world-class, record breaking unemployment figures—there were one million people out of work during the period that the Australian Labor Party was in office.

What has happened since in the 2½ years? It has been 2½ years of hard work and valiant toil and real commitment. Some of it has not been easy. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Forrest, among those in this chamber, have carried a share of some of the difficulties and problems that this government has had in repairing the budget and getting Australia back on the road again—back on the road to prosperity, back on the road to proper planning, back on the road to effective decision making.

And so what has happened? After 2½ years this budget has an underlying surplus of $2.5 billion. That is an amazing turnaround from a current account deficit of $27 billion. Approximately $2 billion a month further into debt was the Australian Labor Party's record—each month, a further $2 billion down the drain. I cannot believe it because in that same year, 1995, the IMF came into Australia and warned the federal government about its practices and about the economy. And the contrast is salutary. Just past November of 1997, the IMF could not visit Australia, because they were too busy doing important things, and say, `We do not need to come to Australia as Australia is managing okay.' What a difference! What a contrast in the world environment—and the attitudes and thoughts of the government.

Not only has the budget been repaired but we have seen changes to workplace relations that are gradually bringing about opportunities that few Australians imagined they could have without tight, centralised control of wages and conditions. The MUA has attempted to divert the Australian work force back to the past. It has been sad meeting some of those representatives of the MUA, because when you suggest to them that they could be part of the solution rather than part of the problem the shutters go up and they want to continue with the past. Well, the past is over and most workers in Australia—perhaps a few in the building industry and a few in the mining industry cling to those past things—are enjoying better benefits, better opportunities, more freedom and a greater sense of direction and vision in their lives than those members of the MUA do. And that is sad. I am pleased that Australia is changing, but it does not alleviate the pain for those who find change too difficult or are too unwilling to undertake change.

So workplace relations are changing. We are having Australian workplace agreements or certified agreements, an option that workers thought they would never have. To sit down with their employers and plan the future of their businesses and their enterprises together is a wonderful opportunity that has been offered to Australians and they are grabbing it with both hands—day after day. In February alone, the number of workplace agreements that were entered into doubled compared to the total of the previous period since the legislation came into action. As for opportunities for small business also—we have changed the scene there.

But there is still one major reform that this government will need to undertake, that is, the reform of taxation. That is on the agenda because, having resolved the budget difficulties created by the Australian Labor Party, having put Australia in the mainstream of the world stage in our workplace relations and how we work together, more has to be done to allow the average Australian to take home the benefits of their hard work; to make sure that those who avoid taxation are brought into the system; and to make sure that there are charges and taxes on those industries that have come into being since we first thought of an income tax and a wholesale sales tax—a spreading of the taxation system so that it is fairer and so that those who save or want to prepare for their future are properly cared for. That is the last remaining process that the government is confronting and will put to the Australian people before the next election.

In the small business area, an area for which I have some responsibility, a surplus budget has produced record low interest rates and record low inflation. What a terrific environment for people who make plans and decisions for their small businesses. Interest rates have fallen 250 basic points since June 1996. They are now at their lowest since 1973—and perhaps longer. That is an amazing figure. On an average bank loan to a small business of $100,000, there is an average saving of $2,500 per year. Banks are keen to lend money. They are providing the lowest rates that we have seen for 30 years.

We now have a growing economy and growing opportunities for small business. Tax reform will give us a fairer, better and more modern system of taxation that will encourage people to work, to save and to provide for families in the process. We have cut paperwork from the Bureau of Statistics. We have reduced paperwork through the paying of withholding tax. We have lessened the tax compliance burden on small business by extending payment and lodgment times.

Under our new fundraising rules it is made easier for small businesses to raise funds. We have eliminated a whole layer of red tape for Victorian small business employers by combining the Commonwealth and Victorian industrial relations systems into one. We have forced government departments to assess small business impacts when reviewing existing or new regulations. We have required government purchasing to make 10 per cent of its purchases from small businesses in Australia. We are providing the Business Entry Point—a cutting of red tape through an electronic system in place. We have changed the processes of the relationships between small businesses and large businesses. We wanted to change the unfair dismissal processes and that has been successful, except in the part where the Senate has chosen to intervene.

And so in all of these areas we have brought change and improvement. It is really interesting and helpful to read comments such as those published in the Economist Intelligence Unit World Outlook 1998, which I quote:
The Australian dollar, long seen as unacceptably volatile, has ridden through the Asian currency crises reasonably well, losing value against the US dollar moderately and predictably.

That is the world judging us, and the Australian Labor Party carps here about minor things. I remind you that Paul Keating said the present Prime Minister was too narrowly focused in his view of world trade. He referred to John Howard as thinking: `I want security from Asia. I want to go back to the United States.' And, says Keating:

He (Howard) is looking for the insularity. He is always hankering after the monoculture. Whenever he has had a chance to beat the immigration drum, he has. He is always hankering after the monoculture. He does not realise that the negotiation with Asia is not complete.
Thank goodness we had a change of government and we were not locked into Asia at the most difficult time in their history and in our own development.

talk.start.para: —Government members have sought to sell this budget with a glib one-liner, `Back in black: back on track.' However, for those of us who reside in Canberra, this is a `back to back: attack after attack' budget. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), in his reply to this budget, said:

speech.para: . . . there is no point in delivering a surplus ringed by deficits. A surplus bought from the million deficits in family budgets.

I would like to take the limited time available to me today to inform the parliament about some of the deficits in the lives of residents in my electorate of Namadgi as a result of three years of the Howard government. Like its two predecessors, the third Costello budget has delivered virtually nothing for the ACT community. This budget, like the two before it, has done nothing to encourage the creation of jobs in the ACT. Unemployment in the territory has come back a little from the historic highs this government created when it sacked thousands of public servants and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), unfortunately, thumbed his nose at Canberra by his actions. However, unemployment is still far too high and more work needs to be done to reduce it.

I would like to give credit to the local Canberra businesses for their efforts to reduce unemployment—the small fall in unemployment that we have witnessed solely due to their continued investment and belief in our city. I only wonder what Canberra business could have achieved if the Commonwealth government had not cut this economy so savagely and reduced confidence so much.

The message out of this budget is that the personal deficits of thousands of unemployed Canberrans are secondary to this government's manic desire to achieve an accountant's surplus. The sad reality is that, aside from some money for minor works in the parliamentary triangle, the budget does very little to increase short-term economic activity in the ACT community. It certainly does nothing to assist Canberra families struggling to meet increased child-care costs, increased health costs and increased education costs.

There can be no doubt that this budget is paid for by two years of savage cuts to health, nursing homes, education, child care, job programs and the Public Service. A total of $821 million has been cut out of child care and not a cent has been put back; $3.6 billion out of public health in cuts to hospitals, dental services, pharmaceutical benefits and Medicare and less than $2 billion put back; $500 million from nursing homes and absolutely nothing put back in this budget; and $3 billion in cuts to universities, TAFEs, government schools and student support and just one-thirtieth of that has now been put back.

talk.start.para: —Where did you get these figures from? Don't you think the people of Canberra can read?

—The Howard government's decision to ignore Australia's unemployment crisis for three consecutive budgets shows very clearly that they have no ability to create a real future that works for Australia's jobless. Labor, by contrast, wants to rebuild and re-energise the Australian nation. Labor aims to cut unemployment to five per cent, as a first step towards achieving full employment.
—Why didn't you do it in your 13 years in government?

—Labor is committed to investing in job creation in regions of high unemployment. Labor has ambition for Australia and wants to create a future that works. I am disappointed to note not only the rude interjections but also the fact that this budget sees a continuation of the slash and burn approach to the Public Service. With another of his inane grins, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has announced 9,000 additional public sector job losses, taking the total number of jobs lost in the public sector to over 30,000 since March 1996. Who can forget the promise of the Prime Minister and the former Liberal member for Canberra, made in full-page advertisements in the Canberra Times in the lead-up to the 1996 election, that there would be only 2,500 job losses in the Public Service under a Liberal government. I do not believe that is honest.

speech.para: Since being elected in March 1996, the Howard Liberal government has delivered us a public health system lurching from crisis to crisis. In his first two budgets Mr Costello took $3.6 billion out of public health in cuts to hospitals, dental services, pharmaceutical benefits and Medicare. He has put back less than $2 billion. That does not include $500 million cut from aged care as part of the continuing nursing home fiasco for elderly Australians.

In the area of child care, the budget papers show that expenditure on child-care assistance is down by $117 million on what the government expected to spend in the year. This is the case because parents simply cannot afford formal care. They are leaving work, or putting their children into backyard care, because this government's policies have put quality child care out of their reach. The $117 million is an additional cut on top of the $820 million slashed from child care in the last two budgets. This means almost $1 billion has gone from child-care funding since the last election.

There are many human losses on which this accountant's surplus has been built. Only two days ago I received a letter from a constituent in Gordon, in my electorate, detailing the effects of this government's child-care policy on her family. This constituent had three children, aged seven, nine and 11, in an after school care program at a local primary school. She and her partner work in the federal Public Service and this after school care was invaluable in ensuring that their children were safe and engaged in supervised activities until they could be picked up after work.

In 1997 this after school care cost the family $220 per fortnight for the three children and they were eligible for the child-care cash rebate. In 1998, as a direct result of this anti-family Liberal government's policies, the new fees payable by the family jumped to $330 per fortnight—an increase of 50 per cent. Add to that the reduced rate of child-care cash rebate and this family's situation is compounded. Because of these huge increases in child-care costs, this family has been forced to remove their now 12 and 10-year-olds from the after school care program years before they intended. In her letter my constituent said:

Whilst the children are responsible and trustworthy and have access to support from adult neighbours with children at the same school, the thought that government decisions are actually working against a safe and supportive family environment is ironic considering the espoused family values upon which this Liberal government campaigned for election.

I am hearing many similar stories from families in my electorate. They are being asked to believe that this budget rewards them for carrying the cost of two years of Howard government. But we all know that it falls way short of doing so. No-one will be fooled by the policy reversals the Treasurer has announced. Most of them do not even go halfway towards making up for the savage cuts he has already made. This is a nothing budget, intended to provide a distraction while the government tries to put a positive gloss on what I believe will be its regressive GST proposals.

This government has stopped caring about people. It is a government that thousands of residents in my electorate of Namadgi want no more to do with. They want to get rid of a government that loses seven ministers and three backbenchers in two years. My Namadgi residents are sick of a Prime Minister who defends Minister Parer, with his tens of millions of dollars in family trusts, yet wants them to pay a GST on food, clothing, rent, education, health care, and rates.

We need a government that believes in progress and change for the good of the whole community, a government that believes in the rights of all individuals, not just those who are rich and powerful or have the loudest voices. As the Leader of the Opposition stated:

Labor will go into this next election believing in a different Australia. We believe in a proud, confident and intelligent Australia. Labor believes in an Australia that wants security in its workplaces, peace of mind in a strong health system, and opportunity flowing from an education system which gives its citizens the best chance they can get in a global economy.
I am looking forward to taking this alternative vision for Australia to the voters in Canberra, doing it very soon, and receiving—I might add—their very strong endorsement at the next election.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker—
—And thank you for the very rude reception. I should stay here and do the same back to you.
—You are quite welcome to.
—The member for Mitchell was heard in silence but you did not give her the same courtesy.

—We have all sat here and listened to the contribution from the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) on the Appropriation Bill, and I really think that she should speak to the Chief Opposition Whip or perhaps the Treasury spokesman because, quite clearly, she has been fed a terrible line. The member for Namadgi has got her facts on health, nursing homes, education, and child care all wrong. I could spend the next 10 minutes going into the detail of all the areas. For example, the member for Namadgi has been trying to claim that we have been taking money out of after school hours care, when the fact is that the federal government has put money into after school hours care in this budget. In fact, almost every example that she gave—cuts of $500 million to nursing homes without putting any money back, cuts of $3 billion to education with one-thirtieth of it being put back—is absolute, arrant nonsense. I would suggest that, before the member for Namadgi embarrasses herself again on an issue of such importance, she should check her facts, otherwise she is going to end up with the same reputation as Gareth Evans when it comes to fiscal credibility, which is pretty limited.

speech.para: In just under one term in government, the coalition have undone the 13 years of fiscal incompetence by the former Labor government and have given Australians a sense of safety, stability and security in the knowledge that our nation has stopped going backwards and is back on track for the 21st century.
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —In just under one term in opposition, the Labor Party have demonstrated that they are no more the wiser, as the comments by the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) from the dispatch box give evidence to. In fact, Labor would have Australia back onto their tax and spend prescription which had Australians so entrenched in national debt during the Asian boom of the early to mid-1990s.

speech.para: But old habits die hard, and Labor have already announced unfunded promises of $8 billion to the health system alone. In the time since these announcements were made, Australians have been wondering which taxes Labor would increase or introduce to fund these promises—and, hopefully, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) might give us some indication of exactly which taxes are going to be introduced or increased to fund the $8 billion of extra promises in health alone that the Labor Party has made.

Last weekend, Kim Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, went one step further in announcing that a Labor government would not only increase spending by over $8 billion, but would also deliver substantial tax cuts to Australian families. But Mr Beazley's credibility on economic issues speaks for itself. In the 1996 federal election, Mr Beazley, as Minister for Finance, looked straight into the television camera and told the Australian people that the budget would not return a deficit. The $10.5 billion budget black hole speaks volumes for the Leader of the Opposition's economic integrity. Indeed, there is a considerable body of evidence to suggest that Labor does not have the ability to deliver tax cuts. The ill-fated l-a-w, law, tax cuts which Labor promised in the 1993 election campaign were abandoned by Labor after the election. Instead of promised Labor tax cuts, Australian families and small businesses were slugged with a two per cent across-the-board increase in wholesale sales taxes.

In reciting the government's many economic accomplishments, the coalition government's fundamental achievement is occasionally overlooked. Put simply, by paying off the debts Labor left all Australians with, we are reducing our interest rate repayments on our national debt so that we have more money to spend on families, older people, education and medical research. If we can start eliminating Labor's debt, we can start redirecting the $8 billion of taxpayers' money per year in repayments, and start spending it on schools health and education instead. Many of my constituents in Sturt are already seeing the benefits of the coalition government's responsible and disciplined economic management and, as we pay off more debts, it is my expectation that people in Sturt, particularly families and older people, will see even more benefits.

The legislation presently before the House makes it possible to fund an additional 220,000 Commonwealth seniors health cards to self-funded retirees. We have raised the income test threshold from $21,000 to $40,000 for singles, and from around $36,000 to $67,000 for couples. As of 1 January 1998, cardholders will be eligible for pharmaceuticals at the concessional rate of $3.20 per year. Any prescriptions above 52 per year will be free of charge.

Also commencing on 1 January 1999 is an expansion of the gold card to include an additional 50,000 Australian World War II veterans who faced danger from hostile forces in that war. The expansion of the gold card will benefit approximately 400 veterans in Sturt, and it is a fitting benefit for their service to Australia and the Allies.

Prudent economic management has resulted in other tangible benefits for elderly Australians. Treasurer Peter Costello's announcement that the government will be further reducing the provisional tax uplift factor to five per cent has also been welcome news to people in Sturt. Increases to single's pensions of $6.80 per fortnight and $5.70 per fortnight for partnered pensioners is another indication that the coalition's policy of addressing the fundamentals of the economy is paying social dividends. The benefits which the coalition has delivered may at times seem modest and humble, but they are real and they are paid for. Any apparent benefits delivered by the former Labor government were rarely paid for and were put on the national credit card. This practice not only put Australia further into debt, but it unfairly created a fool's paradise, deceiving the Australian public into believing that our lifestyle was sustainable.

In fact, all the Labor Party ever offered Australia was deceit, deficit and debt. The coalition government acknowledges that living within our national means is not in itself a guarantee to national prosperity. The coalition government has been very conscious of the need to fund social programs which complement each other. Labor consistently demonstrated an ability to throw taxpayers' money aimlessly at dubiously conceived programs in the desperate hope that some of their expenditure would represent acceptable value for the taxpayer. The coalition has introduced a number of initiatives which complement other policies.

Labor's neglect of nursing homes, culminating in a 75 per cent cut in capital funding by the Leader of the Opposition, has been well documented in this House. Worse, the former Labor government made no attempt to cater for alternative scenarios for the elderly. I am very pleased to say that this legislation provides funding of $280 million for the government's Staying at Home: Care and Support for Older Australians package. This very important social justice program returns some autonomy and independence to the elderly. The coalition recognises that governments should provide assistance to the elderly who choose to live in their own homes when they would otherwise have been placed in a nursing home. It is all about empowering older people.

Complementing this package is a $20 million national industry restructuring package to target nursing homes most in need following the Leader of the Opposition's funding drought to nursing homes which created the appalling conditions that the coalition government has been left to fix up. Indeed, the care of our elderly and the sick remains one of this government's strongest priorities.

The government is building a stronger health system. This legislation allows for additional Commonwealth expenditure of $2.9 billion—almost $3 billion—over five years for Australian health care agreements with the states and territories, in comparison to the hastily signed agreement of 1993. The 1993 agreement between the former Labor government and the states and territories was a flawed document which allowed for state abuses of the Commonwealth funding for health. That fact was acknowledged by the Leader of the Opposition in the 1996 federal election campaign.

The availability of this additional funding underscores the coalition government's support for our public hospitals and Medicare. Again, this government will continue to introduce and develop complementary health programs. A focus on preventative health measures is one such area. Accordingly, this legislation provides for additional spending of $80 million over four years to enhance preventative health programs. Specific measures will include a free influenza vaccination program for older Australians, in addition to strategic investment in public health areas such as cancer control.

Other preventative health initiatives announced by the Treasurer include programs designed specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. An extension of the Tough on Drugs initiative is also an important area of preventative health.

Drug abuse remains one of society's greatest afflictions. The social costs have long been recognised by successive governments. However, the economic costs of drug abuse among our young are only now starting to be assessed. There is no doubt that drug abuse is placing an ever increasing strain on our public health system. The treatment of drug abuse and addiction is placing a necessary but largely avoidable pressure on the resources of Australia's health system.

Similarly, tobacco related illnesses also place a considerable strain on the public and private health systems. Heart disease suspected to be caused by smoking still accounts for an alarming proportion of patients in the health system. Administered separately, these measures will not be responsible for any substantial improvement to the health system. However, as a series of programs which complement one another, there is every reason to suspect that the coalition government's lateral approach to addressing the shortcomings of the health system will yield future dividends.

While the goals are enduring, the coalition remains a patient architect. There is plenty of evidence to suggest that we are getting there. We now have the lowest inflation since the early 1970s. Unemployment is the lowest it has been since 1990 in the recession Labor said we had to have. The coalition government's policies are also securing lower interest rates, with the lowest bank mortgage interest rates since the 1970s producing big savings for home buyers and the lowest small business interest rates since the 1960s. These are the results; we have the runs on the board.

After 13 years of Labor driving the economy into the ground, the coalition government has found a couple of gears and is driving the economy forward. The reverse gears and the double clutching of the former Labor government no longer pose a threat to the Australian economy.

talk.start.para: —The first thing I want to say about the government's budget for 1998-99 is that it is quite clearly a fraudulent document. The reason I say that is that it has been based on quite fraudulent forecasts. This has been confirmed by a former leader of the Liberal Party and a former aspirant for the position of Liberal Prime Minister, John Hewson. The budget indicates that there should be a surplus of $2.7 billion. If there is a surplus, it is going to be the first occasion on which a Liberal government has been able to provide a surplus in a budget at any time since Federation, any time this century.

speech.para: During the 1980s, there were four occasions when the Labor government had the responsibility for national economic management when it was able to provide for four consecutive budget surpluses. If there is any suggestion being made by members of the government that it is an indication of economic and financial competence when a government delivers a surplus, I remind them that during the 1980s Labor delivered four consecutive budget surpluses.

I said it was a fraudulent budget. It is a good example of a way in which a government can use sleight of hand approaches to financial management. There are examples in it of the thimble and pea trick. Media commentators and analysts who have taken the opportunity to spend more time analysing the budget are coming to the same conclusion. We will increasingly find that, in the pronouncements by those people who accept the responsibility for some deeper analysis of government financial statements and documents, they will bring those facts to the attention of the Australian people.

I said it was based on fraudulent forecasts. One of the fundamental elements of the government's forecasts, and one of the parameters on which its budget is based, is an assumption that there will be, during the coming financial year, in the Asian area economic growth of two per cent. There is no question that in the Asian area there will not be growth of two per cent.
