I need go no further in connection with that assumption than to refer, for example, to a comment by Nigel Stapleton, the senior economist with Westpac. He said:
The government still expects 2% growth in South-East Asia, but we—
that is, Westpac, and other financial institutions as well in Australia and elsewhere—
expect a negative for those economies.

That forecast by Nigel Stapleton is certainly much more reliable than the forecasts that were cooked up in the office of the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello), and it is now being refuted by all reputable and creditable economic analysts and forecasters.

I referred as well to some of the comments that have been made by a former leader of the Liberal party, Dr John Hewson. He said, in connection with the question of Australian growth over the next financial year, that it was likely to be more like 2.5 per cent than three per cent.

I draw attention to the discrepancies between the forecasts by the Treasurer's office and those by people like Dr John Hewson and Nigel Stapleton, both of whom I would credit with greater competence in the area of economic forecasting, in the area of objectivity and in the area of credibility, than those people in the Treasurer's office who were cooking up those estimates.

You will remember, Madam Deputy Speaker, that both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised that they would accept and apply the estimates and forecasts of the Treasury. They have not done so. Treasury will not endorse the forecasts which underlie this budget, because they know that those forecasts are crook. The primary underlying forecasts were cooked up in the Treasurer's office, and those forecasts are simply designed to provide the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and this government with pre-election gimmickry.

Some of the comments made by the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), who preceded me in this debate, were quite absurd. I find it difficult to understand how it is possible for members of the government to get up and make the claims they do and keep a straight face. The member for Sturt must know that those claims were not correct.

To take one element as an example, I refer to this government's attitude to the health portfolio. We all remember the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) and the Treasurer making claims that they would be injecting a 15 per cent real increase into Australia's health system over the next few years. Dr John Hewson said they are doing no such thing. Dr John Hewson said that if there is an increase in real terms over that period of time, it will be a one per cent increase.

In connection with health, the Commonwealth is still in dispute with the states. Of that $2.9 billion that is being provided by the federal government as a result of its responsibilities in this area, a mere $69 million can be considered in any way to be new money.

That was an incredible performance at the meeting of heads of government, on the question of health funding in particular. Madam Deputy Speaker, as you know, because both you and I had experience at the state level—our shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) had experience at the state level, so he could confirm this as well—there have been plenty of occasions when premiers and chief ministers of the territories have met with the Prime Minister and, as part of their tactics, they have said to the Prime Minister, `We will not proceed further with this discussion because we are not prepared to accept the offer that you have made and you know it is not fair dinkum.' And they have walked out.

But on every previous occasion when they have walked out, they have reassembled. They have met and redefined their tactics and they have come back in. That was not the case this time. For the first time ever, those premiers and those chief ministers walked out of that meeting and went home. That reflects the amount of credibility that this government has, that this Prime Minister has, that this minister for health has, that this Treasurer has. The premiers and the chief ministers—and all of them but one conservative brothers and sisters of this government—walked out of that meeting and went home. So it is not just people like ourselves who are concerned about the performance, the credibility and the truthfulness of this government—and concerned as well about the fraudulent nature of its budget.

As you know, Madam Deputy Speaker, Labor was in government for 13 years. If there is any strength underlying this economy, then that strength was built up over those 13 years. For a government, after two years, to make the claims that this government has been making is nothing short of absurd. If they believe they are fooling anyone, they fool themselves. I feel sorry, as I said, for some of those people who have attempted to defend the government.

One other thing that concerns me is that people now are referring to the budget as a statement by the government to reflect the government's financial management. I emphasise the expression `financial management'. The reason they are doing that is that the budget has ceased to be an important document, an important strategy, an important plan charting out the future direction of Australia, a document about where the government feels Australia should be heading and how Australia should be moving towards that objective.

You think to yourself, `Well, what should governments do?' The government is moving completely out of any type of involvement in the provision of national production and national services. For example, we know that the most recent exercise being undertaken is the sale of Telstra. The government is moving out of active participation and active involvement in the Australian economy. So you think to yourself, `Well what would it be doing as a national government? How would it be fulfilling its responsibilities? What is its vision? Where does it want Australia to go? How does it want Australia to get there?' Madam Deputy Speaker, you can look through that budget, as I know you and others have, and you will find no evidence of that. You will find something completely to the contrary.

For example, every time we direct a question during question time to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile), we refer to him as the minister for transport. Why do we do that? Because there is no regional development; in fact, the minister himself cancelled out any funds available to him within his portfolio for regional development. So this government has opted out of regional development. It has opted out of the hospitals in that it is now reducing the real volume of funds available for our national hospital system.

There have been reductions in transport funding, and reductions in the real level of funds for all of those types of important national initiatives, all that type of investment in national infrastructure. They have had the guts ripped out of them. Madam Deputy Speaker, I apologise for the use of the expression, but that is precisely what has happened. We expect more from governments; the Australian people expect more from governments. We want governments with vision, we want governments with commitment and we want governments that use the national annual government budget as a strategy to determine where they want the economy to move. This government has not done that.

I think it is a great pity that opportunities of that kind have been lost. I am not the only one who is referring to the change that has taken place, particularly under this government, in the role, the function, the construction and the contents of the federal budget. When they use the expression `financial management', they are talking about ordinary domestic household budgeting: `How much money are we going to get, how much money are we going to spend, what is the bottom line, is it a deficit or a surplus?' But then you look in it for some type of vision, some sort of strategy, some indication as to where this nation is going, and there is simply nothing there. It is a fraudulent document; it is a dishonest pre-election political statement.

The members on the government side know that before the budget the government asked: `Where has the greatest sensitivity been? Where do we need to take some remedial action? We've upset the elderly in connection with nursing homes, so we'll shove a bit of money in there.' They said, `As a result of the savagery of those attacks on elderly Australians, we have alienated people in those older age brackets. What we'll do now is to make a symbolic gesture, and we will lock into legislation a provision whereby the age pension in Australia will be maintained at 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings.' We said, `Well, that was a commitment that we had before.' The government said to us, `Yes, but you didn't legislate for it.'

Madam Deputy Speaker, I will tell you why we did not legislate for it, and I will tell you why they did. We did not legislate for it because we had two annual indexations of the age pension related to the CPI. As it happened, the rate of the age pension increased. We said that we would set a floor under that—that it would never be less than 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, but it could be more. And it most often was. Let every aged person in Australia realise this as well: they are being taken for mugs, the same as all the other interest groups in Australia. Let all those elderly people in Australia know this for certain: as a result of the government saying, `We will lock the age pension rate in at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings,' they have legislatively prevented it from rising above that level.

talk.start.para: —We have increased it.

—The parliamentary secretary at the table—from one of those silvertail north Sydney electorates—sits there and makes no significant contribution at all to the consideration by this parliament of the issues that come before it. The best he can do is to sit there and go on with these puerile, childish interjections. We had the same thing happen with our previous speaker, the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis). The interruptions were persistent from the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) and we see again the childish petty behaviour on the part of these members on the government side. If they spent a little more time examining the documents that have been presented—the documents that they are supposed to be able to defend but have so much difficulty in defending—they would be better using their time.

speech.para: I am aware of the constraints; we have all agreed to limit our contributions so that more people can make a contribution to this debate. I will, of course, be taking the opportunity as well within my electorate, within my ALP branches and with all of those people and organisations that I meet with regularly to expose this budget for what it is—a fraudulent document.

talk.start.para: —I call the honourable member for Dawson. I would remind the members who are in the House that, when the honourable member for Dawson has the floor, she has the floor. I am loath to keep interrupting and calling people to order, but I think out of courtesy we should refrain during this appropriation debate.
—I rise tonight to talk on the Appropriation Bill. I want to start by saying what a responsible and caring budget this has been.
—You will probably get a bit more courtesy from this side than we were getting from your side. We will extend the courtesy to you that we didn't receive.
—That does not appear to be the case. I listened to you in silence.
—I say to the member for Charlton that I have given the call to the honourable member for Dawson.

—I reiterate that this is a responsible and caring budget. It is responsible because for the first time we have an underlying budget surplus of $2.7 billion. The government has taken us back to the days of the Beatles, blue suede shoes and bell bottoms. We now have a strong economy with the lowest inflation since the early 1960s. We have the lowest interest rates since the 1970s. We are on track to more than halve the government debt ratio, the Commonwealth general net debt, by the turn of the century. We have gone from a 20 per cent debt to GDP ratio down to 10 per cent, and by the year 2000 it is anticipated that will be 1½ per cent. That is a tremendous record.

speech.para: In the meantime, we have been paying back Labor's debt. By the end of 1998-99, we will have repaid around $31 billion in net debt from the level of almost $96 billion that the government inherited. Can I explain what that means for a daily debt repayment. Every day we pay back $42 million worth of Labor's debt. Every 34 minutes we pay back a million dollars worth of debt. That is a rate of about $500 a second. That is a tremendous contribution for the people of Australia, because what it means is that inflation and interest rates are coming down.

What does that translate to for average Australians? A family with a mortgage of $100,000, which is apparently the average rate across Australia, is saving $4,000 a year on their mortgage rate. Admittedly, some families choose to draw back the period of the loan through their banking facility or financial institution. Others, however, prefer to have the money in their pockets, as well they should. For a small business, again with an average overdraft or loan, there is a saving of $2,500 each year after those five interest rate drops. That is real money for real Australians—business people and families.

In this budget we have also reduced the provisional tax uplift factor for business. When we came to government, it was eight per cent; it will be brought down to five per cent. We have set up the economy for the next millennium, we have set it up for the difficulties in South-East Asia, and we have certainly set it up as something for our children to inherit and be proud of.

Can I talk now about responsibility. Every week now in Australia we are saving $28 million by stopping social security rorts. That is a tremendous amount of money that has obviously been allowed to slip from the taxpayers' fingers in the past.

I talk about caring as well, and I want to speak about the aspects of the budget that show care and concern for those who deserve it. We are seeing the gold card extended to World War II veterans. There will be 50,000 World War II veterans who will now have access to free treatment as private patients with their choice of doctor, optical, dental, physiotherapy, podiatry and chiropractic services. They will also get the pensioner concession on pharmaceutical products, and they will not pay the Medicare levy. For these people who have in many cases sacrificed their health, and certainly their wellbeing, in facing hostile forces on behalf of us in battles around the world, I think it is a very proud thing to be able to say that we are going to care for them now when they need us most—in their old age, when they are frail and when they need health care for the sacrifices they have made for us.

I also want to talk about other Australians. From 1 January next year, not only is there the gold card for World War II veterans but there is a health care card for independent retirees. The income test threshold is being raised. For single people it is being raised from $21,000 a year to $40,000. For couples it is being raised from $36,000 to $67,000. This means that there are 220,000 self-funded retirees who will now have access to pharmaceuticals for $3.20 and, once their prescriptions exceed 52 a year, they will have those prescriptions free of charge.

This measure is perhaps just a small line in the budget, but it is one that I am particularly pleased about: caring for someone else's child is really a labour of love. Foster parents who are caring for a child who would usually be eligible for a health care card will also have access to that health care card when they are caring for the child. As I said, perhaps it is a small change but one that I think shows that we care for those who are caring for others.

The previous speaker made comments about this being pretty much a nothing budget. Can I say that we have made some very significant changes. One of the things that we are doing—and we have been trying to get it going since 1962—is providing a medical training facility in Townsville. North of Rockhampton, we have an enormous population but no medical training facility, yet in towns in the southern states there is sometimes one if not two medical schools. It has meant that our young people have had to travel sometimes 1,000 to 2,000 kilometres to Brisbane. There has been no facility for our indigenous students to train in. Now for the first time—and I am deeply grateful to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for this, and I have to thank the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who I know has put a great deal of work into this—there will be 60 medical places available through the University of Queensland, initially in Townsville and later at James Cook University as responsibility is transferred; 20 new places that have been created, 20 from the University of Queensland in Brisbane and 20 from the southern universities.

What a difference this is going to make. Five places will be held specifically for indigenous students. I have just finished a tour with one of our standing committees through Cape York and the Torres Strait and the need for indigenous medical practitioners there is very great. An indigenous medical officer is able to give culturally appropriate care. There is a far better opportunity for an indigenous doctor to have indigenous people attend a clinic. It is going to make a tremendous difference. I am pleased that our young people in the north are going to have the opportunity to attend this new medical training facility.

They are going to change the entry criteria. In many of the southern universities entry is based on academic performance. While that is appropriate, it needs to be broadened such that young people who have the desire to serve as a medical practitioner, who are looking to go to far-flung communities, and who are not fazed by the idea of being obstetricians, anaesthetists, GPs or surgeons in difficult circumstances, are able to gain entry to our new university. I am very excited about this change. It is going to cost the Commonwealth $1.2 million a year in recurring costs, but it is a tremendous chance for our young people and one I am very pleased has finally been delivered for the north.

In the few moments left to me I would like to mention another initiative for our regional areas: $50 million for the Australian Tourist Commission, with $8 million specifically for rural and regional areas. This is certainly going to allow us to promote tourism in our regional areas. Sadly, as a result of the South- East Asian crisis, we have seen a fall-off in the number of international tourists, but I believe that this will greatly assist. With the small $1 million package we had for the Whitsundays, we were able to increase our tourist numbers there by six per cent, a very encouraging figure. I believe that budget initiative will greatly assist in boosting those numbers in regional areas. I commend the budget to the House.

talk.start.para: —Clearly, the mantra from the government is `back on track'. I can inform the House that this government is way off track when it comes to the most serious issue of unemployment, be it youth unemployment or mature age unemployment. I suggest to the House that the budget is the final confirmation that the Howard government is a government that will not generate jobs. For the third year in a row, the Howard-Costello government has brought down a budget which does nothing to tackle Australia's No. 1 economic and social problem—unemployment.

speech.para: The government's own forecasts are that the unemployment rate—and the former leader of the government in opposition, Dr Hewson, has seriously questioned these forecasts—will rise above eight per cent again in the coming months and stay stuck at eight per cent on average over the next 12 months. That is in the budget papers—the government's own forecasts. The budget forecasts that economic growth will slump sharply to three per cent in each of the next two years, well below the four per cent levels which this government has never achieved and that are needed to get unemployment down. The forecast of 1¾per cent employment growth for the next year is even less than the original forecast of two per cent employment growth made in last year's budget—and they are back on track! I would hate to see them if they were off track.

As we all know, even the original modest forecast itself had to be reduced sharply mid-year to 1¼ per cent in a humiliating admission of failure by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). The government is now aiming, I might indicate, for less than one-half the employment growth which Labor was generating in government and it will not even get this, based on its own economic growth projections.

The government also expects no improvement in Australia's low participation rate which, interestingly, has fallen by more than half a percentage point since the Howard government came to office, reflecting people's loss of hope of finding jobs. The truth is that some 90,000 fewer people are looking for jobs now than were when the Howard government was elected. If these people had not been pushed out of the search for work by the lack of hope in the capacity of this government to create jobs, the official rate would have risen dramatically to as high as 8.8 per cent today. That is what the real unemployment rate would be today if the participation rate which existed at the time of the last election had held up.

In his budget speech, the Treasurer claimed, `A particular concern has been our unemployed youth.' He tried to make out to the Australian public that the government has done well in this respect, but what he failed to refer to was the actual factual situation. Let us go to the factual situation. It shows very clearly that in fact the government has set youth unemployment rising from 26.4 per cent to 27.1 per cent since it was elected 26 months ago. Moreover and unfortunately, it has also driven up the number of long-term unemployed people in Australia by 33,200. That is important because more and more of those people are middle-aged unemployed people with family responsibilities—and the government suggests that it is back on track!

Unfortunately, the government has now announced further measures which will worsen these trends. It announced in its third budget that $147.6 million less will be spent on employment services in the next four years, and that is at a time of a very serious employment situation. These further deep cuts can only make it harder to get the long-term unemployed back to work. The Treasurer said in his budget speech that the government has `improved incentives for employers to take on apprentices'. Again I ask: what are the facts?

In fact, its first two budgets cut many of these incentives, leading to a fall of 5,000 apprenticeship commencements since Labor's last full year in office. That is 5,000 fewer apprenticeship commencements since this government was elected, and that is at a time of major emerging skill shortages in Australia. We all know the potential impact of those skill shortages not only for employment in Australia but also, unfortunately, for wages and, potentially, the rate of inflation.

The Treasurer now seems to think that an expanded work for the dole scheme is a solution to youth unemployment. That is the Treasurer's way forward, even though the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) has previously clearly admitted in this House that work for the dole is `not a solution to youth unemployment'. Expansion of work for the dole, with no innovation to introduce skills training and turn it into a comprehensive work experience program, will do nothing to generate real jobs. Enforcement of work for the dole on older Australians—the hidden agenda of a second Howard government—who need real jobs and real incomes, rather than being pointed at and blamed for being unemployed, will cause real resentment and alienation in middle Australia.

No serious new measures to tackle unemployment were, I suggest to the House, announced at all in this third Howard-Costello budget. The only new program, or endeavour to create a suggestion that there is a new program, detailed in the budget is for 500 Australians aged under 30—and, interestingly, mostly with professional qualifications—to go and work overseas. This is hardly in line with the need to generate and create tens of thousands of jobs here at home for the most disadvantaged of our young people.

Further, the claimed announcement of an additional $350 million over four years for a range of measures to address problems associated with youth unemployment was all announced way back in January. Talk about recycling announcements—this contribution was actually in a prime ministerial headland speech announced in Adelaide in January this year. This is another endeavour to clearly misrepresent to the Australian public the real situation—announced in January, reannounced on budget night.

The net new spending on jobs programs represents less than one-fifth—that is right, one-fifth—of what has cumulatively been taken out of jobs programs by this government in three Howard-Costello budgets. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs will put up to $13 million more into regional assistance programs. I suppose we can say that, on balance, this is better than nothing. But, at best, it will restore specific funds for regional employment strategies to little more than half the levels when the coalition took office—small bickies from a mealy-mouthed government. It really is small bickies for regional Australia from a mealy-mouthed government that has no commitment to regional Australia.

It is also fair to suggest that the government has inflicted two years of pain on regional Australia by cutting programs and closing offices and services. The end result has seen the unemployment rate rise sharply in seats like Richmond, Page, Gilmore, Braddon and Bass. Now, in acknowledgment of the pain it chose to inflict, the government is making a few soothing sounds rather than acting for genuine repair and regeneration.

The extra $142.8 million for the new literacy and numeracy training program for the young unemployed might sound good on the face of it, but the devil is in the detail. So too do the other small increases in the jobs related programs announced in the budget. But they do not sound as good when you put them into a proper perspective, and that is what tonight's budget discussion is about. It is a real objective analysis of what has occurred not just in this budget but over 26 months of the Howard-Costello regime.

Those announcements must be compared with the $1.8 billion cut—that is what it is—in the Howard government's very first budget from a wide suite of effective jobs programs. The $6.4 million extra to help young people gain the skills necessary to begin an apprenticeship also sounds good, but the truth is that it comes after a $14.3 million cut from vocational training in the previous budget, a cut principally made up of reductions of incen tives for employers to take on new apprentices. In addition, there were huge cuts in vocational education and training grants to the states—short-sighted actions which have caused new training opportunities for our young to decline.

Further, the short-sighted, dishonest and double dealing nature of this government is also apparent in its actions on immigration policy, and its lack of action and support of multiculturalism was again reinforced in question time today by the Deputy Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). Not surprisingly from a government which is now giving preferences to Pauline Hanson, this budget again fails to deliver an active commitment to the anti-racism campaign it promised Australia prior to the last election. I suppose then they were after votes from multicultural Australia; today they are after votes from One Nation Australia.

In this budget, the government has also completely ignored the need to provide help to get newly arrived migrants into jobs. No initiative has been taken to improve the prospects of migrants, who no longer get unemployment benefits, to receive active assistance to find work in their first two years in Australia. You cannot have your cake and eat it too. You cannot say no benefits whilst at the same time saying to those people who want to work that there is no assistance to get the skills and no ability to actually seek out work in Australia. In that vein, there has been no restoration of the hundreds of millions of dollars cut in the two previous budgets from specialised programs which improved migrants training in the English language and their chances of employment—programs like the job seeker preparation and support program, the special intervention program and the highly effective job clubs.

One initiative in this budget is to commit $51.6 million over four years to enhance visa processing and improve border monitoring. Obviously, the opposition supports the intent of those announcements, but we do not support a grab for dollars, as is really the nature of that visa charge.

I suggest to the House that this government is not back on track. Yes, there is plenty in the government coffers, but what about the pain and suffering that Australia at large is now experiencing? What about the fact that, as a result of this budget, yet more Australian Public Service jobs will disappear? In actual fact, 9,000 in total. There have been no initiatives to help the displaced, mature aged unemployed. There has been no help for those new arrivals to actually get the skills to get a job. I suggest that we are going backwards on the training front, with fewer apprenticeship commencements and no commitment in this budget to do something to reduce unemployment.

Labor by contrast wants to rebuild and re-energise the Australian nation. We will aim to cut unemployment to five per cent as a first step towards achieving full employment—a target which, despite intimidation from the coalition once they were elected, the department of employment actually acknowledged that Labor in government could have achieved. We are committed to investing in job creation programs and committed to investing in actual training opportunities for our young people, rather than the cruelty of pointing the finger and suggesting that they themselves are responsible for being unemployed. It is about leadership, it is about decisiveness, it is about a willingness to actually take a few risks and do something for Australia's unemployed.

The government is not on track. The fundamentals go to a sense of security in people's lives, which in turn is about a job, a reasonable level of income and the right to go to work and not be confronted with a situation in which you could be sacked for daring to belong to a union. That is what this government stands for—not safety, security and stability, but really an endeavour to undermine security in people's lives and to rip away from families a capacity to live with a sense of love and compassion not only within their own family home but within the broader community.

One Nation first. No sense of compassion. It is about divisiveness and Australia going backwards. That is the real intent and the end result of three successive Howard-Costello budgets. I believe that the Australian com munity are finally awake to the fact that they were conned in the lead-up to the last election. Promises were made; promises have been broken. There is no sense of cohesion in Australia. It is about governing on the basis of divide and rule, division, short-sighted decisions and no long-term perspectives. Australia deserves better than what is on the table tonight for discussion after three successive Howard-Costello budgets.

talk.start.para: —I think I need to pick up a couple of points that were mentioned by the previous speaker, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), before I go to what I had planned to speak about. The first thing that I would say to the honourable member for Batman is that his statement that the government is giving its preferences to Pauline Hanson is simply not true. That sort of outrageous statement has to be challenged, and it has to be put on the record that it is not true. The government has not made any such statement. In fact, many members in this House—including me and I believe the gentleman at the table, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock)—have made it abundantly clear that that will not happen. So let us make it quite clear that the government has made no statement that it is going to give its preferences to One Nation. The government has made no such statement, and the member for Batman knows that what he said is not true.

speech.para: The second point I want to make about the member for Batman's contribution is that, as the opposition spokesman for employment, he spent a large part of his time talking about unemployment figures, quoting figures, playing with figures and so on. Unemployment is a very serious issue and we can play with the figures all day, but there are a number of key figures that the member for Batman needs to understand, and I will use my electorate as a good example.

My electorate is an outer eastern suburban electorate in Melbourne and in 1983, when the ALP came to power, the local unemployment rate was 1.4 per cent. When the ALP left government, the unemployment rate was about nine per cent. That was the result of 13 years of Labor government. Obviously, we all understand that the vagaries of economics, the influence of world economies and so on mean that the rate is going to vary under any government over a period of time. But if at the end of 13 years we have an unemployment increase of that size, then that sends a very clear message to my electorate.

What this government has done is turn around a super tanker—the national economy is clearly a super tanker—and it is not easy to do that. You cannot turn it around in five minutes but, in a little over two years, we have brought the national unemployment rate down to under eight per cent and the trend is downwards. It seems to me that they are key figures that we need to put into perspective.

I want to try to address in the brief time I have got this evening a couple of issues. I want to talk about the impact of the budget on my electorate and, if I have time, I want to talk about a particular area of interest, overseas aid. My electorate in outer eastern Melbourne is a typical middle-Australia electorate. It is overwhelmingly young. Twenty-five years ago it was all fields and orchards. It has now been built out. We have a huge number of mortgage payers. Until recently, I had the most number of mortgage payers in any electorate in the country. It is filled with young families, blue-collar workers, semi-skilled white-collar workers, not the captains of industry and not particularly people with a high tertiary education—nevertheless, it has a lot of people in wholesale and retail. It is really typical middle-Australia.

This budget has been the third of a series of good budgets for electorates such as mine. Of course there has been some pain. We inherited a huge debt from the previous government. Clearly, to put any household or any national economy on the right track you need to stop bleeding to death every year in terms of debt. That is something we have had to do. Of course that has caused some pain. We regret that, but it is necessary. We have also done a number of very good things partly due to our economic management and partly because of international economic factors, but very largely due to our sound economic management.

Interest rates have come down spectacularly. When I was elected in 1990 by winning the seat from the Labor Party, interest rates in my electorate were 17 per cent. They are now under seven per cent. A large part of that is due to the good economic management of this country. Inflation is under control. That is good for pensioners and that is good for the average family so that their household bills do not go up day by day.

As I said before, unemployment is trending down. Unemployment in my electorate is now 6.4 per cent compared with well over eight per cent when we came to government. So the runs are on the board. As we have heard, we have a surplus in the federal budget for the first time in many years. That is good basic housekeeping that is not achieved without some pain, but it is necessary, because you cannot go on running up a debt year after year as the previous government did.

We have also delivered other things. We promised before we got elected that we would deliver tax cuts to families, and they were delivered on time and in full. I would remind the honourable gentleman who spoke before me that that is in sharp contrast with the promises made by the previous Prime Minister who promised before the 1993 election the l-a-w tax cuts, which never happened. Worse than the fact that they did not happen is that, when the Labor government got returned after 1993, not only did we not get the l-a-w tax cuts for families but also all the wholesale sale taxes went up and went up and went up. So there was an extra tax slug. This government has not increased the tax take at all. There have also been a number of other things in terms of the gold card for veterans and so on and so forth. We have turned around the disastrous financial situation which we inherited and we have started to put together a sound basis for the future.

There is more to be done. One of the things that the opposition has said is, `Why don't you spend some of your surplus out of this budget?' What we know from history is that throwing money at problems does not always work. We saw the previous government throw money at job programs and all sorts of other things and tax more and spend more, but it was not effective in terms of dealing with unemployment. It was not effective in terms of cranking up the economy. It was not effective in terms of boosting our exports. Just throwing money at the problem is not the answer. Given the Asian problem, which is an external factor and a reality that we have to deal with, we need to be prudent. We need to have some money in the bank.

Of course we have more to do. We know that we need to sort out the tax system. We know that the tax package will come before the next election. That will be a replacement tax package for what is there now with no extra tax, with more equity across the board and where the low paid will be well looked after. The reality of life is that when we introduce that tax package the detail will be on the table. That is in marked contrast to everything we have heard from the opposition in recent weeks. We hear a few general good intentions but we do not hear how it is going to happen. The member for Batman said that the Labor Party will aim for a rate of five per cent unemployment but of course gave absolutely no detail—absolutely no detail—of how that would be achieved.

There are things that we will be talking about in the next few weeks. Obviously there are further things we want to do in health. We have already talked about privatising more of Telstra so that we can clear more of the federal government debt so that we have a smaller interest bill so that we, recurrent year after year, can provide the services and the goods to the electorate that they need and deserve.

In the brief time I have available to me I want to say something about a particular area of interest. Although that wide economic question is most important, there are particular areas that I would like to have the chance to talk about. One is the subject of overseas aid. It is interesting that governments of both persuasions over the years have cut the aid budget. This year for the first time for a long time we have seen an increase in the overseas aid budget. This country is going to spend $1.48 billion in aid during the next 12 months. That is a $50 million increase. It is not a huge amount, but at least it is a move in the right direction, and it is a move in the right direction for the first time in many years.

We are spending some 0.27 per cent of GNP on overseas development aid compared with the average of aid giving countries of 0.25 per cent. We are slightly ahead of the game, but it is not as good as the average that both this government and the previous government set of 0.7 per cent. We rank ninth out of 21 of the OECD aid givers. I think it is a creditable performance, but I would certainly be urging the government to spend more. There are some 1.3 billion people in the world who live on less than a dollar a day. A wealthy country like Australia has a responsibility to spend more on overseas aid.

We focus on health, education, infrastructure, agriculture, rural development and governance. We do it bilaterally, we do it through regional arrangements and we do it through multilateral arrangements. We do it through disaster relief. We spend about a quarter of our aid in PNG, but we also help in many other parts of the world. This is an area where I would be pleased to see the government, as we continue to deliver those healthy budgets in future years, take advantage of having got back in the black by increasing our aid budget.

I see that I am out of time. I will leave the House with this thought: we are back in the black. We are back on track, but we are not complacent. We know what we have to do. We have a very clear plan as to how to get there, which is in stark contrast to the opposition.

talk.start.para: —Back on track, on the backs of my constituents. Those opposite can brag as much as they wish about being back on track, but they should just understand that there are many constituents in their electorates in exactly the same situation as my constituents with the loss of services, the increased costs for pharmaceuticals and the entry fees for nursing homes. You can try to pretend that it is not happening but it is there. We know it is there and we know you are getting complaints about it.

speech.para: I say to my dear colleague the member for Aston (Mr Nugent) that the government has a bit of cheek: you have thrown $1.6 billion at private health funds to try to prop them up when less than one in three people in this country think that putting money into private health funds is value for money. With less than one in three people are in private health funds, you have thrown more and more money at them—and now you are proposing to throw more. Well may you complain, but look at your own record and your own performance.

This is a mark time budget, a budget to fill in the gap until the government's real agenda is revealed in the coming election campaign. It is a budget about which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and government members brag. They brag about the estimated $2.7 billion surplus in the coming year—a surplus built on the backs of the families, on the backs of the unemployed and on the backs of the pensioners, the aged, the ill; a surplus obtained by attacking those in our community who need help the most.

There are two major concerns for people today—jobs and job security—but this budget does nothing to address those issues. If anything, it seeks to aggravate those issues. It does nothing to give hope to the unemployed, nor to make those in work feel more secure about their jobs. In fact, this government's policies do the opposite. A budget surplus should be built on growth and job creation, not on savage budget cuts. Bracket creep alone in the income tax scales in this budget will add $4½ billion to revenue in 1998-99.

There is a lack of credibility in the forecasts for economic growth and employment. In 1997-98, employment growth was 1¼ per cent at a time when gross domestic product growth was 3¾ per cent. This government is now forecasting in the budget a GDP growth of only three per cent but an accelerated growth in employment of 1¾ per cent. That cannot be right. It is not factual. If GDP growth goes down, you are trying to tell us, employment growth will go up. Numbers are numbers: it does not add up; it does not compute. It is just a bit of presentation until the election comes. Clearly the growth estimates are fudged, and they cannot be believed.

In this government's first 26 months in office, it has increased employment by an average of 9,077 jobs per month, or 236,000 jobs in total, compared with a growth of 550,000 jobs in Labor's last 26 months in office, which is an average rate of 21,154 new jobs per month. The budget is forecasting unemployment to rise back to over eight per cent—and surely it will with the contents of the budget during the coming year—before again dropping to below eight per cent. As I said, those estimates are fudged.

The participation rate has already dropped from 63.8 per cent to 63.2 per cent. That is, there are 88,000 fewer people in the work force today than in March 1996. Add those 88,000 people into the equation and you have an unemployment rate of 8.8 per cent. So you can play with the numbers, you can fiddle and you can fudge, but the truth is the truth.

In my electorate, in regional Australia, the unemployment rate is considerably higher and rising. That is happening because the government is discouraging people out of the work force with increased child-care charges, with less service available from employment offices and with less money available for programs to help create employment. In regional Australia where I come from people are being discouraged out of the work force and, when they drop out, it means the participation rate goes down. The government seeks to achieve a lower unemployment rate in that way.

Savage cuts since this government was elected include outlays in education down by $3,000 million and outlays in health of $3.6 billion. The budget puts back $2 billion, still leaving a deficit of $1½ billion. That $3.6 billion consists of $1.4 billion cut from pharmaceuticals, $800 million from public hospitals, $1 billion from Medicare and $400 million from the abolition of dental care.

Other cuts include outlays on job programs down by $1½ billion; child care down by $800 million, rising to $1 billion later; aged care down by $400 million; and 79,200 people slashed from the federal Public Service. Australians will not forget these meas ures. Australians in the next few weeks will not forget those actions of this government. Certainly, they will not forget the savage nursing home entry fees that this government has forced in.

The Commonwealth seniors health card will be made available to 220,000 self-funded retirees. My constituents are asking me: why is it that single pensioners on $9,000 per year and couples on $15,000 per year are forced to pay more for the newest and safest drugs under the therapeutic group premiums and why have 20 drugs been removed from the PBS altogether?

Likewise, I have had young families—they are earning between $25,000 and $33,000 a year with children to rear and a mortgage to pay—asking me: why is it that retired people over 65 years of age who have no children and an income of $60,000 a year can pay $3.20 for their prescription when they as a young family have to pay $20? These are questions the government is going to have to answer. As one age pensioner in my electorate commented, `As far as pensioners are concerned, I didn't think we were given anything compared to retirees.'

The budget surplus is built on ruthless and destructive decisions to dismantle public services, to abolish entitlements and to increase taxes and charges that are hurting families, retirees and the unemployed and that are retarding regional Australia—especially people in the Hunter and Central Coast regions where I come from. Since March 1996, in our area, more than 700 federal Public Service jobs have been abolished by this government and the flow-on effect has directly caused the loss of a further 2,000 jobs in the private sector.

Some of the jobs and services that have been ripped from our region include: the Immigration office in Newcastle being closed; the Customs Service reduced to a token level; the Belmont CES office closed, and then all CES offices abolished; the funding of publicly assisted non-CES employment offices cut or abolished altogether; the area office of DEETYA abolished where 104 jobs went in one swoop; Charlestown Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service abolished; and the Swansea Visiting Service of the Department of Social Security abolished. The Department of Social Security has been absorbed into a shrunken Centrelink agency—an agency which is quite unable to handle the tasks being placed upon it, such as the example last week of 4,000 cheques not being sent out to beneficiaries because of inadequate resources being available. The latest is the closure of the Belmont Medicare office.

These closures, these abolitions of staff, are causing more mistakes, longer delays and worse service for people who need Commonwealth services. In government, Labor recognised that regions needed regional services and that services and the jobs that provide services needed to be brought to the regions. So we did that. But this government's speediest action on election was to abolish the regional development division of the Department of Transport and Regional Development. It was first off—bang. I have never seen a departmental division disappear so quickly.

In 1993, Australians saw through the three-card trick of the GST that was canvassed by the Liberal-National parties at that time. The Australian people threw it out; they knew it was unfair to most families in this country. They would not have a bar of it. That is why the current Prime Minister said on 2 May 1995:
A GST or anything resembling it is no longer Coalition Policy. Nor will it be policy at any time in the future. It is completely off the political agenda in Australia.
He went further. Almost a year later on 19 April 1996 he said:
No, there's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy—never, ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters at the last election.

This never-ever Prime Minister's `never-ever' apparently means `in just a few short years'—maybe one and a half years or two years. There is a new definition now. This is the same Prime Minister who cannot even say sorry, who does not have the heart, the feeling, the respect for other fellow Australians to say sorry.

talk.start.para: —What rubbish!
—All the world can see it, if you cannot, dear colleague. If your eyes are shut and your ears are sealed, I am sorry for you.

speech.para: The families of Australia know one thing. A GST takes more tax from families on low incomes and takes less tax from families on high incomes. A GST is not fair. It has no regard for capacity to pay. It is a tax which increases the cost of bread, meat, milk, child care, fruit, vegetables and other necessities in order to make the price of expensive cars and luxury items cheaper. There is one thing you can say about a GST: the price of a Mercedes will go down, but the price of second-hand cars will go up. I have to say that in my electorate there are a number of my constituents who have to make do with second-hand cars as they cannot afford Mercedes.

But this is the same Prime Minister who, as Treasurer, gave us that wonderful trifecta of his: double-digit inflation, double-digit unemployment and record cash interest rates. But there is more: the first negative growth in thirty years, a 60 cents in the dollar marginal personal income tax rate and a company tax rate of 46 cents in the dollar. And there is more: double taxation of dividends—tax the company profits and then tax the dividends in the hands of the recipient. This is the same gentleman. Prime Minister Howard was the Treasurer Howard who did that for several years. And he gave us a top sales tax rate, the sales tax system that he now rails against. The sales tax system is the child of conservative governments since World War II. He had a beautiful rate—the top rate was 32.5 cents in the dollar. The wholesale sales tax system of today is the legacy of earlier Liberal-National Party governments.

But the king hit of Treasurer Howard's legacy was the $25 billion deficit, in today's dollar terms, for the incoming government, concealed—not revealed, deliberately concealed. There was advice from the then Secretary to the Treasury, John Stone, of the deficit which was concealed. That was the legacy that we picked up. So do not ever let me hear from the other side and from this Prime Minister any railing about what our government did. I lived through his government. I saw the results of it and I have heard it, over and over.

The Treasurer also studiously ignored the advice of the then Taxation Commissioner. Under Treasurer Howard, paying income tax for high income earners became optional. The bottom-of-the-harbour tax rorts raged. He had advice to deal with them but he did not. He deliberately ignored it, over and over again. So paying income tax was optional if you were on a high enough income.

But now he says to low and middle income Australians, `Trust me, I will bring you a tax system. It is not too far away. It is a year into the great tax adventure—only a year since I first mentioned it—but trust me, it will be a fair and honest tax. It will be a good tax for you. Trust me.' No Australian trusts him. Ask the pensioners who no longer get their pharmaceuticals or who pay more for their pharmaceuticals. Ask the pensioners and the aged sick who now have to pay to get into a nursing home. Ask the mothers with their children in child care—they trusted him. And so it went on. But this Prime Minister says, `Trust me.'

Journalists have been waiting for a year for this great taxation adventure to take place. Now we see—and we hear it from government members opposite—that they hope to sneak it in, after holding it back as long as they can. They say to the opposition: `What is your tax policy, opposition? You have not revealed it.' We say to you: put your proposal out now because Australia can see what it is that you are trying to do by holding it back. You are trying to sneak it through in the few weeks of an election campaign, just as you did with so many of your policies in the 1996 election. You are trying to make sure there is no time to examine, analyse and expose the unfairness of it.

In my last minute and a half, because of the limited time, I just want to say something about the government's new slogan of safety, stability and security. This Australian, and the Australians where I come from, do not want a bar of your government's security. Your form of government security has been seen around the world as an appalling spectacle: uniformed thugs, balaclavas, guard dogs, mace sprays, midnight raids on law-abiding citizens and their workplaces, vilification of members of unions, their wives and their kids.

All Australians are coming to realise that when you have a government, a prime minister, a treasurer, a minister for workplace relations and a former minister for transport who actively support a corporation and a corporation leader that contrives the bankruptcy of its own companies so that it can avoid its obligations to its own employees, then no working man or woman in this country is safe. More and more people are coming to understand that now.

We are seeing the greatest debacle in transport, in international trade and commerce, that this country has ever seen. How has this happened? Why have hundreds of millions of dollars been lost? It is because of the incompetence, the sheer malice, the malevolence of this government and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) and the apparatchiks around him, and their manic and obsessive hatred for people who work on the waterfront and on ships. The plot was hatched last year and, as the weeks go by, more and more will be revealed. That is not the Australia my constituents want, and that is not the Australia that Australians in general will want. We will see that in the election results in a few weeks time.

talk.start.para: —This budget has been welcomed by hardworking Australians, by those who need and are looking for work, those who are frail and elderly and those who are raising their children. The budget has been welcomed in particular by the people of the electorate of Murray—the people I so proudly represent—because Murray is a region that needs a lot of infrastructure support. It is an area that has a fragile environment and, as a regional area of Australia, that environment needs to be sustained so that the economic basis of the local economy—the agribusiness—can thrive, but not at the expense of our biodiversity and the watertable situation which, as many people in the coalition understand, is one of the most difficult problems we have to deal with.

speech.para: The budget brought some of the nation's hard-earned dollars to the electorate to help build the infrastructure and roads. You can imagine the joy when the $53 million for the four lanes of the Goulburn Valley Highway was finally announced in the budget. That highway has been a federally funded highway for quite some time, but it was ignored by the previous government. When that highway becomes four lanes it can transport the fruit, dairy products, rice and the products of our vineyards to the ports and wharves of Australia where those products can get out of this country quicker, especially after reform on the waterfront. This $53 million is for the first section. In announcing the funding of the section from Seymour to Nagambie, our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced the plan to take the highway through to the border. You can imagine what a difference that will make in a region that depends on our transport systems to ensure we can become world competitive in agricultural trade through fast and reliable delivery.

At the same time, we welcome the continuation of the funding of the Supermarket to Asia initiative. The Murray electorate is a major food producer and manufacturer and without the growing access to markets that our budget encourages through the export market development grants and other initiatives, such as the research and development funds, we cannot compete with other nations that produce products not dissimilar to ours.

With the Supermarket to Asia initiative we have been able to develop a local Murray Supermarket to Asia forum. We have a secretariat funded through the federal initiative. That forum has all of our smaller and larger food manufacturers gathering together where they can address issues such as our skills gaps, energy needs and problems such as brownouts—and our ageing power supply systems. Our manufacturers can get together to talk about collectively bargaining for a cheaper power supply. They can discuss industrial relations issues. In particular, they can discuss how we can ensure the development of new local food manufacturing industries across our region.

Without a government like ours, regional Australia would have continued to feel that they were the poor relations of this nation. We would have continued to see the brain drain, with our brightest and best leaving the country areas as soon as possible in search of education and jobs. Another significant budget initiative for this nation is the attention now given to traineeships and apprenticeships and the extra dollars for our tertiary education systems.

It is incredible that the opposition once claimed to be on the side of the blue-collar worker, yet it was under Labor governments that this nation saw the biggest decimation of trade skilling that there has ever been. In fact, our tradespeople became an endangered species as it became more and more difficult to get an apprenticeship. Skills gaps were evident throughout Australia but particularly in regional Australia. For the first time in the electorate of Murray, we are seeing a growth in apprenticeships. For the first time, we are seeing manufacturers able to go into our schools and have industry-school linked programs where our young people are taking on courses that relate to jobs like metal fabricating and food technology, hospitality and tourism.

It took this government to address the fact that only 30 per cent or so of our young people move on to university education. Under the previous government, the other 70 per cent were supposed to make do as best they could—supposedly failing the system because they did not reach that golden goal of a university education. Our government sees every young Australian as having the same potential to be a major contributor to our economy and to the cultural and social life of our nation. We expect to see, over time, a redressing of the imbalance between people who are skilled technicians and those who are skilled in other areas.

In an electorate such as Murray, which is only a few hours from a capital city like Melbourne, it seems incredible—but it is true—that we have major problems in attracting doctors to our hospitals and general practices. This budget has addressed these significant problems. We see, particularly in Murray, the ongoing funding of the Goulburn Valley-Melbourne University department of rural health. This department is one of seven throughout Australia. It is an initiative that was long overdue, but of course it would never have seen the light of day under the previous government. Labor simply did not understand that, while doctors might cluster in the metropolitan areas of Australia, with bulk-billing clinics on every second corner, our rural population was going without the most basic of medical service provisions, or the access was so limited that the poor and the needy went without.

I remind honourable members that in a city the size of the Shepparton only 26 per cent of those who go to a general practitioner have access to bulk-billing services. The average in Australia is well over 80 per cent. So this government has addressed issues such as the maldistribution of general practitioners in Australia, and is making sure that, as time goes by, we reverse the flow of our young doctor graduates into the cities and see them coming out to the regions.

With our department of rural health in the Goulburn Valley Hospital now established and receiving another $1 million in infrastructure support, we can look forward to perhaps becoming in our part of Victoria an international centre for rural health services training. That is our goal and our vision. I was very proud to preside over a meeting just last week with our medical service providers from the region who will be establishing a reference group to help support this initiative. We look forward to working very closely with Melbourne University as they help us to reverse this status differential between medical service providers who work in cities and those who choose to come to the country. I know that you will agree with me, Madam Deputy Speaker, that doctors who practise in country areas have to be much more skilled, much more dedicated, to take up practices in regions, compared to those who stay in metropolitan centres.

As a regional electorate we looked at the budget and we saw that there was a major commitment to looking after our older Australians and our veterans. Of course, in an area like Murray where much of it was developed through Soldiers Settlements and where we have older and long established communities going back six and seven generations, we have huge numbers of veterans and a number of self-funded retirees. You can imagine how they responded when they saw that we are now going to make sure that self-funded retirees are not treated differently from those who earn extra while they are very rightly in receipt of social security benefits and are of similar age to themselves. They also welcome some access to health care cards.

It is those sorts of initiatives that have made Australians understand that we really do look hard at our constituencies. We listen. We are not captured by minority or interest groups who are mostly to be found in the big cities or around the coastal fringes. This government considers the needs of all Australians. It understands the needs of its ethnic and racial minorities. It understands the needs of women. It understands that regional Australia often does it hard; that at the same time we are communities who deserve the same standards of living; that we have the same sorts of aspirations for our children as those who happen to be born in the cities.

So I am proud to be part of this government and to be a representative of a region. And I am proud to say that I do not expect to see my constituents paying much attention to the sorts of threats and innuendos made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who seemed to suggest, for example, that we let people down when we addressed the problems of maldistribution of funds that previously went too often to health services based in bigger population areas.

I also remind the previous speaker about our spending on the indigenous population of Australia, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. The previous speaker seemed to suggest that we were not as caring as the former government. From one look at this budget you can see that our expenditure on indigenous affairs is substantially higher than its expenditure in previous years. But it is not just dollars that count. For all the dollars spent we want to see an improvement in the life experience of indigenous people.

As I was saying earlier this week, it is one thing to talk about the need for reconciliation in this nation—I do not think any caring Australian ignores or rejects that concept—but you cannot talk seriously about reconciliation if you do not seriously address the fact that our indigenous populations have poor health and poor housing and employment outcomes. As long as a young Australian Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island baby is born with less of an opportunity to grow up healthy compared with a mainstream Australian, no-one on the opposition benches can stand proud.

Not only do we have the right sense of caring and sharing with all Australians, particularly our indigenous populations, but also we believe that the additional dollars we put into our budget will be better spent. We are going to target those dollars where they can be used, where our indigenous populations have said that they feel the dollars need to be spent. We are going to make sure that at the end of the day we monitor that spending and that there are outcomes that change the life experiences and outcomes of our indigenous people.

So this budget is a caring budget. It is economically responsible. It is making sure that our nation can weather the storms that are right now buffeting some of our Asian neighbours. It is a budget that is particularly important for regional Australians. And as a regional representative I have been very proud to present this budget back in my electorate, where it has received nothing but praise. It is with a great deal of pride that as a member of this government I look forward to our next term in office when we can see the groundwork that we have laid in the first three years consolidated and we lead this nation to being a substantial player in our region and, ultimately, internationally.

talk.start.para: —I rise to join tonight's debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1998-99 conscious of the fact that it is getting late in the evening, that the parliament has sat through the dinner break and that there are more than 30 speakers on the list of those waiting to make their contribution. So I intend to limit my remarks.

speech.para: This is the first time in my parliamentary career—which spans more than 14 years as a state parliamentarian and the past two years as a federal parliamentarian—that I have spoken on an appropriation bill, free from the shackles of the dominance and, dare I say, the subjugation by the major political party system that greatly diminishes the integrity of its MPs. This imposition of undemocratic disciplines robs the parliament—and consequently the people—of its proper functions of legislative review and scrutiny of government actions, as well as unconscionably forcing MPs to toe the party line, thereby putting the party ahead of the people.

I listened to contributions by honourable members of the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Labor Party in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1998-99 , the contents of which were predictable. The Liberals and National Party members all fell over each other in their fawning adulation of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and his budget. Everything he did was right and visionary and would prove to be the solution to Australia's ills!

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!
—Of course, they all made sure that they said the obligatory things about the Labor Party being the source of all of our society's ills, and so it went on and on.
—Hear, hear!

—I note the `Hear, hears' from the ministers at the table. No mention was made by any of the coalition members, in the spirit of constructive criticism, as to how the budget may have been improved on or any personal disappointments they may have had as to any lack of specific funding for their electorate, no doubt out of concern of a resultant rebuke from the party elite. The Labor members' contributions were exactly the same but in the reverse; everything contained in the budget was wrong, mean and peppered with their predictions of doomsday being just around the corner. Little wonder then that there is such growing disenchantment by more and more Australians who see Australia's system of government—both Labor and coalition—placing all the power in the hands of the Prime Minister and his cabinet who now dominate the national parliament of this nation.

speech.para: I remind honourable members that it was not always like that. In the beginning, all parliamentarians were independent people—there were no parties—and the government was answerable directly to the people through its representatives. So I join the debate tonight on the appropriation bill before the parliament as an Independent, which differentiates me from the coalition MPs and the Labor MPs in that I can be supportive or otherwise of the government of the day on the issues as I see them. Ultimately, my constituents will judge me accordingly at the ballot box. However, what my constituents know is that I will stand up for them and place them and their interests ahead of that of the interests of the political elite.

Therefore, my comments in tonight's debate follow my new-found freedom, which, incidentally, is now shared by a record number of eight Independent members of the House of Representatives of this, the national parliament of Australia—eight Independent MPs representing a record number of one million Australians.

I turn now to some specific details in the budget that I want to comment upon. On the positive side, the budget predicts a surplus of $2.7 billion in 1998-99, bringing the budget into the black for the first time in 10 years. It also gives an additional 220,000 long-suffering self-funded retirees some assistance in providing a seniors health card. Cardholders can access eligible pharmaceuticals at concessional prices of $3.20, with prescriptions in excess of 52 within a year being free of charge. Also, all Australian citizens aged 65 and over will be able to access free flu vaccines.

From January 1999, the gold card will be extended to an additional 50,000 World War II veterans—those over 70 who faced danger from hostile forces—with free treatment as a private patient, choice of doctor and other benefits.

Another initiative in this budget that will be welcomed by the business community is the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor. The budget will allow businesses to accelerate the tax deductibility of the cost of the computer software to tackle the year 2000 millennium bug by assisting the business community to the sum of $1 billion over a four-year period.

Also, $127 million will be provided over four years to fully index Medicare rebates and to encourage doctors to bulk-bill. I note that there is an extra $50 million for foreign aid, taking the aid allocation to a very respectable $1.48 billion. Indigenous health programs get a much needed lift of $73 million over four years. The environment receives a sizeable amount of $294½ million for Natural Heritage Trust programs. I am pleased to note that defence spending remains virtually unchanged at $10.9 billion—that is, nearly $11,000 million. That, no doubt, will be well received by our military.

I turn now to the negatives contained in this budget. We have a health care system in crisis on our hands. In the Treasurer's first two budgets, $3.6 billion was taken out of public health with cuts to hospitals, dental services, pharmaceutical benefits and Medicare. In this budget, as we have heard stated several times this evening, less than $2 billion has been put back.

Treasurer Costello has taken $500 million from nursing homes and put nothing back. The Treasurer is keen to keep repeating his phrase `the budget is back in the black'. However, it is a black day for our senior citizens who are dependent on nursing homes. Seniors will find it increasingly difficult to obtain a nursing home bed. Additionally and tragically, some nursing homes providing quality care may be forced to close their doors. Despite assurances to the contrary, the coalition government has not provided capital funding for the building of new nursing homes beds for the less privileged and for the refurbishment of existing facilities.

About 10 per cent of Australia's 3,000 older nursing homes are simply not able to produce the necessary funds from their own resources to upgrade. This problem is further com pounded by the fact that there has been a decline in numbers entering nursing homes following the introduction of means tested fees for new residents in April of this year. Under great difficulties, nursing homes are providing top flight care. However, unless they upgrade, they will be forced to close and the government will stand condemned.

In the education portfolio, there have been cuts of $3 billion from universities, TAFEs, government schools and student support, and just one-thirtieth of that has been put back in this budget. No mention at all has been made of science and innovation in this budget—hard to believe, but true. This further compounds the problems caused by the massive $1.7 billion cuts to the research and development tax concessions which have driven down private sector investment just when Australia needs jobs growth. The lack of adequate funding for research and development is forcing many of our top scientists and researchers to relocate overseas, and Australia is the poorer for this.

I believe the cuts to university operating grants of $378 million by the year 2001 represent one of the greatest mistakes of this budget. It will be felt increasingly by our university undergraduates over the next few years, to Australia's detriment.

I turn now to what will no doubt be one of the two or three major issues at the forthcoming election. I refer to unemployment, which languishes at around the eight per cent mark, and at an unforgivable 28 per cent for youth unemployment. Honourable members will no doubt recall the recent debates we have had in this parliament on the issue of youth suicides. Australia now has, on a pro rata basis, the highest rate in the industrialised world, to Australia's shame. A projected three per cent growth figure in this budget is just too low to make any appreciable inroads into our chronic unemployment figures. It certainly gives little hope to our unemployed young people.

I well recall the billboard truck organised by the coalition when they were in opposition which travelled all over Australia prior to the federal election and in which they were highly critical of the Keating government's youth unemployment rate. In fact, I well recall that billboard truck visiting my own electorate when I was the Liberal candidate for Lowe, when the then opposition leader and now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) visited my electorate for a photo opportunity. Two years later, during the term of the Howard government, we find the youth unemployment rate virtually unchanged at an unacceptable 28 per cent. The social impact on our unemployed young people is devastating.

I do not want to in any way belittle the pain and suffering which all of the 740,000 unemployed Australians and their families experience, especially those aged 45 and over who are in the prime of their lives—the mature-aged unemployed who have children to support and mortgages to pay off. However, most of them at least have had a taste of working life. One-third of our unemployed young Australians have not even had that most basic of all experiences, to work, and many will probably continue in the ranks of the unemployed; gradually, they will join the ranks of the long- term unemployed and, regrettably, they will then become unemployable, unless we act now to eradicate this national shame which can only be rectified by government intervention by way of a large job creation program.

I turn now to the issue of families and child care. Parents with unemployed 16- and 17-year-olds will be deprived of government assistance, with no dole and loss of other benefits. Additionally, families with unemployed 18- and 19- year-olds will find that their children's dole payments will be reduced once the parental income reaches $23,350.

In child care, one small mercy is that there have been no further budget cuts to add to the $800 million in cuts since the Howard government came to power. Nothing was put back in this budget. An unheard-of 68 private centres closed their doors last year. The response by the minister to this tragedy is to establish a new child-care advisory council to investigate—another committee under the old and tired, timeworn government excuse to do nothing while awaiting the findings of a committee. This injustice hurts Australia's working mothers with young children the most, as they are badly affected by the Howard government's cutbacks in child-care funding.

The hoped-for assistance for ordinary families with sick children by providing medicines for free or at the $3.20 rate did not eventuate. Perhaps Adele Horin put it best in the Sydney Morning Herald when she said, in describing the budget:
Families are usually the focus of the Government's rhetoric, but in this budget, they hardly rate a mention.

In summary, my assessment of the budget is that it is a `steady as she goes' economic document but it does little for the most disadvantaged in our society. The $7 billion of spending cuts over the past two years, with all the resultant pain and suffering, in hindsight, we now know may not have been necessary at all. As I said earlier, it is regrettable that the federal budget provides little vision and hope for the average Australian, who is under constant social and economic pressure.
