I conclude by saying that the budget, apart from going into surplus, does little to reassure our fellow Australians that the Howard government is other than the classic economic rationalist government, with little heart for pursuing the framework for a just, compassionate and tolerant society.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I am mindful of the time. As I said in my opening remarks, so as to allow as many speakers as possible to speak on the budget, I will go into specific details as to how the budget impacts on my electorate of Lowe when the matter is debated in the Main Committee. I conclude my remarks at this point.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the budget tonight, and I want to take a slightly different angle from that which has been approached by many so far. I think if one term were to sum up what the Labor years in government were about, it was a roller-coaster ride—there were good times and there were bad times. But the bottom line was that there was very little security for the future. People did not know whether we were going to have high inflation, low inflation, a surplus, a deficit, whether we were going to be attacking unemployment, or pumping up the economy with massive inputs of money, which the Keating government certainly attempted to do to bring down unemployment.

speech.para: The one thing that industry needs, the one thing that business needs more than any other, is certainty as to what the future holds. By doing that, they can then invest with some sort of surety. We have seen only too clearly in recent months what has happened in Asia. The tiger economies, as they were known—and they were heralded as being what we should be aiming for—are now seen, as they lie in ruins, to be something of a myth. These were economies that were built on false promises. They were built on governments chasing money, chasing foreign capital, and putting into place a regime which looked good, but the fundamentals were not there.

It is important if you are going to have jobs growth not to hide figures, as the opposition certainly did in job market programs, or to prop up the economy. Japan has tried that. Japan has pumped trillions of dollars into its economy, yet unemployment has continued to rise and there has been very little growth.

These are only short-term measures. It takes a government with real steel and real determination to ensure that the decisions and the policies are put in place so that everybody can benefit long term from economic growth. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), spoke about the lack of growth and that three per cent was going to be insufficient to create jobs. It would be great if the economy was travelling at four or five per cent—and if they are the sorts of projections he would like us to make, I am afraid that he is looking at pie in the sky. The fact is that Asia, which we have got most of our growth from, is now in recession. At best, it is on a level playing field and bumping along the bottom, and many economies are recording negative growth.

On the basis of that, and since we export so much of what we produce, how does he propose to create the jobs and the job making programs that he says the government should produce? It simply cannot happen. Under the previous government, over successive budgets we saw inflation rise rapidly and fall. We saw interest rates rise, as we have heard time and again, with business interest rates exceeding 20 per cent. Let us put that into perspective: if you borrowed $1 million as a small business you would be paying $200,000 in interest—that is, you would have to make $200,000 profit just to repay your interest, and you have not even looked at your capital yet. If you were looking at Australia as an opportunity in which to invest, would you do so on that basis? We are not talking about outside capital; we are talking about Australians investing in Australia. And they wonder why the icons of Australia went offshore. Simply, it was because there was not the money or the confidence in this country for people to invest in their own nation—and that is a very sad state of affairs.

The problems with this economy were also ones of inflexibility in our labour market arrangements. We had the Accord in place for 13 years. It held the Labor government in power and destroyed the framework which made this country great, including the flexibility that allowed people to negotiate in the workplace to ensure that the worker and the boss worked cohesively to produce an outcome which was going to be good for both and good for the country.

This government has taken on industrial relations and, with the assistance of others in other places, in particular the former Senator Cheryl Kernot, ensured that there were major reforms in that area. We have taken on the waterfront. Why? Not for some ideological daydream, as the ALP would have you believe, but simply because business needs to have a framework whereby their products can leave this country and enter this country in an efficient and cost effective manner. It is not about whether you get 24 or 17 or 16 containers out of the port every hour; it is about the surety of knowing that when that ship arrives, it is going to be unloaded and your product is going to be at your door in a very short period of time. I was in small business. I needed that reliability and I never got it. Waterfront reform must be taken on.

Tax reform is the other major reform issue. This government has already indicated, and the whole of Australia knows, that we are prepared to take it on. Why? Because it is a fun thing to do? Well, of course it is not. People stop me in the street and say, `Why the heck don't you just do it after the next election?' If they only looked over at those in the other place, they would know just how obstructionist they are—and that is quite improper. On top of that, aren't we elected to take on the difficult decisions? Aren't we elected to do the things that need to be done for the country? Why should we shrink away from the task that is before us?

Keating recognised that it needed to be done in 1985, but his party room did not have the guts to do it—that is the bottom line. Hewson recognised that it had to be done. Whatever his failings, he recognised the challenge for Australia, took it up and, unfortunately for Australia's sake, he was rejected. People say to us, `Why would you take it up again?' The simple fact is that this system, this Labor system of taxation, has got more holes in it than you can poke a stick at and, at the end of the day, if we do not fix it, then Australia is going to be in peril.

I will return to where Australia's future lies in the few minutes remaining to me. Australia is so fortunately placed geographically in the Asian region, this area which, whilst it has had a major setback, I believe will grow again into the new millennium. We are well placed to take great benefit from that growth, but it will not happen naturally. It will not happen unless the fundamentals are in place so that Australian and foreign companies that intend to work from this country, to export and to create jobs know that we have a low inflation rate which is going to stay, know that we have low interest rates which are going stay, know that we have an industrial relations system which they can rely on and know that they can get productivity for the dollar that they spend. If you have those things, they finally will know that when they produce the product, it is not going to be held up at the port and rot in containers, if it happens to be fresh produce, or know that they are going to lose contracts because they were not able to maintain the contractual arrangements with their overseas customers.

Of what we produce as a nation, 80 per cent is exported. Most countries consume most of what they produce and export the surplus, but we do the opposite. If we close ourselves off to globalisation and to those opportunities, we stop the opportunities for young people to get jobs—and I do not think either party wants to see that happen. That is why the government has undertaken industrial relations and waterfront reform and has ensured that we have the budget back in balance so that we take the pressure off inflation and interest rates.

I saw on the news tonight that GMH had a great announcement for all Australians. They are now selling 7,000 new Holdens to the Middle East. These are not rural products or primary industry or mining products—they are manufactured goods. Australian products are world quality, and they expect to be able to export 40,000 GMH cars in the very near future. That is over $1 billion in cars alone. That is more Australian jobs for South Australia. In an area of South Australia where they are going to have to set up a new assembly line, it will mean jobs for the people in those suburbs. Elizabeth is a suburb that I have visited and I know well. They require those jobs because GMH is the largest single employer. In fact, a lot of people believe that if they do not get a job at GMH their future is very limited. So now more of those people have a future because GMH, working in consultation with this government with the package of reform measures that were put in place to assist that industry, has been able to export cars for Australians. That is a marvellous thing for us.

Madam Deputy Speaker, we must get away from being on the roller-coaster ride. We have to give back to Australians some security into the future. Business has to know that it can invest its hard-earned capital with some surety, and that if it does that, then the jobs that the other speakers have spoken about will be there. They will not be there on a false promise of taxpayers' money being spent on pumping up a false economy. You must get those economically rational fundamentals right. People do not like them; they do not like to talk about them; and they do not necessarily understand them. But if they are not there, you cannot produce the social equities that this country needs. The greatest social equity that any government can produce is a job for everybody that wants one.

This government has achieved the lowest rate of unemployment in eight years; it has done that in only two years of office. Remember, we only sat for the first time on 30 April 1996. We have been in this parliament for just two years, and we have an eight-year low in unemployment. That is something to be proud of, but it will improve only if we are able to ensure that the fundamentals we have put in place can be built on. The waterfront reform must be completed and tax reform must go through.

If we get those two things, we will build much needed infrastructure for this country—I will speak about that at a later time—and this country can be, and will be, not only the focal point for Asia but also the manufacturing sector not just for minerals and primary produce but for manufactured goods and highly technical goods for the rest of the world. We can do it, and we will do it, as long as this government is given the mandate to continue the work that it has commenced in the first two years.

talk.start.para: —I listened with interest to the comments of the previous speaker, the member for Longman (Mr Brough). I must say that, in the parlance of judging Olympic diving, the $2.7 billion surplus delivered by this government is worth a nine for fiscal gymnastics, but for style, in the area of social economics and in terms of social deficit, I would have to give it a mark closer to nil. There were no tax increases, and one would assume there will be no borrowing as a consequence. But we still have a very serious current account deficit. My colleague the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) alluded to this last night. He suggested, and I agree with him, that that is largely a result of the lack of any serious industry policy from this government, in that we have allowed our industry to be downgraded to such an extent over recent decades that we are in a parlous state. In fact, we are in a state far worse than some of our neighbours who are regarded as being in a serious economic condition.

speech.para: We may be back in the black and back on track, and there may be some very good points in this budget, such as the 34c rebate for landcare, which on the surface appears pretty attractive, but I have already had feedback from my electorate to suggest that, on the income threshold that has been set, there is perhaps very little scope for anyone to invest the $5,000 required to attract the 34c. Assuming everyone does, there would be $80 million worth of rebate available, and one would suggest that, at 34c, it means there is a potential $240 million of investment in landcare, fencing and tackling the critical problem of weeds and other issues out there. But I think not. I do not think we are going to get that sort of investment. I do not think it is attractive enough to attack in any way the environmental concerns, particularly of those farmers out there in landcare groups who tell me there is no incentive in the system, particularly for fencing, to pay for the requirements to do a decent job.

This budget is good for self-funded retirees, with the provision of a health card, and for veterans, with the gold card. I must point out here my admiration for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott). There are many ministers with whom I have had a lot of dealings and for whom I have a lot of time, including the minister at the table, the Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government (Mr Somlyay), but Mr Scott is a stand-out in this regard for his understanding of his particular portfolio and his sensitivity to the needs of our veterans.
While my political opponents may say, `What has an Independent achieved in the seat of Calare?' it is interesting to go through the list I have been keeping of what we actually have achieved.

talk.start.para: —Not as much as in Curtin.

—As the member for Curtin would acknowledge, the very fact that an Independent is the incumbent in this seat means that it is disregarded at the absolute peril of both the major parties. That is the irony of the whole situation. I have enjoyed the establishment of offices for veterans' affairs in both Orange and Oberon. I think two out of only three in inland New South Wales are in the seat of Calare. They are doing a very great job to fill a real need out there amongst our veteran community.

speech.para: Calare has had $1.5 million in landcare and $2 million in black spot funding out of a budget of $38 million. Calare has done very well in that regard from this government. There was an announcement last week of $250,000 for the home and community care program in Lithgow. Orange, Blayney and Bathurst have increased amounts under that same program. There are also the multipurpose health centres, which I have spoken about to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). I have put submissions to the two ministers responsible for family services.

talk.start.para: —I thought you did not like this budget.
—The member for Curtin is not in his place.

—If the member for Curtin is patient, I will get on to the negatives in a moment. The Yeoval multipurpose centre in my own electorate is an example of the sort of health service we require in country Australia, delivering everything from acute care through to aged care. In Yeoval's case, it delivers it in an absolutely reactive fashion to the needs of that community and is doing it exceptionally well. That particular community centre was grown from a local cooperative when the classic economic rationalist, Nick Greiner, a graduate of the Harvard School of Economics, decided that Yeoval had no further purpose in the health system in this state. They fought like mad and held on to it, and now they have the absolute model of what smaller community health care should be in this country. This government has recognised that, and I hope it recognises it even further in that particular hospital's claim for dementia care assistance in the next little while.

speech.para: Moving on to the bad aspects of this budget, in the area of health care for the aged, there was no restoration of cuts to the dental health program, which I think every member in this House has had feedback and represen tations on. It was not just a trial program that had run out of time. It filled a real need out there in the community, and I think that no member can fairly say that it did not and that it should not be restored.

There was no restoration of services like the tax office in Orange. The lack of a tax office is continuing to cause enormous difficulties for small businesses, tax agents, accountants and the general public. There is concern over operational subsidies for child care. Why were some of these not restored in some of the areas that have lost them and are finding it particularly difficult to provide an economic service to the clientele?

A lot of this budget is premised on the sale of Telstra. The billion dollar Natural Heritage Trust fund was established with the first sale. I remember speaking on that particular bill, and the former shadow minister for the environment, now the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), spoke to me afterwards and said that he agreed with my point that a billion dollars for the environment is, to use a colloquial phrase, absolutely sweet Fanny Adams given the extent of the problem in the environment that is facing us.

In that speech I said that the Murray-Darling Basin is not a 2001 problem, it is a 2101 problem if we are going to attack it properly and that we need a billion dollars alone for it if we are going to reverse the degradation of that particular catchment area. What happens when this money runs out? If you did a survey or a referendum west of the sandstone curtain, 68 per cent would be against the further sale of Telstra, and Australia-wide it would be up to 80 per cent in the country areas. Why? Because after that one-third sale of Telstra they have seen a decrease in the standard of service out there from Telstra.

They know, the same as with their mobile phone coverage and the analog coverage, that the marketplace is all about maximising the return to shareholders, maximising the income from those major profit generating areas, but not giving a damn about those more remote areas. With the review currently being done on analog, I hope that the ACA listens not to the digital providers but to the many councils, farmers and other community groups that have put in submissions on this. You might find that the analog system will have to remain as it is until we have a cost-effective satellite system or whatever else in place to cover the area that analog covers now.

Driven as it is by the Harvard school and the economic rationalists, or whatever we want to call them, the whole economic debate has lacked for many years discussion of the issue of social economics. I am not talking about socialism, I am talking about social economics. I am talking about the cost of not doing things. I am talking about the cost of not rebuilding our infrastructure, which has fallen in a heap over the last 20 years. I am talking about the cost of not providing adequate services to people in the bush: the banks; the government services; the selling off of banks, and the Commonwealth bank in particular, and the lack of community obligation that they now show; the threat to the post office services in the marketplace situation; and the cost of not adhering to community service obligations, whether it be State Rail or Telstra phones.

I am talking about things like filling in the fiscal black hole where we have a surplus at the end of the day, but we truly do have a social deficit. I am talking about things like the income maintenance period, a particularly cruel innovation which was brought in in September last year. For instance, those laid off from the Clarence coalmine or from the Blayney abattoir suddenly found that they could not access newstart or any social security assistance until such time as they used up their accrued holiday pay, long-service leave, sick pay and such—which, in many cases, particularly in the abattoir and the mine, they had saved up diligently over 25 years.

Those people had worked their butts off, working double shifts in some cases, to set that money aside as a nest egg for retirement, as a compensation for the superannuation they did not have. What do they find now? Wham! From September last year the income maintenance period requires them to use that for the period of the leave for which it applied. How fair is that when we are talking about savings and when we are talking about people providing not only for their retirement but for the insecurity that is in the workplace now. As someone in business said recently, `No-one should expect to go to work on Monday and think they will have a job on Friday.' That is the sort of climate we are working in today, with people seen as units of cost and not employees, and there is bitterness and insecurity out there, and that is the sort of hard edge of economic rationalism that is really cutting people to the quick out there.

Calare is a cross-section of Australia, judging from the parliamentary report that most members have received, with 8½ per cent unemployment which is just above the national average. But it is not the Centrelink client figures that are so often quoted as the official number of unemployed; the figure is 20 per cent, in fact, with underemployment thrown in. People are cobbling together a portfolio of part-time and casual jobs to try to keep the whole thing together. They are the people who are really hurting out there. You only have to work for an hour a week and you are not on the unemployment list. That is the hidden unemployment and the hidden hurt in our economy.

America claims that it has four per cent or three per cent unemployment, but let us look at the underemployment in economies like that. Let's not just spruik the official figures, because there is a very large hidden number of people in all of the Western economies, particularly Germany, who are going to be the seeds of discontent in this 80:20 society that is emerging in the Western world. In America, they do not have to vote, so the government does not have to care a hell of a lot about them. I am very concerned about any moves to cut out compulsory voting in this country because I fear that the sort of people who consider just marketplace economics will not give a damn about that 20 per cent either, and I do not want to see that sort of country here.

We are not talking about the dead hand of government, as has been suggested by the Japanese finance minister recently. I am talking about a benign hand of government. We are all representatives of the people, for heaven's sake, whether it be in parliament or in government. It is not a dead hand of gov ernment unless you let the bureaucrats, the Treasury people and the executive get hold of it. We should debate things here, talk about them openly, talk about the hurts out there. We should not do it behind the closed doors of the party room but in here, in the debating chamber, where only the Independents really give questions from left field and debate these issues with any real passion.

Trade policies are bewildering people out there. The pig farmers at the moment are told, `Readjust. Get used to it. If you're a 100-sow piggery, you're too small. Get out.' So what do we have? We have corporation piggeries from Canada sending boned leg ham into this country. Of course they could do it cheaper. It is the same story as Thailand where apple producers from my electorate worked their butts off for 10 years to get a market in Thailand—good exporters, efficient. What happened? The Chinese gazumped that market with American help. They planted a million acres of Fuji apples, I think it was. They took their market away, undid 10 years of hard work, and they said, `What's the worth of this? We're not big enough. How do we get critical mass together to challenge that sort of thing?' That is the sort of thing we have to look at in this whole trade debate.

Infrastructure support: why are we running away from government supporting infrastructure? Why is there $18 million less for roads in this budget? I know they have taken the local government component of that out and added it on to the general roads grant—and it looks pretty impressive. But when I look at the figures—correct me if I am wrong—it stands out. It is $18 billion less than last year. It is a trend that has continued for the last six or seven years.

What about the Great Western Highway? Is there going to be some sort of announcement about a road of national importance before the election? Let us hope there is. What about the Parkes IMC export airport concept? There are 50 councils out there supporting it. Already the consultants have said it is a goer. Let us see if David Asimus says it is or whether the excuse of a depressed Asia will be a convenient way out. Let us look at the social economic factor. Build social economics back into it because there are people out there who are hurting and seriously questioning why we have to downsize by so much in both the government and the corporatised sectors. The power industry is another on the agenda.

I support, and have supported, the `user who can pay' principle in aged care. I have been out there arguing that in very difficult circumstances for this government. I have been talking to big meetings of old people and saying, `Those who can afford to pay should expect to pay.' I have no problems with that. I support the amendments to the unfair dismissal legislation. I know that in small business it drives a wedge between the employer and the employee. It should not be there for just 15 employees—perhaps 20 or fewer employees.

The government has better targeted child care generally, but I have concerns about some of the operational subsidies in several cases. I support workplace reform—and I have said so—but the amended one that includes the Industrial Relations Commission. You must have the arbitrator. You must have the judge. You must have the middleman. But I do not support a payout using a public line of credit to help Patrick's out of their problem.

There has to be a fair return to the bush. Local governments are down on their grants over the last couple of years, despite the two per cent increase this year. They are behind the Council of Australian Governments' agreement several years ago. We have to finance from the non-productive into the productive sectors of the economy. The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the member for Kalgoorlie alluded to that last night so eloquently.

Job generation in the bush is what we should be about, and that involves the benign hand of government spending some more to generate those jobs and to get those infrastructure projects rolling, especially for the young people. I have 21 per cent young unemployed—the 15s to 19s—in Calare. The Australian average is not much above that. There is very little sign in this budget of anything that tells me about job generation.

talk.start.para: —It is very easy in this place to be negative, to harp on things that are facing governments, and in many respects I think that is when they see their leaders, the representatives of communities, spending so much time dwelling on negatives and criticisms at a time when we are looking for fresh ideas. We are looking for reasons to provide encouragement to young people, some of those young unemployed that the member for Calare (Mr Andren) spoke of.

speech.para: We are not so much talking, though, about the beauty and the elegance in the dive—to pick up the member for Calare's analogy. The fact that it is technically sound is a good step in the right direction, I believe, because you can always add some flair to sound technique. It is when the flair is presented as a substitute for technique that we have problems, and this is what this budget is about rectifying.

The member for Calare may be interested to know that, under the former Labor government where flair and the sizzle were more important than the stake and the technique, we had $80 billion of debt accumulated to this nation—$4,500 for every man, woman and child. Not only do we know in our own lives and in our own homes that we cannot continue to accumulate debt, as it is lead in our saddlebag in many respects, but in servicing that debt we displace the resources that are available into probably the singularly most unproductive use of resources of this nation—that is, paying off the debt.

This budget sets about ending that sizzle and that flair that the member for Calare seemed to be alluding to. That is the same fluff and fanfare that the vast majority of Australians found quite repugnant in the former Labor government, where the fanfare and the fluff seemed to be more important than getting on with addressing some of the real issues in real people's lives.

This is why I am quite proud to be standing here tonight talking about this third budget as the representative of the fine community of Dunkley on the Mornington Peninsula in Victoria. It is a place that has for many years always looked within itself and to itself to address some of the issues that are before the community. It has that spirit that says, `We've got challenges before us but, gee, we've got some opportunities.' There is one thing that inspires the community that I am a part of and that I seek to support: the simple fact that our opportunities, by any measure, far outweigh the difficulties and challenges that we face.

But we need a bit of wit, we need a bit of courage, we need a bit of creativity, we need people with ideas, we need people like the members of the Howard government, who are prepared to look at the issues standing in the way of our achieving those opportunities and securing the benefits of those opportunities for our people. That is what we need in this place. That is what this nation needs—people who can identify those opportunities and deliver them as good results for real people in this nation, not people who sit back and nitpick over myopic details and spend a lot of time hand-wringing about things we would all like to address.

This is not a perfect world, but this is a great nation. Dunkley is a great electorate with fantastic people in it, and we have got this opportunity now before us as a nation to build on these solid fundamentals—the technique that the member for Calare sought to deride—and move forward and take advantage of the opportunities that are all around us. I would much rather have a solid technique and a solid foundation to pursue those opportunities than have the fluff, the sizzle and the fanfare because that goes. When people stop gum-flapping, that goes and the opportunities go with them.

This is truly a terrific budget. It is an exciting time in our nation's history. To those people who are listening to the discussion tonight, I just ask them to think about the opportunities that are here. People in my electorate say to me, `Bruce, there is so much going on in this world, sometimes you can't hear your own heartbeat.' Things are moving so quickly. Issues are before them. They are getting bombarded with information, and they cannot sometimes hear themselves think. Now we have got a budget that is actually saying that, to help separate the good from the bad, to secure the opportunities that are there and to protect us against the risks that we are exposed to—that every citizen of the world is exposed to—let us get the foundations right. Without a solid base, securing those opportunities is not doable. If you cannot rely on where your feet stand, how do you reach up for something that is in the stars? How do you do it? You do not do it.

You do not secure those opportunities for the nation by standing up in this parliament—and I am talking about any member in this parliament—and just deriding and making negative points. Negative points sell in politics; you know that, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is far easier to sell a negative line than it is to inspire someone with something positive and something that is looking forward. The Howard government has actually accepted that great challenge of trying to map out a better future for the nation and trying to tackle the difficult issues that are before us so as to secure that.

You have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talk about safety, security and stability. I think we would all like that peaceful life where we know what the next day holds, where we can be certain about the sorts of issues we have to put our minds to and where we can be certain about the sorts of experiences we can expect. That is a luxury that I do not think many of us can enjoy. I certainly cannot and most of the people I represent cannot. What they do look for in their representative is someone to help them improve their circumstances, and that is what is really terrific about this budget.

This is the third budget in a series of Howard government budgets. It is the third budget in a series that has helped deliver the lowest unemployment rate since Paul Keating told the Australian people that it was the recession we had to have. That is what he told the people, and they are the same people who the Labor Party members are telling us are so terrified. Guess who frightened them. It was the Labor government which stood up and said, `I'm sorry. We're going to turn your life on its head because this is the recession we had to have.' That was the arrogance of the Labor government and Keating. You wonder what has shaken the tree of many of the people in our country. I think that had a large part to play in it. It ruined so many small businesses. It meant people who dreamed of owning their own homes all of a sudden saw negative equity in their homes. They were paying ballistic interest rates. An enormous proportion of the income that was available to their household was going just to keep a roof over their heads, and having a roof over their heads was the No. 1 goal for them.

The government sought to address these issues in a sensible and thoughtful way that recognised that we do have to make some choices and live within our means. Above all, we sought to provide a solid foundation to secure those opportunities that were before us and we are starting to see the advantages. For example, low interest rates are like a breath of fresh air to the small businesses in the Dunkley electorate. For the families who are trying to buy their homes, this is like an enormous weight off their backs. There was trauma in their lives, wondering if they were going to be able to make that mortgage payment because interest rates in the past were so high. We have greatly reduced that burden on them and they are more comfortable and more secure in their own homes because of it.

I have spoken of the unemployment rate. On the Mornington Peninsula, there are 25,000 more people in employment now than when the Labor government was thrown out and the Howard government was elected. That is 25,000 real people who now have an income stream from working. If you are wondering what that does for people, how that inspires them, I can tell you that all of a sudden we have had this enormous leap in the participation rate of those of working age on the Mornington Peninsula. From being some way behind the national average, it is now four per cent above the national average and over 67 per cent. Our unemployment rate on the Mornington Peninsula is too high, as long as there is one person looking for employment and not able to secure it.

I am suggesting that we have achieved, over the three coalition budgets, enormous steps in the right direction. But within that third budget that we are speaking about tonight, we are not seeing promises that are irresponsible, that cannot be funded and that are reckless. We are seeing modest commitments that are funded and that are responsive to very real needs in real people's lives, like the lives of the people in the electorate of Dunkley.

To take one example, I refer to the decision to give seniors health cards to self-funded retirees. What a sensible move that is for people who have gone without, who have been frugal in their earlier lives or have provided for their own retirement and who, on most measures, may have very little difference in their disposable income from those perhaps on an old aged pension, yet are denied the reward for their frugalness. This is a sensible, affordable measure that 1,500 self-funded retirees in the community I represent will benefit from. I say good on them and congratulations to the Howard government.

There is also the issue of the gold card for the very many veterans in the Dunkley community. We have a very proud veterans community in the Dunkley electorate with very good veterans organisations supporting them. The decision to allocate the gold card to those World War II veterans over 70 who faced danger in their service of this nation is an enormously positive decision for those people.

My theme tonight is to look at the foundations the Howard government has delivered this nation and to look at how we are now better placed to secure some of those opportunities that we all know are in our lives and in our region. What I hope to be talking about for years to come in this place in representing the Dunkley community is how we have continued to reduce the unemployment rate and how we have continued to be able to provide more benefits to those that need them because we have a solid base to work from whereby those benefits are secure simply because they are not funded on the bankcard—and we all know that we cannot fund programs on that basis forever.

You wonder about security and you wonder about those sorts of social programs. The best way to put those programs at risk is to have more of them than we can afford, because then it is just a matter of time before they disappear before our very eyes. That is not the sort of comfort, the security and the safety that I hope to contribute to the Dunkley community by being a part of the Howard government. I will save many of my other remarks for another occasion in this place.

talk.start.para: —Australian science will always be a sound enterprise, given the quality of the people and institutions which underpin the endeavour. But, taken as a whole, science now lacks public policy direction and vision. In the context of this parliament, we seem to be running towards an election even though the term of this parliament still has something like nearly a year to run, but it does seem as if the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is in election mode. Following his third budget, something which the House is debating this evening, it is indeed appropriate at this two-year mark to review those three Howard budgets in the context of science and to see how science and innovation have fared under this government.

speech.para: That can be best expressed in a quotation from the President of FASTS, the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies. In response to the budget document, Professor Peter Cullen said:
This Government seems bereft of ideas. Competitive success in the next century will be won by countries which follow the knowledge-based path, to generate real and enduring employment.
This requires a strong science base and smart programs to link industry with science. This needs strong leadership from Government.
That is not what we are getting from this government in the area of science. Let us look at the way in which this government has treated the various aspects of our science budget.

Again, in this year's budget statement and the budget speech by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) there was no mention of science or of innovation or of research and development. Unfortunately, the government has again failed to highlight in the Treasurer's budget speech the importance of science and technology, of innovation and of research and development in the generation of economic wealth in this country and securing jobs for Australians in the next century.

We have many fine institutions in this country who have a long and proud record of public sector science. The CSIRO, our CRCs and the universities are all institutions that have contributed a lot to Australian science over the years and have ensured that this country has a sound base on which to build a good scientific reputation in the world.

The CSIRO is an organisation which this government promised, when it was in opposition, would benefit from a substantial injection of public funds. Unfortunately, the promise was honoured both in the undertaking and in the breach. The funds were provided to CSIRO but additional funds were taken from CSIRO to bring that total back to a net negative for the organisation. Although the additional funding was provided, the final consequence, as is so often the case with this government, has been a record of failure, a record of withdrawing funding rather than boosting it. The same is true of the CRCs, the cooperative research centres, which are such a good mechanism for bringing industry, academics, leading edge research and postgraduate students together in one environment which is well directed towards the applied benefit of industry. Those CRCs have again seen their overall budget reduced.

After allowing the CRCs to be suspended in a period of disbelief following the Mortimer report, which recommended the abolition of the program, the government referred that to a committee, spent months taking advice on the subject and then finally decided to continue the program at a slightly reduced level. How was that to inspire confidence in the CRCs, in their supporters and in the private sector partners who fund the CRCs' work? Naturally, they were left very unsure of this government's response to the CRC program and were left very unsure of the strength of their commitment to it.

The universities have always been a mainstay of public sector science in this country. There is a very substantial contribution by academic research to future job creation opportunities by industry. Academic research indeed has a very high percentage return as an investment. The estimates from the United States are that academic research returns perhaps 25 per cent on the investment made in it in terms of the economic wealth which it subsequently generates for the country. Estimates by the academies of science are that the universities in this country, under the Howard government, have suffered something like a $3 billion reversal where costs have been transferred to parents, to students and out of the public sector purse. The universities have suffered considerably as a result of that and their funding is significantly depleted.

Science suffers even more in that context. Good science is expensive to do. Good science costs dollars in the universities. A university faced with a reduction in funding under this government will turn first to its science budget and cut that first, because that is where the money is, that is where the easy reductions can take place. University administrators, confronted by a declining base in their funds and confronted by a declining base in infrastructure funding in grants from government institutions like the ARC, are bound to cut the science budgets first because of the cost.

What message has this government sent to science and engineering students themselves? Well, it nearly doubled their HECS fees contribution. Any government that believes in market forces and then doubles the cost to students of doing a science degree in this country can only expect—as will subsequently prove to be the case—that students will respond to those market forces in the way we know they will; that is, by withdrawing from science courses in the universities.

New enrolments in science in our universities have declined under this government for the very simple reason that the government sent science students a very powerful message about the way in which it values their future career and about the way in which it values science in Australia by doubling the cost of their degree to them. Of course, students have had to withdraw from those courses in significant numbers. I think the cost of that to the nation will not be felt for many years, but it will be a very real and very powerful cost.

One thing which exemplifies what value is placed on science by this government is the way in which they have treated the position of Chief Scientist. One of the first decisions of this government on coming to office just over two years ago was to reduce the funding for the position of Chief Scientist in the federal government from a full-time position to a one day a week job. Any government that can reduce the funding for its Chief Scientist and say, `This is a part-time job of one day a week,' clearly does not take science as a very serious undertaking. It may have been better if the government had scrapped the position altogether, if they had been honest and up-front about it and said, `Look, we don't value science and we're reducing the funding to just a day a week.'

That has still not been restored in this budget. That is something which I consider it to be a very serious insult to the science community. I believe the Chief Scientist actually contributes a fair bit more than a day a week because he understands the importance of his job. We are probably taking advantage of his good will and gaining more than what we pay him for. While that is a credit to him, it is certainly a debit to this government.

What has happened to many of the other important science programs under this government? In the very early part of their term, they reduced the R&D tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent and they abolished the syndication scheme. The Treasurer has sought, and continues to seek, to portray the syndication arrangements and R&D funding generally as a tax rort. He has sought to diminish the value of this in industry and business by painting them as nothing but rorters, as people who have had their hands in the public trough in some improper way. Of course, there is always the opportunity for dishonest people to exploit any version of the tax concession.

But I happen to believe that the R&D tax concessions and the syndication schemes sent a very strong message to industry that the Labor government of the day—certainly not this government—valued very highly industrial research and development. It also valued the mechanism whereby companies who had substantial amounts of taxable income could assist those start-up companies who were ideas rich but cash poor with a syndicated R&D scheme under which resources were transferred to the company that needed the innovative break and that needed the assistance. But, of course, that scheme has been entirely abolished.

If we look at the overall funding for some of the important programs like R&D support, we see that it is in decline. That is best summarised by looking at the government's own budget papers. If we turn to Budget Paper No. 1 where the government sets out its budget philosophy and we look at government support for science and innovation, the government's own words in describing that budget are very revealing. They say:
Total outlays decline slightly over the forward estimates. This is largely explained by a decline in ARC—
that is, the Australian Research Council—
funding for research infrastructure, collaborative research grants and the High Performance Computing and Communications Programme.

So this government itself describes in the budget papers a decline in overall funding, and how true that is. If we look at the constant price summary of major Commonwealth support for science and innovation through the budget and other measures, which again is a table from that budget paper document, we see that science is very much in decline under this government. The reality is that science funding under the Commonwealth budget is now back to 1993 levels.

I know that the Prime Minister wanted Australians to be relaxed and comfortable, and I think the decade in which the Prime Minister would have been most relaxed and most comfortable would have been the 1950s. Well, he is very slowing driving the science budget back to the 1950s. We are already back to 1993. That is the last time when in real consequent dollars science funding was at the same level that it is now. We have seen an approximate 11 per cent decline in science funding in real terms under this government. I expect that that represents their view of the importance of science research and innovation.

But the reality is that the importance of science is very different from that. Although the new Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore—in his first budget as science minister following the resignation of the former minister—claimed after this year's budget that science funding was $90 million up, I am afraid that is somewhat of a misleading of the public and of this parliament. The reality is that, although in strict actual dollar terms, the budget is $90 million up, on the government's own figures that is minus one-half of one per cent in real terms. Combined with the previous budgets where science funding dropped some nine per cent, in real terms we see that it is this year down half a per cent of the total budget. Contrary to the minister's assertion that it is $90 million up, the reality is that after inflation his budget is significantly down.

Why is all this so important to the country? It is important because science is not a cost; it is an investment. Education is an investment. Science and education go hand in hand in ensuring that this country has a competitive place in a globally competitive world in the next century. The reality is that if Australia is to take a real and meaningful role in the Asia-Pacific region in the next century—if it is to be a high wage, high skill country and not a low wage, low skill country—and not just a farm and quarry for the rest of the world, then we need real investment in science, in innovation and in education to ensure our people are able to meet those challenges in the next century.

Science and innovation can deliver to this country a real future, one which people will be very pleased to leave to their children. It can certainly be said in very clear terms that our greatest responsibility is to be good ancestors. If we are good ancestors to the next generation, then we will have made a real contribution during our term of office in this parliament and in any term of government that the people may bestow on us. In that context, the best thing that we can do is to bequeath to the next generation a very sound economy and a sound education system—one which values science and innovation and one which encourages, through the overall public policy budget, strong investment by business in science and in research and development.

So we have all of those factors coming together. We need sound public policy in CSIRO, in the CRCs and in the universities. We need strong investment in R&D by the private sector to ensure that the jobs are there in the next century. We need the government to provide the necessary leadership and to send the right messages to the community to ensure that this process occurs as we have discussed this evening.

The reality is that this government have abandoned any attempt at leadership in the science infrastructure. Their constant reduction of budgets, their dismantling of programs, the declining forward estimates, the messages they send to students by doubling the HECS fees, the messages they send to the community and the universities by slashing tertiary sector expenditure all combine to show a complete lack of leadership in science and public policy, as the academies of science and the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies have all recognised in their budget response. This government has lost the opportunity that this budget presented to make a strong investment in science and R&D. It is a budget of lost opportunities and one which will be a real cost to this nation for decades to come.

talk.start.para: —In standing to speak tonight in support of Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I am proud to be part of a government which unapologetically has committed itself, through fiscal responsibility, to building a better Australia for all those who call themselves Australians.

speech.para: In taking this budget to my electorate—a very representative electorate, I might add, with diverse needs—I found an overwhelming response. I doorknocked businesses in Gladstone as recently as last Friday and I was surprised at the level of support there was for the budget. I came to the conclusion that the people of Australia know a fair deal when they see one. They also recognise a committed and responsible government doing what is best for all Australians.

Many of my colleagues tonight have outlined the various attributes of the budget and some of them bear repeating, if only in dot point form. For example, the $2.7 billion surplus, taken against a deficit of $10.3 billion, means that over the period of this government there has been a turnaround of $13 billion. There was no increase in income tax, no increase in company tax, no increase in sales tax, no new excise taxes and no increase in the Medicare levy. The provisional tax uplift factor has been reduced from six to five per cent, having at an earlier date been reduced from eight to six per cent; so it has come down three per cent overall. We have the lowest unemployment since 1990.

One of the benefits which has flowed from the budget is 50,000 extra World War II veterans to receive the gold card—a very popular measure, I might add, with veterans in my area. One of the great wishes of 220,000 self-funded retirees was to be included along with pensioners in the seniors health care card, and they have had that wish granted in this budget. That too is enormously popular and gives a lot more security to that sector of the community whose overall income is not that much further ahead of the pensioners—something that is not readily understood. Two hundred extra Medicare easy claim centres will be placed in pharmacies in rural and regional areas. Those things are all great for my electorate and for Australia as a whole.

However, if we look at the effects that this budget and the two previous budgets have had on the economy of Australia we see that, as I said before, we have had the lowest unemployment since 1990; further surpluses projected to 2002 to halve the government's net debt by the turn of the century; the lowest inflation since the 1960s; the lowest mortgage interest rate since 1969-70—in recent times down from 10.5 per cent under Labor to 6.5 per cent under the current government; and the lowest business overdraft interest rates, down from 11 per cent to 7.7 per cent.

Growth of three per cent, though derided by a number of opposition speakers, is an extraordinary result given the events that have occurred in Asia. I ask those who were denigrating them: where do you think we would have been if we had continued along the track that the previous Keating government laid down for us? Where do you think we would be another two or three years down the track with a deficit of who knows what? The accumulated deficits of the previous government were in the vicinity of $70 million, so perhaps they would now be $110 billion, $120 billion or $130 billion. It is extraordinary to think where we might be and what effect that might be having on the economy of Australia.

I hate to inject any negative tone into a speech like this, but there is one aspect of Australian life that I deplore and despise, and that is the tactic that the opposition has well honed since the 1993 election campaign. It goes something like this: when you have no cogent argument, when you do not have a recognisable policy, but, worse, when you do not have any vision for Australia, you go out like a pack of hyenas, a policy-devoid mob of agitators, and you target the old, the frail and the deprived and you make your one objective to scare the pants off them—to scare the hell out of them.

That has been done over and over again and tonight I refer to two instances—nursing homes and labour market programs. Labor and its cronies in the nurses union have been peddling the line in my area of Queensland that we have reduced spending on aged care. Clearly, that is not the case. It is quite wrong. If you look at the figures on what has been spent on residential care in nursing homes and hostels, you will find that, when we came to office, the government was spending $2.4 billion on that sector. In the last three budgets we have taken that from $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion to $2.8 billion and, in the most recent budget, to $2.9 billion.

The line is also peddled that somehow, because of our new and simplified RCS, which replaces a seven-tier system with an eight-tier system and changes the denominators, nursing home proprietors will have to reduce staff and services. I have even had this claim thrown at me in my electorate. On investigation of the particular nursing home where the claim was made, I found that, under the new reassessment of classifications, the first 31 residents that were reassessed in this nursing home resulted in that nursing home having an increase of two per cent—not a reduction. Yet the nursing union and a number of nurses went round peddling the line that the ALP have been pushing in Canberra.

On top of that, the accommodation charge, which in its earlier form was to have been a bond—again, this was the subject of a scare campaign—has been replaced with an up-front accommodation charge. This will return $1.3 billion to the nursing home sector over the next 10 years. Anyone who has looked at Australian demographics knows that, if we do not act now on aged care, there will be a chaotic situation by the turn of the century or early into the next century. It is something we must confront now. We must do it in such a way that we can build, renovate and extend nursing homes.

One of the things that I find extraordinary after the scare campaign concerning the bond is that when I go into nursing homes patients say to me, `Mr Neville, we would have preferred to pay the bond,' or nursing home proprietors say, `We were a bit hasty at first. Really, the bond scheme would have been better.' It was interesting to see the Minister for the Status of Women (Mrs Moylan), who is at the table, unfairly pilloried by the ALP at that time. Again, it is this unconscionable idea that any time you cannot get your own way you scare the pants off people.

I now refer to tonight's presentation by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). I would have thought that someone interested in employment and something for the young could have produced something more than the mean-spirited and pessimistic retort he made to the budget. Why would he harass this government for an unemployment rate of 7.9 when his own track record was 11.2—the worst since the Great Depression? How could he have the gall to come in here and criticise the government?

The honourable member painted a very negative picture of work for the dole. Again, he was just trying to scare the old. He was saying that older people are going to have to work for the dole in future and it is the big scheme of the Howard government to trap these poor oldies into that scheme. I do not know whether that will occur or not, but I can tell you the effect it is having on young people. In one work for the dole scheme in my electorate, which has been licensed for 240, 182 have been placed. Of those 182, 38 have found jobs and 10 have gone on to further training or education.

I understand that another skillshare down the road from Gympie, which is working in the Isis shire in the southern part of my electorate, has had kids going to work on the third and fourth days of the week because they are so keen. They are not just going for the two days as required; they are turning up and wanting to participate on the other two days of the four-day work for the dole week. I understand—and I did not get this directly from them; I got it second-hand—that of their first 40 clients about a third have found jobs.

Let us compare that with what the Labor Party offered, which was an endless cauldron of hopelessness as people were churned around in these labour market programs. The daddy of them all must have been the NWO program—the last one—which worked out at $140,000 for each positive outcome. You could have given the kids $100,000 to go out and buy a business and you would still have been $40,000 in front. What a terrible and unconscionable waste of public funds. Then the Labor Party comes in here and tries to scare the pants off people about work for the dole.

By comparison, this government has given us the schools to work program; the schools to apprenticeships program; Green Corps; and apprenticeships and traineeships. I say to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), through you, Mr Speaker, that I am most grateful that in my area of Wide Bay, which encompasses the Hinkler and Wide Bay electorates, we have been granted 1,900 new apprenticeships which will go a long way to covering the needs of the 1,600 young people who are out of work in that area.

The member for Batman visited my area recently. I thought I would have to take to him with a stick in the media because of his negative approach up there, but I found I did not even have to put out a press release. Some of the 10 job providers that have these new programs under the Job Network program came out themselves and gave him a nice old touch-up. In fact, it was not necessary for me to get involved. It is interesting that, whereas before we had two CES offices and a couple of private providers, in my electorate we now have 10 providers and two Employment National offices. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Mr Andrews)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following bills be referred to the Main Committee for consideration:
Payment Systems and Netting Bill 1998
Cheques and Payment Orders Amendment (Turnback of Cheques) Bill 1998
Cheques and Payment Orders Amendment Bill 1998
Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1998
Film Licensed Investment Company Bill 1998
Taxation Laws Amendment (Film Licensed Investment Company) Bill 1998
The following notices were given:
Mr Warwick Smith to present a Bill for an Act to provide financial assistance for the period of 5 years starting on 1 July 1998 in respect of health care services.
Mr McClelland to move—
That this House:
(1) notes that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) proposes to ship consignments of used research reactor fuel back to countries of origin for reprocessing;
(2) notes that the shipping operation will mean that such consignments of used research reactor fuel will be transported through suburban streets;

(3) calls upon the Minister for the Environment to conduct a full environmental impact statement procedure under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act to enable full and proper public input into issues relating to the transportation of used research reactor fuels including (a) ensuring that (i) the spent fuel is properly packaged, (ii) each package is properly certified as meeting all relevant international and national regulations for safe transport of radioactive materials including the Australian code of practice for the safe transport of radioactive substances and (iii) there is proper coordination between all regulating authorities for the shipment and (b) the extent to which Australia's international obligations restrict publication of transportation routes;

(4) further notes that there remains unresolved complex issues of liability as to which authority would be responsible for compensating any private citizen in the event of an accident during the course of such transportation; and
(5) calls upon the Government to assume strict liability in respect of the consequences of any such spillage which may affect an Australian citizen.
Mr Sawford to move—
That this House calls on the Government to:

(1) recognise that the largely single option of a comprehensive high school system in this country is inappropriate for a majority of students at a secondary level and that this fact often leads to a perception that the public secondary school system does not meet the needs of parents and students; and
(2) encourage through differential funding a range of types of public secondary schools that among others would include a re-evaluation of single sex and technical high schools.
Mr Robert Brown to move—
That the House of Representatives:
(1) declares its total opposition to a goods and services tax (GST) and notes that:

(a) as an indirect tax any GST would be seriously regressive and would impact most severely on low and middle income earners because (i) a GST would be imposed at a flat rate on purchases irrespective of the income or wealth of the purchaser and thus lower income earners would pay a higher proportion of their income in the form of the tax than would higher income earners, (ii) a GST is imposed on what people spend, not on what they save, and thus lower income earners who have to spend most of their income are forced to pay tax on a larger proportion of their income than high income earners who are able to save more and avoid the tax, (iii) a GST which must be regressive would replace part of direct income tax which is structured at a progressive rate to ensure greater equity by taxing higher incomes at a higher rate, (iv) the revenue from a GST which is largely paid by low and middle income earners would be used to compensate for the reduced personal income tax which would be paid by high income earners who would benefit from any reduction in the higher marginal tax rates and (v) a flat rate GST would impose retail taxes on a wide range of basic household purchases which ordinary Australian families need while, at the same time, reducing the rates of tax imposed on the purchases of the rich such as furs, jewellery and luxury cars;

(b) a GST would have an adverse economic impact because (i) it would increase the inflation rate by increasing the prices of all goods and services to which it was applied, (ii) higher prices would translate into higher interest rates with adverse impact on home buyers, small business and farmers, (iii) an unfair burden of administration, record keeping and tax collecting would be imposed on about one million retail and service outlets across Australia and (iv) higher prices, higher interest rates and increased administration would stifle enterprise and discourage small business production and employment;

(c) a GST is not necessary to achieve sensible reform of the taxation system which can be achieved by such measures as the (i) removal of anomalies in the present wholesale sales tax system, (ii) adjustment of marginal tax rates to eliminate the incidence of bracket creep and ensure that all tax increases are discretionary and transparent, (iii) elimination of tax law provisions which have allowed the rorting of the tax system as high income earners and corporations have been able to construct sophisticated and artificial arrangements to avoid their tax obligations and (iv) effective policing of the existing tax system to eliminate tax evasion by the shysters and prosecute those who persist; and

(d) experience in other countries which have adopted a GST indicates that (i) of 26 industrial countries with a GST the rate has been increased in all but three countries and the average rise was 42 per cent, (ii) a GST provides governments with an opportunity to increase the rate and extend its application thus imposing an ever increasing burden on the people, (iii) any arrangements built into the initial GST to compensate lower income earners are soon dissipated thus leaving those people—especially pensioners, other welfare recipients, single income families and the unemployed—with a continually declining defence against a continually increasing tax and (iv) core services such as education and health are effectively priced out of the reach of many low and middle income families often with appalling sectional impact;

(2) acknowledges that the main support for a GST comes from highly paid financiers, bureaucrats and other high income interests and from the corporate business community while the chief opposition comes from people and organisations, including church and welfare groups, which represent the broad mass of Australians;

(3) urges all Australians to reject any attempt to burden them with a GST and to condition them with the false claim that a GST is either inevitable or essential for Australia's economic wellbeing; and
(4) calls on the federal Government to abandon its push to introduce this discriminatory, regressive, unfair and unjust tax.

debateinfo.title: VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT (MALE TOTAL AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS BENCHMARK) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The object of the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill is to ensure that the indexed component of the war widows pension is maintained at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings and that it retains parity with the maximum single rate of the age and service pensions. As shadow minister for veterans affairs, I indicate from the outset that it has the strong support of the opposition. The war widows pension was introduced in 1914. It is a form of compensation payable to the surviving partner of a veteran whose death arose out of or was attributable to their war service. The pension is also automatically payable to the widow of an ex-prisoner of war, or of a TPI or EDA pensioner.

speech.para: Just under 100,000 war widows and a small number of widowers currently receive the payment with a majority also receiving the means tested income support supplement of up to $120.10 a fortnight. Australia's war widow population overwhelmingly arises from our participation in World War II. Ninety thousand war widows receive the pension as a result of their late husbands' World War II service. A further 2,600 are the surviving partners of veterans of World War I.

Given this background, it is not surprising that most are over 75 years of age. Indeed, more than a quarter are over 80 years of age. This bill is therefore directed at a very vulnerable and increasingly frail group of women to whom the nation owes a considerable debt of gratitude. Many made their own largely unheralded contribution to our war effort. They raised children and often subsequently cared for their grandchildren as well as their partner.

To understand the rationale of this bill, it is necessary to consider the history of adequacy benchmarks for Australian pensions. For several decades there has been debate about the best way to maintain the relative living standards of pensioners in relation to both inflation and the growth in average earnings. It is not being partisan to point out that Gough Whitlam was the first Prime Minister to explicitly commit his government to raise the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. This followed from the groundbreaking work of the committee of inquiry into poverty, led by the late Ronald Henderson. This inquiry decisively identified the persistence of poverty in Australia, despite the post-war economic boom and the prevalence of poverty amongst older people, particularly widowed or single older people.

It is easy to forget that, prior to the Whitlam government, pension rates were set purely on an ad hoc basis, being increased only when governments felt compelled to act. During the period 1972 to 1975, the real level of payments was significantly increased. In 1976 the system of twice yearly indexation of payments, in line with increases in the consumer price index, was introduced. It was not until Brian Howe established a social security review in 1986, that the question of an adequacy benchmark regained prominence on the wider political and policy agenda in this country. As a major by-product of that review, the Hawke government developed a white paper on a national retirement incomes policy.

Amongst other things, this white paper contained the crucial commitment that the single rate of pension would be increased to at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and that its real value would be maintained in line with increases in overall community earnings. As part of this, the 1989 budget provided funding for an additional increase in the pension on top of indexation. That took it above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings as from April 1990.

Since that time, pensions have maintained their value in comparison with both inflation and average earnings, thus providing pensioners with a twin guarantee. It is true that, until recently, no further additional increase was needed on the average weekly earnings front because the relative growth in inflation was generally much higher than the corresponding growth in average earnings. This does not alter the fact that a benchmark or guarantee of adequacy has been continuously in place since 1990.

I provide this lengthy history because the coalition's commentary on the matter strangely seems always to begin with a piece of legislation that was passed by the parliament just last year. This was the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Act 1997. It was introduced in an attempt to reassure pensioners in the face of the 1996 report of Treasurer Costello's National Commission of Audit which had seriously questioned the 25 per cent benchmark and many other benefits for older Australians. So, in reality of course, this was an attempt by the current government to say that Costello's initiative in regards to that commission of audit and its questioning of whether we really were paying war widows and pensioners in this country too much money was correct.

Despite its rhetoric, the government's original bill was far from reassuring. Not only did it contain a five-year sunset clause but it also excluded a number of veterans and social security payments from the benchmark. As well, the bill implemented a revised methodology whereby the pension is benchmarked against male total average weekly earnings on an annualised rather than a quarterly basis. Fortunately, Labor was successful in having the coalition's sunset clause deleted in the Senate but the other features remained intact. All this meant that when average weekly earnings for the September and December quarters in 1997 increased substantially more than the consumer price index, legislation was in place to automatically apply the 25 per cent AWE benchmark to age and service pensioners, amongst others, to provide them with a $6.80 a fortnight increase from March. This legislation did not, however, encompass war widows pensions, veterans disability pensions, or a number of social security payments.

When war widows became aware in March that they would not receive an increase in their pension, there was an immediate outcry. The strength of this outcry was such that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, was forced to announce on 26 March that the increase would flow on to war widows and would be backdated to 20 March. With the benefit of hindsight, it is clear that the position of war widows was not fully considered during the passage of the earlier legislation.

As I have already noted, the chief concerns at the time were about the original sunset clause and the coalition's restrictive interpretation of the 25 per cent benchmark. In addition, the total of the war widows pension was so far above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings—that is the total rate, I am stressing—that it did not appear conceivable that it would ever fall below 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Strictly speaking, this remains the case today.

The key to this is to closely examine what the government has been saying about this welcome increase for war widows. The Prime Minister's original announcement said he was raising their pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. A simple check of the rate of the pension reveals, however, that it has never actually fallen below 25 per cent of AWE and was at the time more like 27 per cent. For the 52,000 war widows who also receive the income support supplement, their total pension payments were more like 36 per cent. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) knows this, which is why his second reading speech refers to a linkage between the basic rate—I stress basic rate—of the war widows pension and the rate of the age pension. It is also why the explanatory memorandum for the bill refers to an adequacy benchmark for the indexed component of the pension.

Essentially what has happened is that the government has rediscovered the fact that the war widows pension consists of an indexed supplement of $347.80 a fortnight and a non-indexed component of $24 a fortnight. As noted by the minister, since about 1964 the indexed component has always been the same as the maximum rate of the age pension. Given the outcry over the original exclusion of war widows from the March pension increase, what the government has actually decided to do is to apply the 25 per cent average weekly benchmark to the indexed component of the war widows pension. The real object of this bill is thus to maintain existing relativity between the rate of the war widows pension and that of the age pension.

In passing, I note that the rate of the war widows pension is, in round terms, 107 per cent of the age pension and 140 per cent for those who also receive the full income support supplement. In making these comments I imply no criticism of the government's action or of the provision to the bill. As I said earlier, the proposal has the opposition's strong support. I simply put the correct situation on the public record for those who would otherwise be misled by government media releases uncritically reported by a media that apparently does not even check the accuracy of the prime ministerial announcements on an ordinary calculator.

talk.start.para: —They don't read them.

—Yours either, mate. You need a bit more publicity, and I am constantly trying to help you. As I noted in my media release at the time, pension payments to a large number of disabled veterans, including TPI and EDA pensioners, are still not covered by the March increase. Whilst I recognise the complexity of their situation and particularly the large number who are also on service or age pension, it is remarkable that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has not formally outlined the government's thinking on their situation and on the relativities that apply to their disability pensions. I trust that he will do so in his reply. I would also be interested in the minister's response to three other outstanding issues in regard to war widow pensioners. The first two arise directly from the coalition's own 1996 election statements for veterans. They include the commitment on page 9 which states:
