speech.para: The Coalition will review the situation which has seen the Income Support Supplement (age and disability) paid to widows/widowers frozen since 1986. Another area for review will be the treatment of widows who remarried prior to 1984 and the Coalition will reassess this.

They have had quite a bit of time to reassess, to review, to investigate and to look at these issues. Given that since the last election three coalition budgets have come and gone without any action on these matters, one has to question the sincerity of these commitments prior to the last election.

talk.start.para: —What about the gold card?

—The member interjects by asking, `What about the gold card?' As we quite well realise, the government has followed the precedent of the Labor government at the time—and the Prime Minister has stressed this constantly and consistently—in introducing, roughly, a similar time period from the previous war. That has been stressed by the Prime Minister and the minister. If we are to believe—and this a very interesting point for the minister over there, when we are talking about commitments, honesty and integrity—the leaked cabinet documents reported in the Financial Review of 4 May, these commitments were apparently not even included in the minister's bids in the recent budget. These commitments, these promises, these reassurances to war widows that his predecessor in opposition committed this government to, were not even put to the cabinet. The reality is that these commitments in regard to war widows were just basically put on the backburner for another decade.

speech.para: The third issue is one that I have been pursuing for several years on a personal level, under successive governments. It concerns the widows of intermediate rate disability pensioners who have to go through a complex and distressing process to establish their eligibility for the war widows pension. Unlike the widows of TPI and EDA pensioners, and of ex-prisoners of war, they are not automatically transferred to the war widows pension. This is an issue that affects only a small number of widows each year but does need looking into. In my experience, it causes incredible and unnecessary distress to veterans on the intermediate pension rate, who worry that their spouse may not be eligible for the war widows pension and its associated benefits after their death.

I stress that both sides of politics have basically had an attitude that there are very few people affected, and essentially there is no outcry, no public pressure on the matter. But I want to stress again that this matter does need review. We are talking about a very insignificant number of people who go through a traumatic experience wondering whether or not they are eligible. At the end of the day the vast majority of them receive the war widows pension. I question whether we really have to continue this process of putting them through that. Quite frankly, it probably costs us just as much having this apparatus, this investigatory process, as it does to give them the pension. In conclusion, I note that there is a bipartisan commitment in this parliament that war widows are entitled to support and recognition. The opposition supports the bill and will help expedite its passage through the parliament.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to see the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Bruce Scott, here with us this morning. His stewardship has delivered very many benefits to veterans, and his work is highly regarded widely in the veteran community and certainly in my area, Townsville. Minister, you are welcome any time to come to Townsville, because I get continual feedback about the good work that you and the Veterans' Affairs department are doing.

speech.para: I am really pleased to be able to speak on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 today, because it has delivered an increase of $6.80 per fortnight to our war widows, and that has been warmly welcomed in Townsville and Thuringowa. It is a welcome change; it is a positive change; it is a change which flowed through from the government's decision to generally index pensions at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. That is going to occur, backdated from 20 March this year.

For some people, an extra $6.80 per fortnight might not seem like a great increase, but each time those CPI records come out, my office takes calls from pensioners—as would the office of the honourable member for Swan (Mr Randall)—asking how the change in the CPI is going to affect their pension payments and if they are going to go up. For many people on pensions and low incomes, $6.80 is certainly a very significant increase. Pensioners tell me—as they would tell other members of the parliament—that, even though CPI may be zero or negative, the price of such basics as bread, milk and so on still seems continually to rise. So this is a wonderful opportunity to look after pensioners, low income people and certainly war widows, in relation to rises in basic commodities that are not covered with CPI rises.

A point was made by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) in what I would call a rather smart-alec manner during question time on October 22 last year. You may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn) putting a question to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) about inflation results and how the government had achieved sound economic growth without fuelling higher inflation and higher interest rates. In his answer to that question, the Treasurer said, `If you happen to be a pensioner, because of the inflation outcome, you will know that you are protected against price rises,'—which is quite true, as the member for Jagajaga should have noted before she went to the dispatch box and basically screeched down the microphone, `No pension rise: that's what it means!'

The coalition knows this to be the case—which is why, in the run-up to the 1996 election, we promised to index pensions to 25 per cent of average male weekly earnings, and we have done that. That is something which the member for Jagajaga and the Labor Party had 13 years to do—but, of course, they were going to do it in the fourteenth year. The government realises the need, and that is why we have legislated to maintain the age and service pensions at the 25 per cent benchmark.

Extending the indexation arrangements to war widows means that their pension stays in alignment with the other age and service pensions, and that is a good result, too. It also ensures that, as people in the work force receive benefits, the benefits will also flow on to pensioners, making sure that the buying power of the pension is well and truly maintained. For Townsville and Thuringowa war widows, this means that they received a payment increase of $6.80 on 9 April as a result of the government's support. It is a decision that has been warmly welcomed by war widows and the veteran community in general. I have certainly had a lot of contact with the war widow community, particularly through Betty Rintoul at the RSL villas at Rose Bay in Townsville, and the feedback that I have received has noted very strong support indeed.

More recently, the government announced its intention to extend repatriation health gold cards to an additional 50,000 World War II veterans. This decision, to take effect on 1 January next year, will directly benefit those World War II veterans aged 70 years and over with qualifying service. In Townsville, that means about 280 veterans; and throughout North Queensland, 1,100 veterans.

Townsville Returned Services League welfare officer and advocate, Mr David Turnbull, was one among a number of local veterans who welcomed that significant decision. As Mr Turnbull said to me, `The RSL has been working very hard for a long time to have the gold card entitlements extended to World War ll veterans. This decision will ensure that our veterans will be able to access a wide range of health care benefits at a stage of their life when it is needed the most.'

I also note that the RSL's national president, Major General Peter Phillips, said of the decision on April 27, `This is certainly the most significant achievement for the RSL, and indeed the whole veteran community, in many years.' The extension of gold card benefits has been a high priority for the RSL for some years now. We worked and lobbied long and hard for this change. I would like to acknowledge today the efforts of many veterans in Townsville who helped to bring about this important change. I have no doubt that the RSL would like to see the gold card extended further to include veterans from the Korean, Malayan and Borneo conflicts. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not sure whether you get feedback from your electorate that those veterans from Korea, Malaya and Borneo are now seeking this extension. Bearing in mind their rapidly diminishing numbers, I believe there is a strong case for the government to give this urgent consideration; certainly, sooner rather than later.

talk.start.para: —Are you going to contact the minister?

—I am sure, Mr Slipper, we will have the strong support of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. He is a great supporter of veterans in Australia. I wholeheartedly support this amendment bill which indexes the war widows and war widowers pension. I certainly commend it to the House.

—I am happy to speak on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . I will not be using my full time. I just want to take a short time to make sure that people realise that I wholeheartedly endorse this bill because of its positive nature and the positive things that it does for veterans, particularly war widows. As we know, this bill completes a commitment made by the coalition government to maintain the pension benchmark of at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Last year this government introduced legislation which now brings certain pensions into line with the 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings.

speech.para: This bill in tandem with that legislation introduces parity and equity between like pension rates, and has been warmly received by war widows in my electorate of Swan. In fact, I spoke to Mrs Joan Fitzgerald from the Belmont RSL around Anzac Day. She mentioned just that point, that this bill gives them certainty. The member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), who I think is a very decent sort of person—

talk.start.para: —But politically misguided.

—But he is a good sort of person. In this case, I found it unusual that, even though he said he endorsed the bill, he had to criticise it all the way through. I know what a good sort of person he is; I would have thought he would have been a bit more positive. I am pleased that, in general, the opposition supports this bill.

speech.para: My local constituents tell me that this commitment gives them certainty into the future, that they are not going to be at the whim of some political force into the future and that this is actually benchmarked now. All war widows and widowers in receipt of war pensions will receive this pension increase. Around Australia there are 100,000 war widows. In my electorate of Swan, there are approximately 882 war widows who will directly benefit from this increase—that is a significant number of widows. Similarly, the benchmarking of pensions against male total average weekly earnings, as provided for by the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill last year, has also been warmly received by pensioners in my electorate of Swan.

A lot of people in Swan and a lot of people around the country will be better off under this legislation because, as has been stated earlier this morning, they receive increases of up $6.80 a fortnight on top of any CPI increase. I must make that point—this is on top of any CPI increase, not standing alone. This increase will cost the government around $23 million in 1998-99 and around $164 million over four years, so it is a significant financial commitment.

People receiving pensions, which will be maintained at no less than 25 per cent of the male total average weekly earnings, who are on the age pension, wife pension, disability support pension, widows pension, parenting payments, carer payment, mature age allowance and mature age partner allowance, service pension, partner service pension and income support supplement will all be better off under this legislation. So it certainly covers a wide range of people who are going to benefit.

These people do deserve a hand. These people are genuinely in need and deserve government assistance. This is the direction of the government's welfare assistance—to the genuinely needy, those identified as needing help. One of the hardest parts of my job as the member for Swan is taking calls from pensioners who have waited for the consumer price index to be announced only to find that it did not increase and so their pensions did not increase. Try telling a pensioner that their increase is going to be 70c, or even less, as happened last year.

The complete lack of increase was a reflection of the consumer price index, the CPI, and the fact that there is no increase really means that inflation is stable, whereas we know that in some cases it has been negative and the cost of living has not increased. As the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) said, these people do not understand. They will show you a shopping list from 12 months before, and the price of bread and the price of milk has gone up marginally. Try telling them that they are not paying any more money, that because of negative inflation they do not deserve an increase in their pensions. As I said, the rudeness of it was that 70c was one of the increases—and that is not even the price of a `scratch and match'. It certainly did not go down too well.

One of the great benefits of this benchmarking is to take the pensioners and the aged out of the ridiculous CPI way of calculating things which included mortgages. Mortgages, as we know, have dropped substantially in this country under the coalition government. But I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that very few seniors and aged people are subject to the effect of mortgages, so it really does not benefit them at all. It is really quite sensible to see that they have been taken out of this CPI calculation, where one of the great impacts has been the reduction of mortgages, because they have either paid off their mortgage or they are renting. I think that is a lot fairer system of calculating the way that these people should be remunerated.

As I said, one of the hardest things to do is to tell a pensioner that they are not too badly off. I know that no matter what we give, $6.80 or whatever—certainly 70c was no good, but $6.80 is something they can appreciate—it does mean a lot to people who count every cent that they get. But when they only get a few cents increase per fortnight they just will not wear the fact that they are well off. Most pensioners will tell you that they battle to live on any sort of pension. At least this government has acknowledged that there needs to be some increase and has given them the assurance of doing so through benchmarking.

This increase of $6.80 a fortnight is something much more tangible and, as I said earlier, it is on top of any other increase they may receive through the CPI. So it does go some way towards giving these people the recognition they deserve by providing them with a little more that they can either use or save. In saying that pensioners find the amount of money that they get is quite often insufficient, I do know some pensioners, though, who tell me they can save on these pensions. I know one gentleman, a Mr Coffey, next to the school where my daughter goes, who regularly buys the children at the school ice-creams and Smarties and all that sort of thing from the amount of money he saves on his pension. So there are some people who actually can live, even though frugally, on the pension. But I am aware that in general, seniors and veterans, et cetera, find it difficult to live or save with the amount of money they get.

In conclusion, I am pleased to be part of a government which does take seriously its commitment and responsibility, particularly in this case to war widows and widowers and those people I mentioned earlier on age pensions, people whom this increase will directly and significantly assist. It is with pleasure that I support this bill and commend it to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak this morning on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . The very narrow purpose of this legislation is to align the treatment of war widows pensions with the treatment of other pensions, and therefore to treat those pensions consistently with the decision that was made by the government to introduce the 25 per cent benchmark.

speech.para: I have not yet heard an explanation from the government of why war widows were not included in the first place. Perhaps I missed something on the way, but I can only assume that they were forgotten or that it was because of some oversight that they were not included in the first place. It was a rather serious oversight. I was a member of the government at the time and I recall, very quickly after the announcement came out, starting to get calls from veterans organisations and from war widows organisations, in particular, asking where was the parity in the treatment of war widows. I would have liked to hear at some stage an explanation from the government of why they were not included and perhaps an apology to Australia's 100,000 or so war widows for having overlooked them in the first place.

We cannot disagree in any respect with the merits of this legislation, and I certainly do not. But I do think some explanation is owed as to why they were forgotten in the first place. Perhaps it was not fully realised at the time that there would be problems with parity and equity between pension rates if all like pensions were not included, but to have forgotten the war widows pension was obviously a very serious oversight. An apology from the minister might have been in order rather than an attempt now to portray this legislation as having all the merits it does have, without an acknowledgment simply that this legislation is necessary because of an oversight in not taking care of war widows at the time it occurred.

I should declare an interest in this. My mother is a war widow and at 83 years of age she deserves every dollar she gets from her war widows pension. She took care of my father, who served throughout the Second World War and suffered throughout his life as a result of his war service. In the years prior to his death he was a very sick man and my mum, true to her wedding vows, which I pay tribute to her for, did not renege for one moment on the care that she had to provide to my very sick father, which for 18 months or two years was a very difficult task indeed. I pay tribute to war widows because of the first-hand experience I have had in the situation I have just described and because I know that many of them suffered the same sort of difficulties. Hence the importance of the war widows pension. Now that I am not a government member I feel liberated to talk much more freely about this and a number of other issues. I feel passionately about veterans matters, for a number of reasons which are probably perfectly obvious to most people—

talk.start.para: —Would it have anything to do with the badge you're wearing?

—I am wearing an RSL badge, thank you, you are quite right. The member for Bendigo is very observant this morning. I am proud to be wearing this badge because the RSL is a very fine organisation. It is not full of Bruce Ruxtons, contrary to popular opinion. It is actually a very fine organisation. It still speaks not only for veterans, ex-servicemen and current servicemen, but it speaks also for a lot of Australians who do not necessarily qualify for membership of the RSL. So I thank the member for Bendigo because his comment gives me an opportunity to pay tribute to a great Australian institution. That is what the RSL is today. We appreciate the good work that they do.

speech.para: Now that I am the federal parliamentary leader of the Christian Democratic Party, I want to place on record a little bit about my—

talk.start.para: —You're the deputy leader and the membership as well.
—Yes, the deputy leader and the membership. That is pro tem. I need to underline that. But I do want to say a few things about my—
—I thought you would be modest and call yourself the deputy leader.

—Hang on, I do not want to waste my time here by being distracted. I want to put on the record a few comments about my new party's policy on veterans affairs, which I am taking some interest in developing. The CDP will be uncompromising in its support of veterans. I want to be seen personally, and I want my party to be seen, as the voice of veterans, in this parliament. Veterans do need a voice. We hear from both sides, from all members in this place, about veterans and about how valuable their service was. However, in the end we are not seeing, I am sorry to say, the rhetoric matched entirely by action.

speech.para: The latest budget is an example of that where we see some reductions in a number of important areas in the veterans appropriation. The government's current program, `Their Service—Our Heritage', sounds fine, but what veterans want now, particularly our older veterans, is substance, not symbolism. Very often what they are served up is symbolism, and most of them do not want that.

In 1995 we had the Australia Remembers year. It was a great year, an appropriate year, and all of us got into the spirit of that. My friend Con Sciacca was the minister at the time. I was not on the same side of politics as him but—

talk.start.para: —He did a good job.

—He did more than a good job, he did an outstanding job. He was a fine minister and he served the veterans community extremely well, and so did that year of Australia Remembers. The government of the day did a great service to the veterans of Australia in 1995, and I pay tribute to them.

speech.para: I suppose `Their Service—Our Heritage' is something of a pale imitation of that year. I must say I thought at the time when it came into being that the program was something of an attempt to carry on the euphoria of 1995 and to carry it over from the Labor Party to the coalition. I do not want to be too much of a detractor of it. There are obviously some real benefits. Some people have got certificates—I suppose I have awarded about six. But in Australia Remembers I awarded hundreds.

One of my great moments during the eight years I was the member for McPherson—I still am, but I will not be for much longer—was the day I presented those Australia Remembers certificates to veterans. We filled one of our local community centres with people. I received more accolades and more letters of thanks and deep appreciation for the day that I put on to award those Australia Remembers certificates than I did for anything else I ever put on. I look back at 1995 as being a high point. What we are attempting to do now is something of a pale imitation, as worthy as some aspects of it might be. As long as it is not costing a lot of money—

talk.start.para: —You're leaving out a lot of substance.
—What veterans want is recognition of—
—There are worthwhile benefits there.

—Okay, I accept what the member for Macquarie is saying. I accept that there are some very worthwhile benefits coming out of that. I concede that point, that that is the case. We have the heritage, and what a wonderful heritage we have as a result of the service of those who went and gave their lives and those who came back. But theirs was the service. Let us get this in its right context. We have the heritage, but they had the service. Many of them are still fighting today, I believe, for benefits to which they are entitled.

speech.para: I feel a sense of grief when I talk to some of the old diggers on Anzac Day, and other days, and hear how difficult it still is for them to get entitlements. We still seem to take the attitude that we will make it as difficult as possible for them to get what they believe they are entitled to. The latest decision by the government is to restrict access to legal aid for them, and for appeals to the AAT, which is a part of the process to which they are entitled. They are entitled to go to the AAT as the ultimate point of appeal in relation to claims that they are making on the system. Yet that is now a Clayton's right, because legal aid is being restricted and some bureaucrat will be making a judgment about whether the case has merit. Surely the point of going to the AAT is to determine whether the case has merit. It is abrogating the rights of veterans if there is to be some bureaucratic interpretation put on that or a decision made on that.

The government has to revisit this whole issue. I know it is being reviewed because I saw a statement by the minister about it the other day. However, at the moment, veterans are being prevented from seeing their full rights exercised in terms of their appeals. There are financial constraints being imposed on appeals. I am told by advocates, with whom I deal almost on a daily basis, that, with respect to the amount of money allowed for appeals, it is not possible to prosecute an appeal. So, even when appeals do go through, there is that practical limitation.

I would like some clarification as to what the government is doing to reinstitute the original arrangements whereby legal aid was granted by the Commonwealth. It is now granted by the states but the states have other priorities for legal aid—for example, Queensland has got family law matters and every other matter—and to lump veterans appeals into that whole pot is unsatisfactory and unfair to veterans. Again, let us have substance instead of rhetoric on the question of legal aid so that veterans are able to prosecute their entitlements to the full extent to which they are entitled to do so.

As I said, on behalf of the Christian Democratic Party I want to be uncompromising in support of veterans. I understand, perhaps better than anyone in this place, or as well as anyone, that there have to be limits in place. There have to be rules in place and there have to be definitions. The act is very clear about defining all sorts of things in terms of qualifying service and so on. I understand all of those things, and that we cannot go totally overboard, but my appeal today is for our Second World War diggers. They are now all getting very old and I believe that life should not be made difficult for them. They should be helped every step of the way to get their full entitlements but the point is: they are not. They are still having to fight for entitlements. Many of them they fought in the war 50 years ago and now they are having to fight the system.

I know the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) has a lot of veterans in his electorate, and I know that he gives them very good service, but if he is not getting them coming to him with these sorts of complaints, then I suspect that something is wrong. I get veterans coming to me and I talk, as I said a moment ago, to the people who are advocates for them and they are not entirely happy.

Sometimes veterans are described as whingers but the categorical response to that is that they are not. Many believed that, having served their country, their country would take care of them as a result of any disabilities they suffered. However, many veterans now feel that their country has let them down and, progressively, over time, I think it can be demonstrated that their benefits have diminished. I do not mind whether they were conscripts or volunteers. Some people make a distinction between whether people were conscripts or volunteers, and whether it was for the Vietnam War or whether it was for the Second World War.

If you were a conscript, in a sense you may argue a case such as, `I did not choose it. I was taken.' I am not speaking personally here, but a person can be taken off civvy street and put into the services and sent overseas essentially against their will. They obviously deserve special consideration. On the other hand, of course, those who volunteered, as my father did—incidentally he left Australia in January 1940 with the 6th Division—certainly would be entitled to the very best attention they could get. I described my situation a moment ago. I should say in addition to that, that my dad, when he got back from the war and despite some serious disabilities, got on with his life and actually made pretty much a success of it.

In the context of this debate, I want to talk about disability pensions for a moment. There is a lot of confusion about disability pensions and the average member here probably has a bit of difficulty understanding how it all hangs together. I just want to say that whilst these are indexed to the CPI this act we are dealing with deals with some of the complexities about the cross-fertilisation between the indexation and the 25 per cent benchmark. With disability pensions, of course, they are not income in the assessment of service pension payable.

I want to draw the attention of the House to an important element of discrimination which exists within the disability pension regime in the way that the disability pension is treated by the Department of Social Security vis-a-vis the way that it is treated by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I say this contains a very serious element of discrimination. If you are entitled to a Veterans' Affairs pension, a service pension, then your disability pension is treated exactly as it should be and that is as compensation. You get it on top of your pension. But if your service was such that you do not get a service pension and you get an age pension through the Department of Social Security, then you are a second-class veteran for a start. It is a pity that we treat a large number of our veterans as second class. The point is that your disability pension which is compensation for your service related injuries is actually treated as income and so you lose the value of it or at least some portion of the value of it.

I have been drawing the attention of successive governments to this matter now for years. I first wrote to the current government—I have only got the latest part of the file—when I wrote to Senator Jocelyn Newman in April 1997 about this issue. She wrote back and thanked me for the letter inquiring about the progress of the review. The government promised a review when it came to government of the treatment of disability pensions as income for social security pensions purposes. The review had taken longer than expected but was then close to finalisation. This letter came in on 26 June 1997 almost a year ago. I wrote back again shortly after that and you always get an interim letter from the minister's director. Finally a letter came back in February of this year—I will not read it all—saying:
My department concluded the review of the social security treatment of the Department of Veterans' Affairs disability pension under the income test for social security payments this month.
Now get this:
The report acknowledges the difficulty of this issue and the underlying concerns of veterans.
That is a big step forward. That is progress.

I am currently considering the recommendations made in the report. Any move to exempt the DVA disability pension would involve significant costs which would need to be considered in the light of budget priorities for the social security and veterans affairs portfolio. I appreciate your interest in this matter.

I am glad that the minister appreciates my interest. We waited for the budget, did we not? We got this far with the review. The review is finished. She understands the problem. However, they have got to spend money to fix it. We waited for the budget. I assume nothing happened in the budget. It is very difficult and maybe the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) when he responds can make it clear now. It is probably not so much a matter for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It is really a matter for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) seeing she would have to, I assume, cough up the money. But somebody needs to tell us whether they have fixed this problem.

The minister says, `Yes, there is a problem. Yes, it affects veterans, but it is going to cost money to fix.' This has been going on for years. I have been raising this matter in this place for eight years—with both the previous government and the current government. As I said, we had a review: we waited months for the review. The review was delayed but finally the review said, `Yes, there is a problem, but it is going to cost money to fix.' I wrote to the minister again, on 22 May 1998, just the other day, asking what was going to happen next. I will wait a few months and see what the minister tells me on this particular issue.
I did have a large number of other matters I wanted to raise about the gold card issue and the fact that again there is a large group of—

talk.start.para: —A very good initiative, I might add.
—Yes, but a lot of people have missed out on getting the gold card, and I was going to speak up for them as well. (Time expired)

—It is a pleasure to rise in support of any legislation that enhances the entitlements of our veteran community, a community that is well deserving of any help that we can give them. It is a privilege to speak for this particular piece of legislation, the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . It is a shame, however, that the debate is not in the main chamber. Certainly I can understand that this is not a controversial piece of legislation, but it is a shame that something so significant cannot be debated in the main chamber itself.

speech.para: It seems to me that this legislation is significant for at least three main reasons. Firstly and most obviously, it is of vital significance and importance to the war widows and war widowers themselves—those dependent for their living on the pension that they receive.

talk.start.para: —Why were they forgotten the first time around?

—This covers 100,000 members of our community, and I am pleased to say that those 100,000 members of our community will be better off as a result of the enactment of this legislation. The bill provides for the continuation of the link between the age pension and the war widows pension, a link that has been in place since 1964. Further, it builds on the potential for steady growth. It is not that there was no growth potential there before—there was. However, that growth was limited to growth in the CPI.

speech.para: This legislation links growth to male average weekly earnings. It provides a benchmark for the war widows pension to be linked to a minimum of 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings. This ensures that the 100,000 recipients will benefit from the general rise in living standards that the community experiences.

The bottom line is that average weekly earnings and also male average weekly earnings tend to rise faster than inflation does. For example, between the March quarters of 1995 and 1998, the CPI grew by 4.88 per cent, whereas male total average weekly earnings grew by 13.32 per cent. There is a significantly faster rate of growth in male average weekly earnings. Therefore, this step of linking war widows' pension entitlements to male average weekly earnings gives them a much greater rate of growth in their pension than does indexation to the CPI.

This step means that there will be a real increase in the value of their pensions; it means that war widows and war widowers will benefit from the growing affluence of the community and the growth in productivity in the community, and their living standards will rise as a result. In the last quarter, the March quarter of 1998, this step meant a fortnightly rise of $6.80 for each single recipient, and $5.70 for each of a couple, and that has been the best rise for some time.

Secondly, this legislation is indicative of the commitment of the government to our veteran community. Notwithstanding some of the comments from the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), I believe that this government is honouring its commitment to our veteran community. Since 1914, successive Australian governments have honoured the undertaking that widows and widowers of deceased servicemen and service women would be looked after.

For the hundreds of thousands who so willingly risked all, this was a vital commitment. They had to know that their partners would be looked after. For the 102,000 who, over the decades, have paid the ultimate sacrifice in various conflicts around the world, it was the very least that could be done. I am pleased to say that successive governments have honoured that commitment. Obviously, the payment of such a pension could in no way compensate for the death of a loved partner owing to war related causes. It could in no way go close to easing the pain but it does at least provide a minimum and growing standard of living for those pensioners.

The legislation before us in fact involves a commitment of around $168 million over the next four years, and it does not stand alone in this government's commitment to the veteran community. The introduction of the program called `Their Service—Our Heritage', to which the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) referred, provides more avenues not only to recognise the contribution of our veteran community but also to assist them.

For instance, under the community seeding grants, there is a potential to provide tangible benefits to our veteran community. I am pleased that some veteran organisations in my community have benefited. For instance, the Blue Mountains Ex-Servicewomen's, the Blue Mountains Vietnam Veterans and Associated Forces Incorporated, Springwood RSL, the Kurrajong-Colo RSL sub-branch and the Leura Memorial in Lone Pine Avenue in Leura have all benefited as a result of this program of the government.

Further, and very significantly, there has been the introduction of the health gold card for another 50,000 World War II veterans. Sure, we could say that it could have gone further—the member for McPherson has said this. Obviously, there are other groups in the community who would like the benefit as well. But that should not in any way be seen to undermine the value of this commitment. It is a benefit to another 50,000 recipients who were not beneficiaries before, and a commitment of $500 million over the next four years that will directly benefit the health of our World War II veterans. That is an enormous, significant, very worthwhile and valuable commitment by this government that should in no way be underrated. It is a very strong commitment of this government to our veteran community.

There are some 260 veterans in the electorate of Macquarie who previously had no access to the gold card. They will now have access to the health gold card and those 260-odd World War II veterans are, I am sure, very grateful for that commitment from the government.

Thirdly, in a broader sense, this legislation is indicative of the government's commitment to our older Australian community generally. It is tangible evidence of our commitment to improving the welfare of older Australians. Month after month, we have had the dishonest rubbish from the opposition about how we are undermining the commitment to our older Australians. This is absolute nonsense. There have been many measures—and this is one of them—that in many ways improve the wellbeing of our aged citizens.

The indexation of pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings does not only cover war widows and widowers but also all aged pensioners. All aged pensioners will benefit from the growth in living standards that will come from having their pensions indexed at a rate generally faster than the rate of growth of inflation because, as I said, male average weekly earnings grow significantly faster than CPI. Here is a commitment to our whole pension community for a steady, ongoing rise in their standard of living—a genuine commitment of this government to the welfare of older Australians. This was a pre-election commitment by the coalition that has been delivered in full.

I bring to the attention of the chamber some of the other benefits that this government has introduced to enhance the welfare of older Australians. There has been an increase in the carers allowance incorporating the domiciliary nursing care benefit—an increase of $16.80 a fortnight. This is an increase of 29 per cent in the carers allowance—the allowance for those caring for frail aged. There are reforms to the nursing home sector that will bring about a tangible improvement in the quality of care in nursing homes, something the former government had neglected and ignored year after year.

There was the recently announced $280 million staying at home package, a package that will make it easier for the thousands of elderly citizens who would rather stay in their homes if appropriately assisted. This package includes provisions such as an extra 3,900 community aged care packages, on top of the growth that is already planned; a program for continence assistance; the establishment of another 15 carer respite centres; greater assistance for carers of those with dementia; increased funding for aged care assessment teams. This commitment of $280 million is further evidence of our commitment to the welfare of older Australians.

The provision of the seniors health card to another 220,000 self-funded retirees, allowing them pharmaceuticals at concessional rates, is a very significant, very worthwhile improvement for those people who have worked and saved all their lives to look after themselves in their retirement. It is a measure that has gone down very well in the broader community. Also, there was the provision in the budget last year raising the tax-free threshold for low income self- funded retirees to the same level as that which applies to pensioners on similar incomes. These are all very clear measures that prove beyond doubt the commitment of this government to the welfare of older Australians generally.

This bill provides for an ongoing, real and substantial improvement in the living standards of war widows and widowers. It is further evidence of this government's concern for the welfare of our veteran community and it is further evidence of this government's commitment to older Australians generally. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to strongly support the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . This bill will continue our government's commitment to our veterans and their families by making amendments to maintain war widows and widowers pensions at a rate of no less than 25 per cent of the male total weekly earnings. The bill proposes amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and makes this necessary adjustment.

speech.para: For the last 34 years, the war widows pension has increased at the same rate as the age and service pensions. Adjustments to all pension payments were made in an ad hoc manner which finally led to the current situation where all pensions were adjusted to the CPI twice a year. Legislative changes were made last year to link the age and service pensions to the male earnings benchmark. However, the amendment did not include the widowers pension.

The linkage between the three pensions continues to have very widespread community support and reflects community expectations that the war widows pension is a form of compensation for the loss of a loved one. This amendment to benchmark the war widows and widowers pensions should have been made when the changes were made to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act in 1997. However, given that this action was not taken at that time, I am extremely pleased that we are now rectifying that situation. I believe it would have been a great travesty not to have continued to link the war widows pension with the single rate of the age and the service pensions.

The amendment will cost an additional $168 million over four years, which I am proud to say is totally and fully funded, unlike many of the opposition's policy initiatives. These amendments came into effect on 26 March, with the first increase for widows and widowers pension recipients resulting in an increase of $6.80 per fortnight for a single pensioner, increasing the pension to a level of $378.60 per fortnight. I acknowledge that this legislation is retrospective. However, the benefits that will flow through to this very deserving group were far too important for me not to comment today.

The recipients of the widows pension find themselves receiving this pension through no fault of their own. The reason they are receiving this pension is that their partners, in most cases, have paid the ultimate price in serving their nation. It is these people that Labor certainly forgot while in government, just as they forgot to adequately fund and support the currently serving men and women of the Australian Defence Force.

As indicated in the budget, the budget for the Defence Force for 1998-99 is nearly $11 billion, an increase of some $589 million on the forecast outlays for 1997-98. This budgetary figure, although a substantial amount, representing 1.9 per cent of our GDP and 8.7 per cent of the Commonwealth outlays, still does not really paint the full picture of the revitalisation of the ADF since the coalition came to government in 1996. The approach to the defence forces by this government, and a renewed commitment to veterans and their widows, is shown through legislation like this that is being put forward here today.

These pension recipients fall into two categories. First, where a veteran dies as a result of a war or defence caused disease or injury, then a pension is payable to the surviving partner, whether married or de facto. Second, where a veteran was severely incapacitated as a result of war or defence, then the widow or widower of the veteran may qualify for the pension.

This amendment bill will make sure that the rate of widows and widowers pension is increasing by a mechanism that is clearly understood and, therefore, does not continue on the ad hoc adjustment basis that it has in the past. The amendment will ensure that, in the low inflation economic climate, the pension keeps pace with the rest of the community and is not depreciated in real terms by the low CPI figure. In this way, as we benefited from their partners' wartime service, widows and widowers can benefit from the country's economic growth.

The linking of the widows and widowers pension to 25 per cent of the total average male weekly earnings follows on the back of other very major policy announcements designed to lighten the load and recognise the immense contribution of groups of Australians that deserve recognition but, in the majority of cases, are never the first ones to ask for handouts. These government initiated reforms, like this amendment bill, will see benefits flowing through to the silent majority in our community, the majority which I believe Labor has certainly continued to ignore.

The gold health card is a prime example of the positive changes that this government is making. The gold health card will be extended from 1 January 1999 to an additional 50,000 World War II veterans, who are over 70 years of age and faced hostile forces. This, again fully funded, $500 million initiative will provide veterans with free treatment as a private patient with a choice of doctors and a range of other benefits. This has all come about, quite frankly, because, as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said, we are now in the black.

I believe that special consideration should be given to extending the gold health card to other groups of veterans. I would certainly like to see, as we recover economically, those extensions made to other World War II soldiers and also to Korea and Vietnam veterans. We are starting to see even Vietnam veterans get up into that age group, and I think that that would be a very appropriate recognition for their very important contribution to this nation. I would like to see such an extension in the not so distant future.

The member for McPherson raised the matter that the veterans disability pension is viewed by the Department of Social Security as income. That is an area that I also have had some concern about. It is an area that we need to look at seriously. For example, a constituent in my electorate—in Cooktown—John Shea, and his wife Bev are very seriously affected by the way in which this formula is dealt with by Social Security. He has three boys, two of them at university at the moment. He has been compelled to take a relatively small disability pension. This pension, from Veterans' Affairs, puts his income slightly over the benchmark for Austudy. As a consequence, he is in a situation where he has two kids away at university, both of whom he is funding—I think that costs somewhere in the vicinity of $400 a fortnight each, which leaves them with a pay of less than $250 a week—and he has got a third boy ready to go to university next year. So it is causing the family considerable concern.

I support the view of the member for McPherson that these are little areas that we should be tidying up around the side. I believe that they may cost a little bit but, as I say, we are in the black and we are focusing on needy groups that have missed out in the past. I am of the view that this is one of those areas that we need to look at very seriously. I would certainly encourage our government and the minister to rectify this anomaly because that disability pension has been earned through a service and a commitment to this nation that did not have to be given by a lot of other people. I think that that should be recognised independently. Like the gold card that was issued, nobody asked for a means test on any of the soldiers that were sent overseas. They came from all walks of life and many of them died.

I certainly applaud the gold card. The gold card is given irrespective of financial situation. I think that veterans pensions and things like that, where people have war related disabilities, should be treated in the same way. So I certainly encourage our government to look very seriously at that and deal with it, hopefully, before Bev and John Shea's third son goes to university. Because, unless that is done, unfortunately, they are not going to be able to afford it, and I would hate to see that happen.

I am very proud to state that there have certainly been other initiatives, as well, that have been targeting our veterans. The budget allocation, for example, was the largest ever, at $7.25 billion. Other measures include $600 million to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio for the direct purchase of hospital services over four years. Another one is the Australian War Memorial which has had its base funding increased by $2 million per annum for repair and maintenance of the building.

I think that this bill certainly continues to give war widows and widowers the recognition that they deserve and it certainly will assist them in contributing to their financial security. I believe that this additional money is certainly money very well spent. On that basis, I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I, too, would like to associate myself with the support shown by previous speakers for the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . This bill, if passed, will amend section 198 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. In doing so, it will allow increases in the rate of pension payable under paragraph 31A of that act to widows and widowers of a deceased veteran, linking those payments to male total average weekly earnings.

speech.para: There are approximately 100,000 war widows and widowers in this country. The war widowers' side of things is very small indeed—I think there are only about 150 of those. But this act, if passed, will provide for payment of a pension to the widow or widower of a veteran whose death was war caused, or defence caused, or to the widow or widower of a prisoner of war, or one who was in receipt of a special rate of pension or an extreme disablement adjustment immediately before death, such as a TPI pension. As I say, it is very welcome.

We have had a history in this country of supporting veterans to the degree that we could. In fact, war widows pensions have been paid since 1914. This is a recognition of the special compensation that is due to these people for the loss of a family breadwinner. Those widows themselves stayed at home throughout the war. They looked after the children and, in some cases, looked after the business, or the farm, and made a contribution to the war effort during the period of the war.

For a number of them, their real service started after the spouses returned. Whereas the spouses had been to the war for five years or so, the wives often had to look after them through illness for another 50 years or so. In many cases, that has been a lifetime of sacrifice that, I believe, is appropriately recognised through the payment of this pension.

The pension, of course, is not taxed and it is not means tested. For the first time it gives a formal link, a legislative link, to the male average weekly earnings. It is pitched at the rate of 25 per cent of those earnings whenever they increase at a greater rate than the CPI. And in determining the rate it is rounded up to the nearest 10c. This link was an election commitment that the coalition made in 1996 and I am pleased to say we have fulfilled it.

In passing this legislation here today, it ensures that war widows and widowers will have this backdated to the last rise which was given to single pensioners, granted by other legislation, which for a single pensioner worked out at $6.80 per fortnight. In this case with war widows it will lift that pension rate to $378.60 per fortnight, or $189.30 a week. There will be a cost to revenue in doing this and for the remainder of this financial year that will be $4.74 million. Next financial year it is projected to rise to $22.59 million for the full year. For the year after that it rises to $35.29 million, and in the year 2000-01 it rises to $46.72 million. For the year after that it rises to something in excess of $50 million. So there is a total commitment over the next four years in excess of $165 million, in round figures. The reason why the cost to revenue goes up is not just because of the extra payments, it is also a recognition that many spouses who fought in the war will unfortunately pass on between now and then and so there will be an increase in the number of widows and widowers who are entitled to receive the pension.

I might join with previous speakers in mentioning briefly other initiatives that have been taken to assist not only veterans but also other aged people in the community. These initiatives have come in over the last two years since this government took office in March 1996. The gold card, the benefits of which are enjoyed already by 135,000 diggers, will be extended to another 50,000 who are over 70 years of age. That is recognition at long last, 53 years since the cessation of World War II, that they should be looked after properly. All their medical expenses will be picked up and they will be given private hospital care. Ultimately, that entitlement will be further extended, I believe, to Korean War veterans and Vietnam War veterans, as is right and proper.

The Commonwealth seniors health care card will be given to another 220,000 people, a welcome initiative, by raising the means test threshold for a single person from $21,000-odd to $40,000, and for a couple from about $37,000 up to $67,000. This will enable them to receive their pharmaceutical scripts at $3.20 instead of a maximum of $20. And after 52 scripts, an average of one a week, they can receive those for nothing. I was talking to a person the other day, a person of limited means, who outlays over $100 a month in prescription fees. You can imagine what this benefit will mean to that particular person.

The savings rebate of 7½ per cent on the first $3,000, lifting next year to 15 per cent, will put another $450 a year into the hands of self-funded retirees, those who have been able to look after themselves. Self-funded retirees have also been specifically recognised by giving them the same tax treatment as pensioners. I believe that was a very welcome and long overdue initiative. That means a single, self-funded retiree can have an income of $12,163 before that person starts to pay tax. I think that is only right and proper. Of course, the new five-year health agreement which we will be debating in parliament shortly will give another 15 per cent of Commonwealth funds in real terms to the states over the next five years to be put into public hospitals and so on.

We have also introduced initiatives over the last couple of years that recognise carers more than before, by making more places available for respite assistance for people who are suffering from incontinence. Other initiatives increasing funding to HACC programs, and other measures all show the coalition's commitment to the welfare of older Australians.

The veterans budget this year is pitched at a record level. I acknowledge the presence of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who has joined us for the debate, and particularly compliment him for the initiatives in the program `Their Service—Our Heritage.' These initiatives are being extremely well received in the Parkes electorate. The money is helping to restore memorials, and also it is being used to purchase such things as community buses to help ferry veterans around, making their lives so much more enjoyable in the twilight years of their life. I conclude by saying that I strongly support the bill and I congratulate the government for introducing it to the House.

talk.start.para: —In rising to comment on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 being debated today, I think it is only fitting to pay tribute to some of the heroic actions carried out by those Australians who defended our country at times of world and regional conflict. It is not just the heroic actions that must be recognised; equally important is the recognition of the day-to-day activities carried out by all of our veterans, male or female.

speech.para: Indeed, Australia owes much to these people. When our community sent our young service men and women to other countries we promised that, in the event of war causing their death, their widow or widower would be looked after. In other words, they would be compensated for the loss of the family breadwinner. This undertaking has been adhered to since 1914 and has been in the form of the payment of the war widows pension. It is important to note that this payment is neither taxed nor means-tested and until now it has been indexed according to the consumer price index.

In the lead-up to the 1996 federal election, the coalition gave a commitment to deliver a pension benchmark of at least 25 per cent of the total male average weekly earnings. This is an important measure because male incomes are generally recognised as being pegged at a higher level than those of females in our community. The war widows pension is but one of the many pensions where the rate of pension will be maintained at 25 per cent of the total male average weekly earnings.

The Veterans' Affairs Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998, links the war widows and widowers pension to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings, whenever this measure exceeds the growth of the consumer price index. This means that it will ensure that war widows and widowers will continue on the same level as the age and service pensions, thereby retaining parity. Without the application of this bill the rate of the war widows pension would fall behind that of other pensions. The immediate impact of this bill is an increase of $6.80 bringing this pension up to $378.60 per fortnight. This new measure is expected to cost approximately $164 million over the next four years and will provide further financial security to 540 women in my electorate of Canning. It clearly shows that the commitment that this government has is enhancing the quality of life and the living standards for older Australians.

In talking about this, we should not forget the extension of the gold card to veterans aged 70 years or over who faced hostile contact in World War II. In my electorate of Canning alone just over 150 additional people are eligible for this. As I understand it, right around Australia, more than 50,000 World War II veterans will benefit from the gold card initiative. The gold card enables qualifying veterans to access the comprehensive health care arrangements of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. These arrangements include private patient hospital care, specialised care and many other services such as physiotherapy, dental and others.

I will just take a moment to make some comments on the 1998-99 Budget because there are other measures in that budget that will also help the elderly and that includes our widows and veterans. The staying at home package; the funding that we have provided for medical research; the funding for preventive health programs; and the funding that we have extended to self-funded retirees are all initiatives that have been very enthusiastically received in my electorate of Canning and no doubt right around Australia.

I think the very important aspect that we should all remember is that elderly people, more than anybody else in this country of ours, understand the need to live within their own means. They understand how to budget. They understand that they cannot exceed their household budget and I think they have recognised the tremendous job that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has done by making sure that once again Australia too has managed to live within its means and has brought its budget into surplus. I congratulate the Treasurer on doing that.

I meet with many veterans in my electorate. Indeed, many of my personal friends are people who were involved in the theatres of war in the Second World War as well as Vietnam and Korea. It is quite disheartening to see at times the impact that those particular conflicts have left on them. Many of them, of course, have come back from Vietnam troubled with potential diseases associated with Agent Orange. Their lives in many cases have been destroyed and it is sad to see that many of these people were forgotten. But I am happy to say that not only have they been recognised by the previous government but more exceedingly so by this government which has ensured that they have been given some financial benefits through the measures in this budget, especially in regards to the widows pension.

As I have already said, I am very often touched by the stories that these people tell me. I would suggest that today's Australians can truly be very proud of what the veterans did for us, because they protected our country for us and that is a very important aspect. This government recognises the sacrifices that many of these families have made and we express our thanks to them—sometimes through very small things such as presenting `Their Service—Our Heritage' certificates to them and sometimes in larger ways by enabling their war monuments or their RSL halls to be extended and to be upgraded. Again, the government has done much through this bill and I, too, would like to join my colleague, the previous speaker, the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) in thanking the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) for the very responsible way in which he treats his portfolio.

Just briefly, in summing up, the difficult times that veterans experienced were often made even more difficult because they were separated from family members in far-flung places around the world. I am quite sure that everyone in this House, regardless of which side we sit on, has met people of that calibre and admired them for what they have done for our country. Ensuring that those who survived do not have to endure unnecessary hardship is extremely important. This bill goes a long way towards doing just that. It provides safety, it provides security and it provides stability. It clearly indicates that this government has a strong commitment to enhancing the quality of life for all Australians, including those who helped to serve and protect this country.

talk.start.para: —In legislating the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 , the government is underlining the longstanding commitment by the coalition parties and their antecedents to repaying the debt that we owe to our veterans. It was the Cook Liberal government in 1914 which first announced that there would be a war widows' pension to ensure that those who were bereaved of loved ones on whom they had been dependent and who had made the supreme sacrifice would not be left destitute. It was the United Australia Party government under Joseph Lyons which in 1935 first introduced the veterans service pension to recognise the valour shown and the sacrifice made by Australians in such theatres of war as Gallipoli, the Somme and the Passchendaele. It was the Fraser coalition government in 1976 which first introduced twice-yearly indexing of pensions, including the veterans service pension. Now it is the Howard coalition government that has enshrined in legislation for the first time that pensions shall not fall below 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings.

speech.para: The bill seeks to bring the war widow and war widower pensions into line with the legislation enacted last year with regard to other pensions. It is interesting to read Hansard pertaining to the implementation of the original war widows pensions in 1914. By the time the bill came to be implemented, it was the Labour government under Andrew Fisher which controlled the Treasury benches. It was pointed out by the then Liberal opposition that the new plan was not as generous in its provisions as theirs had been, in particular with regard to the provision made for totally incapacitated returned servicemen and their wives.

The Liberal opposition further argued that the wives of totally incapacitated returned servicemen should receive a set amount—not one graduated according to their husband's rank, as was the case in the Labour government's bill. Nevertheless, the broad thrust of the bill was supported on both sides of the House, and I am sure that a similar sentiment will prevail today.

In my electorate of Makin, the bill will be a welcome initiative. It fulfils our commitment to our servicemen and service women when we sent them to war: if the war caused their death, their widow or widower would be looked after. More than indexation to inflation does, this measure ensures that the recipients of this pension keep pace with living standards and do not fall behind as the rest of the community becomes more affluent.

It is appropriate also to place this measure in context with other initiatives undertaken by this government to pay proper respect to the contribution made by our veterans in the service of their country. I am happy to inform the House that the allocation of $660 million over four years to extend the gold card to male veterans of World War II who had experienced danger from hostile forces was warmly welcomed in the electorate of Makin. Prior to the government's announcement of this initiative, considerable support was expressed by veterans in my community for the idea that, just as we had done for veterans of World War I, we should also honour our veterans of World War II by extending gold card privileges to that group.

The government has also demonstrated its commitment to our veterans in its other budget commitments. These have included an additional $750 million over five years to be given to the states and territories for veterans hospital care, and a permanent increase of $2 million in the funding base of the Australian War Memorial. These and other measures add up to a record budget for Veterans' Affairs of over $7 billion.

This government has underlined its commitment to veterans not with empty rhetoric but with practical measures to show our veterans that we do appreciate the immeasurable contribution that they have made to our security and our way of life. This government has remembered, and I congratulate the government and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, for his tremendous achievements for our veterans.

talk.start.para: —in reply—Firstly, I thank members on both sides of the parliament who have contributed to the debate on the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1998 . I certainly want to thank the seven members from the government side—the members for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), Swan (Mr Randall), Macquarie (Mr Bartlett), Parkes (Mr Cobb), Canning (Mrs Johnston), Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) and Makin (Mrs Draper)—for their contributions, which showed an excellent understanding of the reasons for this legislation and also of other matters relating to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio.

speech.para: I will say at the outset that the legislation will affect approximately 100,000 war widows and war widowers currently. This initiative will in fact be magnified in the years ahead, because it is anticipated—based on the department's predictions—that the numbers of war widows and war widowers will in fact increase from that current 100,000 to approximately 125,000. Whilst the initiative brings improved benefits to those currently receiving this entitlement, the number of recipients is going to increase over the next five to seven years. The initiative will be magnified, as obviously will the financial contribution that will be required.

The legislation gives great certainty to our war widows and war widowers because it links male total average weekly earnings to their compensation payment—the war widows or war widowers pension as we refer to it. Linking it to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings will ensure that they can share in the improved living standards of our nation. And why shouldn't they share in the improved living standards? That is why this is an important initiative: they should share in the improved living standards of our nation because our improved living standards are a direct result of the efforts of our older generations. Our war widows and war widowers have a very special place in our society and they, too, should share in the improved living standards.

Many of them rely wholly and solely on this income. The CPI increases were the only linkage to the war widows or war widowers pension, and that was just a measure of the cost of living and not a measure of the improved living standards that our nation achieves as it gets bigger and stronger. We believe that our war widows and war widowers should be able to share in that living standard.

I thank the shadow minister for his commitment that the opposition intends to expedite this legislation through the parliament. His contribution this morning was a bit of a history lesson down memory lane. I thank him for that. For a moment, I thought he was going to say that this was something that was on the opposition's agenda way back in the days of Whitlam, but somehow, in their 13 years of government, they did not do anything about it.

I want to touch on some of the issues of concern that he raised. He mentioned the frozen rate or the income support supplement for war widows and war widowers. I remind the opposition that, in 1986, it was the then government, the now opposition, who actually froze the income support supplement for war widows and war widowers. He said that this is now a concern. It was actually the opposition who froze it, and they had reasons at the time for that.

He did not suggest in his speech that the opposition was going to do something about it in the future. He just flagged it as a concern. I would like to know from the shadow minister whether it is the intention of the opposition to put forward a policy, whether they intend to do something about it or whether it is just something that, as he travels around Australia, he raises on radio and at meetings in a veiled way to indicate that it is a problem. I wonder whether he is trying to get people to believe that, if the opposition were ever in government again, they would do something about it. I remind him that it was the Labor Party, when they were in government, who froze the income support supplement.

The opposition spokesman focused on the question: why is this bill in the parliament now? Why wasn't it passed with the original bill that increased age and service pensions? Why didn't it link them to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings? A quick glance of Hansard will reveal that there were no amendments moved in relation to war widows or war widowers when that bill was in the House or the Senate. There was not one word mentioned about it. There were no amendments moved. He comes in here and asks: why didn't it happen then? I ask: why didn't the opposition come up with amendments then, if they felt strongly about it?

I looked at the Hobart policy statement of the opposition. I thought something in there might suggest that war widows and war widowers pensions or compensation should be linked to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. I found about five or six dot points with no mention of the 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings for the service pension, let alone the war widows pension or widowers pension.

So he does not come in here with any record of having fought for this or suggested this. It is this government that has introduced it. I would hope people out there will judge people on actions rather than statements. This Hobart document really was one of dot points, vague references to continuing to honour the debt to veterans through programs and compensation: `Labor will continue to provide compensation,' `Labor will continue to fund veterans' community organisations.' That was in February. This is May. I have to ask why the shadow minister comes in here and vaguely refers to the fact that perhaps this should have been something that was done earlier. There was no reference to it in the House when the social security legislation went through.

To the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), now the Independent member for McPherson, can I just say that I was rather disappointed with his contribution. I say to him also that my doors are always open to any member of this parliament to come forward to me with a concern relating to veterans; that if they are not receiving adequate attention from the Department of Veterans' Affairs and they want to bring it to my attention, my doors are always open.

One of the great things about this portfolio is that members on both sides of the House have generally tried to achieve the maximum that this nation can afford to compensate the very worthy veterans of our nation. But I do not think the member for McPherson has actually been through my doors once since we have been in government. I would welcome him to my office with some of the concerns. He suggested that in the budget brought down a few weeks ago there had been cuts. I have actually brought a kit in and, had he been here, I was going to present him with the budget review for 1998-99 which clearly shows that this budget has a 7.2 per cent increase in appropriations over the next 12 months over the figure for the previous 12 months. That, to me, does not indicate a cut in the funding for veterans. In fact, it is an increase over the next 12 months of something like $500 million—hardly a cut.

I would suggest that the member for McPherson gets his facts right before he starts getting around his own community, as he represents it now as an Independent, not as a member of the coalition. He was suggesting that `Their Service—Our Heritage', the commemorative program that we have put in for the next four years, is a very pale imitation of Australia Remembers. I well remember when I became minister that in my first answer to a question in the parliament I paid a tribute to the work of the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs. We have the opposition's first spokesman on veterans affairs sitting opposite at the moment. I think all members of the parliament participated in that Australia Remembers program. It was an extremely successful commemoration in 1995 of the end of the Second World War in 1945.

I do take exception to the fact that the member for McPherson says, `This is a pale imitation.' We are not trying to imitate Australia Remembers; what we are trying to do is continue the commitment of commemoration, awareness and education. It is to commemorate all those who have served this great nation of ours since Federation. His comments clearly, I believe, do a grave disservice to those who have served, from the Boer War and the First World War, to Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam—his own service was in Vietnam and in 1996 there was a pilgrimage under `Their Service—Our Heritage' back to Vietnam to commemorate those who served in Vietnam—and in the Gulf and the peacekeepers in Somalia, Cambodia and Rwanda. It is to commemorate all those who have served this great nation of ours. As we lead up to the centenary of Federation, I believe it is important that we focus on those who have served this country and those who are prepared to put all on the line in the defence of our and others' freedoms.

I remind the member for McPherson that we have the regional memorial upgrade program under `Their Service—Our Heritage'. I think it was in Victoria that the one millionth dollar was granted recently; that went to upgrade a memorial that was built commemorating those from that community that served in the Boer War—a very small grant but it is upgrading a very important memorial, a very important part of the nation's heritage.
We have the regional art collections and the collection from the War Memorial which travels around Australia. I think the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) recently opened one of those—

talk.start.para: —No, I didn't; your department—
—Order! I ask the member to address his remarks through the chair.
—One travelled to Hamilton.

—It has been to Hamilton, too. It is another way of communicating with the broader community, with the very powerful message that art has to give, particularly the art from the Australian War Memorial. So I would just ask the member for McPherson, before he goes off on such a tangent, to look at the budget papers and look more closely at the commemorative program of `Their Service—Our Heritage' over the next four years. If he really wants to make a contribution, he could involve his own community in a very meaningful way in those commemorative programs.
