I would have thought that it was in his best interest to see this as a commemorative program that all members, whether independent, opposition or government, can get behind. This portfolio, I have always thought, is one that has more of a bipartisan approach than a political approach. I think that is the way the veterans see it; it is the way that I think governments for a long time have seen it. Long may that be the case.

speech.para: The government certainly does seek to do more. Perhaps we would have liked to do more in the budget that was introduced by the Treasurer on 12 May, but I have to remind people that when we came to government we had a deficit problem to deal with, a $10.5 billion debt that had to be addressed. We cannot ignore that, but we do have the best repatriation system in the world because a nation must, firstly, look after its veteran community. But it has to be able to afford improvements in those entitlements.

Whilst we have the best repatriation system in the world, I want to assure the chamber that we do not intend to rest where we are. There is a lot of work to be done. The numbers of veterans that will receive benefits in the coming four to five years and up to eight to nine years are even going to increase, according to the department's estimates. So there is a lot of work yet to be done and, of course, that will require budget appropriations. But it is about making sure that a nation can afford it and so through that process we are able to deliver greater benefits to our well-deserving and wonderful veterans.

In conclusion, I just thank those who have made a contribution. I note that the opposition has said that it is going to expedite this legislation through the parliament. I thank the opposition for that and I thank all members for their contribution to this landmark legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset and before making not too many comments—because, clearly, this is very much a technical bill—I just want to indicate to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss), and to the government, naturally, that the opposition will not be opposing the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1998 . I wish to indicate to the minister that, as was the case with the last piece of legislation debated in this chamber this morning, we offer to expedite its passage through the other place, as well.

speech.para: There are only a couple of comments that I would make on this now. Of course, this technical amendment is simply to pick up an issue associated with avgas and to reflect a decision that was introduced in some earlier package of measures dealing with fuel substitution. Effectively, this proposal seeks to ensure that the amendments made in this bill reduce the excise duty payable on avgas from 3 July 1997 to 0.17403c per litre, and that reflects a package of measures which was introduced into the parliament, and I understand that that has probably passed through this place, as well. As a consequence, of course, this amendment is required.

Very briefly, the fuel substitution issue is one that we touched on when the package of measures came through earlier and was debated in this place. I note that there was extensive consultation with the petroleum industry and that there were no objections raised at that time. Similarly, of course, there are no objections raised to ensuring that the policy, which had certainly been announced previously, is included through this amendment in the existing regime.

Minister, I simply say to you again that the opposition has absolutely no problems with this. It is a sensible measure and it simply puts in place the issues which had been flagged before. I shall therefore not detain the business of this committee any further.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) for his comments and support for the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1998 . As he says, it is simple and straightforward. I, also, will therefore not detain the committee further. These are obviously sensible amendments. They reduce the rate of excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline, as was pointed out by the member for Cunningham, and they contain some technical amendments to remove any misunderstandings in relation to the fuel substitution issues. I commend the bill to the House.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to discuss the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The National Measurement Amendment Bill 1998 is a relatively technical measure which makes certain drafting changes to the National Measurement Act to rectify drafting errors in relation to the certification of regulatory measurements. It also amends the act to remove the compulsory retirement age of the executive director of the National Standards Commission. As it is a particularly technical matter, the opposition does not propose to oppose this bill. In fact, we will support it and ensure a speedy passage if that is the government's wish.

speech.para: However I think that it is appropriate at this point to place on the record some brief remarks about the national measurement system and the importance of it. It is often too easy to neglect the importance of standards and measurements systems in the technological age in which we now live. For our industry to be competitive on a global basis, and for us to take advantage of technological advances in other countries, it is very important that our national system of measurements—our system of standards in Australia—are well maintained and that adequate investment is undertaken in research and development in that area to ensure that industry is equipped to take advantage of these advances in the technology of measurement. It is a very precise and exacting science, and one in which Australia has a substantial presence. So I believe that it is important to acknowledge the work of the standards associations and the work of the National Measurement Laboratory in ensuring the global competitiveness of industry and encouraging industry throughout Australia to ensure that it is up to date in standards and measurement areas because that has a very significant impact on our ability to export and on the productivity of Australian industry generally.

Many Australian companies are now ensuring that their quality standards are to international best practice. However, it is certainly something which we need to continue to work on. We need also to continue to understand the importance of an aspect of industrial practice which is often not remarked upon because it is something which is so much an underlying part of the activity. Despite the fact that it is not particularly obvious, it is very important. This bill is a small contribution to that process and so I commend the bill to the committee.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) for his comments and interest in the National Measurement Amendment Bill 1998 , and indeed for his interest in these matters. I certainly concur with his view that these are significant issues that are perhaps not often thought about by the men and women of Australia. They are the sorts of underlying regulatory frameworks that are essential to almost every aspect of our daily life, but we just tend to take those things for granted.

speech.para: The government has been taking a number of initiatives in response to the Kean report in relation to standards issues. Indeed, only last week I chaired the first meeting of the Standards and Conformance Advisory Council that has been established to assist the government in addressing some of these issues. It is particularly pleasing for me that Mr Kean has himself agreed to be the vice-chairman of that council, and so we have the benefit of his expertise and knowledge still available to us.

As indicated by the member for Bonython, these amendments are largely of a technical nature. There were some previous amendments to provide for mandatory meteorological requirements for legal measuring instruments, and at the same time for improving chemical measurements by the use of certified reference materials. Unfortunately, both of those initiatives were frustrated by a drafting error in the definition of a certifying body. Therefore, it has been necessary for that error to be corrected in this legislation.

A second feature of the bill is to remove the retirement age of 65 for the executive director of the National Standards Commission, and that is in line with government policy. Similar measures are being taken in relation to a number of authorities. I again thank the committee for its speedy consideration of this matter and I commend the bill to the committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mrs Moylan:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be opposing this particular piece of legislation, the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Amendment Bill 1998 . The bill seeks to impose new carrier charges on telecommunications carriers to meet the cost of monitoring the performance of carriers in meeting their industry development plan obligations. The Labor Party is a very strong supporter of the Australian communications manufacturing industry. We believe that the obligations which the former Labor government imposed on telecommunications companies played a very important role in making sure that we had a vibrant and growing manufacturing capacity in telecommunications.

speech.para: It was not that long ago that Australia's exports in this area were quite small. In fact, when the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) left office as Treasurer of Australia in 1983, Australia only exported about $50 million a year worth of telecommunications products. However, when we left office in 1996 it was $800 million and heading for $1 billion a year. I am sure that despite the fact that we have had a severe economic downturn in Asia, Australia still has a very strong, vibrant, growing telecommunications manufacturing capacity.

The attitude that we took in office as we deregulated the telecommunications market is one which the current government has continued; that is, we do not impose obligations on telecommunications carriers to meet particular targets or numbers in levels of Australian content in purchasing but instead we require carriers to submit an industry development plan. The obligation which was placed on companies such as Telstra, Optus and Vodafone was to meet the plan that they themselves had drawn up rather than seek to meet some criteria that the government had artificially imposed on them in some Soviet centrally planned manner. We believe that it is important that the obligation remains on carriers that they meet that industry development and that they be required to prepare industry development plans. We think that is the guarantee to the Australian public that telecommunications companies will not be allowed to simply import all of their equipment requirements. That then allows me to make a few other comments about other areas that are funded by carrier licence charges.

Telecommunications carriers are also hit with licence fees that meet the cost of the Australian communications authorities' regulatory role and also the ACCC's role. On several occasions when we have been debating telecommunications legislation in the parliament, I have been expressing my very strong view that in many ways I think Telstra is out of control. I think that the move to ACCC regulation of telecommunications has seen Telstra no longer being regulated by Austel and the former telecommunications act is out of control. We are facing, in my opinion, a diminution in competition in the communications market if we do not see the regulator playing a stronger role than the ACCC has played to date. If I could be allowed to express a personal view: if the ACCC and Professor Fels are not prepared to use the powers that the parliament has given them in being tougher on Telstra then I think it is time for us consider whether the ACCC should continue to have those regulatory roles. Professor Fels and the ACCC want to go off on their escapades in investigating other activities that have been in the news in recent times, but while Professor Fels likes to open up new fronts for publicity, it is very important that he makes sure that he is doing the job that the parliament has given him in making sure we have as much aggressive communication and telecommunications as possible.

I have made the comparison in the past that we used to talk about Telstra being a 600-pound gorilla in the Australian communications market because of its monopoly inheritance; it is now the 600-tonne godzilla. I have mentioned this before and I will not repeat it but if you have seen the preview for Godzilla with it approaching the gentleman fishing at the end of the wharf you will know what I mean.

Telstra does have the power to dominate the Australian communications market. Sure, in mobile telephony and to some extent in long distance, to a greater extent in international calls, there is competition, but on local calls and to some extent in long distance calls Telstra is the price setter. Telstra has a virtual monopoly in local calls. It is the price setter in many of the other markets. I think we need to have a strong regulator using the powers that the parliament has given it. If the regulator needs extra powers then the regulator should let the parliament know that it needs extra powers to make sure that Telstra does not sit back to maximise its profits, which provide a benefit to the government at the moment through the dividend stream. I think there is a real danger that if the regulator does not do its job properly then ordinary consumers will be the big losers, because when we set out down the path of greater competition in telecommunications we wanted to make sure that the big winners were consumers. While there have been some price reductions to date, I am sure people on both sides of this committee would want to see the greatest possible reductions in prices in future.

The other thing that has been happening lately—and I do not know if other members are finding this—is that I have had an explosion in the number of complaints that are coming into my office about Telstra's performance. The number of people who are ringing my office every week with reports of greatly increased times for Telstra to repair faults or install telephones is really quite disturbing. I will just go through a few.

I might begin with a letter from a resident of Berkeley Vale. The gentleman sent me a copy of his letter addressed to the Manager of Customer Service at Telstra. I am not sure if there is such a human being but I hope there is a manager of customer service at Telstra. The letter reads:
I would like to express my deep disappointment at the way we were treated in our recent experience at having our phone go `out of order'.

On Monday morning May 4th I discovered our home phone wasn't answering—gave an engaged call. Using the service difficulties check I realised we were out of order. I reported the difficulty at 9.00 Mon morning and I was told by a very helpful consultant that he would have me contacted at work about 2.00 p.m.

At 6.00 p.m. I again rang Service Difficulties—this time I was made to feel rather stupid as this consultant proceeded to tell me how it must have been my fault that our phone was out because I have a modem! I was also told that it is not policy to ring back a customer (despite their giving a contact number!). On ringing on Tuesday evening I learned that she had registered my complaint as a `minor service' difficulty—the line was dead, how much more major could it get? The consultant that evening corrected this registration but told me our phone couldn't be attended to until Monday 11th—a tough call seeing I am a casual teacher and rely on schools ringing me.

Wednesday, Thursday I contacted the centre to see what progress was being made. Then `shock, horror' Friday afternoon we had a line out but incoming calls only gave one weak `bleep'. On ringing the S.D. centre a very helpful consultant had me check the main phone and extension point—all had line out but incorrect incoming—she warned me it could drop out as it seemed to still be a line fault not an instrument one. Sure enough, by 6.30 p.m, we had no line out. Another call to S.D. informed me that I had a serviceman booked for Mon 11th—a bit hard because I work in Sydney on that day. Mark rebooked me for Wed 13th (a.m.) . . . .

Imagine our surprise when on coming home on Saturday (2.15 p.m) I find a card in the book telling me that Gary had called in and I needed to contact S.D. for a further booking. It was then that I spoke to Mark who alerted me to the Monday booking which we then changed.

Again imagine my surprise that on our return from Mother's Day Lunch, there was another note to say that Peter had come around, but, alas, we were not at home—again please ring for another appointment.
I rang and again confirmed that Wednesday was the day.
Then Monday morning (6.30 a.m) without any warning we had a line in and out.
And guess what? A serviceman called around on Monday! Only that my son was home sick was he able for some mysterious reason to inspect our phone . . . .

I guess, I'm amazed at this rather sorry saga of confusion and lack of apparent co-ordination from such a professional body as yours. We were without a phone for eight days—had to go to the local shops to use the public phone and, as a casual teacher, I still don't know what damage has been done to my work this term.
I hope this may give you some guide for a review of some of the aspects of your repair procedures.

That letter was from a gentleman in Berkeley Vale. I also have a complaint from a resident of Mardi whose phone was due to be installed on 20 May and who has now been told that it will not be installed until 24 July. He is a fireman and his daughter is an asthmatic. He obviously needs to be able to receive messages when he is needed to provide to the local community his services as a fireman, and it is pretty outrageous that this gentleman and his family have to wait until 24 July for the work to be done.

Another constituent has had to wait three months; another has been told they have to wait six weeks to have their phone fixed. There is a very long list of residents of the central coast that are being forced to wait too long to get their phones repaired. I suspect that if I were to raise this with the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) I would get the response that the government has actually improved the system by offering a customer guarantee.

I hope the people I have listed do get the compensation payments that the government claims that they will now be entitled to. But these people do not want a rebate on their next telephone bill: they want their telephone to work. My concern is that either Telstra is becoming less efficient or the staff reductions at Telstra mean that the waiting time for telephones to be installed or repaired is blowing out because of the changes that the government has made. Without wanting to reveal the contents of briefings that have taken place within this building, I know some members of the government—they may be in this room this afternoon—have raised concerns about the impact of changes in Telstra's ownership on service to the bush in rural and regional areas.

Many people believe that, if this government has its way and sells the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, the staff reductions that will inevitably follow that full privatisation will mean that these complaints will only increase. The times to have telephone faults repaired will blow out. The times to have telephones installed will get worse and there is very little hope of any aggressive competition from Optus or Vodafone, or any of the other carriers, to fix local telephones in my electorate or to install phones in most other electorates around Australia.

Competition is not the answer. What we need is a more aggressive regulation to try to ensure that Telstra lifts its standards. For those reasons, I have made the point that the charges that we levy on telecommunications carriers, that we are discussing today, do fund the regulatory role of the ACCC. As a parliament, we need to make sure that the ACCC is using those powers of regulation. If they need more powers to make sure that Telstra is doing its job, then I, for one, am prepared to put up my hand to give the regulator the powers it needs to make sure that the customers receive the service to which they are entitled. For those reasons, we think it is important that Professor Fels puts in a bit of time to focus on this particular issue. I pointed out at the start, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the opposition will not be opposing this particular bill, but we are very concerned about the apparent increase in the costs and times of making repairs to Australia's telecommunications services.

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that Australians should feel a lot more comforted as a result of this government's actions with regard to consumer based issues in the delivery of services by the various telecommunications carriers. The Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Amendment Bill 1998 involves the mechanics of raising the funds that are necessary to run some of the watchdogs and the instruments in determining that proper plans are place and that proper execution of those plans occurs.

speech.para: It is worth reflecting on some of the previous comments, as I generally do in telecommunications bills. I often follow the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and I always delight in that particular approach. It is worth reflecting on a few of his comments. It is certainly a fact that the previous government set in train a series of events that have led to a lot of the complaints the member for Dobell has aired today. The natural advantage they legislated for Telstra in their 1991 act springs to mind immediately. Telstra was allowed to turn its back on legitimate requests from potential competitors to provide the infrastructure for those competitors to compete. This was a great shame. Before the member for Dobell interjects and says that I am suggesting a socialist instrument in the form of some sort of national telecommunications infrastructure, I have said this before and I will continue to say it: it is a legitimate role of government in this country, with sparse population, to provide infrastructure for industries to use.

Essentially, to paraphrase the way the 1991 act worked, it would be like getting Lindsay Fox and TNT and a couple of other transport companies each to build a Pacific Highway for their own trucks to travel on. Essentially, the Labor government was not going to legislate that there should be infrastructure in place. They essentially said, `If you want to go and run a telephone company, Optus, you go and build your own cable system.' It was like saying, `If you want to run your own trucking company, Lindsay Fox, build your own Hume Highway.' That is just a nonsense. That approach has cost the country $8 billion or $9 billion in infrastructure duplication and the unsightly mess of mobile telephone arrays scattered on corners in your electorate, I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, as they are in mine. Those matters were addressed in the 1996 Telecommunications Bill that this government brought to this place, which was passed and which brought about a tougher regime on telecommunications carriers, just as we are bringing about a tougher regime to make sure consumer issues are being addressed.

It is worth knowing that Telstra as an organisation will continue to dominate the Australian marketplace for those sorts of reasons and many others. The aspirations of local call providers—and there are umpteen different companies that would like to provide cheaper local calls to Australian consumers—are always going to be dashed by the difficulty of infrastructure. This government has provided a requirement on telecommunications infrastructure providers to give access to those aspirants. That, I think, is proof that this government has acted. The previous government signed away the potential for change because of technology in the area of analog phones in rural and regional Australia, on which I know the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), amongst others, has had some strong views.

talk.start.para: —Yes, I have.

—I know you have. The matter of analog phones in rural and regional Australia is a matter created directly by the previous government's failure and lack of insight to properly plan. Planning is what is at the heart of this particular bill before us today. It is interesting to know, on the question of analog phones, who signed the contract, who signed the deal with Vodafone that effectively is at the heart of why analog phones have to be phased out in a compulsory sense. It was the Hon. K.C. Beazley. Mr Beazley, of course, is now the Leader of the Opposition.

speech.para: All I will say is that if Telstra is failing to meet certain matters of consumer expectations on deadlines for repairs and maintenance and those sorts of matters, they are things that I believe the ACCC has to look at. The ACCC, within its functions and powers, has some specified directives that they can offer. They have tougher powers and tougher penalties that they can impose because of this government's own actions. But the reason some of these matters might be occurring is simply because the previous government set the whole system up for a fall.

I have my own complaint: the Network Operations Centre in Brisbane has been relocated to Melbourne. I think the Hon. Jeff Kennett, the Premier there, provided a very aggressive incentive program to Telstra to do that. But 90 jobs were lost for Queenslanders involved in the NOC centre. In my letter to Frank Blount about that, which he never did respond to—he got someone from some department somewhere to respond to me, which I thought was quite discourteous—my argument was that if a line broke in Julia Creek, the NOC centre in Melbourne would probably fix the one between Melbourne and Geelong before they got around to Julia Creek. So there are some understandable difficulties that are perhaps inherent in the system. The member for Bruce (Mr Griffin) might be happy about that particular result but I am sure the electors of the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) would not be. In fact, I said to him that Melbourne is as close to an area like Julia Creek as a place like Vanuatu is, or perhaps Jakarta, so I suspect the Network Operations Centre could have been there.

I do think the member for Dobell has expressed a legitimate concern, as others on this side of the chamber have, about the staff allocation priorities of Telstra. But again, if they do not perform, if they do not get results, there are some tough measures in place to penalise them, and I think that is good. But at the heart of the difficulties is the fact that the Labor Party in government did not legislate for real competition. To have the member for Dobell in here today talking about competitive regimes and the need for real competition to perhaps, through market forces, keep Telstra honest in these particular maintenance areas is in itself an absolute farce. You only have to look at the collapse of the Galaxy-Australis group in recent weeks to know that they are also a victim of the big fall that the previous government legislated for, to know that exactly what I mean is true.

The bill before us today is all about the imposition of an annual charge on the carriers, to be sure that the ACA, the Australian Communications Authority, and the ACCC are able to meet their very modest costs in monitoring the industry development plan arrangements—some $600,000 in the first year, based on the expectations of part 2 of schedule I of the Telecommunications Act 1997. It is likely to grow as the number of carriers increases, and that is fair enough. This bill will enable all the various costs imposed in the monitoring of these matters to be recovered by the Commonwealth.

The other point I would like to make is to offer a caution to these various instrumentalities monitoring the progress and processes of commercial enterprises. I would hate to see them go the way the Department of Communications and the Arts spectrum management people have gone. Under the previous government, progress on the matter of local area plans for commercial radio operations, amongst other things, fell way behind. For people who need to be able to plan with certainty and to understand what might be occurring in what particular area, having three- and four-year delays in getting basic plans in place is an absolute farce.

With new technology constantly imposing itself in the area of telecommunications, carriers would be rightly upset if the bureaucracy monitoring them were to retard their natural aspirations to progress their industry in order to provide better technology, better services. Those involved in the monitoring must not slow the operator's natural aspirations for progress.

In this bill the government is showing an understanding of the need to plan and to have Australian content involved in the equipment for the delivery of telecommunications services. It is important in a regime which is encouraging more carriers to get involved, and more participants in offering telephone and telecommunication services generally to the Australian consumer, that we have proper monitoring of standards and proper planning. It is, though, as I said at the outset, of great regret that the previous government set up the whole matter, not necessarily to collapse—it has not done so—but certainly in a way which put a great deal of pressure on the system. To get real competition in this requires, perhaps, a heavier financial commitment than would have been the case if infrastructure, rather like the Pacific Highway or the Hume Highway, had been offered for universal access, rather than the situation being set up that Optus had to go and spend so much money. About $8 billion or $9 billion more than this country should have had to spend was expended to duplicate, in a lot of cases, our telecommunications infrastructure. Naturally, I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) and the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) for their contributions to the summing up of the debate on the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Amendment Bill 1998 .

speech.para: I would like to make a few points on the importance of this bill. The first concerns what the bill is designed to do. From July 1998 this bill will enable the recovery of costs incurred by the Commonwealth in monitoring telecommunications industry development plans under the Telecommunications Act 1997. These costs will be recovered as a component of the annual carrier licence charges which are currently levied on carriers to recover other administrative costs, including those of the ACA and the ACCC. Also, the bill will give effect to the government's decision to recover the costs, which was announced in the context of the 1997-98 budget.

Part 3 of the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Act 1997 provides for the imposition of an annual charge on carrier licences. It currently limits the amount of the charge, however, to the amounts attributable to the ACA's and the ACCC's telecommunications functions and powers for the immediately preceding financial year, the proportion of the Commonwealth's contribution to the budget of the International Telecommunications Union for the calendar year that is to be recovered from carriers, and an estimate of the grants likely to be made by the minister during the financial year to fund consumer representation and research in relation to telecommunications.

In regard to industry development plans I make the following points. The IDPs are telecommunications carrier plans for the development in Australia of industries involved in the manufacture, development or supply of facilities and related research and development activities. They are part of the sector specific industry policy measures which, since their introduction in July 1997, have provided a regulatory environment that actively encourages carriers to maximise their involvement with the domestic telecommunications supply industry on a commercial and competitive basis, and to form long-term strategic alliances that benefit all parties.

These industry-specific policies which build on arrangements put in place under the previous 1991 regulatory regime, have been successful in encouraging the carriers to seek out price and quality competitive domestically manufactured telecommunication equipment, software and services. They have encouraged the carriers to enter into strategic commercial supply alliances with domestic based transnational equipment and software manufacturing and service firms and, in turn, have encouraged these transnational firms to form strategic commercial supply partnerships with indigenous firms. These partnerships have assisted local firms to gain access to technology, quality systems, capital and export markets. They have encouraged carriers to source their telecommunications equipment and software requirements locally wherever possible and have increased the level of R&D spending by carriers, equipment manufacturers and software suppliers while not imposing any significant costs on the carriers or users of their networks, and at the same time they are being World Trade Organisation consistent.

Lastly, what this bill proposes to do is sensible and it will impose only a minor additional burden on telecommunications carriers. Of course, in that respect, the yearly cost associated with the administration of the IDPs is estimated to be around $600,000. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

debateinfo.title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (COMPANY LAW REVIEW) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The two bills that we are now debating, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Law Review) Bill 1998 and the Income Tax (Untainting Tax) Bill 1998 , involve related anti-avoidance measures which are necessary because of the proposed reforms to company law. Those relevant reform measures are contained within the Company Law Review Bill 1997 which is presently before the Senate.

speech.para: Labor supports the Company Law Review Bill 1997 as it represents an evolution of our own initiative in government. However we do intend to move some amendments to improve that particular bill and to attempt to address the deficiency which has allowed the Patrick corporation to unjustly dismiss members of the Maritime Union of Australia.

Indeed, the need for those sorts of amendments to that particular bill was pointed out as recently as yesterday by Henry Bosch, who is, of course, a former chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission. Mr Bosch said that he was concerned about the long tradition in Australia of parent companies being allowed to walk away from the debts of their subsidiaries. That was a reference, of course, to the collapse of the four Patrick subsidiaries which employed some 2,000 waterside workers after the subsidiaries were stripped of their assets. Mr Bosch said that the winding up of subsidiaries was a serious problem in Australia, which had a long tradition of allowing companies to walk away from subsidiary debts because of the basic legal notion that every company was a separate legal personality.

I am most concerned about that and I know a lot of Labor MPs are most concerned about what Patrick has been able to do. Therefore we intend to endeavour to do something about it when the Company Law Review Bill 1997 is being debated in the Senate.

This particular piece of legislation, however, is necessitated by the fact that some of the company law reforms that are part of the Company Law Review Bill 1997 give rise to what might perhaps be described as `tax planning opportunities'. In particular, the Company Law Review Bill 1997 contains a proposal for the abolition of the concept of a par value for shares. This reform, in the absence of the bills now before us, would have allowed companies to make distributions to shareholders which were classified as capital distributions and which are not taxable, instead of the current situation where the distribution would have been a taxable dividend.

In addition, the bills are designed to stop dividend streaming. That occurs where some shareholders are paid a non-taxable capital amount where that is advantageous, and other shareholders are paid normal dividends. This is achieved through a general anti-avoidance provision in the bill. Also, the bills ensure that the existing provisions in the tax law that are dependent on the concept of a par value operate consistently with the new company law structure.

The legislation also ensures that bonus issues of shares and the issue of shares at a premium, that is to say at a higher price than the par value, are treated in the same manner that the law currently treats such transactions. A share premium account, or SPA, is a reserve where a company has raised capital in excess of the par value of a share. Currently, funds from a share premium account can be distributed back to shareholders as a non-taxable capital distribution. This is not a rort. However, the rule could be rorted if other amounts, for example, profits which would be taxable when distributed, could be included in the share premium account.

To deal with such a situation the law currently provides that if incorrect funds are included in the share premium account then that share premium account is described as tainted. The result of such tainting is that the share premium account ceases to be a share premium account and therefore any distributions from it will not be tax free.

This same concept of tainting is adopted in the bills before us now to ensure that the new share capital account, or SCA, will be tainted if profits are transferred into it. Any distributions made from a tainted SCA will be fully taxable to the recipient. If a company with a tainted SCA wishes to untaint it, it may do so. However, the untainting, which is complex, involves paying tax on the tainted amount within the share capital account.

This legislation is necessary to ensure that the proposed reforms to company law which abolish the concept of par value for shares cannot be abused to convert what would be taxable dividends paid by companies into tax-free distributions. I stated when this issue was previously being debated before the Main Committee that Labor would not be passing the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Law Review) Bill 1998 unless and until appropriate anti-avoidance legislation was introduced to ensure that tax loopholes were not introduced through reform of company law. Accordingly, we will be supporting these bills

However, on the subject of tax avoidance I should say that we are concerned that the government has failed to pick up some of the real issues concerning tax avoidance. On 27 April this year the Sydney Morning Herald produced a report which made it clear that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has sat on his hands and watched hundreds of millions of dollars leached from the tax system by so-called independent contractors. The Treasurer has ignored Taxation Office warnings, delivered into a detailed confidential paper in 1996, that the existing tax law is unfair and has to be changed in order to stem the flow of sham contractors avoiding PAYE tax. As a result, ordinary employees are required to pay more than their fair share of the tax bill. Soon after the 1996 election, Treasurer Costello promised:
I make it clear on behalf of this government that where anomalies and exemptions are being unfairly exploited, they will be addressed.
That was said on 20 June 1996. But the Treasurer has failed to correct a major tax anomaly where a section of the work force uses artificial schemes to avoid paying its fair share of income tax.

Firstly, he refused to proceed with Labor's legislation introduced before the 1996 election which, by broadening the definition of salary and wages under the PAYE system, would have ensured that individuals doing the same jobs face a similar tax regime. Secondly, the Treasurer has refused to follow up on the Labor initiative to cut down on tax avoidance by artificial schemes involving interposed entities, that is to say, companies, trusts or partnerships.

Instead of paying PAYE income tax like other workers, some independent contractors set themselves up as companies, partnerships or trusts. As a result, they are able to take advantage of the tax law to claim deductions which are not available to PAYE workers, to defer income tax, or to split income with other members of their families. Hundreds of thousands of ordinary workers, doing the same job, at their side, often at the same site, pay higher income tax as a result of this scam. And millions of ordinary taxpayers pay higher taxes because of the subsequent erosion of the income tax base.

A former Labor Treasurer, the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) began a more detailed analysis of legislative remedies to cut down on tax avoidance through the use of artificial schemes of this kind. He announced the release of a public discussion paper, with legislation to apply from 1 July 1996. But in the 1996 budget, Treasurer Costello announced that `in a boost to small business' he would not be proceeding either with Labor's PAYE amendments or with any legislation to deal with the interposed entity problem. How can we take seriously the government's claim that the tax system is broke, when they fail to take action on a tax scam which is costing hundreds of millions of dollars each year?

Their deliberate refusal to do anything about bogus independent contractors makes a mockery of their claim that they want a fairer tax system. We have seen this, similarly, with the issue of high-wealth individuals. Nothing has been happening on that front, despite the identification by the tax office of that as a major problem for revenue in this country. It is not good enough to say, `The tax system is broke. The only way to fix it is with a GST.'—which results in extra costs on just about everything: nappies, prams, school fees, schoolbooks, food, electricity, water, council rates, visits to the footy, the theatre, hairdresser, you name it, the necessities of life which are presently untaxed—when the government has not been the slightest bit interested or fair dinkum about addressing real tax avoidance problems and maintaining this nation's revenue base.

We have had circulated today a number of amendments to be moved to the government's own bill. The opposition has had the benefit of a briefing concerning those amendments and I indicate at this point that we will not be opposing those amendments during the committee stage of the debate.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) for his contribution, although some of the comments I could not agree with on this area. I would just like to say that there is a difference between the opposition and the government, particularly at this stage, in regard to reforming an outdated and outmoded taxation system in Australia. Basically, the coalition believes that it has to be reformed—there needs to be change; it needs to be done as a gradual evolutionary change—whereas the Labor Party really wants to stick with an archaic dinosaur which is really out of date and outmoded. It is a matter of going ahead as a country in regard to taxation reform. I think that the overwhelming majority of Australians believe that we have to move forward into the third millennium with a reform in taxation which is appropriate for this stage in Australia's development.

speech.para: I just want to very quickly summarise this particular debate in regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Law Review) Bill 1998 . The changes made in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Law Review) Bill 1998 make various consequential amendments to the taxation laws as a result of changes to the Corporations Law made by the Company Law Review Bill 1997 , which will abolish the concept of par value for shares and the associated concepts of share premiums as well as make it easier for companies to return capital to shareholders. The amendments will ensure that the provisions in the tax law that are currently dependent on the concept of par value can continue to operate appropriately in the future and introduce an anti-avoidance measure to prevent companies entering into capital streaming and dividend substitution arrangements. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will be moving a number of amendments in the consideration in detail stage. I commend the bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

I want to make a few comments about the amendments that we are moving. There are 19 amendments and they are minor technical changes that it is important to make at this stage. Amendment 1 will ensure that the amendments made by the bill and those made by the Company Law Review Bill 1997 can commence on the same date. Amendments 2 and 3 will correct two minor technical errors to the provisions dealing with the tainting rule within the bill.

Amendment 4 will prevent an unintended consequence to the tainting rule within the bill. Broadly speaking, the tainting rule is designed to prevent companies disguising a profit distribution—that is, a dividend—as a tax preferred capital distribution from the share capital account by first transferring profits into that account and then distributing them from it. As drafted, the rule applies where a company transfers an amount to its share capital account from any other account.

However, the rule can adversely impact on certain transfers that do not confer any tax advantage. These circumstances are where a company transfers debt to its share capital account, under a debt for equity swap arrangement. As a result, the government will be moving an amendment to the bill by providing an exception to the tainting rule where an amount is transferred to the company's share capital account under a debt for equity swap arrangement.

Amendment 5, a transitional provision within the tainting rule, also provides an exception to the tainting rule where companies transfer share premiums to their share capital account upon the abolition of par value shares and share premiums in accordance with schedule 5 of the Company Law Review Bill. The transitional provision recognises the nature of genuine share premiums as being equivalent to share capital. Unlike under the Corporations Law, the tax law definition of `share premium account' results in the account ceasing to be such an account if it includes amounts other than share premiums.

It has been suggested to the government that the transitional provision is drafted in such a way that the term `share premium account' could take the meaning provided in the Corporations Law and not that in the tax law. If this argument were to be upheld, the transitional provision could sanction the inappropriate transfer of tainted share premiums to a company's share capital account. To prevent this possible outcome, the government will be moving a clarifying amendment to the bill by providing that the term `share premium account' takes the meaning provided in the tax laws, for the purposes of the transitional provision.

Amendments 6 to 10 and 16 make technical amendments to the provisions of the bill dealing with the taxation of bonus shares, to ensure that the provisions operate as intended and to improve their readability. Amendments 11 to 15 and 17 to 19 make minor technical amendments to the definitions of amounts paid up on a share, paid-up share capital and share capital account, to ensure that they operate as intended. I commend the amendments to the chamber.
Amendments agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —As no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, the question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —In speaking in this debate, I want to make a number of comments in continuation of those that I made the other day in relation to the splitting of the city of Wanneroo, an event of some considerable importance to people who live in my electorate. At present, the city of Wanneroo is the only municipality that serves my electorate; following the split, it appears that there will be two: the shire of Wanneroo and the city of Joondalup.

speech.para: The state government has not actually indicated what it believes the real effect of this split will be on residents of Wanneroo. That is a key question and one which the state government seems unable to answer to the satisfaction of residents. Surely, it cannot believe that smaller councils will be that much more representative, when it seems happy to maintain its appointed commissioners until the year 2000.

I am not alone in my criticism of the splitting of the city of Wanneroo. My colleague the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) appeared in the local paper recently, criticising the lack of information available from the state government on this matter. He also opposed the government proceeding with the split, and although I commend him for this courageous stand, no doubt he would have received some unpleasant attention from the Western Australian Liberal Party for his troubles.

My electorate of Moore has one of the highest proportion of young families who are new home owners in Australia. It is a very fast growing region which relies fundamentally on the ability of the local government authorities to provide a range of services which ensure that their quality of life meets their aspirations. I am opposed to any action by any level of government which might diminish the ability of local government to deliver these services.

The Commonwealth is not without blame in this area. Since the removal of tax sharing with the Commonwealth, local government financial assistance grants have been on a downward trend. The Western Australian Municipal Association advises that the real FAGs per person have fallen by nearly a quarter of their value since 1985-86. The recent budget has redressed this to some extent by restoring adjustment to local government assistance in real terms per capita in 1998-99. It remains a fact that the Commonwealth general purpose funding assistance to local government has declined substantially over the last 15 years, both in real per capita terms and as a share of the total taxation revenue. They were 0.62 per cent of Commonwealth revenue in 1997-98 and reduced to 0.59 per cent in 1998-99.

In 1996-97, the budget cut the funding base further, resulting in a loss of around $7 million to councils in Western Australia. The base assistance to local government was lowered in 1997-98 by failing to restore the per capita guarantee. This has already cost local government $30 million in two budgets. This is yet another symptom of vertical fiscal imbalance and its effects are increasing every day that the Howard government reneges on its election promise to solve this tax income-spending dilemma.

All I can do, as part of my presentation today, is to urge the coalition, with great seriousness and a great deal of urgency, to examine the whole question of Commonwealth-state fiscal relations as part of their tax reform process. If there is no real change or reform to Commonwealth-state fiscal relations, then much of the other debate around tax reform is irrelevant. This area of local government is one of those key areas where this type of problem is a very serious one indeed. I understand that Treasury has argued that this reduction has helped fund the Commonwealth recovery from deficit.

I want to make the point that, unlike the states, local government was not consulted on the cuts or given the opportunity to negotiate reasonable options. The cuts to financial assistance agreed to by the states last year were temporary and quarantined from the state FAGs, but the local government cuts had been permanently built into the system. While the states receive supplementary competition incentive payments to offset their contributions, local government's only incentive to implement competition policy was the real terms per capita guarantee.

Although this report is important in maintaining an overview of the third tier of government, without adequate support from state and federal levels, our entire system of basic service provision to residents who are electors is jeopardised. I commend my views to both the federal and state governments in Western Australia for their serious consideration and immediate remedial action.

I might reflect again on this problem of vertical fiscal imbalance between the Commonwealth and the states. It has been estimated that Western Australia has lost somewhere in the region of $775 million of its real share of taxation revenue during the past five years. One of the problems we have in our system at present is that it has been entirely possible for state members of parliament, when questioned about the absence of state government provided services, to merely flick the ball to the Commonwealth and accuse Canberra of failing in its obligations.

Conversely, when one comes to Canberra and questions the Commonwealth government about its responsibilities, one gets a reply, as I did from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), `Oh, well, Western Australia is doing very well indeed. What are you talking about?' What that in effect means is another handball flick back to the states. The problem for the residents and service recipients, the people who have the expectation of these services, is that in the meantime this leads to poor decision making, poor management and, in many instances, the failure to deliver the services at all. Local government is now fulfilling very critical service delivery, particularly in municipal areas in the Perth metropolitan area.

Western Australia has, as we all know, its own peculiar geographic problem of being a very large territorial area with a relatively small population which requires service delivery over vast areas of the state. This means that in the local government division of the state grants, in the distant areas or those areas—I will not to use the word `regional' because that applies to all parts of the state—that are considered to be remote or that have areas that require special assistance, the dividing up of those grants is done on the basis of trying to alleviate these particular problems. This exacerbates the problems for municipalities such as the city of Wanneroo because they then receive, as a proportion, a far smaller share than would be the case if Western Australia did not have this peculiar geographic feature of being a very large state—one-third of the continent, to all intents and purposes.

So we have a situation where the taxation system, the sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states, not only impacts on the delivery of state and Commonwealth services to residents in my electorate but also impacts on the service delivery of municipal services by local government. Local government is a very important tier of government. I recollect that in 1988 there was a move by the then Labor government to have local government recognised in the constitution. I opposed that because at the time it was tagged to other constitutional amendments which in my view were not a benefit and should have been resisted, and they were. Western Australia ended up with one of the largest `No' votes in the country. But it is important that local government has recognition as being responsible for the delivery of services that are inherently important to residents.

This problem of the sharing of revenues between the Commonwealth and the states not only exacerbates the problems for local government, particularly when they are not consulted about funding cuts in budgetary outlays, but it also brings us to the essential nub of taxation reform. That is that no matter what sort of consumption or sales tax regime you might introduce as part of a tax reform process, if there is no real change to Commonwealth-state fiscal relations, it is all really irrelevant.

Western Australia is shackled by the present Commonwealth-state fiscal arrangements. If part of the taxation raising processes was given back to the states, and in particular to Western Australia, in my view we could liberate our state to become one of the powerhouse economies of the region—and I say `region' because I am talking about the Indian Ocean region. That is something that Western Australia desperately needs to do, to be able to access markets and to draw in capital from this incredibly dynamic region. Local government deserves better. I commend the report, but I urge the government to consider taxation reform as a matter of urgency. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —As is apparent from the contribution of the previous speaker, the member for Moore (Mr Filing), and given the nature of this report on the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act, this is a fairly wide-ranging debate. There are a range of issues raised in the report which relate to the full ambit of activities of local government. I will just take up a couple of points made by the previous speaker on the question of the circumstances of Western Australia with respect to its position in relation to grants received versus the potential for raising revenue in its own state.

speech.para: I come from another state, Victoria, which historically has had a similar problem in that we have been subsidising some other states. That has varied over time, but it has been a problem for some of the larger states for a very long time. It is certainly an issue which is raised with me by constituents, as a question of how much they pay in taxes and so on in relation to what they see in service delivery. I am collating some results from a survey that I have done in my electorate. One thing that has come through clearly from that is concerns by local residents about service delivery at the local government level.

That also comes back to the question of what state and federal governments, both past and present, have done on the question of funding. Another very important issue which was raised earlier was the whole question of funding that has been provided to local government—from the federal government directly, in some respects, but more particularly in terms of grants through the states—and what that means in terms of services in our electorates. It has some very important implications.

In addition to that, in the Victorian situation there has been the question of council amalgamations and also a greater push towards competitive tendering. I personally support aspects of competitive tendering, or certainly the principles behind competitive tendering. But I am very concerned about what is occurring in Victoria in some council areas in regard to competitive tendering. I do not think that it is appropriate that some of the services that are being tendered out are evaluated solely on, essentially, an economic rationalist model as has been happening in Victoria. It has some real implications with respect to service delivery.

talk.start.para: —Give some examples.

—As one example, there are aspects of services by outdoor staff of one of the local councils, in the city of Greater Dandenong. Although I do not object to those services themselves being tendered out, the interesting question there is that the best tender, as I understand it, was actually from a company from New Zealand. It is a question of a company or a council in New Zealand actually operating within the Victorian context, to provide council services in a particular municipality. I have got some real concerns about what that really means in terms of—
—Probably they would stay over on weekends. But it certainly does raise some very important issues.

speech.para: There have been aspects of other issues like library services and other directly community related services which I think are of considerable concern. Although competition is important, there are also issues about service delivery. It relates to the question, in a broader sense, of privatisation in terms of services like the SEC. Although I can see an economic argument in some respects as to why this is being done, an increasing number of concerns is raised by constituents about what they believe is shown by the examples they raise of service implications for them—an increased number of blackouts, inability to get maintenance work done. There are real issues there which relate to that question of service delivery and it is something that governments should look at closely.

On the question of amalgamations as a whole, it has certainly produced some potential economies of scale but it is taking local government some time to adjust to that question of amalgamation. In the longer term, however, that has probably been a good thing. But it also raises the general question of how much federal government should go through a state government with respect to dealing with councils. It is a longstanding issue, about the three tiers of government. There is an argument more and more for federal government to work directly with local government in many ways, shapes and forms. The issue with local government is always that it is closer to the people because it is there on the ground, it is a smaller area; local government will by definition know a lot more about the needs of a particular area and be able to plan accordingly.

There are also issues of overall national interest and overall national policy settings. That is important. As to just where state governments fit into that as councils get bigger, I have got some concerns and some questions. I note that the previous speaker, the member for Moore, talked about Western Australia being such a huge geographical area. That is true. In the same way we can make points about the question of what WA has in common with, say, Queensland or Victoria. We can also ask what Perth has in common with Kalgoorlie.

There are issues there about how relevant even the state boundaries are and it is a wider issue, not something that can be resolved today. It is something that may be looked at in the future. I think that the amalgamation processes led to a situation with local government where there is scope to look to them as a better instrument for implementation of national policy issues, and a more effective approach can be taken in that way.

One of the issues that is a key to all of that is the question of funding. As was mentioned earlier, if the money is not there to provide the services and the work, then the work will not be done as well as it should be and people will suffer accordingly, and that is an issue. When we look at governments addressing budgetary concerns through squeezing other levels of government, we have got to ask ourselves whether that is really in the interests of the community, or whether it is merely a question of budget bottom lines and, if so, is that the way we should go? I note the time and I will leave my comments there at this stage and I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Is there a telephone which can receive (a) both the GSM digital signal and an analogue system signal and (b) both the CDMA signal and an analogue system signal.
(2) Can the GSM signal interface directly with satellites.
(3) Will a system be produced which allows direct interface between the GSM signal and satellites; if so (a) which satellites and (b) will the satellites use GSM or CDMA technology.
(4) Is it a fact that there is no difference between GSM and analogue signals; if so, why is the analogue system being discarded.
(5) Does the GSM system have technological advantages over analogue systems; if so, what are they; if not, why is the former being preferred to the latter.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) There are a number of different interfaces that are used for mobile telephony resulting in different standards being used around the world. Equipment manufacturers have started to produce mobile handsets that are compatible with more than one standard, much like some modern television receivers that can receive either the European PAL signal or the American NTSC signal.

It is entirely up to the commercial judgement of the equipment manufacturers to determine what combinations of standards are built into the handsets they design and sell. While any combination of standards may be theoretically possible, there are some combinations that are likely to become available and other that are not, depending on how the various technical standards are taken up in various regions of the world. In response to the specific questions:
. the GSM/analogue AMPS combination in the 800/900 MHz band is not currently available, and is unlikely to be developed;
. there are phones available that have analogue AMPS and CDMA in the 800 MHz band. The 800 MHz spectrum being offered in the current auction process could be used for CDMA.

(2) and (3) There are a number of new global satellite systems being developed and coming into service in the next few years. They are intended to operate in a complementary way with digital terrestrial mobile services. The subscriber will use the terrestrial cellular service where it is available and will use the satellite where terrestrial is not available. The subscriber will need a new handset (GSM + satellite) or (CDMA + satellite) to access satellite services which have their own frequency bands and interface standards. Manufacturers are producing a variety of handsets with various interface combinations to suit the different regional markets.
(4) There are fundamental differences between the GSM and analogue signals in the same way as there are fundamental differences between vinyl records and CD discs.
All analogue phones transmit speech as identifiable and decipherable waves on particular radio frequencies.
All digital technologies, by contrast, encode speech and transmit this code which is subsequently decoded when it is received.

(5) In the 1990 Government policy statement, the decision was announced to license three public mobile carriers and to accept prima facie AUSTEL's recommendation that GSM digital technology should be adopted as Australia's first digital standard. At the time of the decision, the AMPS analogue technology was capable of supporting only two operators, whereas digital technologies such as GSM could support more than two operators. GSM was adopted as the first digital standard, but this does not restrict the introduction of further digital standards.
The technical advantages of changing from analogue to digital technology include:
. digital technology allows the telephone network to carry more conversations at one time and this helps to minimise network congestion;
. digital transmissions are far less easily intercepted than the unencoded analogue transmissions; and
. by virtue of the signal processing that is a necessary part of a digital system, digital services also potentially offer more enhanced services to the user. For example:
- data and fax originating and terminating
- fax mail store and forward
- sending and receiving short messages—Mail
- personal answering service—Memo
- integrated voicemail services
- advice of message by voice call, SMS or pager
- remote mail, LAN and Internet access, fax back
- full control of diversion, on voice, data, fax, SMS
- virtual private network—dial plan
- auto national and international roaming 48 countries.
